<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Units">Units</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=82nd_Training_Wing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Units">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The 82 TRW is the largest of four technical training wings in <a href="/wiki/Air_Education_and_Training_Command" title="Air Education and Training Command">Air Education and Training Command</a> and is the most diversified in scope of training. The 82d, 782d, and 982d Training Groups conduct training at Sheppard and at geographically separated locations around the country. The 982d Training Group conducts training at locations worldwide.
</p>
<div>

&#32;
<table class="multicol" role="presentation" style="border-collapse: collapse; padding: 0; border: 0; background:transparent; width:100%;"><tbody><tr>
<td style="width: 50%;text-align: left; vertical-align: top;"><b>82d Training Group (82 TRG)</b><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup>
<ul><li>The 82nd Training Group is responsible for aircraft maintenance and armament and munitions including nuclear munitions. The 82d Training Group provides aircraft maintenance and munitions training to satisfy the full range of customer requirements for respective apportioned United States Air Force specialties, including officer and enlisted initial skills courses in 17 different Air Force Specialty Codes, advanced and supplemental courses, the Maintenance Course for Operational Commanders, and the Mission Generation Road Course.
<ul><li>359th Training Squadron (359 TRS)</li>
<li>361st Training Squadron (361 TRS)</li>
<li>362nd Training Squadron (362 TRS)</li>
<li>363rd Training Squadron (363 TRS)</li></ul></li></ul>
<p><b><a href="/w/index.php?title=782d_Training_Group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="782d Training Group (page does not exist)">782d Training Group</a> (782 TRG)</b><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>The 782d Training Group is the most diverse group in Air Education and Training Command, with courses in seven distinctly different career fields in four training squadrons. The 782d Training Group is also responsible for a diverse set of training to include aircraft systems and telecommunications, avionics test equipment, combat avionics, flight line training and explosive ordnance disposal. They are also responsible for electrical, fuels and mechanical training. Detachments 1, 3, and 6 are responsible for media production and interactive courseware.
<ul><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=364th_Training_Squadron&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="364th Training Squadron (page does not exist)">364th Training Squadron</a></li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=365th_Training_Squadron&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="365th Training Squadron (page does not exist)">365th Training Squadron</a></li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=366th_Training_Squadron&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="366th Training Squadron (page does not exist)">366th Training Squadron</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/367th_Training_Support_Squadron" title="367th Training Support Squadron">367th Training Support Squadron</a> (Hill AFB, UT)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/368th_Training_Squadron" title="368th Training Squadron">368th Training Squadron</a> (Fort Leonard Wood, MO)</li></ul></li></ul>
<p><b>982d Training Group (982 TRG)</b><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>The 982d Training Group provides quality hands-on aircraft, munitions and communications-electronics maintenance training to meet the evolving needs of its primary customer, the first-line supervisor. The 982d Training Group has more than 1,200 people assigned within two training squadrons and one maintenance squadron. The 982d Training Group provides weapon systems training at 44 detachments and operating locations worldwide. Exercising single-point training management, the group is the Air Education and Training Command's first point of contact for many weapons systems. In this capacity, the 982d develops comprehensive training programs and provides technical support for design and development of training equipment during acquisition and modification of aircraft and associated equipment. The vision of the 982nd Training Group is to provide field training and training support that makes a lasting difference.
<ul><li>372nd Training Squadron (372 TRS)</li>
<li>373rd Training Squadron (373 TRS)</li>
<li>982nd Maintenance Squadron (982 MXS)</li></ul></li></ul>
<p>&#32;
</p>
</td>
<td style="width: 50%;text-align: left; vertical-align: top;"><b>82d Mission Support Group (82 MSG)</b><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
<ul><li>The 82nd Mission Support Group provides security, personnel support, food services, communications, contracting services, logistics, supplies, vehicle maintenance, housing, lodging, facility maintenance and emergency services for Sheppard's two wings and 17 tenants composed of more than 5,900 military, civilian and contractor personnel, 81,900 joint trainees annually and 9,200 dependents and retirees.
<ul><li>82d Communications Squadron (82 CS)</li>
<li>82d Security Forces Squadron (82 SFS)</li>
<li>82d Force Support Squadron (82 FSS)</li>
<li>82d Civil Engineer Squadron (82 CES)</li>
<li>82d Logistics Readiness Squadron (82 LRS)</li>
<li>82d Contracting Squadron (82 CONS)</li></ul></li></ul>
<p><b>82d Medical Group (82 MDG)</b><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>The 82nd Medical Group provides comprehensive health services for 20,000 beneficiaries for the Sheppard military community and surrounding referral areas. Large numbers of group personnel are ready to deploy in response to any contingency worldwide. Additionally, the 82nd Medical Group provides aerospace and physiology services for the NATO alliance and Department of Defense instructors and their families in the <a href="/wiki/Euro-NATO_Joint_Jet_Pilot_Training_Program" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro-NATO Joint Jet Pilot Training Program">Euro-NATO Joint Jet Pilot Training Program</a>.
<ul><li>82d Medical Operations Squadron (82 MDOS)</li>
<li>82d Dental Squadron (82 DS)</li>
<li>82d Aerospace Medical Squadron (82 AMDS)</li>
<li>82d Medical Support Squadron (82 MDSS)&#32;</li></ul></li></ul>
</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<p><sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Additionally, the 82d Comptroller Squadron (82 CPTS) reports directly to the 82 TRW.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=82nd_Training_Wing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The wing's history started with the <a href="/wiki/82d_Fighter_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="82d Fighter Group">82d Fighter Group</a>, which fought in Europe during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cold_War">Cold War</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=82nd_Training_Wing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Cold War">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The 82d was established as a <a href="/wiki/Strategic_Air_Command" title="Strategic Air Command">Strategic Air Command</a> fighter wing on 28 July 1947 at <a href="/wiki/Grenier_Field" class="mw-redirect" title="Grenier Field">Grenier Field</a>, New Hampshire. The 82d Fighter Wing was established in accordance with the <a href="/wiki/Hobson_Plan" title="Hobson Plan">Hobson Plan</a> which established a controlling wing at each Air Force Base that commanding all groups and support units on the facility.  However, the Air Force did not organize (assign personnel) to the wing until 15 August 1947. The wing was attached to the 307th Bomb Wing from 15 August 1947 to 15 December 1948. On 16 December 1948 the wing was reassigned to <a href="/wiki/Fifteenth_Air_Force" title="Fifteenth Air Force">Fifteenth Air Force</a>.
</p><p>The operational flying component of the wing was the <a href="/wiki/82d_Fighter_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="82d Fighter Group">82d Fighter Group</a>, composed of the 95th, 96th and 97th Fighter Squadrons and were equipped with <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_P-38_Lightning" title="Lockheed P-38 Lightning">Lockheed P-38 Lightning</a> aircraft.  Most officers that arrived were rated pilots that had recently returned to military life. Many had World War II combat experience. Many officers and enlisted men arrived at Grenier from 62nd Fighter Squadron, a unit that had just returned from a winter test in <a href="/wiki/Alaska" title="Alaska">Alaska</a>.
</p><p>The wing was relieved of its responsibilities to the Fifteenth Air Force on 22 August 1949 and was inactivated on 20 October 1949.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Air_Training_Command">Air Training Command</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=82nd_Training_Wing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Air Training Command">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_first_ten_female_officers_to_graduate_from_the_Air_Force_Undergraduate_Pilot_Training_Program_pose_for_a_group_photo_in_front_of_a_T-38_training_aircraft,_Williams_Air_Force_Base,_AZ_DF-ST-84-00864.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/The_first_ten_female_officers_to_graduate_from_the_Air_Force_Undergraduate_Pilot_Training_Program_pose_for_a_group_photo_in_front_of_a_T-38_training_aircraft%2C_Williams_Air_Force_Base%2C_AZ_DF-ST-84-00864.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/The_first_ten_female_officers_to_graduate_from_the_Air_Force_Undergraduate_Pilot_Training_Program_pose_for_a_group_photo_in_front_of_a_T-38_training_aircraft%2C_Williams_Air_Force_Base%2C_AZ_DF-ST-84-00864.jpg/330px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/The_first_ten_female_officers_to_graduate_from_the_Air_Force_Undergraduate_Pilot_Training_Program_pose_for_a_group_photo_in_front_of_a_T-38_training_aircraft%2C_Williams_Air_Force_Base%2C_AZ_DF-ST-84-00864.jpg/440px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2850" data-file-height="1880" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_first_ten_female_officers_to_graduate_from_the_Air_Force_Undergraduate_Pilot_Training_Program_pose_for_a_group_photo_in_front_of_a_T-38_training_aircraft,_Williams_Air_Force_Base,_AZ_DF-ST-84-00864.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>First ten women officers</div></div></div>
<p>The 82d replaced and absorbed resources of the 3525th Pilot Training Wing in February 1973 at <a href="/wiki/Williams_Air_Force_Base" title="Williams Air Force Base">Williams Air Force Base</a>, Arizona and assumed undergraduate pilot training operations in <a href="/wiki/Cessna_T-37_Tweet" title="Cessna T-37 Tweet">Cessna T-37 Tweet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northrop_T-38_Talon" title="Northrop T-38 Talon">Northrop T-38 Talon</a> aircraft. Assigned to the wing were the <a href="/wiki/96th_Flying_Training_Squadron" title="96th Flying Training Squadron">96th</a> and <a href="/wiki/97th_Flying_Training_Squadron" title="97th Flying Training Squadron">97th Flying Training Squadrons</a>.
</p><p>On 19 September 1976, the first women entered undergraduate pilot training. Ten female students were in Class 77-08. First Lieutenant Christine E. Schott became the first woman to solo in the T-38. On 2 September 1977, Class 77-08 graduated. The ten women received their wings along with 36 male classmates. In March 1978, the 82d's first female instructor pilot, Capt Connie Engel, was assigned to the 97th Fighter Training Squadron to instruct T-38 students.
</p><p>Air Training Command activated the <a href="/wiki/98th_Flying_Training_Squadron" title="98th Flying Training Squadron">98th</a> and the <a href="/wiki/99th_Flying_Training_Squadron" title="99th Flying Training Squadron">99th Flying Training Squadrons</a> on 1 June 1988 to test a four-squadron organization. The test showed the wing needed a fifth squadron to provide operational support. On 1 September 1989, ATC activated the <a href="/wiki/100th_Flying_Training_Squadron" class="mw-redirect" title="100th Flying Training Squadron">100th Flying Training Squadron</a>.
</p><p>In 1991 Congress approved the second round of base closures, as identified by the Base Realignment and Closure Commission. On that list was Williams. The base was to cease operation as of 30 September 1993.  With Williams scheduled to close, ATC decided to move part of that base's T-38 fleet to <a href="/wiki/Sheppard_Air_Force_Base" title="Sheppard Air Force Base">Sheppard Air Force Base</a> during 1992.
</p><p>HQ USAF redesignated the 82d Flying Training Wing as the 82d Training Wing and assigned the designation to Air Education and Training Command on 1 July 1993. The 82d was inactivated at Williams and HQ AETC activated the 82d Training Wing at Sheppard and assigned it to Second Air Force. The 82d's new mission was to conduct ground technical training.  The 82d also became the host unit at Sheppard.
</p><p>The 782d Training Group was activated on 23 March 1994 and assigned it to the 82d Training Wing. At the same time, the 396th Technical Training Group changed its name to the 82d Training Group, the 82d Medical Group became the 882d Training Group, and the 82d Field Training Group became the 982d Training Group.  On 30 March, the wing began providing mission ready technician training, first in the C-141 crew chief course and, a day later, in the F-16 crew chief course. The C-141 program graduated its first class in August, followed in September by the F-16 class.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Lineage">Lineage</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=82nd_Training_Wing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Lineage">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>Established as the <b>82 Fighter Wing</b> on 28 July 1947</li></ul>
<dl><dd>Organized on 15 August 1947</dd>
<dd>Inactivated on 2 October 1949</dd></dl>
<ul><li>Redesignated <b>82 Flying Training Wing</b> on 22 June 1972<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<dl><dd>Activated on 1 February 1973</dd>
<dd>Inactivated on 31 March 1993</dd></dl>
<ul><li>Redesignated <b>82 Training Wing</b> and activated on 1 July 1993<sup id="cite_ref-82TWfacts_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82TWfacts-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Assignments">Assignments</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=82nd_Training_Wing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Assignments">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Strategic_Air_Command" title="Strategic Air Command">Strategic Air Command</a>, 15 August 1947 (attached to 307 Bombardment Wing)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Fifteenth_Air_Force" title="Fifteenth Air Force">Fifteenth Air Force</a>, 16 December 1948</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/First_Air_Force" title="First Air Force">First Air Force</a>, 22 August – 2 October 1949</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Air_Training_Command" title="Air Training Command">Air Training Command</a>, 1 February 1973 – 31 March 1993</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Second_Air_Force" title="Second Air Force">Second Air Force</a>, 1 July 1993 – present<sup id="cite_ref-82TWfacts_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82TWfacts-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Components">Components</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=82nd_Training_Wing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Components">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p><b>Groups</b>
</p>
<ul><li>82d Airdrome Group (later 82d Air Base Group, 82d Support Group, 82d Mission Support Group): 15 August 1947 – 2 October 1949, 1 February 1973 – 31 March 1993, 1 June 1993 – present</li>
<li>82d Field Training Group (later 982d Training Group): 1 June 1993 –  present</li>
<li>82d Fighter Group (later 82d Operations Group): 15 August 1947 – 2 October 1949 (detached 4–29 April June 1948), 15 December 1991 – 31 March 1993<sup id="cite_ref-82TWfacts_11-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82TWfacts-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>82d Maintenance &amp; Supply Group (later 82d Logistics Group): 15 August 1947 – 2 October 1949, 15 December 1991 – 31 March 1993, 1 July 1993 – 1 August 2002</li>
<li>82d Medical Training Group (later 882d Training Group): 1 June 1993 – 15 September 2011</li>
<li>82 Station Medical Group (later 82d Medical Group, 82d Flying Training Wing Clinic, 82d Medical Squadron, 82d Medical Group): 15 August 1947 – 2 October 1949, 1988 – 31 March 1993, 1 June 1993 – present</li>
<li>82d Technical Training Group (later 82d Training Group): c. 1 June 1993 – present</li>
<li>782d Training Group: c. 1 July 1994 – present</li>
<li>882d Training Group (see 82d Medical Training Group)</li>
<li>982d Training Group (see 82d Field Training Group)</li></ul>
<p><b>Squadrons</b>
</p>
<ul><li>82d Comptroller Squadron: 1 June 1993 – present</li>
<li>82d Field Maintenance Squadron, 1 February 1973 – 3 April 1990</li>
<li>82d Medical Squadron (see 82d Station Medical Group)</li>
<li>82d Organizational Maintenance Squadron, 1 February 1973 – c. 3 April 1990</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/96th_Flying_Training_Squadron" title="96th Flying Training Squadron">96th Flying Training Squadron</a>: 1 February 1973 – 15 December 1991</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/97th_Flying_Training_Squadron" title="97th Flying Training Squadron">97th Flying Training Squadron</a>: 1 February 1973 – 15 December 1991</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/98th_Flying_Training_Squadron" title="98th Flying Training Squadron">98th Flying Training Squadron</a>: 1 June 1988 – 15 December 1991</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/99th_Flying_Training_Squadron" title="99th Flying Training Squadron">99th Flying Training Squadron</a>: 1 June 1988 – 15 December 1991</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/100th_Flying_Training_Squadron" class="mw-redirect" title="100th Flying Training Squadron">100th Flying Training Squadron</a>: 1 September 1989 – 15 December 1991<sup id="cite_ref-82TWfacts_11-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82TWfacts-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<dl><dt>Other</dt></dl>
<ul><li>USAF Hospital, Williams: 15 October 1970 – 1988 (consolidated with 82d Station Medical Group)</li>
<li>82d Flying Training Wing Clinic (see 82d Station Medical Group)</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Stations">Stations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=82nd_Training_Wing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Stations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li>Grenier Field (later Grenier Air Force Base)], New Hampshire, 15 August 1947 – 2 October 1949</li>
<li>Williams Air Force Base, Arizona, 1 February 1973 – 31 March 1993</li>
<li>Sheppard Air Force Base, Texas, 1 July 1993 – present<sup id="cite_ref-82TWfacts_11-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82TWfacts-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Aircraft_Operated">Aircraft Operated</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=82nd_Training_Wing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Aircraft Operated">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/North_American_P-51_Mustang" title="North American P-51 Mustang">North American P-51 Mustang</a> (later F-51) (1947–1949)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Cessna_T-37_Tweet" title="Cessna T-37 Tweet">Cessna T-37 Tweet</a> (1973–1992)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Northrop_T-38_Talon" title="Northrop T-38 Talon">Northrop T-38 Talon</a> (1973–1993)<sup id="cite_ref-82TWfacts_11-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82TWfacts-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=82nd_Training_Wing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Notes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130713082314/http://www.sheppard.af.mil/library/factsheetspage/factsheet.asp?id=5175">"Archived copy"</a>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.sheppard.af.mil/library/factsheetspage/factsheet.asp?id=5175">the original</a> on 13 July 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">23 September</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Archived+copy&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sheppard.af.mil%2Flibrary%2Ffactsheetspage%2Ffactsheet.asp%3Fid%3D5175&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3A82nd+Training+Wing" class="Z3988"></span><span class="cs1-maint citation-comment">CS1 maint: archived copy as title (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_archived_copy_as_title" title="Category:CS1 maint: archived copy as title">link</a>)</span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140406182546/http://www.sheppard.af.mil/library/factsheetspage/factsheet.asp?id=5169">"Archived copy"</a>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.sheppard.af.mil/library/factsheetspage/factsheet.asp?id=5169">the original</a> on 6 April 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">23 September</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Archived+copy&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sheppard.af.mil%2Flibrary%2Ffactsheetspage%2Ffactsheet.asp%3Fid%3D5169&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3A82nd+Training+Wing" class="Z3988"></span><span class="cs1-maint citation-comment">CS1 maint: archived copy as title (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_archived_copy_as_title" title="Category:CS1 maint: archived copy as title">link</a>)</span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-9">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140405214702/http://www.sheppard.af.mil/library/factsheetspage/factsheet.asp?id=5177">"Archived copy"</a>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.sheppard.af.mil/library/factsheetspage/factsheet.asp?id=5177">the original</a> on 5 April 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">23 September</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Archived+copy&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sheppard.af.mil%2Flibrary%2Ffactsheetspage%2Ffactsheet.asp%3Fid%3D5177&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3A82nd+Training+Wing" class="Z3988"></span><span class="cs1-maint citation-comment">CS1 maint: archived copy as title (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_archived_copy_as_title" title="Category:CS1 maint: archived copy as title">link</a>)</span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-10">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Despite the similarity in names, the wing is not related to the 82d Flying Training Wing (Flexible Gunnery) that was constituted in 1943, activated on 25 August 1943 at <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas_Army_Airfield" class="mw-redirect" title="Las Vegas Army Airfield">Las Vegas Army Airfield</a>, Nevada and assigned to <a href="/wiki/Western_Flying_Training_Command" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Flying Training Command">Western Flying Training Command</a> and disbanded on 16 June 1946.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-82TWfacts-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-82TWfacts_11-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-82TWfacts_11-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-82TWfacts_11-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-82TWfacts_11-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-82TWfacts_11-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-82TWfacts_11-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFHaulman2017" class="citation web cs1">Haulman, Daniel L. (21 June 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.afhra.af.mil/About-Us/Fact-Sheets/Display/Article/432816/82-training-wing-aetc/">"82 Training Wing (AETC)"</a>. Air Force Historical Research Agency. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180119120619/http://www.afhra.af.mil/About-Us/Fact-Sheets/Display/Article/432816/82-training-wing-aetc/">Archived</a> from the original on 19 January 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 January</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=82+Training+Wing+%28AETC%29&amp;rft.pub=Air+Force+Historical+Research+Agency&amp;rft.date=2017-06-21&amp;rft.aulast=Haulman&amp;rft.aufirst=Daniel+L.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.afhra.af.mil%2FAbout-Us%2FFact-Sheets%2FDisplay%2FArticle%2F432816%2F82-training-wing-aetc%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3A82nd+Training+Wing" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<p><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/62/PD-icon.svg/12px-PD-icon.svg.png" decoding="async" width="12" height="12" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/62/PD-icon.svg/18px-PD-icon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/62/PD-icon.svg/24px-PD-icon.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="196" data-file-height="196" />&#160;This article incorporates&#160;<a href="/wiki/Copyright_status_of_works_by_the_federal_government_of_the_United_States" title="Copyright status of works by the federal government of the United States">public domain material</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Air_Force_Historical_Research_Agency" title="Air Force Historical Research Agency">Air Force Historical Research Agency</a>&#32;website <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.afhra.af.mil/">http://www.afhra.af.mil/</a>.
</p>

</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;background-color:#DCDCDC;text-align:center;">Transport</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;background-color:#DCDCDC;text-align:center; background-color:#DCDCDC;"><a href="/wiki/List_of_commanders-in-chief_of_the_Strategic_Air_Command" title="List of commanders-in-chief of the Strategic Air Command">Commanders</a></th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

~~~~
      <table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">January 2020</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<li><a href="/wiki/Joshua_L._Chamberlain" class="mw-redirect" title="Joshua L. Chamberlain">Joshua L. Chamberlain</a></li></ul>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <b>133rd Engineer Battalion</b> is a component of the <a href="/wiki/Maine_Army_National_Guard" title="Maine Army National Guard">Maine Army National Guard</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army" title="United States Army">United States Army</a>.  The organization is the oldest in the <a href="/wiki/Maine" title="Maine">Maine</a> Guard and is one of the largest organizations in the state.  The <a href="/wiki/Battalion" title="Battalion">battalion</a> has responded to natural disasters at home as well as military actions overseas.  The current battalion has the capacity to execute a variety of Army Engineer missions, from horizontal construction, vertical construction, <a href="/wiki/Combat_engineer" title="Combat engineer">combat engineer</a> missions, and surveying.  The battalion has two horizontal companies, one vertical company, one combat engineer company, a forward support company, a survey and design detachment, and a headquarters company.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=133rd_Engineer_Battalion&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>(Note - The primary source for the historical information below is the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://history.army.mil/html/forcestruc/lineages/branches/eng/0133enbn.htm">Lineage and Honors of the 133rd Engineer Battalion</a> from the U.S. Army Center for Military History.)
</p><p>The 133rd Engineer Battalion is the oldest unit in the Maine Army National Guard and one of several National Guard units with <a href="/wiki/Army_National_Guard_and_Active_Regular_Army_Units_with_Colonial_Roots" title="Army National Guard and Active Regular Army Units with Colonial Roots">campaign credit for the American Revolution</a> and <a href="/wiki/Army_National_Guard_units_with_campaign_credit_for_the_War_of_1812" title="Army National Guard units with campaign credit for the War of 1812">the War of 1812</a>.
</p><p>Known as “Maine’s Regiment” the 133rd traces its beginnings back to the formation of the Cumberland County Regiment of the Massachusetts Militia in 1760 and its subordinate element, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Portland_Light_Infantry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Portland Light Infantry (page does not exist)">Portland Light Infantry</a> in 1804.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> The Portland Light Infantry manned the defenses around <a href="/wiki/Portland,_Maine" title="Portland, Maine">Portland</a>, such as Forts Preble and Scammell, to prevent British attack in 1814 during the <a href="/wiki/War_of_1812" title="War of 1812">War of 1812</a>. Other militia units flooded Portland that year, responding to a British invasion from the north that had already seized <a href="/wiki/Bangor,_Maine" title="Bangor, Maine">Bangor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Castine,_Maine" title="Castine, Maine">Castine</a>. Veterans of the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, the British were tough and determined fighters. The British government had decided to take control of Maine and turn it into a colony called “New Ireland.” Several thousand British soldiers assembled in Castine with seven ships of the line, intent on taking Portland in 1814. However, militia units from all over Maine put up such a strong defense that after a few skirmishes on the outskirts of town, the British decided that an attack would be too costly and cancelled the invasion.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Civil_War">Civil War</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=133rd_Engineer_Battalion&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Civil War">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Maine men would be called on again in 1861 when war divided the nation into North and South. The Portland Light Infantry was designated as Company A of the <a href="/wiki/1st_Maine_Volunteer_Infantry_Regiment" class="mw-redirect" title="1st Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment">1st Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment</a>, a 90-day regiment, and marched off to Virginia but was not engaged in the <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_Bull_Run" title="First Battle of Bull Run">Battle of Bull Run</a>. The 1st Maine was mustered out of service on 5 August 1861.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Many members of the 1st Maine Volunteer Infantry reenlisted as members of the <a href="/wiki/10th_Maine_Volunteer_Infantry_Regiment" class="mw-redirect" title="10th Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment">10th Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment</a> when it was formed in October 1861.  It fought at the battles of <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cedar_Mountain" title="Battle of Cedar Mountain">Cedar Mountain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Antietam" title="Battle of Antietam">Antietam</a> in 1862.  Most enlistments in the 10th Maine expired on 8 May 1863 except for 3 companies of "three year men" who were retained in service as the 10th Maine Battalion. The 10th Maine Battalion served as the Provost Guard for the <a href="/wiki/Army_of_the_Potomac" title="Army of the Potomac">Army of the Potomac</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gettysburg" title="Battle of Gettysburg">Battle of Gettysburg</a>.  The <a href="/wiki/29th_Maine_Volunteer_Infantry_Regiment" class="mw-redirect" title="29th Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment">29th Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment</a> was mustered into service on December 17, 1863, and was transferred to the southern theater, fighting in Louisiana in the <a href="/wiki/Red_River_Campaign" title="Red River Campaign">Red River Campaign</a> from March to May 1864, and then in Virginia from July 1864 to April 1865. On 29 May 1864, the 10th Maine Battalion was consolidated with the 29th Maine, thus establishing continuity with the 10th Maine Regiment and the 1st Maine Regiment. The 29th Maine served on occupation duty in South Carolina starting in June 1865 and was mustered out of service on June 21, 1866.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/2nd_Maine_Volunteer_Infantry_Regiment" class="mw-redirect" title="2nd Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment">2nd Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment</a> was called into service the same time as the 1st, and saw action during the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Days_Battles" title="Seven Days Battles">Seven Days Battles</a>, 2nd Bull Run, Antietam, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fredericksburg" title="Battle of Fredericksburg">Fredericksburg</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Chancellorsville" title="Battle of Chancellorsville">Chancellorsville</a>. The regiment's enlistments ran up in 1863, but about half the unit had signed papers to serve for the three years, so they were amalgamated into the <a href="/wiki/20th_Maine_Volunteer_Infantry_Regiment" class="mw-redirect" title="20th Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment">20th Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment</a>.
Also in 1862, the <a href="/wiki/20th_Maine_Volunteer_Infantry_Regiment" class="mw-redirect" title="20th Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment">20th Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment</a> was raised from the Brewer area. The 20th would become one of the most famous units in the Civil War. The regiment saw limited action at Antietam but made up for it at the Battle of Fredericksburg, where they were part of the assault element that aimed to take the Confederate defenses on the high ground. The 20th sustained heavy casualties and was pinned down for over twenty-four hours under enemy fire in the cold December weather. They were positioned on the far left of the Union line at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gettysburg" title="Battle of Gettysburg">Battle of Gettysburg</a> in 1863 and sustained multiple enemy attacks, until the regiment had nearly run out of ammunition. They had been ordered to hold to the last man. The regimental commander, Colonel <a href="/wiki/Joshua_L._Chamberlain" class="mw-redirect" title="Joshua L. Chamberlain">Joshua L. Chamberlain</a> then gave the order, “Bayonet, Forward!” knowing that he could not withdraw or the enemy would outflank the Union army. The bayonet charge by the Mainers took the Confederates by surprise and ended their attacks entirely. For his actions, Colonel Chamberlain was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Medal_of_Honor" title="Medal of Honor">Medal of Honor</a>. The 20th would serve until the end of the war, fighting with distinction in the savage battles through Virginia, such as the <a href="/wiki/Wilderness" title="Wilderness">Wilderness</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spotsylvania_County,_Virginia" title="Spotsylvania County, Virginia">Spotsylvania</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Petersburg,_Virginia" title="Petersburg, Virginia">Petersburg</a>.  The 133rd Engineer Battalion carries on the lineage and traditions of the 20th Maine.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1865-1940">1865-1940</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=133rd_Engineer_Battalion&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: 1865-1940">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>At the end of the war, the Soldiers came home and returned to their civilian lives. Many kept up their military experience by membership in the 1st Maine Volunteer Militia, organized in 1873. The 1st M.V.M. had companies in Portland, Augusta, Skowhegan, Auburn, Norway, Bangor, Belfast, Hampden, and Old Town, laying out the footprint for the future 133rd Engineer Battalion. In 1893, the Maine Volunteer Militia was re-designated as the <a href="/wiki/National_Guard_of_the_United_States" class="mw-redirect" title="National Guard of the United States">Maine National Guard</a>, and the 1st M.V.M. was designated the 1st Maine Infantry.  The 2nd Maine Infantry was also brought under the Maine National Guard when it was formed from the Maine Volunteer Militia in 1893.
</p><p>In May 1898 the 1st Maine Infantry was mobilized as the 1st Maine Volunteer Infantry for service in the <a href="/wiki/Spanish-American_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish-American War">Spanish-American War</a>.  It served stateside and was mustered out of service on 13 December 1898.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1909, the 1st M.V.M. reorganized and re-designated as the Coast Artillery Corps, with batteries from Bath to Kittery. In 1917 it was mobilized to protect the Maine coast, manning coast defenses, primarily near Portland.  In December 1917 four companies were attached to the <a href="/wiki/54th_Coast_Artillery_(United_States)" class="mw-redirect" title="54th Coast Artillery (United States)">54th Artillery</a> (<a href="/wiki/Coast_Artillery_Corps" class="mw-redirect" title="Coast Artillery Corps">Coast Artillery Corps</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> and deployed to France, where they fought on the Marne and the Meuse-Argonne Campaigns.  The remaining companies remained in Maine until they were demobilized in December 1918.
</p><p>The 2nd Maine Infantry was called into service in 1916 for service on the Texas border and then again in 1917 for <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> where it was combined with a unit from New Hampshire to become the <a href="/wiki/103rd_Infantry_Regiment_(United_States)" title="103rd Infantry Regiment (United States)">103rd U.S. Infantry</a>, which was one of the four Infantry regiments in the <a href="/wiki/26th_Infantry_Division_(United_States)" title="26th Infantry Division (United States)">26th Division</a> (a.k.a. the "Yankee Division").<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> They served on the front lines in France, taking part in the battles of <a href="/wiki/Champagne-Marne" class="mw-redirect" title="Champagne-Marne">Champagne-Marne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aisne-Marne" class="mw-redirect" title="Aisne-Marne">Aisne-Marne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saint-Mihiel" title="Saint-Mihiel">Saint-Mihiel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Meuse-Argonne" class="mw-redirect" title="Meuse-Argonne">Meuse-Argonne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ile_de_France" class="mw-redirect" title="Ile de France">Ile de France</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lorraine_(region)" class="mw-redirect" title="Lorraine (region)">Lorraine</a>. One soldier, Private First Class <a href="/wiki/George_Dilboy" title="George Dilboy">George Dilboy</a>, was posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor for his actions in single-handedly overrunning a German machine gun position.
</p><p>The 103d Infantry was demobilized in April 1919 and was reassigned to the <a href="/wiki/43rd_Infantry_Division_(United_States)" title="43rd Infantry Division (United States)">43rd Infantry Division</a> when it was formed in the early 1920s.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1922 the Coast Artillery units were re-designated as the 1st Coast Defense Command, and re-designated again on 17 September 1923 as the <a href="/wiki/240th_Coast_Artillery_(United_States)" title="240th Coast Artillery (United States)">240th Coast Artillery Regiment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II">World War II</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=133rd_Engineer_Battalion&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: World War II">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>As the United States prepared to enter World War II, the <a href="/wiki/240th_Coast_Artillery_(United_States)" title="240th Coast Artillery (United States)">240th Coast Artillery</a> was mobilized to defend Portland on September 16, 1940.  On 7 October 1944 the regiment was re-organized into the 185th and 186th Coast Artillery Battalions.  On 1 April 1945 the two battalions were consolidated into the <a href="/wiki/Harbor_Defenses_of_Portland" title="Harbor Defenses of Portland">Harbor Defenses of Portland</a>, which was inactivated in June 1946.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During World War II, the 103rd Infantry, as an element of the <a href="/wiki/43rd_Infantry_Division_(United_States)" title="43rd Infantry Division (United States)">43rd Infantry Division</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> served in the Pacific theater, fighting in the battles of <a href="/wiki/Guadalcanal" title="Guadalcanal">Guadalcanal</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Solomon_Islands" title="North Solomon Islands">North Solomons</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Guinea" title="New Guinea">New Guinea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Luzon" title="Luzon">Luzon</a>, helping General Macarthur liberate the Philippines. They were the first unit to reach the <a href="/wiki/Ipo_Dam" title="Ipo Dam">Ipo Dam</a>, which controlled the water supply for Manila, a crucial step in liberating the city.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Post_WWII">Post WWII</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=133rd_Engineer_Battalion&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Post WWII">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In February 1947, the Coast Artillery units were re-organized and re-designated as the 703rd Anti-Aircraft Gun Battalion.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> They were mobilized from August 1950 to April 1952 to replace Regular Army units which had deployed to Korea during the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a>.
</p><p>On 1 March 1959 Companies A, B and C of the 703rd AA Bn consolidated with the 103d Infantry and were reorganized and re-designated as the 103d Armored Cavalry Regiment (ACR).  Meanwhile, Headquarters and Company D of the 703rd AA Gun Bn were re-organized and re-designated and consolidated with the 314th Anti-Aircraft Artillery Battalion to form 1st Battalion, 240th Artillery.   On 1 June 1961 the 103d ACR, less the headquarters company, was reorganized and re-designated as the 20th Armor Regiment.  At the same time, the Headquarters Company of the 103rd ACR was re-designated as Headquarters, 113th Armor Group.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The 240th Artillery was converted, reorganized, and re-designated on 1 June 1961 as the 262d Engineer Battalion with headquarters at Bangor.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1962, 3d Battalion, 20th Armor was mobilized for the Berlin Crisis and stood ready in Fort Stewart, Georgia, until the crisis defused.  In 1963, the 1st Battalion, 20th Armor was stood up in readiness during the Cuban Missile Crisis but the issues was resolved before the unit had to deploy.  The 240th Coast Artillery served until the 1960s before being disbanded, but its lineage was assumed into the 20th Armor.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 31 December 1967 the 20th Armor consolidated with Headquarters, 113th Armor Group to form the 133d Engineer Battalion.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 1 September 1993 the 133rd Engineer Battalion was consolidated with the 262nd Engineer Battalion while retaining its designation as the 133rd Engineer Battalion.<sup id="cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CMHLH1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="133d_Engineer_Battalion">133d Engineer Battalion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=133rd_Engineer_Battalion&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: 133d Engineer Battalion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Since 1970, 133d Engineer Battalion has served both at home for disaster relief missions and abroad in defense of the nation. In 1992 the battalion deployed to <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a> to improve infrastructure in rural areas.  In 1994, the battalion functioned as Mission Command in support of <a href="/wiki/New_Horizons" title="New Horizons">New Horizons</a>, Task Force Dirigo, in Guatemala, a humanitarian and disaster relief mission.  In 1997, units of the 133rd were deployed to Bosnia-Herzegovina in support of <a href="/wiki/Operation_Joint_Guard" class="mw-redirect" title="Operation Joint Guard">Operation Joint Guard</a>.
</p><p>After 9/11, the 133d was mobilized in support of <a href="/wiki/Operation_Iraqi_Freedom" class="mw-redirect" title="Operation Iraqi Freedom">Operation Iraqi Freedom</a> II between 2004 and 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> The battalion served as the Engineer Task Force for <a href="/wiki/I_Corps_(United_States)" title="I Corps (United States)">I Corps</a>’ <a href="/w/index.php?title=Task_Force_Olympia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Task Force Olympia (page does not exist)">Task Force Olympia</a> in the Multi-National Brigade-Northwest Area of Operations.  As a battalion, the 133d completed over 730 troop missions, completed host-nation improvements in excess of 15 million dollars, built over 12 kilometers of earthen berms for force protection, and completed 15 airfield assistance missions.  In addition, the 133d completed 84 humanitarian assistance missions, donating 1473 boxes of school supplies, clothes, shoes, food, and toys to Iraqi communities as well as building roads, wells and multiple schools and medical clinics.  The 133d Engineer Battalion's area of operations (AO) spanned an area the size of the U.S. northeast, significantly larger than most Engineer battalion's normal span of control in Iraq.  The 133d was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Meritorious_Unit_Commendation" title="Meritorious Unit Commendation">Meritorious Unit Commendation</a> for their participation in the Transition of Iraq and Iraqi Governance Campaigns.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>
In 2005, members of the 133d responded to Louisiana to provide security and disaster relief assistance after <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina" title="Hurricane Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Similarly, the 133d sent Joint Task Force Maine to Vermont in 2011 to assist in <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Irene" title="Hurricane Irene">Tropical Storm Irene</a> recovery.  The 133d opened several key routes in Vermont that had been closed from debris or washouts, enabling communities to get assistance.</p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:U.S._Army_Spc._Symone_Sherrill,_an_engineer_with_the_150th_Engineer_Company,_New_Jersey_Army_National_Guard,_assigned_to_the_133rd_Engineer_Battalion,_Maine_Army_National_Guard,_carries_a_traffic_cone_while_131228-A-MU632-903.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/U.S._Army_Spc._Symone_Sherrill%2C_an_engineer_with_the_150th_Engineer_Company%2C_New_Jersey_Army_National_Guard%2C_assigned_to_the_133rd_Engineer_Battalion%2C_Maine_Army_National_Guard%2C_carries_a_traffic_cone_while_131228-A-MU632-903.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="353" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/U.S._Army_Spc._Symone_Sherrill%2C_an_engineer_with_the_150th_Engineer_Company%2C_New_Jersey_Army_National_Guard%2C_assigned_to_the_133rd_Engineer_Battalion%2C_Maine_Army_National_Guard%2C_carries_a_traffic_cone_while_131228-A-MU632-903.jpg/330px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/U.S._Army_Spc._Symone_Sherrill%2C_an_engineer_with_the_150th_Engineer_Company%2C_New_Jersey_Army_National_Guard%2C_assigned_to_the_133rd_Engineer_Battalion%2C_Maine_Army_National_Guard%2C_carries_a_traffic_cone_while_131228-A-MU632-903.jpg/440px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1938" data-file-height="3108" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:U.S._Army_Spc._Symone_Sherrill,_an_engineer_with_the_150th_Engineer_Company,_New_Jersey_Army_National_Guard,_assigned_to_the_133rd_Engineer_Battalion,_Maine_Army_National_Guard,_carries_a_traffic_cone_while_131228-A-MU632-903.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>U.S. Army Spc. Symone Sherrill, an engineer with the 150th Engineer Company, New Jersey Army National Guard, assigned to the 133rd Engineer Battalion, Maine Army National Guard, carries a traffic cone while marking off her work area during a project to build an earth-filled barrier at Bagram Airfield in Parwan province, Afghanistan, Dec. 28, 2013.</div></div></div>
<p>Following <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Irene" title="Hurricane Irene">Hurricane Irene</a> in 2011, a task force of vertical and horizontal Engineers from the 133rd assisted communities in Vermont in their recovery efforts.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Following <a href="/wiki/Superstorm_Sandy" class="mw-redirect" title="Superstorm Sandy">Superstorm Sandy</a> in 2012, a task force of vertical and horizontal Engineers from the 133rd assisted communities in Connecticut in their recovery efforts.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>In the spring of 2013, the 133d deployed a company of vertical engineers to El Salvador to assist in critical infrastructure repairs in support of Operation Beyond the Horizon.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>On 10 August 2013, the 133d was mobilized in Support of <a href="/wiki/Operation_Enduring_Freedom" title="Operation Enduring Freedom">Operation Enduring Freedom</a>, Afghanistan.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>An article in the <i>Portland Press Herald</i> dated April 30, 2014 stated the 133d Engineer Battalion is under consideration for transfer to Pennsylvania and replacement in-state by an infantry battalion.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> These plans were declared shelved in November 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Organization">Organization</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=133rd_Engineer_Battalion&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Organization">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The unit is composed of:<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<ul><li>Headquarters and Headquarters Company, <a href="/wiki/Brunswick,_Maine" title="Brunswick, Maine">Brunswick, Maine</a></li>
<li>Forward Support Company, <a href="/wiki/Brunswick,_Maine" title="Brunswick, Maine">Brunswick, Maine</a></li>
<li>136th Engineer Company (Vertical), <a href="/wiki/Skowhegan,_Maine" title="Skowhegan, Maine">Skowhegan, Maine</a></li>
<li>185th Engineer Company (Engineer Support), <a href="/wiki/Caribou,_Maine" title="Caribou, Maine">Caribou, Maine</a></li>
<li>251st Engineer Company (Sapper), <a href="/wiki/Norway,_Maine" title="Norway, Maine">Norway, Maine</a></li>
<li>262nd Engineer Company (Horizontal), <a href="/wiki/Westbrook,_Maine" title="Westbrook, Maine">Westbrook, Maine</a></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Honors">Honors</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=133rd_Engineer_Battalion&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Honors">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Meritorious_Unit_Commendation" title="Meritorious Unit Commendation">Meritorious Unit Commendation</a> for <a href="/wiki/Operation_Iraqi_Freedom" class="mw-redirect" title="Operation Iraqi Freedom">Operation Iraqi Freedom</a><sup id="cite_ref-:0_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Meritorious_Unit_Commendation" title="Meritorious Unit Commendation">Meritorious Unit Commendation</a> for <a href="/wiki/Operation_Enduring_Freedom" title="Operation Enduring Freedom">Operation Enduring Freedom</a><sup id="cite_ref-:0_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=133rd_Engineer_Battalion&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Notes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-CMHLH1-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-8"><sup><i><b>i</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-9"><sup><i><b>j</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-10"><sup><i><b>k</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-11"><sup><i><b>l</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-12"><sup><i><b>m</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-13"><sup><i><b>n</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-14"><sup><i><b>o</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-15"><sup><i><b>p</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CMHLH1_1-16"><sup><i><b>q</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFU.S._Army_Center_of_Military_History" class="citation web cs1">U.S. Army Center of Military History, . <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.history.army.mil/html/forcestruc/lineages/branches/eng/0133enbn.htm">"133d Engineer Battalion | Lineage and Honors | U.S. Army Center of Military History (CMH)"</a>. <i>www.history.army.mil</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <table class="infobox" style="width:22em;width:25.5em;border-spacing:2px;"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" Kroatisches Infanterie-Regiment 369</i><br /> <i>369. pojačana pješačka pukovnija</i></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align:center;border-bottom:1px solid style="padding-right: 1em;">Motto(s)</th><td><i>Što Bog da i sreća junačka!</i><br />("<i>By the grace of God and a stroke of luck!</i>"<br />"lit. <i>What God gives and luck of <p>The <b>369th Reinforced Infantry Regiment</b> (<a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a>: <i lang="de">Verstärktes Kroatisches Infanterie-Regiment 369</i>, <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a>: <i lang="hr">369. pojačana pješačka pukovnija</i>) was a unit of the German <a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">Wehrmacht</a> that fought on the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">Eastern Front</a> in <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. The regiment was raised from volunteers drawn from Croatia and was commonly referred to as the <b>Croatian Legion</b> (<i>Hrvatska Legija</i>).
</p>
