<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Aftermath"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Aftermath</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#Commanders"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Commanders</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-10"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Formation">Formation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=369th_Croatian_Reinforced_Infantry_Regiment_(Wehrmacht)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Formation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia.svg/220px-Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia.svg/330px-Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia.svg/440px-Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="324" data-file-height="216" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Flag of the regiment with unit's motto</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia_(Reverse).svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia_%28Reverse%29.svg/220px-Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia_%28Reverse%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia_%28Reverse%29.svg/330px-Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia_%28Reverse%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia_%28Reverse%29.svg/440px-Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia_%28Reverse%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="324" data-file-height="216" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_369th_Infantry_Regiment_of_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia_(Reverse).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Flag of the regiment (Reverse), the inscription reads, "For <i><a href="/wiki/Poglavnik" title="Poglavnik">Poglavnik</a></i> and for the homeland."</div></div></div>
<p>On 10 April 1941, the <a href="/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Independent State of Croatia">Independent State of Croatia</a> (NDH, Croatian: <i>Nezavisna Država Hrvatska</i>) was created as a puppet state aligned to the occupying <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Germans</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Usta%C5%A1e" title="Ustaše">Ustaše</a> fascist government of the NDH asked Germany for military assistance as they feared Italian territorial ambitions after ceding much of the coastal area of <a href="/wiki/Governorate_of_Dalmatia" title="Governorate of Dalmatia">Dalmatia</a> to <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy_(1861%E2%80%931946)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)">Italy</a> in treaties signed on 18 May 1941.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> By 25 June 1941, <a href="/wiki/Poglavnik" title="Poglavnik">Poglavnik</a> <a href="/wiki/Ante_Paveli%C4%87" title="Ante Pavelić">Ante Pavelić</a>, the leader of the NDH, had sent an envoy to Berlin to offer volunteers to serve on the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">Eastern Front</a>. By 2 July, Hitler had accepted the offer, and military units were formed under the supervision of two German army officers.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> The NDH viewed this as a means of strengthening its ties with Germany, potentially an ally in resisting further territorial losses to Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Although the unit was considered by the NDH to be a part of the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Home_Guard_(Independent_State_of_Croatia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian Home Guard (Independent State of Croatia)">Croatian Home Guard</a> and the NDH authorities retained responsibility for providing replacements, the members of the regiment swore an oath to Adolf Hitler. Whilst not an official part of the Wehrmacht, the regiment was under German military jurisdiction and direct German command throughout its existence, serving as part of the <a href="/wiki/100th_Light_Infantry_Division_(Wehrmacht)" class="mw-redirect" title="100th Light Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)">100th Light Infantry Division</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Muller98_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Muller98-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> All soldiers wore Wehrmacht uniforms with a Croatian checkerboard patch incorporating the word <i>Hrvatska</i> (Croatia) on the upper right sleeve and right side of the helmet.
</p><p>Initially, two battalions were raised and formed into a regiment at <a href="/wiki/Varazdin" class="mw-redirect" title="Varazdin">Varazdin</a>. This was followed by the raising of a third battalion at <a href="/wiki/Sarajevo" title="Sarajevo">Sarajevo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-David18_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-David18-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> Only <a href="/wiki/Croats" title="Croats">Croats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a> or <a href="/wiki/White_%C3%A9migr%C3%A9" title="White émigré">White Russians</a> were accepted as volunteers, and about one third of those accepted were <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks" title="Bosniaks">Bosnian Muslims</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Tomasevich395_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tomasevich395-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> A training battalion was formed for the regiment in <a href="/wiki/Stockerau" title="Stockerau">Stockerau</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ostmark_(Austria)" title="Ostmark (Austria)">Austria</a>. The regiment was then transported to <a href="/wiki/Dollersheim" class="mw-redirect" title="Dollersheim">Dollersheim</a>, Austria for training. With an effective strength of 5000, the regiment consisted of three infantry battalions, a machine-gun company, an anti-tank company, three batteries of field artillery, headquarters staff and a supply company.<sup id="cite_ref-David18_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-David18-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 21 August 1941, the regiment was transported to <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a>. From there, it spent several weeks marching on foot to the front line. On 10 October, the regiment linked up on the line of the <a href="/wiki/Dnieper_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Dnieper River">Dnieper River</a> with the 100th Light Infantry Division, which was then part of the <a href="/wiki/17th_Army_(Wehrmacht)" title="17th Army (Wehrmacht)">17th Army</a>, <a href="/wiki/Army_Group_South" title="Army Group South">Army Group South</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Military_action_on_Eastern_Front">Military action on Eastern Front</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=369th_Croatian_Reinforced_Infantry_Regiment_(Wehrmacht)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Military action on Eastern Front">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In order to accustom the regiment to the conditions and divisional procedures, as well as to further progress their training, the units of the regiment were initially divided up among other regiments of the division immediately after their arrival on the front line near Kharkov. The divisional diary recorded that the main goal for units of the regiment during this period was to improve discipline across various areas.<sup id="cite_ref-Muller98_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Muller98-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> To improve poor discipline, on 30 September 1941, Colonel <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ivan_Markulj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ivan Markulj (page does not exist)">Ivan Markulj</a> sent 43 officers and NCOs as well as 144 soldiers back to the NDH due to illness and/or for disciplinary reasons.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After the <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> counterattacked and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Rostov_(1941)" title="Battle of Rostov (1941)">re-took Rostov</a> in November 1941, the 100th Light Infantry Division was marched south to the front line on the <a href="/wiki/Mius_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Mius River">Mius River</a> on 22 November.   Temperatures dropped as low as -18C and the regiment had no winter clothing. The units of the regiment, still divided among the other regiments of the division, dug in alongside the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovak_Mobile_Brigade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Slovak Mobile Brigade (page does not exist)">Slovak Mobile Brigade</a> and <a href="/wiki/5th_SS_Panzer_Division_Wiking" title="5th SS Panzer Division Wiking">SS-Division <i>Wiking</i></a>. In mid-January 1942, the 100th Light Infantry Division was deployed to the <a href="/wiki/Donetsk" title="Donetsk">Stalino</a> area to assist in fighting off a Soviet cavalry corps that had broken through the front line. Through some heavy fighting along the line of the <a href="/wiki/Samara_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Samara River">Samara River</a>, the division held on through the winter.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Starting in early 1942, soldiers of the unit were able to send messages back to the Independent State of Croatia. Messages for family members and friends were written on any paper the troops could find, such as cigarette papers or pages torn from notebooks. Communications from the Regiment's soldiers were subsequently broadcast on Radio Zagreb (later known as <i><a href="/wiki/Hrvatski_Krugoval" class="mw-redirect" title="Hrvatski Krugoval">Hrvatski Krugoval</a></i>), alongside propaganda announcements that praised the Croatian authorities and did not mention the soldiers' fate – most often death or capture.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The commander of the 100th Light Infantry Division, Generalleutnant <a href="/wiki/Werner_Sanne" title="Werner Sanne">Werner Sanne</a> commended the regiment's successes over the winter, especially the actions of Lieutenant Colonel <a href="/wiki/Marko_Mesi%C4%87_(1901%E2%80%931982)" class="mw-redirect" title="Marko Mesić (1901–1982)">Marko Mesić</a>'s artillery battalion on 21–22 February 1942. On 23 February 1942, Sanne awarded Mesić the Iron Cross.
</p><p>During April 1942 four soldiers of the regiment were sentenced to death and shot while many others were sentenced to imprisonment of between 2–10 years.
</p><p>From mid-May 1942 the regiment was re-united under Colonel Markulj, after which the 100th Light Infantry Division joined in the final phases of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Battle_of_Kharkov" title="Second Battle of Kharkov">pincer attack</a> on the Red Army bridgehead at Kharkov. In June, the division supported the drive of the <a href="/wiki/1st_Panzer_Army" title="1st Panzer Army">1st Panzer Army</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Don_River_(Russia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Don River (Russia)">Don River</a>, through <a href="/wiki/Voronezh" title="Voronezh">Voronezh</a> to <a href="/wiki/Kalach,_Kalacheyevsky_District,_Voronezh_Oblast" title="Kalach, Kalacheyevsky District, Voronezh Oblast">Kalach</a> where the regiment incurred heavy casualties trying to cross the river in the face of serious resistance.<sup id="cite_ref-Muller100_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Muller100-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After the Second Battle of Kharkov, Colonel Markulj, Lieutenant Eduard Bakarec and six other officers of the regiment were awarded the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Cross" title="Iron Cross">Iron Cross</a> First Class. A report dated 21 June 1942 states that Legion contained 113 officers, 7 military clerks, 625 NCOs, and 4317 soldiers, as well as 2902 horses.
</p><p>After participating in mopping-up operations in along the Don, the division rested briefly in September, and the regiment was re-organised after receiving some reinforcements.<sup id="cite_ref-Muller100_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Muller100-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Markulj was transferred back to Croatia and was temporarily replaced by Colonel <a href="/wiki/Marko_Mesi%C4%87_(1901%E2%80%931982)" class="mw-redirect" title="Marko Mesić (1901–1982)">Marko Mesić</a> on 7 July 1942 and Lieutenant Colonel <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Babi%C4%87_(soldier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ivan Babić (soldier)">Ivan Babić</a> who was finally replaced by Colonel <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Pavi%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Viktor Pavičić">Viktor Pavičić</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>At 'Proljet Kultura,' the regiment suffered 53 dead and 186 wounded in desperate hand-to-hand combat during the German attack on 27 July and subsequent overwhelming Soviet counterattack on 28 July. The worst recorded casualties before Stalingrad were 171 dead suffered in combat in various villages along the <a href="/wiki/Samara_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Samara River">Samara River</a>. Lt. Tomljenović, Lt. Tomislav Anić and Lt. Ivan Malički were killed in action during this period.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 24 September 1942, during a visit to the <a href="/wiki/6th_Army_(Wehrmacht)" title="6th Army (Wehrmacht)">6th Army</a> headquarters, Pavelić decorated and promoted some soldiers of the regiment. Two days later the 100th Light Infantry Division was committed to the Battle of Stalingrad.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:218px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Memorial_badge_Croatian_Legion.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c7/Memorial_badge_Croatian_Legion.jpg" decoding="async" width="216" height="200" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="216" data-file-height="200" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Memorial_badge_Croatian_Legion.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>369th Legion Memorial badge</div></div></div>
<p>The number of legionnaires from that date was fast reducing to a reported total of 1,403 altogether by 21 October 1942.  New fresh forces from Croatia were not added except for returns of sick and wounded and a few officers and staff.  A total of 22 (15%) officers were killed, 38 (26%) wounded and 66 (45%) returned to Croatia from the original 147 Legion officers in total before fall.  Only 20 officers, including Mesic, remained in Stalingrad and one is treated as MIA.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Lt. Bakarec, who was the first Legion soldier ever to receive the Iron Cross 2nd class, was later wounded at Stalingrad and evacuated to Croatia, where he was killed on 5 July 1944.  Col. and later NDH general Markulj was tried and executed in Belgrade in September 1945. Markulj was court-martialled and executed after his capture by the Allies, who extradited him to the Yugoslav army in summer 1945.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Battle_of_Stalingrad">Battle of Stalingrad</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=369th_Croatian_Reinforced_Infantry_Regiment_(Wehrmacht)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Battle of Stalingrad">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The 100th Light Infantry Division, including the 369th Croatian Reinforced Infantry Regiment, was involved in the heavy fighting for the <a href="/wiki/Krasny_Oktyabr_Closed_Joint-Stock_Company" class="mw-redirect" title="Krasny Oktyabr Closed Joint-Stock Company">"Red October" factory</a> and for <a href="/wiki/Mamayev_Kurgan" title="Mamayev Kurgan">Mamayev Hill</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Stalingrad" title="Battle of Stalingrad">Battle of Stalingrad</a>.  By November 1942 the fighting in their sector had become a locked stalemate with little progress.  By December 1942 the regiment had seen such intense combat that it was at 1/3 strength.  Despite the harsh conditions, the German high command credited the regiment with maintaining 'proper and military bearing'.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Sergeant Dragutin Podobnik was awarded Iron Cross Second and First Class as well as many Croat decorations including one personally from Pavelic in September 1942 for his actions at Stalingrad.  Pavicic ordered a strategic building to be captured in the Red October factory, however the armored vehicle support was delayed.  Podobnik and his 18 men surprised the Soviets and captured the building without loss, then handed it over to units from the German 54th Army Group.  Sergeant Podobnik was later wounded and evacuated from Stalingrad and was killed in spring 1945 whilst serving in Pavelic's elite unit.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Several distinctions and citations are noted in war diaries and official military documents.  There are several citations for bravery, valor, and leadership under fire for men of all ranks, including Lieutenant <a href="/wiki/Rudolf_Bari%C4%8Devi%C4%87" title="Rudolf Baričević">Rudolf Baričević</a>.  In addition, the regimental doctors received distinction for their actions and success in saving lives.  One notable citation is that of Captain Madraš, who was wounded and was to be flown out of Stalingrad, but refused and instead stayed and fought with his men.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>There were also acts of insubordination, dereliction of duty, and cowardly behaviour cited in reports.  This was common for the demoralized and surrounded German and German-allied troops at Stalingrad, as the conditions were extremely harsh on the soldiers. Major Tomislav Brajkovic is noted to have desperately attempted to keep morale and discipline high.  However, due to major disagreements with other officers, including his commanding officer, he was transferred out of the regiment.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>By 14 January the regiment's section of the front line had reduced to 200&#160;m held by some 90 remaining troops, all suffering from extreme cold, hunger, fatigue and lack of ammunition.  Colonel Viktor Pavicic reportedly left a resignation letter and disappeared from the theater for good.  He recommended Colonel Mesić to General Sanne to be his successor.  General Sanne officially reported that Pavicic was a deserter, but Sgt. Erwin Juric claimed that Pavicic had received written orders signed by Sanne to leave Stalingrad by air on 15 January.  During its last days at Stalingrad, the Legion was desperately retraining about 700 inexperienced artillery and support soldiers to infantry combat duty.  The last official report from 21 January 1943 counted 443 infantry and 444 artillery soldiers in Stalingrad.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> Just before the surrender of the 6th Army at the end of January, about 1,000 wounded were flown out, and of the remaining men in the regiment, nearly 900 became <a href="/wiki/Prisoners_of_war" class="mw-redirect" title="Prisoners of war">prisoners of war</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Among the last Wehrmacht soldiers to leave Stalingrad by air were a group of 18 wounded and sick Croat legionnaires, including Lt. Barićević, who were flown out by Luftwaffe pilots and were landed on the last serviceable German airfield at Staljingradskaja near the 369th's artillery section positions on the night of 22 to 23 January 1943. The regiment's war diary and other documents were also saved in this evacuation. The previous night, several Luftwaffe planes had crashed attempting to take off and land perilously close to fast-advancing Soviet forces, thus fewer planes flew in for rescue missions. During the day of 23 January Stalingradskaja airfield fell into Soviet hands.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Elements of the regiment fought as long as they could but ultimately surrendered to the Soviet General Vasiljev on 29 or 30 January 1943. In the three months between 21 October 1942 and 21 January 1943 they had lost 540 of 983 troops fighting for the Red October factory.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 31 January 1943 <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Paulus" title="Friedrich Paulus">General Paulus</a> announced the surrender of the German 6th Army. On 2 February the Legion became Soviet prisoners of war including all officers, approximately 100, mostly wounded, sick, and frostbitten combat soldiers, as well as some 600 other legionaries from artillery and support units. In the two weeks leading up to the capitulation the 369th Regiment had lost 175 soldiers.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Legion assembled at Beketovka on river Volga where they were joined by some 80,000 mainly German as well as Italian, Romanian and Hungarian POWs. They were sent on a forced march to Moscow where they were joined by Croatian legionnaires from the <a href="/wiki/Light_Transport_Brigade" class="mw-redirect" title="Light Transport Brigade">Light Transport Brigade</a> who had been attached to Italian forces on the Eastern Front.  From there, they were sent to <a href="/wiki/German_prisoners_of_war_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="German prisoners of war in the Soviet Union">work camps</a> in Siberia.  Many died on the march due to starvation, hypothermia or disease.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Regiment_veterans">Regiment veterans</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=369th_Croatian_Reinforced_Infantry_Regiment_(Wehrmacht)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Regiment veterans">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>More than 1000 legionnaires were evacuated from the Soviet Union and later Stalingrad by various means and for various reasons.  They were awarded the <i>Croatian Legion 1941 Linden Leaf</i> for their service and formed the core of a new unit, the <a href="/wiki/369th_(Croatian)_Infantry_Division_(Wehrmacht)" title="369th (Croatian) Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)">369th (Croatian) Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Stamp_Croatian_Legion.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Stamp_Croatian_Legion.jpg/220px-Stamp_Croatian_Legion.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="173" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Stamp_Croatian_Legion.jpg/330px-Stamp_Croatian_Legion.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Stamp_Croatian_Legion.jpg/440px-Stamp_Croatian_Legion.jpg 2x" data-file-width="467" data-file-height="368" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Stamp_Croatian_Legion.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>NDH Stamp issued for 369th Regiment</div></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Aftermath">Aftermath</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=369th_Croatian_Reinforced_Infantry_Regiment_(Wehrmacht)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Aftermath">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/German_prisoners_of_war_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="German prisoners of war in the Soviet Union">German prisoners of war in the Soviet Union</a></div>
<p>In late October 1944, the Yugoslav Legion numbering about 3,000 operated as part of the Red Army around <a href="/wiki/%C4%8Ca%C4%8Dak" title="Čačak">Čačak</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Belgrade_Offensive" title="Belgrade Offensive">Belgrade Offensive</a>. This unit was formed in early 1944 partly from former members of the 369th (Croatian) Reinforced Infantry Regiment, and was commanded by the former Ustaše Lieutenant Colonel Marko Mesić assisted by Captain Milutin Perišić, a Serb. Both officers were praised by Soviet general <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Biryuzov" title="Sergey Biryuzov">Sergey Biryuzov</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Tomasevich395_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tomasevich395-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Summer of 1943 one hundred legionaries and 6 officers including Marko Mesic were transferred to Suzdalj and later to Krasnogorsk near Moscow, where they met with most of the surviving Croat soldiers. At Krasnogorsk, the Soviets formed a new unit that utilized Royal Yugoslav uniforms (At the time, Soviets did not recognize Tito's forces as a sovereign state). During early Soviet imprisonment, Col. Mesić may have been forced to appear in Soviet propaganda wearing a Royal Yugoslav Army uniform and Tito's flag to save the lives of his remaining men. Upon news of this, the Ministry of the Armed Forces removed him from the Croatian Armed Forces and rescinded his awards.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>Col. Mesić was given command by the Soviets of this newly formed <a href="/w/index.php?title=First_Yugoslav_Volunteer_Brigade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="First Yugoslav Volunteer Brigade (page does not exist)">First Yugoslav Volunteer Brigade</a>, assembled from prisoners of war of Yugoslavian origin as well as volunteers living in Russia at the time. It is quite likely that most former Croatian soldiers of the 369. Regiment chose Communist Partisan service to avoid almost certain death in Soviet prisoner-of-war camps. During the first few months in captivity, Legionnaire numbers were reduced from some 700 to around 400 odd survivors or a 40% loss of life in under twelve months. The new Yugoslav partisan brigade, now wearing old Royal Yugoslav Army uniforms, was commanded by experienced former 369th Regiment Croat Legion officers like Lt.Col. Egon Zitnik, the former commander of the Light Transport Unit; Major Marijan Prislin, the former second in command of the 369. Regiment's artillery section; and Major Marijan Tulicic, the former artillery unit commander. New unit military training was very fast as most men were experienced soldiers.   As late as March 1944 they were joined by 200 more former 369th legionaries led by former 369th Stalingrad Doctor Bogoljub Modrijan as well as Lt. Vlahov, Lt. Tahtamišimov, Lt.Draženović and Lt. Ivan Vadlja, who was wounded at Stalingrad but missed the last flight out. They were transported to Yugoslavia in late 1944 under direct orders from Tito, where they were sacrificed in combat against superior German forces, suffering very high casualties. The few remaining survivors were suspected and most were later convicted of being Soviet infiltrators by the partisans as well as Croat NDH authorities.<sup id="cite_ref-Pojić,_Milan_2007_8-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pojić,_Milan_2007-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Commanders">Commanders</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=369th_Croatian_Reinforced_Infantry_Regiment_(Wehrmacht)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Commanders">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>Colonel <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ivan_Markulj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ivan Markulj (page does not exist)">Ivan Markulj</a></li>
<li>Lieutenant-Colonel <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Babi%C4%87_(soldier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ivan Babić (soldier)">Ivan Babić</a></li>
<li>Colonel <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Pavi%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Viktor Pavičić">Viktor Pavičić</a></li>
<li>Lieutenant-Colonel <a href="/wiki/Marko_Mesi%C4%87_(1901%E2%80%931982)" class="mw-redirect" title="Marko Mesić (1901–1982)">Marko Mesić</a></li></ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=369th_Croatian_Reinforced_Infantry_Regiment_(Wehrmacht)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.naklada-ljevak.hr/knjiga/show/id/2079">Milan Pojić Hrvatska pukovnija 369. na Istočnom bojištu 1941. - 1943.</a></li>
<li>Welz H. Verratene Grenadiere. — Berlin, Deutscher Militärverlag, 1965</li></ul>

scope="row">Preceded by</th><td><a href="/wiki/Sindoorkhela" title="Sindoorkhela">Sindoorkhela</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Followed by</th><td><a href="/wiki/Thik_Jeno_Love_Story" title="Thik links</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="url" style="text-align:center"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.hotstar.com/#!/star-jalsha-817">Website</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Aanchol</b> was a Bengali television serial which used to air on GEC <a href="/wiki/Star_Jalsha" title="Star Jalsha">Star Jalsha</a> every Monday to Saturday's at 9pm. The series portrayed the life story two sisters Tushu and Bhaadu who sets on a journey to take revenge from the people who ruined their family.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cast">Cast</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Aanchol&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Cast">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sriparna_Roy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sriparna Roy (page does not exist)">Sriparna Roy</a> as Tushu Roy / Adrija</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Moumita_Gupta" title="Moumita Gupta">Moumita Gupta</a> / <a href="/w/index.php?title=Swagata_Mukherjee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Swagata Mukherjee (page does not exist)">Swagata Mukherjee</a> as Aditi Roy</li>

<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Maffin_Chakraborty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maffin Chakraborty (page does not exist)">Maffin Chakraborty</a> as Ketoki Talukdar (KT)</li>

~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">July 2019</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">In this <a href="/wiki/Philippine_name" class="mw-redirect" title="Philippine name">Philippine name</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Middle_name" title="Middle name">middle name</a> or maternal &#32;<a href="/wiki/Surname" title="Surname">family name</a> is <i>Mirando</i>&#32;and the surname or paternal family name is <i>Abante</i>.</div>

<p><b>Bienvenido</b> "<b>Benny</b>" <b>Mirando Abante Jr.</b> (born May 15, 1951) is a Filipino politician and pastor serving as the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Representatives_of_the_Philippines" title="House of Representatives of the Philippines">Representative</a> of <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Legislative_districts_of_Manila" title="Legislative districts of Manila">6th district</a> since 2019, a position he previously held from 2004 to 2010. He was the <a href="/wiki/Minority_Floor_Leader_of_the_House_of_Representatives_of_the_Philippines" title="Minority Floor Leader of the House of Representatives of the Philippines">House Minority Leader</a> from 2019 to October 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> He is also the host pastor of the Metropolitan Bible Baptist Church and Ministries in <a href="/wiki/Santa_Ana,_Manila" title="Santa Ana, Manila">Santa Ana, Manila</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_and_education">Early life and education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Benny_Abante&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life and education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Abante was born in the outskirts of <a href="/wiki/Sampaloc,_Manila" title="Sampaloc, Manila">Sampaloc, Manila</a> on May 15, 1951, the eldest of four sons of the Rev. Ben O. Abante Sr. and Priscilla Mirando. He has two younger brothers, Jose Hernes and Reuben, who both grew up to be ministers.
</p><p>He grew up taking on odd jobs such as shining shoes, selling newspapers and corsages and working on a construction site at a young age to support himself. He also worked in an accounting firm as an auditor to support his college education. In 1975, he started the Metropolitan Bible Baptist Church and Ministries in <a href="/wiki/Santa_Ana,_Manila" title="Santa Ana, Manila">Santa Ana</a>, Manila. He graduated with a degree in theology, and also holds a master's degree in Government Management from the <a href="/wiki/Pamantasan_ng_Lungsod_ng_Maynila" class="mw-redirect" title="Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila">Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila</a>. 
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Benny_Abante&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In 1986, he founded the Bible Believers League for Morality and Democracy (BIBLEMODE),<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> and also heads the Abante International Ministries (AIM), the Grace and Truth Community International Foundation, Inc., and the Ben O. Abante Baptist Bible College.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Congress">Congress</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Benny_Abante&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Congress">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>He ran and won a seat in Congress in May 2004. He was subsequently named chairman of the Committee on Public Information. His major undertakings in his district focused on health, education, social services and infrastructure development and/or improvement. Abante's committee also scrutinized the <a href="/wiki/Right_of_reply" title="Right of reply">Right of Reply</a> Bill that was criticized by the media organizations as a curtailment to the freedom of the press.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> He also proposed an Anti-Sex Video Bill that imposes stiffer penalties of the people involved in the manufacture of sex videos.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> He was one of the principal authors of the Freedom of Information (FOI) Bill during the <a href="/wiki/14th_Congress_of_the_Philippines" title="14th Congress of the Philippines">14th Congress</a>. The FOI bill was defeated in Congress after its opponents questioned if there was a <a href="/wiki/Quorum" title="Quorum">quorum</a> on the final session day.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> Abante unsuccessfully defended his seat in the <a href="/wiki/2010_Manila_local_elections" title="2010 Manila local elections">2010 election</a>, losing to former representative Rosenda Ann "Sandy" Ocampo. He attempted a comeback to the Congress in <a href="/wiki/2013_Manila_local_elections" title="2013 Manila local elections">2013</a> and <a href="/wiki/2016_Manila_local_elections" title="2016 Manila local elections">2016</a> but was unsuccessful, losing both to Ocampo. Abante was elected as Representative of Manila's 6th District in <a href="/wiki/2019_Manila_local_elections" title="2019 Manila local elections">2019</a> with the previous incumbent Ocampo ineligible for reelection. He ran against Councilor Cassy Sison and newcomer Yvette Ocampo, Sandy's sister. He ran under the banner of Asenso Manileño with <a href="/wiki/Isko_Moreno" title="Isko Moreno">Isko Moreno</a> running for Mayor.
</p>

Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2011-12-15</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Manila+Bulletin&amp;rft.atitle=Bill+vs+sex+videos+pushed&amp;rft.date=2009-06-13&amp;rft.aulast=Mabutas&amp;rft.aufirst=Gabriel&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mb.com.ph%2Farticles%2F206838%2Fbill-vs-sex-videos-pushed&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABenny+Abante" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/><sup class="noprint Inline-Template"><span style="white-space: nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Link_rot" title="Wikipedia:Link rot"><span title="&#160;Dead link since July 2017">permanent dead link</span></a></i>&#93;</span></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFMangahas2010" class="citation news cs1">Mangahas, Malou (2010-06-07). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/192814/news/nation/secrets-of-nograles-house-could-be-exposed-by-foi">"Secrets of Nograles House could be exposed by FOI"</a>. <i>GMA News Online</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Benny_Abante&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100326043515/http://www.mbbcintl.com/bma.html">https://web.archive.org/web/20100326043515/http://www.mbbcintl.com/bma.html</a></li></ul>

</div></td><td class="noviewer navbox-image" rowspan="5" style="width:1px;padding:0px 0px 0px 2px"><div><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Ph_seal_ncr_manila.svg/100px-Ph_seal_ncr_manila.svg.png" decoding="async" width="100" height="100" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Ph_seal_ncr_manila.svg/150px-Ph_seal_ncr_manila.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Ph_seal_ncr_manila.svg/200px-Ph_seal_ncr_manila.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="490" data-file-height="490" /></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Government</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">July 2020</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Independent early learning, primary and secondary day and boarding school in Australia</div><table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" class="fn org" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;background-color: lavender">Abbotsleigh</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Abbotsleighghs2.png" class="image"><img alt="Abbotsleighghs2.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/1/12/Abbotsleighghs2.png" decoding="async" width="170" height="139" data-file-width="170" data-file-height="139" /></a></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:lavender">Location</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a class="mw-kartographer-map mw-kartographer-container center" style="width: 270px; 151.11306</span></span></span></a></span></span></span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:lavender">Information</th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Type</th><td>Independent <a href="/wiki/Pre-school_education" class="mw-redirect" title="Pre-school education">early learning</a>, primary and secondary <a href="/wiki/Day_school" title="Day school">day</a> and <a href="/wiki/Boarding_school" title="Boarding school">boarding</a> school</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Motto</th><td><a href="/wiki/Latin_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin language">Latin</a>: <i lang="la">Tempus Celerius Radio Fugit</i><br />(Time Flies Faster than a Weaver's Shuttle)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Denomination</th><td><a href="/wiki/Anglican_Church_of_Australia" title="Anglican Church of Australia">Anglican</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Established</th><td>20&#160;July 1885<span class="noprint">&#59;&#32;135&#160;years ago</span><span style="display:none">&#160;(<span class="bday dtstart published updated">1885-07-20</span>)</span></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Headmistress</th><td>Megan Krimmer</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Employees</th><td>~265<sup id="cite_ref-Annualreport_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Annualreport-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Years</th><td><a href="/wiki/Pre-school_education" class="mw-redirect" title="Pre-school education">Early learning</a>; height: 200px;" data-mw="interface" data-style="osm-intl" data-width="270" data-height="200" data-zoom="13" data-overlays="[&quot;_37a481bb1a4531e40c02d030ce67a737023eb89e&quot;]" href="/wiki/Special:Map/13/a/a/en"><img src="https://maps.wikimedia.org/img/osm-intl,13,a,a,270x200.png?lang=en&amp;domain=en.wikipedia.org&amp;title=Abbotsleigh&amp;groups=_37a481bb1a4531e40c02d030ce67a737023eb89e" alt="" width="270" height="200" decoding="async" srcset="https://maps.wikimedia.org/img/osm-intl,13,a,a,270x200@2x.png?lang=en&amp;domain=en.wikipedia.org&amp;title=Abbotsleigh&amp;groups=_37a481bb1a4531e40c02d030ce67a737023eb89e 2x" /></a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Abbotsleigh</b> is an independent <a href="/wiki/Anglican" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglican">Anglican</a> <a href="/wiki/Pre-school_education" class="mw-redirect" title="Pre-school education">early learning</a>, primary and secondary <a href="/wiki/Day_school" title="Day school">day</a> and <a href="/wiki/Boarding_school" title="Boarding school">boarding</a> school for <a href="/wiki/Single-sex_school" class="mw-redirect" title="Single-sex school">girls</a>, located in <a href="/wiki/Wahroonga,_New_South_Wales" title="Wahroonga, New South Wales">Wahroonga</a>, on the <a href="/wiki/Upper_North_Shore_(Sydney)" class="mw-redirect" title="Upper North Shore (Sydney)">Upper North Shore</a> of Sydney, New South Wales, Australia.
</p><p>Established in 1885 on Sydney's lower north shore, the school has a selective enrolment policy from <a href="/wiki/Year_5" class="mw-redirect" title="Year 5">Year 5</a> upwards and currently caters for approximately 1,400 students from Transition to <a href="/wiki/Year_12" class="mw-redirect" title="Year 12">Year 12</a>, including 170 boarders from <a href="/wiki/Year_7" class="mw-redirect" title="Year 7">Years 7</a> to 12.<sup id="cite_ref-Annualreport_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Annualreport-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Abbotsleigh is a member of the <a href="/wiki/Alliance_of_Girls%27_Schools_Australasia" title="Alliance of Girls&#39; Schools Australasia">Alliance of Girls' Schools Australasia</a> (AGSA),<sup id="cite_ref-AGSA_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AGSA-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Junior_School_Heads_Association_of_Australia" class="mw-redirect" title="Junior School Heads Association of Australia">Junior School Heads Association of Australia</a> (JSHAA),<sup id="cite_ref-jshaa_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jshaa-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> the Association of Heads of Independent Schools of Australia (AHISA),<sup id="cite_ref-AHISA_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AHISA-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> the Australian Boarding Schools' Association (ABSA),<sup id="cite_ref-ABSA_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABSA-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> and a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Heads_of_Independent_Girls%27_Schools" title="Association of Heads of Independent Girls&#39; Schools">Association of Heads of Independent Girls' Schools</a> (AHIGS).<sup id="cite_ref-AHIGS_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AHIGS-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Abbotsleigh was ranked the top independent school in the state based on academic performance in 2013–2015.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Abbotsleigh was founded by Marian Clarke in 1885 in a small <a href="/wiki/Terrace_house" class="mw-redirect" title="Terrace house">terrace house</a> in <a href="/wiki/North_Sydney,_New_South_Wales" title="North Sydney, New South Wales">North Sydney</a>. The school then moved to <a href="/wiki/Parramatta,_New_South_Wales" class="mw-redirect" title="Parramatta, New South Wales">Parramatta</a>; first to Honiton House, then to more spacious premises at the corner of Church and Marsden streets, a site now covered by a car park. The school proved successful in Parramatta, but in 1895 Miss Clarke left 80 pupils behind to set out for a year in England to visit her family. The school declined during her absence, and on her return only a small number of boarders remained.<sup id="cite_ref-History_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-History-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Abbotsleigh's final move was to its current location at Wahroonga in 1898, where Miss Clarke purchased land and built a new school. It is here that Abbotsleigh became the first girls' school in Sydney to have a sports field. Significant buildings that developed over the years include the Marian Clarke building facing the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Highway_(Australia)" title="Pacific Highway (Australia)">Pacific Highway</a>, Vindin House, Lynton House and Poole House on the junior campus. The last three are listed on the local government heritage register.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Miss Clarke was determined to found Abbotsleigh as an academic school for girls with a full curriculum and strict order of discipline- in other words, a proper school, not a finishing school for ladies (as was typical of the era). The school offered physics and classical subjects such as Latin, classes which were only offered to boys at the time.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Headmistresses">Headmistresses</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Headmistresses">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The following individuals have served as the Headmistress:
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Structure">Structure</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Structure">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Abbotsleigh has a total enrolment of approximately 1,400 girls across Years K–12. In 2016, the Senior School campus had an enrolment of approximately 900 girls in Years 7–12. The main high school is divided into the Middle School (Year Seven and Eight), Senior College Archdale (Year Nine and Ten), and Senior College (Year Eleven and Twelve).
</p><p>Each house group within a year has a tutor, and every year is managed by a year coordinator, and overseen by the Dean of Middle School or Deans of Senior College.
</p><p>There is also a nearby Junior School, also located in Wahroonga, which houses the Early Learning Centre, Transition and Kindergarten to Year Six. Each year, approximately two-thirds of the incoming Year Seven class at Senior School are from the Junior School, while the rest are drawn from schools in Sydney, from interstate and overseas, having passed selective entry examinations and/or interviews to gain an enrolment place.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The school council is responsible for the school's governance. <a href="/wiki/Glenn_Davies" title="Glenn Davies">Glenn N Davies</a>, Archbishop of Sydney, serves as its chair.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Campus">Campus</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Campus">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Abbotsleigh_Wahroonga_Simon_Fieldhouse.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Abbotsleigh_Wahroonga_Simon_Fieldhouse.jpg/220px-Abbotsleigh_Wahroonga_Simon_Fieldhouse.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="118" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Abbotsleigh_Wahroonga_Simon_Fieldhouse.jpg/330px-Abbotsleigh_Wahroonga_Simon_Fieldhouse.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Abbotsleigh_Wahroonga_Simon_Fieldhouse.jpg/440px-Abbotsleigh_Wahroonga_Simon_Fieldhouse.jpg 2x" data-file-width="721" data-file-height="386" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Abbotsleigh_Wahroonga_Simon_Fieldhouse.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Marian Clarke Building, Abbotsleigh (Elevation)</div></div></div>
<p>The senior and junior campuses cater for 1400 students in total from Transition to Year 12 (<a href="/wiki/Higher_School_Certificate_(New_South_Wales)" title="Higher School Certificate (New South Wales)">Higher School Certificate</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Annualreport_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Annualreport-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Junior Campus is located in Woonona Ave, Wahroonga. Poole House is the oldest building on the campus and features an after-school care and music centre with a number of music rooms for individual lessons and practice. The library, school hall and administration centre are housed in the same block as the junior years' classrooms. In 2002 a new Years 4–6 centre was built surrounding a grassy courtyard featuring an arts facility and a canteen. Sporting facilities include a large oval, outdoor pool, three tennis courts, 2 courtyards, two sets of play equipment and a human-sized chess board. An underground parking facility was built in 2007 with the kindergarten classrooms built above. 
The new Early Learning Centre was completed in January 2010. It includes new Infants precinct and an Early Learning Centre for the youngest learners from birth to five years old. It is a seventy-place, coeducational centre providing long day care. Girls of the age of 5 are now able to enter the school in the Transition class (preschool age) where they are able to make the smooth transition from preschool to kindergarten. The ELC is run according to the Reggio Emillia principles.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:(1)Marian_Clarke_Building.jpg" class="image"><img alt="(1)Marian Clarke Building.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/%281%29Marian_Clarke_Building.jpg/220px-%281%29Marian_Clarke_Building.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/%281%29Marian_Clarke_Building.jpg/330px-%281%29Marian_Clarke_Building.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/%281%29Marian_Clarke_Building.jpg/440px-%281%29Marian_Clarke_Building.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2225" data-file-height="1481" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:(1)Marian_Clarke_Building.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>The Senior Campus is at a separate site on the Pacific Highway, and incorporates a number of facilities including a 350-seat auditorium, large assembly hall, Senior Studies Centre, Aquatic Centre and two gymnasiums. Other sporting facilities include 11 tennis courts, three indoor gymnasiums, two weights gyms, 2 cricket nets, a 25-metre indoor pool and two large ovals used for hockey, touch football and soccer, with one multi-purpose synthetic turf oval and spectator stands. A new library named the Abbotsleigh Research Centre (ARC) was built and officially opened on 2 April 2006. The ARC contains the Library Teaching Room (LTR) – a computer room, study and teaching spaces, an archives centre and three seminar rooms. There are over 40,000 books, over 4,000 videos and DVDs and approximately 70 Periodical titles. The ARC has won awards for its unique interior design.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> The ARC includes a new Art Centre which has three classrooms, an Arts staffroom and a number of storage spaces. A large outdoor area incorporated into the design, with 6 tables for students and sails, is often used for a number of school events overlooking the top oval. Vindin House was converted into the Grace Cossington Smith Gallery (named after Old Girl <a href="/wiki/Grace_Cossington_Smith" title="Grace Cossington Smith">Grace Cossington Smith</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> with art rooms and gallery exhibitions open to both students and the general public.
In addition to this, a new canteen was built in 2008 to join with the Saturday morning sport canteen, featuring new outdoor café-style eating areas overlooking the oval. The Judith Poole Sports Hall was built in 2015, accommodating three basketball courts or twelve badminton courts, dance studios, change facilities, offices, classrooms and an underground carpark, an award-winning design at the 2018 World Architecture Awards.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Motto_and_crest">Motto and crest</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Motto and crest">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The Abbotsleigh <a href="/wiki/Motto" title="Motto">motto</a>, <i>Tempus celerius radio fugit</i>, may be translated from <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> as "Time flies faster than the weaver's shuttle". As the <a href="/wiki/Shuttle_(weaving)" title="Shuttle (weaving)">shuttle</a> flies a pattern is woven; the shuttle of time also weaves a pattern of which the threads are people, buildings and events. The motto was given to the school by Miss Marian Clarke, whose family <a href="/wiki/Crest_(heraldry)" title="Crest (heraldry)">crest</a> was a weaver's shuttle surrounded by the motto, <i><a href="/wiki/Tempus_fugit" title="Tempus fugit">Tempus fugit</a> radio celerit</i>. The school used this form until 1924, when it decided that the ungrammatical Latin should be changed to the present word order, which has been used ever since.
</p><p>The reference to the weaver's shuttle is also believed by many to be a reference to the "proper" place of women in terms of domestic duties/servitude to men. Some members of the school community have called for the motto to be changed to keep pace with modern views on feminine rights.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>The 1934 edition of <i>The Weaver</i> explains the <a href="/wiki/Symbol" title="Symbol">symbolism</a> of the school crest: "the lion for the strength in God, lillies for purity and <a href="/wiki/Jesus_fish" class="mw-redirect" title="Jesus fish">fish</a> as the symbol of Christianity through <a href="/wiki/Baptism" title="Baptism">baptism</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-Identity_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Identity-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Associated_schools">Associated schools</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Associated schools">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Abbotsleigh has a number of international <a href="/wiki/Sister_schools" class="mw-redirect" title="Sister schools">sister schools</a> and exchange agreements with other institutes, including the École Alsacienne in Paris, France, Ohtani High School, Japan, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing_Yucai_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beijing Yucai School (page does not exist)">Beijing Yucai School</a>, China, Annette-von-Droste-Hülshoff-Gymnasium in <a href="/wiki/M%C3%BCnster" title="Münster">Münster</a>, Germany, Miami's <a href="/wiki/Palmer_Trinity_School" title="Palmer Trinity School">Palmer Trinity School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moreton_Hall_School" title="Moreton Hall School">Moreton Hall</a> in Oswestry, England, <a href="/wiki/Queenswood_School" title="Queenswood School">Queenswood School</a> in Hertfordshire, England, and <a href="/wiki/Ridley_College" title="Ridley College">Ridley College</a> in Ontario, Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> Girls have the opportunity to host an incoming exchange student or, in Years 9 and 10, to attend one or more of these schools on exchange for a period of one or two terms.
</p><p>Abbotsleigh is also unofficially associated as the sister school to <a href="/wiki/The_King%27s_School,_Parramatta" title="The King&#39;s School, Parramatta">The King's School</a>, an independent Anglican day and boarding school for boys in North Parramatta, and <a href="/wiki/Sydney_Church_of_England_Grammar_School" title="Sydney Church of England Grammar School">Sydney Church of England Grammar School</a>, an independent Anglican day and boarding school for boys in North Sydney.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Curriculum">Curriculum</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Curriculum">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Abbotsleigh offers an extensive range of subjects. The academic departments are:
</p>
<ul><li>Christian studies</li>
<li>Drama</li>
<li>English</li>
<li>History (Australian, Ancient and Modern)</li>
<li>Languages</li>
<li>Mathematics</li>
<li>Music</li>
<li>PDHPE</li>
<li>Science</li>
<li>Social sciences (Economics, Geography, Business Studies)</li>
<li>Technology and applied sciences (also known as Design and Technology)</li>
<li>Visual arts</li></ul>
<p>Abbotsleigh provides a focused academic education, with Maths, Science and English being graded by class from years 7–10. Other subjects, such as languages and music, also place students in streamed classes. In Year 8, students choose elective subjects to study for Years 9 and 10. Students must study Maths, English, Science, <a href="/wiki/PDHPE" class="mw-redirect" title="PDHPE">PDHPE</a>, Australian History/Geography, and Christian Studies. They may then choose three elective subjects from: Commerce, Elective History, Elective Geography, Design and Technology, Information Software Technology, Music, Drama, Visual Arts, Photography and Digital Media, Chinese Mandarin, French, German, and Latin.
</p><p>In the Upper School, students have an even wider range of subjects to choose from, which follow the Board of Studies HSC syllabus. Subjects offered include English (Advanced, Extension 1 and Extension 2), Mathematics (General, 2-unit, Extension 1 and Extension 2), sciences (Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Earth and Environmental Science), histories (Modern, Ancient and Extension History), social sciences (Business Studies, Geography, Economics), Music (1, 2, extension), Theology and Studies of Religion(1 and 2 unit) a wide range of languages including French, German, <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> and Japanese, Art, <a href="/wiki/PDHPE" class="mw-redirect" title="PDHPE">PDHPE</a>, Software Design and Development, Drama, Design and Technology.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Co-curriculum">Co-curriculum</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Co-curriculum">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Students can participate in a number of extracurricular activities. Most girls participate in at least one activity, if not many. Abbotsleigh has a significant number of students achieve the Gold Duke of Edinburgh Award each year, which is presented at the school's Speech Day in December. Additionally students may participate in chess teams, debating, mock trial, public speaking, ski team, jewellery making, ceramics, sewing classes, film club, SRC, Environment Club, and over seven different charity and service groups such as World Vision and Amnesty International clubs. Students from Year 10 are selected to form the charity and service group boards with students taking the positions of president, secretary, treasurer and committee member. The school also has an Agricultural group (Ag Club) for the boarders where two cattle are raised between January and April for a number of competitions including the Sydney Royal Easter Show.
</p><p>There is also a dance program of considerable size at the school, with over 500 girls from Kindergarten to Year 11 participating in several types of dance such as street, <a href="/wiki/Tap_dance" title="Tap dance">tap</a> and contemporary.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Sport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The school participates in <a href="/wiki/Independent_Girls%27_Schools_Sporting_Association" title="Independent Girls&#39; Schools Sporting Association">Independent Girls' Schools Sporting Association</a> (IGSSA) sports including, <a href="/wiki/Softball" title="Softball">softball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>, swimming, <a href="/wiki/Diving_(sport)" title="Diving (sport)">diving</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>, soccer, <a href="/wiki/Sport_of_athletics" title="Sport of athletics">athletics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cross_country_running" title="Cross country running">cross country</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hockey" title="Hockey">hockey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Netball" title="Netball">netball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Waterpolo" class="mw-redirect" title="Waterpolo">water polo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Touch_football_(rugby_league)" class="mw-redirect" title="Touch football (rugby league)">touch football</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">cricket</a>, achieving remarkable results.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup> Other offered sports include equestrian, golf, sailing, snow sports and rhythmic and artistic gymnastics. Abbotsleigh employs an extensive sports staff department and provides sports coaches and much of the sport equipment including hockey kits, golf sets etc. It is compulsory for Abbotsleigh girls to take part in PE once a week to enhance their physical activity until Year 11.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Music">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Abbotsleigh boasts a rich co‑curricular music program. Its varied instrumental ensembles include Orchestra, Symphonic Winds, Jazz Ensemble, Senior Strings, String Ensemble and <a href="/wiki/Concert_Band" class="mw-redirect" title="Concert Band">Concert Band</a>. Chamber groups such as <a href="/wiki/String_Quartets" class="mw-redirect" title="String Quartets">String Quartets</a>, Flute Ensemble, Brass Ensemble, Guitar Ensemble and Clarinet and Saxophone Ensemble are also available to girls without an audition. Girls are invited to participate in <a href="/wiki/Choir" title="Choir">Choir</a>, and may audition for smaller vocal groups such as Vocal Ensemble and Chamber Choir. Girls can also be involved in the Gospel Choir, which performs at various Chapel services throughout the year. These ensembles participate in multiple school-based events throughout the year, as well as eisteddfods and music festivals. There are also opportunities to participate in interstate and international music tours, musicals and gala concerts.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Abbotsleigh also offers an Extended Tuition music program from Kindergarten to Year 12, where girls have the opportunity to learn an instrument (piano, singing, woodwind, <a href="/wiki/Brass" title="Brass">brass</a>, strings or percussion instruments) from one of their Peripatetic instrumental teachers. Girls who are involved in this program are also encouraged to participate in their co‑curricular ensembles.
</p><p>Additionally, Abbotsleigh's Junior School offers a Year 2 String Program, where girls are required to learn either violin or cello. Girls in Year 3 participate in the Year 3 Instrumental Program, where they are introduced to a band instrument, such as flute, <a href="/wiki/Clarinet" title="Clarinet">clarinet</a> or trumpet. Girls then have the option of continuing these studies in the Extended Tuition music program and Junior School co‑curricular ensembles.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Performing_arts">Performing arts</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Performing arts">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Abbotsleigh caters for a range of creative talents and provides an extensive performing arts program. In addition to drama classes (compulsory in Middle School), it is offered as a subject in Senior College years and the HSC. Student-directed productions, Middle and Senior School plays, an annual "Shakespeare festival", theatre sports and school musicals are just a few of a plethora of performing arts events in the school calendar.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> Musicals and plays are often produced and performed in collaboration with neighbouring boys' school <a href="/wiki/Knox_Grammar_School" title="Knox Grammar School">Knox Grammar.</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Debating_and_public_speaking">Debating and public speaking</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Debating and public speaking">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Abbotsleigh has a fine tradition of debating and public speaking and has established a reputation for outstanding results in competitive debating. The school participates in several major competitions, including the Independent Schools Debating Association (ISDA), consisting of 32 private schools, the Archdale Debating Competition established in honour of former headmistress Miss Betty Archdale, also involving over 20 schools and the Sydney Debating Network (SDN). Abbotsleigh has consistently achieved championship results in these competitions, fostered due to extensive coaching and development squad programs.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> Girls also often debate at representative level in <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Heads_of_Independent_Girls%27_Schools" title="Association of Heads of Independent Girls&#39; Schools">AHIGS</a> and NSW state squads.
</p><p>Abbotsleigh also participates in several public speaking competitions including Rostrum Voice of Youth, <a href="/wiki/Legacy_Australia" title="Legacy Australia">Legacy Public Speaking</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Sydney_Morning_Herald" title="The Sydney Morning Herald">SMH Plain English Speaking Award</a> and <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Heads_of_Independent_Girls%27_Schools" title="Association of Heads of Independent Girls&#39; Schools">AHIGS</a> Festival of Speech.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Service_programs">Service programs</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Service programs">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Abbotsleigh nurtures responsible citizenship through its Service-Learning program and leadership opportunities. A number of student-run charity clubs exist within the school, with elected positions such as president, treasurer and secretary. These include <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fairtrade_Canada" title="Fairtrade Canada">Fairtrade</a>, Interact Club (in collaboration with <a href="/wiki/Rotary_International" title="Rotary International">Rotary</a>), <a href="/wiki/Oaktree_(foundation)" title="Oaktree (foundation)">Oaktree</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Vision_International" title="World Vision International">World Vision</a> and Zonta Club (supporting the Hornsby Ku-ring-gai branch of <a href="/wiki/Zonta_International" title="Zonta International">Zonta International</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>All Year Nine girls undertake the <a href="/wiki/The_Duke_of_Edinburgh%27s_Award" title="The Duke of Edinburgh&#39;s Award">Duke of Edinburgh International Award</a>, with many achieving the Gold Level in senior years.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> In Year Ten, all girls are required to participate in a week of service learning, ALE (Abbotsleigh Learning Experience). Such experiences include assisting in house construction in Fiji, undertaking environmental conservation projects on Fraser Island, visiting remote indigenous communities in far North Queensland and volunteering at local non-government organisations such as the <a href="/wiki/International_Red_Cross_and_Red_Crescent_Movement" title="International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement">Red Cross</a>. In Senior College years, a committee-run Breakfast Club organises termly breakfast functions with a guest speaker. Nearby schools are invited and students participate in discussion and discourse regarding a wide range of social issues, such as freedom of speech, women in medicine careers and mental health and well-being.
</p><p>Furthermore, a Service Prefect is a member of the executive student leadership, running a Service Council composed of girls selected across year groups and chooses a whole school service theme and project. Abbotsleigh girls can participate in overseas service trips such as visiting St Andrew's School in Hyderabad, India, and the <a href="/wiki/Crossroads_Foundation" title="Crossroads Foundation">Crossroads Foundation</a> in Hong Kong.
</p>
