<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="House_system">House system</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: House system">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/House_system" title="House system">house system</a> was introduced by Miss Everett. The <i>Weaver</i> for May 1931 explains: "Points are awarded for work, conduct and sport and a shield will be presented annually to the winning House". "The "Malloch Shield", given the following year by A Malloch, was won for the first time by Sturt.
</p><p>In the junior school there are five houses:
</p>
<ul><li>Blaxland (blue), named after <a href="/wiki/Gregory_Blaxland" title="Gregory Blaxland">Gregory Blaxland</a> (1778–1853), an Australian explorer and pioneer farmer.</li>
<li>Lawson (green), named after <a href="/wiki/William_Lawson_(explorer)" title="William Lawson (explorer)">William Lawson</a> (1774–1850), an Australian explorer.</li>
<li>Macquarie (red), named after <a href="/wiki/Lachlan_Macquarie" title="Lachlan Macquarie">Lachlan Macquarie</a> (1771–1824), the Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821.</li>
<li>Sturt (yellow), named after <a href="/wiki/Charles_Sturt" title="Charles Sturt">Charles Sturt</a> (1795–1869), an Australian explorer.</li>
<li>Wentworth (purple), named after <a href="/wiki/William_Wentworth" title="William Wentworth">William Wentworth</a> (1790–1872), an Australian explorer, statesman and lawyer.</li></ul>
<p>In the senior school there are eight houses:
</p>
<ul><li>Chisholm (dark blue), named after <a href="/wiki/Caroline_Chisholm" title="Caroline Chisholm">Caroline Chisholm</a> (1808–1877), an Australian pioneer.</li>
<li>Franklin (green), named after <a href="/wiki/Miles_Franklin" title="Miles Franklin">Miles Franklin</a>, an acclaimed Australian author.</li>
<li>Gilmore (brown until 1982, now pink), named after <a href="/wiki/Mary_Gilmore" title="Mary Gilmore">Mary Gilmore</a> (1865–1962), an Australian poet and writer.</li>
<li>Melba (light blue), named after Dame <a href="/wiki/Nellie_Melba" title="Nellie Melba">Nellie Melba</a> (1861–1931), an Australian opera singer.</li>
<li>Prichard (black until 1990, now purple), named after <a href="/wiki/Katharine_Susannah_Prichard" title="Katharine Susannah Prichard">Katharine Susannah Prichard</a> (1884–1969), an Australian writer.</li>
<li>Richardson (orange), named after <a href="/wiki/Ethel_Florence_Lindesay_Richardson" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethel Florence Lindesay Richardson">Ethel Florence Lindesay Richardson</a> (1870–1946), an Australian novelist.</li>
<li>Tennant (yellow), named after <a href="/wiki/Kylie_Tennant" title="Kylie Tennant">Kylie Tennant</a> (1912–1988), an Australian World War II and <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a> novelist.</li>
<li>Wright (red), named after <a href="/wiki/Judith_Wright" title="Judith Wright">Judith Wright</a> (1915–2000), an Australian poet.</li></ul>
<p>The house system has been modified over time to reflect the changing needs of the school, and its increased enrolment. One of the most significant changes occurred in the late 1960s under then Headmistress <a href="/wiki/Betty_Archdale" title="Betty Archdale">Betty Archdale</a>. Senior school houses had previously been named after well-known male Australian poets, and Archdale introduced new house names recognising accomplished Australian women. This was the basis for the senior school houses in use today. Houses now compete for the House Choir banner and the Spirit Cup, as well as the Sports Cup.
Since 2008 girls have organised get-to-know-each-other events and House Days where students of the same house assemble at lunch time and have a large "house picnic".
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Boarding">Boarding</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Boarding">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Abbotsleigh has offered boarding since its establishment, and currently caters for boarding students from the greater metropolitan area, rural New South Wales and overseas. The school currently has five boarding houses:
</p>
<ul><li>Hirst, opened in 1980 and 1985. Catering for Year 12 boarders. Now replaced by the newly opened Wheeldon House.</li>
<li>Lynton, opened in 1969. Catering for Year 7 boarders.</li>
<li>McCredie, opened in 1990. Catering for Year 9 to 10 boarders.</li>
<li>Read, opened in 1931. Catering for Year 8 to 9 boarders.</li>
<li>Wheeldon, opened in 2008. Catering for Year 11 to 12 boarders</li></ul>
<p>There are currently approximately 150 boarders at Abbotsleigh from Years 7 to 12.<sup id="cite_ref-Annualreport_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Annualreport-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> Boarders make up about one-sixth of the senior school population.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notable_alumnae">Notable alumnae</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abbotsleigh&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Notable alumnae">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<ul><li><a href="/wiki/St_Stithians_College" title="St Stithians College">St Stithians College</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">in <a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe" title="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a></th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Chisipite_Senior_School" title="Chisipite Senior School">Chisipite Senior School</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div>
~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">May 2019</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</p>
<table class="infobox vevent" style="width:22em;font-size:90%;"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" class="summary" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;font-size:110%;font-style:italic;">Accident</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Accident_(1985)_poster.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Accident (1985) poster.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/c/cf/Accident_%281985%29_poster.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="301" class="thumbborder" data-file-width="220" data-file-height="301" /></a><div style="font-size:95%;padding:0.35em 0.35em 0.25em;line-height:1.25em;">Poster</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Directed by</th><td><a href="/wiki/Shankar_Nag" title="Shankar Nag">Shankar Nag</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Written by</th><td>Vasant Mukashi</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Screenplay by</th><td>Vasant Mukashi</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Starring</th><td><a href="/wiki/Anant_Nag" title="Anant Nag">Anant Nag</a><br />Shankar Nag<br /><a href="/wiki/Arundhati_Nag" class="mw-redirect" title="Arundhati Nag">Arundhati Nag</a><br /><a href="/wiki/Ramesh_Bhat" title="Ramesh Bhat">Ramesh Bhat</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Music by</th><td><a href="/wiki/Ilayaraja" class="mw-redirect" title="Ilayaraja">Ilayaraja</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Cinematography</th><td>Devadhar</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Edited by</th><td>P. Bhaktavatsalam</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Distributed by</th><td>Sanket</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;white-space:normal;">Release date</div></th><td><div class="plainlist">
<ul><li>9&#160;November&#160;1984<span style="display:none">&#160;(<span class="bday dtstart published updated">1984-11-09</span>)</span></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;white-space:normal;">Running time</div></th><td>125 minutes</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Country</th><td>India</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Language</th><td>Kannada</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><i><b>Accident</b></i> is a 1984 Indian <a href="/wiki/Kannada_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Kannada language">Kannada language</a> film directed by <a href="/wiki/Shankar_Nag" title="Shankar Nag">Shankar Nag</a>. The film starred his elder brother <a href="/wiki/Anant_Nag" title="Anant Nag">Anant Nag</a> and wife <a href="/wiki/Arundhati_Nag" class="mw-redirect" title="Arundhati Nag">Arundhati Nag</a> in lead roles.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
The film won the <a href="/wiki/National_Film_Award_for_Best_Film_on_Other_Social_Issues" title="National Film Award for Best Film on Other Social Issues">National Film Award for Best Film on Other Social Issues</a> at the <a href="/wiki/32nd_National_Film_Awards" title="32nd National Film Awards">32nd National Film Awards</a> in 1985.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> It also won multiple awards at the 1984–85 Karnataka State Film Awards including the award for <a href="/wiki/Karnataka_State_Film_Award_for_Best_Film" class="mw-redirect" title="Karnataka State Film Award for Best Film">First Best Film</a>. It's a  milestone movie in the history of Kannada cinema. The film was praised for placing a politician against justice system and media revealing the nexus between politics and drug mafia.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cast">Cast</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Accident_(1985_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Cast">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Anant_Nag" title="Anant Nag">Anant Nag</a> as Politician Dharmadhikari</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shankar_Nag" title="Shankar Nag">Shankar Nag</a> as Journalist Ravi</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Arundhati_Nag" class="mw-redirect" title="Arundhati Nag">Arundhati Nag</a> as Rich Widow Maya Rani</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ashok_(Kannada_actor)" title="Ashok (Kannada actor)">Ashok Mandanna</a> as Deepak</li>
<li>Makeup Naani as Editor Shamanna</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Srinivas_Prabhu" title="Srinivas Prabhu">Srinivas Prabhu</a> as Rahul</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ramesh_Bhat" title="Ramesh Bhat">Ramesh Bhat</a> as Inspector Rao</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/T._S._Nagabharana" title="T. S. Nagabharana">T. S. Nagabharana</a> as Ramanna</li>
<li>H. G. Somashekhara Rao as Mechanic Pinto</li>
<li>Shimoga Venkatesh as Police Commissioner</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Analysis">Analysis</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Accident_(1985_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Analysis">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Critics call it one of the first films depicting corruption in public life and the futile struggle against it. The film also throws light on the unholy nexus between politicians and media whilst focusing on the impact of drug abuse and addiction. Contrary to stereotypes of Indian cinema which include romantic interests, intense background music and songs which are generally accompanied by dance sequences. the movie takes a neo-noir approach towards investigative journalism which forms the bulk of the movie. This can be considered one of the earliest approaches towards a paradigm shift in film making in India which unfortunately didn't take off until the early 2000s due to the tragic death of Shankar Nag in 1990.
</p><p>Ilayaraja’s score is sombre which plays an important role in the film attuning to the grim nature of grief suffered by the lone survivor of the Accident. Background noise such as clanking of typewriter keys, camera clicks, car screeches, white television noise , bullets sliding inside a pistol, etc. form the bulk of the spacing in the movie. The silence at the scene of the accident scene is haunting. There are no songs in this movie, which provides it a far more serious pacing in comparison to the casual overtones found in most Kannada movies. Distinction amongst different classes in society is well represented in the movie and the disdain powerful politicians have towards ordinary working class people whilst not campaigning for an election is wonderfully portrayed.
</p><p>Every movie directed by Shankar Nag is a master piece. It would be wise to remember that with Malgudi days, he does inhabit the heart of every Indian, not just Kannadigas. He is the director that in ways more than one represents a direction which was not fully realized in India for quite sometime until independent film makers with the assistance of social media started to take things into their own creative control. Whether be it his revolutionary approach towards grand theft auto combined with prison break in <i>Minchina Ota</i> <sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> or his portrayal of everyday family life amongst the middle class in 1980 Bengaluru as witnessed <i>Nodi Swamy Navirodu Heege</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> Mr. Nag did not shy away from showcasing his versatility in directing at every opportunity presented to him.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Accident_(1985_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Notes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Shankar Nag made the film in two months flat. The political atmosphere of the country was in turmoil. The sanctity of the "<a href="/wiki/Operation_Blue_Star" title="Operation Blue Star">Golden Temple in Punjab</a>" had been desecrated; the air was charged with helplessness, anger and confusion. While shooting climax of the film, Ananth Nag who was playing the politician, was to be shot in the courtyard of his house. He originally wanted to work it around the <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Indira_Gandhi" title="Assassination of Indira Gandhi">assassination of Indira Gandhi</a>.
Shankar Nag was dead sure that it had to be that way and changed ending of film.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Plot">Plot</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Accident_(1985_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Plot">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Deepak (Ashok Mandanna), the spoilt son of a powerful politician Dharmadhikari (Ananth Nag) runs his imported car over pavement dwellers one fateful night under the influence of drugs.
Except for a lone survivor, all are killed. Ramanna (Nagabharana), the survivor, identifies the driver. His friend Rahul (Srinivasa Prabhu), son of an advertising agency chief (Arundhati Nag), is with him during the accident. The shock of the accident leaves Rahul deeply traumatised.
Unable to hold keep the secret any longer, Rahul shares the truth with his mother. She in turn implores to Dharmadhikaari to save them. Dharmadhikari who is slated to win a by-election cannot afford to let this accident ruin his political ambitions. He hushes up the case with the help of Chief Minister and sends his son on a trip abroad.
Inspector Rao, (Ramesh Bhat) is the investigating officer. Ravi (Shankar Nag), a daring investigative journalist, joins him and the duo begin to putting together the evidence. With Rao’s help, Ravi gets to the bottom of the whole affair.
When Rao identifies the culprits, Dharmadhikari asks his retired driver to say he was driving the car. Rao is asked to go on leave and Ravi’s editor refuses to run the story. On his way to the airport, Deepak dies in an accident. Dharmadhikari wins, but loses at the same time. Shankar Nag, apparently changed the climax. He originally wanted to work it around the assassination of Indira Gandhi
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Reception">Reception</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Accident_(1985_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Reception">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p><i>Accident</i> was well received by critics and audience. The movie won the Karnataka State Film award. <i>Accident</i> is a testimony to the exceptional directorial ability of Shankar Nag.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Accident_(1985_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Awards">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p><a href="/wiki/32nd_National_Film_Awards" title="32nd National Film Awards">32nd National Film Awards</a>
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/National_Film_Award_for_Best_Film_on_Other_Social_Issues" title="National Film Award for Best Film on Other Social Issues">National Film Award for Best Film on Other Social Issues</a></li></ul>
<p><a href="/wiki/Karnataka_State_Film_Awards_1984-85" class="mw-redirect" title="Karnataka State Film Awards 1984-85">Karnataka State Film Awards 1984-85</a>
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Karnataka_State_Film_Award_for_First_Best_Film" title="Karnataka State Film Award for First Best Film">First Best Film</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Karnataka_State_Film_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress" title="Karnataka State Film Award for Best Supporting Actress">Best Supporting Actress</a> – <a href="/wiki/Arundathi_Nag" title="Arundathi Nag">Arundathi Nag</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Karnataka_State_Film_Award_for_Best_Screenplay" title="Karnataka State Film Award for Best Screenplay">Best Screenplay</a> – Vasantha Mokashi</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Karnataka_State_Film_Award_for_Best_Sound_Recording" title="Karnataka State Film Award for Best Sound Recording">Best Sound Recording</a> – Pandurangan</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Karnataka_State_Film_Award_(Special_Jury_Award)" title="Karnataka State Film Award (Special Jury Award)">Special Award (Stunts)</a> – Hasan Raghu</li>
<li>It screened at 14th IFFI Homage to Shankar Nag.</li></ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Accident_(1985_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<div role="navigation" class="navbox" aria-labelledby="National_Film_Award_for_Best_Film_on_Other_Social_Issues" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks mw-collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th scope="col" class="navbox-title" colspan="2" style="background: #BDB76B"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:National_Film_Award_for_Best_Film_on_Other_Social_Issues" title="Template:National Film Award for Best Film on Other Social Issues"><abbr title="View this template" style="background: #BDB76B;;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; <table class="box-Unreliable_sources plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-unreliable_sources" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg" class="image"><img alt="Text document with red question mark.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/40px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/60px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/80px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="48" data-file-height="48" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">Some of this article's <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">listed sources</a> <b>may not be <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources">reliable</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help this article by looking for better, more reliable sources. <table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Nazir Ahmad<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><span style="display:none"> (<span class="bday">1950-01-01</span>) </span>1 January 1950<span class="noprint ForceAgeToShow"> (age&#160;70)</span></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Alma&#160;mater</th><td><a href="/wiki/King_Edward_Medical_University" title="King Edward Medical University">King Edward Medical University</a></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><b>Scientific career</b></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Fields</th><td class="category"><a href="/wiki/Neurosurgery" title="Neurosurgery">Neurosurgery</a></td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Nazir Ahmad</b> (<i>Urdu:</i> نذیر احمد,) is a <a href="/wiki/Neurosurgeon" class="mw-redirect" title="Neurosurgeon">neurosurgeon</a> from Pakistan. Known for his role in modernization of neurosurgical practices in the country, Ahmad has published over 60 international research articles in the field of neurosurgery,<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> and is regarded as the "Father of Modern Neurosurgery in Pakistan". He is credited with laying the foundation for the Punjab Institute of Neurosciences,<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nazir_Ahmad_(neurosurgeon)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>He is credited for having introduced the surgical treatment of Brain AVM'S and Aneurysms in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> Special areas of research and practice include, Stereotactic surgery for movement disorders.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> Currently he is supervising studies comparing plate and screw systems with cage devices used to correct spinal instability.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Positions">Positions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nazir_Ahmad_(neurosurgeon)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Positions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>Founder PINS (Punjab Institute of Neurosciences)<sup id="cite_ref-auto_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Ex. Vice President ACNS (Asian Congress of Neurological Surgeons)<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Chief Editor <i>Pakistan Journal of Neurological Surgery</i> (PJNS) - To Date<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>

November 1, 2010.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Nation&amp;rft.atitle=LGH+Neurosciences+Institute+to+be+equipped+with+modern+technology&amp;rft.date=2010-11-01&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fnation.com.pk%2F01-Nov-2010%2FLGH-Neurosciences-Institute-to-be-equipped-with-modern-technology&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANazir+Ahmad+%28neurosurgeon%29" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-auto-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-auto_4-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-auto_4-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFChaudhry2013" class="citation web cs1">Chaudhry, Asif (October 31, 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.dawn.com/news/1053078">"Neurosciences facility in funds dilemma"</a>. <i>DAWN.COM</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=DAWN.COM&amp;rft.atitle=Neurosciences+facility+in+funds+dilemma&amp;rft.date=2013-10-31&amp;rft.aulast=Chaudhry&amp;rft.aufirst=Asif&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dawn.com%2Fnews%2F1053078&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANazir+Ahmad+%28neurosurgeon%29" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://pkdoctors.com/index.php/doctors-directory/select-specialty?sobi2Task=sobi2Details&amp;catid=10&amp;sobi2Id=265">http://pkdoctors.com/index.php/doctors-directory/select-specialty?sobi2Task=sobi2Details&amp;catid=10&amp;sobi2Id=265</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.jourlib.org/paper/2394353">http://www.jourlib.org/paper/2394353</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.spineuniverse.com/specialist/neurosurgeon/pk/nazir-ahmad-20496">"Nazir Ahmad MD - Neurosurgeon in Lahore lahore"</a>. <i>SpineUniverse</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=SpineUniverse&amp;rft.atitle=Nazir+Ahmad+MD+-+Neurosurgeon+in+Lahore+lahore&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.spineuniverse.com%2Fspecialist%2Fneurosurgeon%2Fpk%2Fnazir-ahmad-20496&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANazir+Ahmad+%28neurosurgeon%29" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.fujita-hu.ac.jp/~neuron/en/acns_awna/3rd_acns/member.html">"The 3rd Asian Conference of Neurological Surgeons"</a>. <i>www.fujita-hu.ac.jp</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.fujita-hu.ac.jp&amp;rft.atitle=The+3rd+Asian+Conference+of+Neurological+Surgeons&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.fujita-hu.ac.jp%2F~neuron%2Fen%2Facns_awna%2F3rd_acns%2Fmember.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANazir+Ahmad+%28neurosurgeon%29" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-9">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://pakjofneurolsurg.com/editorial.html">http://pakjofneurolsurg.com/editorial.html</a></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<div role="navigation" class="navbox authority-control" aria-labelledby="Authority_control_frameless_&amp;#124;text-top_&amp;#124;10px_&amp;#124;alt=Edit_this_at_Wikidata_&amp;#124;link=https&amp;#58;//www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q18379760#identifiers&amp;#124;Edit_this_at_Wikidata" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks hlist navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th id="Authority_control_frameless_&amp;#124;text-top_&amp;#124;10px_&amp;#124;alt=Edit_this_at_Wikidata_&amp;#124;link=https&amp;#58;//www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q18379760#identifiers&amp;#124;Edit_this_at_Wikidata" scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Help:Authority_control" title="Help:Authority control">Authority control</a> <a href="https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q18379760#identifiers" title="Edit this at Wikidata"><img alt="Edit this at Wikidata" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8a/OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg/10px-OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg.png" decoding="async" width="10" height="10" style="vertical-align: text-top" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8a/OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg/15px-OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8a/OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg/20px-OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20" /></a></th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

<table class="box-Orphan plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style ambox-Orphan" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w.svg" class="image"><img alt="Wiki letter w.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6c/Wiki_letter_w.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6c/Wiki_letter_w.svg/60px-Wiki_letter_w.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6c/Wiki_letter_w.svg/80px-Wiki_letter_w.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="44" data-file-height="44" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article <b>is an <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Orphan" title="Wikipedia:Orphan">orphan</a>, as no other articles <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:Whatlinkshere&amp;target=Fuad_Akhundov&amp;namespace=0">link to it</a></b>. </div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Fuad Akhundov</div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td>12 May 1966<br /><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace"><a href="/wiki/Baku" title="Baku">Baku</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Occupation</th><td class="role">Financier and businessman</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Fuad Akhundov</b> is a <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijani</a> financier and businessman. Akhundov has worked as the Chairman of the Board of the <a href="/wiki/International_Bank_of_Azerbaijan" title="International Bank of Azerbaijan">International Bank of Azerbaijan</a>, as the CEO of the <a href="/wiki/Nikoil_Financial" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikoil Financial">Nikoil Financial</a> Corporation (since 2001), and as the President and Chief Executive Officer of <a href="/wiki/Uralsib" title="Uralsib">Uralsib</a> (since 2003). In 2014, Akhundov became the Chief Executive Officer of the <a href="/wiki/Akkuyu_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Akkuyu Nuclear Power Plant">Akkuyu Nuclear Power Plant</a> Stock Company.
</p><p>Fuad Akhundov led the team which achieved approval for the first Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) and Side Parameters Report (SPR) for a nuclear power plant in Turkey.
Under Akhundov's leadership, Akkuyu Nuclear undertook a so-called "multi-lot" construction strategy which later became a foundational strategy for bringing outside investors into the project.
In 2016 Akhundov founded Independent Energy Fund, a fund whose primary focus is financing Rosatom's foreign expansion.
He continues to lead Akkuyu Nuclear in the capacity of the Deputy Chairman of the Board.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biography">Biography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Fuad_Akhundov&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Biography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Akhundov was born on 12 May 1966 in <a href="/wiki/Baku" title="Baku">Baku</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic">Republic of Azerbaijan</a>. He graduated from school №6 in Baku. In 1991 he graduated with honors from the <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan_State_University_of_Oil_and_Industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Azerbaijan State University of Oil and Industry">Azerbaijan State Oil Academy</a> with a degree in engineering and economics.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> In 1993, he graduated from the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Texas" class="mw-redirect" title="University of Texas">University of Texas</a> (<a href="/wiki/Austin,_Texas" title="Austin, Texas">Austin</a>, United States) with a degree in corporate and international finance. In 1994, he studied at the Joint Vienna Institute at the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> and at the Japanese Center for International Finance, where he received a diploma in <a href="/wiki/Macroeconomic" class="mw-redirect" title="Macroeconomic">macroeconomic</a> management. He is fluent in <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijani_language" title="Azerbaijani language">Azerbaijani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>. He is married and has three children.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Fuad_Akhundov&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Akhundov started his career in 1986 as the Chief Engineer in the Engineering and Construction Department of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_of_the_USSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Defense of the USSR">Ministry of Defense of the USSR</a>. During 1987-1991 he was appointed as a head of the regulatory research station in the system of Special Construction of the Ministry of Defense of the USSR. In 1991 he joined the State Committee for Economy and Planning of the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Azerbaijan" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of Azerbaijan">Republic of Azerbaijan</a> at the position of Chief Economist and Deputy Director of the Directorate of Business Regulation and Economic and Legal Expertise.
</p><p>Akhundov was engaged in the development of draft laws in the field of economy that laid the foundations of the market reforms in the Republic of Azerbaijan. He took part in the drafting of the following laws: "On the Securities Market", "On the Liberalization of Business", "On the Stock Exchange". In 1992 he was appointed as the advisor of the Presidential Administration of the Republic of Azerbaijan. He continued to participate in the development of the economic legislation of the Republic of Azerbaijan.
</p><p>Akhundov took part in the development of <a href="/wiki/Antitrust" class="mw-redirect" title="Antitrust">antitrust</a> legislation and of laws including "On the Property" and "On the Committee for State Property", which ensured the country's transition from a centrally <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">planned economy</a> to a <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a>. After the post-graduate studies at the University of Texas (Austin, Texas, United States), he began his career in the banking system of the Republic of Azerbaijan. In 1993 he headed the International Banking Operations Department at the Industrial Investment Bank of Azerbaijan. In 1994 he took the position of Director of the Department for Regulation of Foreign Exchange Transactions and International Financial Institutions in the National Bank of Azerbaijan (NBA). Later, Akhundov was appointed Director of the Department for Monetary Policy and Regulation of Foreign Exchange Operations in the NBA.
</p><p>From August 1994 to September 1995, Akhundov was the Deputy Chairman of the National Bank of Azerbaijan. While working at the National Bank of Azerbaijan, he led the bank's team at the negotiations of the NBA with the IMF and the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>. Being one of the founders of the first monetary program of the NBA, he personally developed and presented the law "Regulations on Foreign Exchange Regulation" to the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(Azerbaijan)" title="National Assembly (Azerbaijan)">Parliament of Azerbaijan</a>.
</p><p>Under the leadership of Akhundov, a new national payment system and the first payments balance of the country were introduced. As the Chairman of the Board of the Baku Interbank Currency Exchange, he organized the first auction, which laid the foundation for the inter-bank <a href="/wiki/Foreign_exchange_market" title="Foreign exchange market">foreign exchange market</a>. In 1995, Fuad Akhundov headed the International Bank of Azerbaijan (IBA). By 2001, the IBA had become the leading bank in the Republic of Azerbaijan, with a market share estimated at 2/3 of the country's banking capital, and with about 50% of retail deposits.
</p><p>In 1996 the bank launched a <a href="/wiki/Credit_card" title="Credit card">credit cards</a> program, Azerbaijan's first <a href="/wiki/Automated_teller_machine" title="Automated teller machine">ATM</a> was installed the same year, and the first international credit cards were issued in 1997. Later, the IBA served over 2 million cardholders and controlled 90% of the country's market. As a strategy for <a href="/wiki/Retail_banking" title="Retail banking">retail banking</a> operations, the scheme of payment of utility bills was launched in Azerbaijan's capital, the city of Baku, in 2000. The bank was recognized as the best regional bank in the CIS (<a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">Commonwealth of Independent States</a>) in the field of management, and as the bank with the best management information system and IT system in the CIS countries.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> According to <i><a href="/wiki/Euromoney" title="Euromoney">Euromoney</a></i> magazine, it was recognized as the "Best Bank in Azerbaijan" in 1998, 1999, 2000, and was nominated "Bank of the Year" in <i>Banker</i> magazine. In 1998, Thomson Financial Bankwatch awarded the IBA with a credit rating; it was the first company in the history of Azerbaijan to receive an international credit rating.
</p><p>Since 2001, Akhundov has been the Chief Executive Director and First Vice President of Nikoil Finance Corporation (<a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a>). In August 2001, he led the team on the acquisition of Industrial Insurance Company (now "Uralsib-Insurance"), which was an insurance company in Russia at the time. In November 2001, Akhundov led the team in the acquisition of Autobank (tenth place among retail banks in Russia). In July 2003, Akhundov began heading the working committee for the integration of Nikoil Group and the acquired Autobank. He was Chairman of the Committee for the Investment and Underwriting in the Autobank-Nikoil Financial Corporation. As the chairman of the investment committee he was directly involved in the acquisition of <a href="/wiki/Kopeyka_(supermarket)" title="Kopeyka (supermarket)">Kopeyka</a>, one of the largest Russian retail chains, by Nikoil.
</p><p>In summer 2003, he began negotiations with the shareholders of the Bank Uralsib, which held the top 5 in all-Russian rankings at the time. Uralsib had an extensive regional network, with over 300 branches in 80 cities of Russia. In November 2003, Nikoil Group acquired a 15% stake in Uralsib through a privatization auction held by the State Property Fund, and a few weeks later Akhundov closed a transaction for a 57% stake in the bank. Another 3.5% stake was purchased on the open market, and the share in the equity of Uralsib increased to 75 + 1%, which allowed him to head the Management Board of the bank. In December 2003, Akhundov was appointed President and Chairman of the Management Board of the Bank Uralsib JSC.
</p><p>From February 2004 to the end of 2005 he managed the merger of the Autobank-Nikoil FC and the Bank Uralsib. By the end of 2005, the consolidated Uralsib Financial Corporation increased its assets by almost 10 times, and took the 5th place in the DCM. It was also among the three leading private banks and asset management companies. The Uralsib FC was among the top five research teams, according to the rating of Thompson-Extel, was the seventh among the banks engaged in retail, and the tenth among the creditors of corporations in the Russian Federation.
</p><p>In 2006, Akhundov founded and headed the United Capital Investment Group and served as a member of the Supervisory Board in the Silkroutefinancial Foundation (<a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>).
</p><p>Fuad Akhundov led the team which achieved approval for the first Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) and Side Parameters Report (SPR) for a nuclear power plant in Turkey.  Under Akhundov's leadership, Akkuyu Nuclear undertook a so-called "multi-lot" construction strategy which later became a foundational strategy for bringing outside investors into the project.
</p><p>In 2016 Akhundov founded Independent Energy Fund, a fund whose primary focus is financing Rosatom's foreign expansion.
</p><p>He continues to lead Akkuyu Nuclear in the capacity of the Deputy Chairman of the Board.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Fuad_Akhundov&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px </li>
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Source: Information Memorandum of KPMG on the privatization of the IBA</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Fuad_Akhundov&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.akkunpp.com/generalnyj-direktor-ao-aes-akkuyu-vystupil-na-mezhdunarodnom-forume-atomekspo-2014/update">Генеральный директор АО АЭС АККУЮ выступил на Международном форуме «АТОМЭКСПО 2014»</a></li></ul></div>
~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">May 2020</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="box-Unreliable_sources plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-unreliable_sources" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg" class="image"><img alt="Text document with red question mark.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/40px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/60px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/80px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="48" data-file-height="48" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">Some of this article's <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">listed sources</a> <b>may not be <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources">reliable</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help this article by looking for better, more reliable sources. colspan="2">
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Simon Aldridge</b> (born London, 1974) is a <a href="/wiki/Post-conceptual" class="mw-redirect" title="Post-conceptual">post-conceptual</a> artist working in New York City.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Simon_Aldridge&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Simon Aldridge was born in London, England. He attended <a href="/wiki/Haberdashers%27_Aske%27s_Boys%27_School" title="Haberdashers&#39; Aske&#39;s Boys&#39; School">Haberdashers' Aske's School</a> and <a href="/wiki/Winchester_College" title="Winchester College">Winchester College</a>. He graduated with a BSc from <a href="/wiki/The_Bartlett" title="The Bartlett">The Bartlett</a> and an MA from <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">Harvard University</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Simon_Aldridge&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_development">Early development</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Simon_Aldridge&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Early development">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 1995, Aldridge won the <a href="/wiki/RIBA_President%27s_Medals_Students_Award" title="RIBA President&#39;s Medals Students Award">RIBA President's Medals Students Award</a> in 1993. From 1995 to 1996 Aldridge worked on a building site on the construction of the <a href="/wiki/No._1_Court_(Wimbledon)" title="No. 1 Court (Wimbledon)">No. 1 Court (Wimbledon)</a><sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> where he began developing artwork using construction materials, office photocopiers, and <a href="/wiki/Epson" title="Epson">epson</a> engineering plotters. In 1996 he was awarded a <a href="/wiki/Kennedy_Scholarship" title="Kennedy Scholarship">Kennedy Scholarship</a> to study a Masters in Architecture at the <a href="/wiki/Harvard_Graduate_School_of_Design" title="Harvard Graduate School of Design">Harvard Graduate School of Design</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Wall_Ride_-_Simon_Aldridge_2001.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Wall_Ride_-_Simon_Aldridge_2001.jpg/220px-Wall_Ride_-_Simon_Aldridge_2001.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="140" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Wall_Ride_-_Simon_Aldridge_2001.jpg/330px-Wall_Ride_-_Simon_Aldridge_2001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Wall_Ride_-_Simon_Aldridge_2001.jpg/440px-Wall_Ride_-_Simon_Aldridge_2001.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1019" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Wall_Ride_-_Simon_Aldridge_2001.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>"<a href="/w/index.php?title=Wall_Ride&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wall Ride (page does not exist)">Wall Ride</a> by Simon Aldridge (2001)</div></div></div>
<p>Before graduating, Aldridge had in 1999 already taken a studio space in the <a href="/wiki/Meatpacking_District,_Manhattan" title="Meatpacking District, Manhattan">Meatpacking District, Manhattan</a>, in the same building as artist <a href="/wiki/Matthew_Barney" title="Matthew Barney">Matthew Barney</a>. There, he began to make wall mounted sculptures out of construction materials and using industrial paint and printing techniques. These ‘Wallride’works were first exhibited in 2001 at Mark Pasek Gallery in the <a href="/wiki/Lower_East_Side" title="Lower East Side">Lower East Side</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Jennifer_Park_-_Substancezine_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jennifer_Park_-_Substancezine-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> where Aldridge met and began collaborating with Wes Lang and <a href="/wiki/FAILE_(artist_collaboration)" title="FAILE (artist collaboration)">FAILE (artist collaboration)</a>. Aldridge, Lang and Faile were all working with sampling and <a href="/wiki/Graffiti" title="Graffiti">graffiti</a>. Two books – ‘Orange’, and ‘Death’ were produced by <a href="/wiki/FAILE_(artist_collaboration)" title="FAILE (artist collaboration)">FAILE (artist collaboration)</a> and published as limited editions<sup id="cite_ref-Faile_Book_Collaborations_-_Orange,_Death_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Faile_Book_Collaborations_-_Orange,_Death-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> featuring work by Aldridge.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Work">Work</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Simon_Aldridge&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Work">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 2001 Aldridge was a World Views Artist-in-Residence at the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001)" title="World Trade Center (1973–2001)">World Trade Center (1973–2001)</a> where he had an art studio on the 91st Floor of Tower One together with <a href="/wiki/Monika_Bravo" title="Monika Bravo">Monika Bravo</a> and 13 other artists. Aldridge shared his studio with Jamaican-American <a href="/wiki/Michael_Richards_(sculptor)" title="Michael Richards (sculptor)">Michael Richards (sculptor)</a> who died aged 38, in the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001)" title="World Trade Center (1973–2001)">World Trade Center</a> in the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Michael_Richards_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Michael_Richards-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After surviving the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a> Aldridge relocated his studio to the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Navy_Yard" title="Brooklyn Navy Yard">Brooklyn Navy Yard</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NY_Arts_Magazine_-_editor_Bakke,_Erik_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY_Arts_Magazine_-_editor_Bakke,_Erik-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> In 2002 then <a href="/wiki/New_Museum" title="New Museum">New Museum</a> curator Anne Ellegood included Aldridge in ‘The Meaning of Style’ which also featured <a href="/wiki/Steve_Ellis_(comics)" title="Steve Ellis (comics)">Steve Ellis (comics)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Stone_(architect)" title="Robert Stone (architect)">Robert Stone (architect)</a>, writing in the exhibition catalogue, "Simon Aldridge pushes conventional limitations of monochromatic painting and minimalist sculpture through forms that function as a hybrid of these media and are simultaneously imbued with content related to everyday street culture. His use of spray paint is seductive for its surprisingly variable surface texture while remaining, as the artist describes it, consistently 'atonal'.  The painterly concerns of the medium are then meaningfully related to the subcultures of graphiti artists and even construction workers, who use these standardized materials on an ongoing basis."<sup id="cite_ref-The_MEaning_of_Style_Exhibition_Essay_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_MEaning_of_Style_Exhibition_Essay-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Aldridge's work was first shown with other <a href="/wiki/Post-conceptual" class="mw-redirect" title="Post-conceptual">post-conceptual</a> artists <a href="/wiki/Wade_Guyton" title="Wade Guyton">Wade Guyton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kelley_Walker" title="Kelley Walker">Kelley Walker</a> and <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Meagher_(artist)" title="Patrick Meagher (artist)">Patrick Meagher (artist)</a> in ‘Retrofit’ curated by Lauri Firstenberg at Lombard Freid Fine Arts, New York in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> Firstenberg was at the time the curator of <a href="/wiki/Artists_Space" title="Artists Space">Artists Space</a> and described Aldridge's work - "Foregrounding architectural illusion, Aldridge produces a delicate balance between accident and intention, structure and agency, theoretical intervention and subjective aimlessness."<sup id="cite_ref-Painting_as_Paradox_Catalogue_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Painting_as_Paradox_Catalogue-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> At the close of 2002, Aldridge was included in <a href="/wiki/Flash_Art" title="Flash Art">Flash Art</a> Magazine's survey of ‘Contemporary Painting Today’.<sup id="cite_ref-Flash_Art_-_Focus_Painting_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Flash_Art_-_Focus_Painting-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Artificial_Environments_-_Installation,_Simon_Aldridge_1999.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Artificial_Environments_-_Installation%2C_Simon_Aldridge_1999.jpg/220px-Artificial_Environments_-_Installation%2C_Simon_Aldridge_1999.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="125" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Artificial_Environments_-_Installation%2C_Simon_Aldridge_1999.jpg/330px-Artificial_Environments_-_Installation%2C_Simon_Aldridge_1999.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Artificial_Environments_-_Installation%2C_Simon_Aldridge_1999.jpg/440px-Artificial_Environments_-_Installation%2C_Simon_Aldridge_1999.jpg 2x" data-file-width="835" data-file-height="473" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Artificial_Environments_-_Installation,_Simon_Aldridge_1999.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>"Artificial Environments" installation by Simon Aldridge (1999)</div></div></div>
<p>In 2003 German art critic Daniel Marzona, author of Minimal Art,<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> and curator at <a href="/wiki/MoMA_PS1" title="MoMA PS1">MoMA PS1</a> included Aldridge in ‘Framing Architecture’, an exhibition which also included <a href="/wiki/Wade_Guyton" title="Wade Guyton">Wade Guyton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Terence_Gower" title="Terence Gower">Terence Gower</a>, <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Meagher_(artist)" title="Patrick Meagher (artist)">Patrick Meagher (artist)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Anton_Vidokle" title="Anton Vidokle">Anton Vidokle</a>.
</p><p>Aldridge had his second solo show in New York at Cohan and Leslie in Chelsea<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> in 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Exhibitions">Exhibitions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Simon_Aldridge&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Exhibitions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Monotype_-_Simon_Aldridge_2015.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Monotype_-_Simon_Aldridge_2015.jpg/220px-Monotype_-_Simon_Aldridge_2015.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="185" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Monotype_-_Simon_Aldridge_2015.jpg/330px-Monotype_-_Simon_Aldridge_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Monotype_-_Simon_Aldridge_2015.jpg/440px-Monotype_-_Simon_Aldridge_2015.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2500" data-file-height="2106" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Monotype_-_Simon_Aldridge_2015.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>"Monotype Iteration 24" by Simon Aldridge (2015)</div></div></div>
<p>Aldridge's work has been exhibited at the <a href="/wiki/Grey_Art_Gallery" title="Grey Art Gallery">Grey Art Gallery</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/New_Museum" title="New Museum">New Museum</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Museum_of_Contemporary_Art" title="Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art">Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/SculptureCenter" title="SculptureCenter">SculptureCenter</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/MoMA_PS1" title="MoMA PS1">MoMA PS1</a><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> and the Kunsthalle Fridericianum in Kassel, Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Simon_Aldridge&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Awards">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In 2001, Aldridge was a World Views Artist-In-Residence at the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973-2001)" class="mw-redirect" title="World Trade Center (1973-2001)">World Trade Center (1973-2001)</a> in New York, and he was also the recipient of a Pollock-Krasner Grant from the <a href="/wiki/Pollock-Krasner_Foundation" title="Pollock-Krasner Foundation">Pollock-Krasner Foundation</a>. In 2002 his design for the Pentagon Memorial was shortlisted and exhibited at the <a href="/wiki/National_Building_Museum" title="National Building Museum">National Building Museum</a> in Washington, DC.
</p>
<ul><li>RIBA – Bronze Medal for Part 1 Students – 1995<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kennedy_Scholarship" title="Kennedy Scholarship">Kennedy Scholarship</a> to <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">Harvard University</a> – 1996</li>
<li>World Views Artist-In-Residence at the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001)" title="World Trade Center (1973–2001)">World Trade Center</a> – 2001<sup id="cite_ref-World_Views_-_Simon_Aldridge_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Views_-_Simon_Aldridge-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Pollock-Krasner Grant / <a href="/wiki/Pollock-Krasner_Foundation" title="Pollock-Krasner Foundation">Pollock-Krasner Foundation</a> – 2001</li>
<li>Jury Selection, Pentagon Memorial Competition – 2002<sup id="cite_ref-CNN-Simon_Aldridge_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-Simon_Aldridge-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/American_Institute_of_Architects" title="American Institute of Architects">American Institute of Architects</a> Alice Washburn Award – 2012</li></ul>

Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. pp.&#160;268–269. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-9726973-1-4" title="Special:BookSources/0-9726973-1-4"><bdi>0-9726973-1-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Site+Matters%3A+The+Lower+Manhattan+Cultural+Council%27s+World+Trade+Center+Artist+Residency+1997%E2%80%932001&amp;rft.pages=268-269&amp;rft.pub=Lower+Manhattan+Cultural+Council&amp;rft.isbn=0-9726973-1-4&amp;rft.aulast=Kocache&amp;rft.aufirst=Moukhtar&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASimon+Aldridge" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-15">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFBasha" class="citation book cs1">Basha, Regine. <i>An Exchange with Sol Lewitt</i>. MASS MoCA. p.&#160;8. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781932698527" title="Special:BookSources/9781932698527"><bdi>9781932698527</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=An+Exchange+with+Sol+Lewitt&amp;rft.pages=8&amp;rft.pub=MASS+MoCA&amp;rft.isbn=9781932698527&amp;rft.aulast=Basha&amp;rft.aufirst=Regine&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASimon+Aldridge" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Catalogues">Catalogues</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Simon_Aldridge&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Catalogues">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Joel_Sternfeld" title="Joel Sternfeld">Joel Sternfeld</a>, Lynn Gumpert, <a href="/wiki/Dale_Jamieson" title="Dale Jamieson">Dale Jamieson</a> and Chris Wiley, NYU <a href="/wiki/Grey_Art_Gallery" title="Grey Art Gallery">Grey Art Gallery</a>, Hall Art Foundation and Hirmer Publishers, Munich, 2018 <i>Landscapes after Ruskin: Redefining the Sublime</i>, <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/><a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-3-7774-2989-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-3-7774-2989-2">978-3-7774-2989-2</a><sup id="cite_ref-Landscapes_After_Ruskin_-_Redefining_the_Sublime_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Landscapes_After_Ruskin_-_Redefining_the_Sublime-22">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Moukhtar Kocache and <a href="/wiki/Erin_Shirreff" title="Erin Shirreff">Erin Shirreff</a>, New York, 2004 <i>Site Matters: The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council's World Trade Center Artist Residency 1997–2001</i>, <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/><a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-9726973-1-4" title="Special:BookSources/0-9726973-1-4">0-9726973-1-4</a></li>
<li>Regine Basha, Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, 2011 <i>An exchange with Sol LeWitt</i>, <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/><a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-932698-52-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-932698-52-7">978-1-932698-52-7</a></li></ul>

<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Tiana Alexandra-Silliphant</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Tiana_Alexandra.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Tiana Alexandra.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Tiana_Alexandra.jpg/220px-Tiana_Alexandra.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Tiana_Alexandra.jpg/330px-Tiana_Alexandra.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Tiana_Alexandra.jpg/440px-Tiana_Alexandra.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4368" data-file-height="2912" /></a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><div style="display:inline" class="nickname">Du Thi Thanh Nga</div><br /><span style="display:none"> (<span class="bday">1956-08-11</span>) </span>August 11, 1956<span class="noprint ForceAgeToShow"> (age&#160;64)</span><br /><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace"><a href="/wiki/Saigon" class="mw-redirect" title="Saigon">Saigon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Nationality</th><td class="category"><a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">American</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Occupation</th><td class="role">Actress, filmmaker, singer, activist</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Years&#160;active</th><td>1975–present</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Title</th><td class="title">Director</td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Spouse(s)</span></th><td><div style="display:inline;white-space:nowrap;"><div style="display:inline-block;line-height:normal;margin-top:1px;white-space:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Stirling_Silliphant" title="Stirling Silliphant">Stirling Silliphant</a></div>
   <div style="line-height:0;margin-bottom:-2px;">&#8203;</div>&#32;<div style="display:inline-block;margin-bottom:1px;">&#8203;</div>&#40;<abbr title="married">m.</abbr>&#160;1974&#59;&#32;died&#160;1996&#41;<wbr />&#8203;</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Children</th><td>2</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Website</th><td><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.tianaworld.com/">www<wbr />.tianaworld<wbr />.com</a></span></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Tiana Alexandra-Silliphant</b> (<b>Thi Thanh Nga</b>; August 11, 1956) is a Vietnamese-American actress and filmmaker. Her indie movie <i>From Hollywood to Hanoi</i><sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> was the first American documentary feature film shot in Vietnam by a Vietnamese-American. Tiana's life's work, <i>Why Viet Nam?</i> is about her personal story as a child of war and a widow of peace.
</p><p>Alexandra made her feature film debut in <a href="/wiki/Sam_Peckinpah" title="Sam Peckinpah">Sam Peckinpah</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Killer_Elite" title="The Killer Elite">The Killer Elite</a></i>, co-written by her husband <a href="/wiki/Stirling_Silliphant" title="Stirling Silliphant">Stirling Silliphant</a>. Currently, Alexandra is director of Hampton-Silliphant Productions with <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Hampton" title="Christopher Hampton">Sir Christopher Hampton</a>.
</p>
