<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tiana_Alexandra&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Alexandra was born in <a href="/wiki/Saigon" class="mw-redirect" title="Saigon">Saigon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> in 1956. Her father Dư Phước Long, was a South Vietnamese politician, serving as Director of Press in Saigon and <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Attach%C3%A9" class="mw-redirect" title="Cultural Attaché">Cultural Attaché</a> in Washington DC for the US allied administration of <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Di%E1%BB%87m" class="mw-redirect" title="Ngô Đình Diệm">President Ngô Đình Diệm</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NY_Times_Review_of_FHTH_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY_Times_Review_of_FHTH-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fresh_air_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fresh_air-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-patrick_cnn_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-patrick_cnn-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Alexandra's father moved the family to <a href="/wiki/Fairfax,_Virginia" title="Fairfax, Virginia">Fairfax</a>, <a href="/wiki/Virginia" title="Virginia">Virginia</a>, in 1966 after the assassination of President Diệm. He worked at the South Vietnamese Embassy in Washington, DC, and pursued studies at <a href="/wiki/Georgetown_University" title="Georgetown University">Georgetown University</a>'s Diplomatic School and <a href="/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_University" title="Johns Hopkins University">Johns Hopkins University</a>'s Graduate School of Advanced International Studies. He became Patrick Du Long and became a scriptwriter and newscaster for the <a href="/wiki/Voice_of_America" title="Voice of America">Voice of America</a>. He authored a book, <i>The Dream Shattered: Vietnamese Gangs in America</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Dream_Shattered_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Dream_Shattered-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> In 1998, he was a candidate for the <a href="/wiki/California_State_Assembly" title="California State Assembly">California State Assembly</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NY_Times_Review_of_FHTH_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY_Times_Review_of_FHTH-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-voterinfo_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-voterinfo-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As a child of war refugee, the pre-teen attended [[Thomas Jefferson Jr. High School in Arlington Virginia during the worst years of desegregation. After being beat up in the girl's room for being Vietnamese, Tiana sought out <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Lee" title="Bruce Lee">Bruce Lee</a> as her Jeet Kune Do Self Defense master. Bruce, who was not yet the international movie star, honed her interest in both the performing arts and martial arts. GrandMaster <a href="/wiki/Jhoon_Rhee" class="mw-redirect" title="Jhoon Rhee">Jhoon Rhee</a> crowned her TianaKaratePrincess and introduced her to his best friend <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Lee" title="Bruce Lee">Bruce Lee</a>, at his National Tournament in Washington, DC. Bruce Lee introduced Alexandra to his best friend <a href="/wiki/Stirling_Silliphant" title="Stirling Silliphant">Stirling Silliphant</a> who was "Hollywood highest paid screenwriter".<sup id="cite_ref-Reed_Ferrel_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reed_Ferrel-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> Silliphant had written Lee into numerous TV shows, including <i><a href="/wiki/Longstreet_(TV_series)" title="Longstreet (TV series)">Longstreet</a></i>, an original two hour TV pilot called <i>The Way of the Intercepting Fist</i>. He believed in Bruce so much that he wrote the young Bruce into his script of <a href="/wiki/Raymond_Chandler" title="Raymond Chandler">Raymond Chandler</a>'s <i>Marlowe</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-bruceleefoundation_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bruceleefoundation-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> Silliphant had also written most of the episodes for the acclaimed television series <i><a href="/wiki/Route_66_(TV_series)" title="Route 66 (TV series)">Route 66</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-IMDb_Route_66_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMDb_Route_66-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-route66_cftc_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-route66_cftc-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> and won an Oscar for Best Screenplay<sup id="cite_ref-Academy_in_the_heat_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Academy_in_the_heat-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> on the feature film <i><a href="/wiki/In_the_Heat_of_the_Night_(film)" title="In the Heat of the Night (film)">In the Heat of the Night</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-IMDb_In_the_Heat_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMDb_In_the_Heat-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Alexandra and Stirling Silliphant were married in a ceremony at Chasen's Restaurant in West Hollywood on July 4, 1974. As reported by CBS News, the celebrity event included <a href="/wiki/Robert_Wagner" title="Robert Wagner">Robert Wagner</a>, <a href="/wiki/Natalie_Wood" title="Natalie Wood">Natalie Wood</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_Holden" title="William Holden">William Holden</a> and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Mancini" title="Henry Mancini">Henry Mancini</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-wedding_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wedding-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tiana_Alexandra&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hollywood_career">Hollywood career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tiana_Alexandra&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Hollywood career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Silliphant's blockbuster films <i><a href="/wiki/The_Poseidon_Adventure_(1972_film)" title="The Poseidon Adventure (1972 film)">The Poseidon Adventure</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Towering_Inferno" title="The Towering Inferno">The Towering Inferno</a></i>, coupled with his newlywed status with Alexandra, led to their joint appearances on television talk and game shows such as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Mike_Douglas_Show" title="The Mike Douglas Show">The Mike Douglas Show</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-SS_on_MD_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SS_on_MD-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> <i>The Reed Ferrell Show</i><sup id="cite_ref-Reed_Ferrel_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reed_Ferrel-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/Tattletales" title="Tattletales">Tattletales</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-Tattletales_youtube_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tattletales_youtube-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Tattletales_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tattletales-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> during the mid-1970s.
</p><p>Alexandra made her film debut in <a href="/wiki/Sam_Peckinpah" title="Sam Peckinpah">Sam Peckinpah</a>'s martial-arts thriller <i><a href="/wiki/The_Killer_Elite" title="The Killer Elite">The Killer Elite</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Robert_Duvall" title="Robert Duvall">Robert Duvall</a> and <a href="/wiki/James_Caan" title="James Caan">James Caan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> She was the first Vietnamese-American to join the <a href="/wiki/Screen_Actors_Guild" title="Screen Actors Guild">Screen Actors Guild</a>.
</p><p>In 1978, Alexandra starred with <a href="/wiki/Angie_Dickenson" class="mw-redirect" title="Angie Dickenson">Angie Dickenson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Wagner" title="Robert Wagner">Robert Wagner</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dennis_Weaver" title="Dennis Weaver">Dennis Weaver</a> as Holly Nagata in the <a href="/wiki/ABC_Television" title="ABC Television">ABC</a> mini-series <i><a href="/wiki/Pearl_(miniseries)" title="Pearl (miniseries)">Pearl</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-Pearl_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pearl-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> which dramatized the events surrounding the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor">Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor</a>.
</p><p>In 1981, Alexandra starred with <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Boxleitner" title="Bruce Boxleitner">Bruce Boxleitner</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brian_Dennehy" title="Brian Dennehy">Brian Dennehy</a> as Mai, a Vietnamese medic in the <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros." title="Warner Bros.">Warner Bros.</a> made-for-television feature film <i><a href="/wiki/Fly_Away_Home" title="Fly Away Home">Fly Away Home</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Fly_away_home_youtube_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fly_away_home_youtube-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fly_away_home_youtube_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fly_away_home_youtube-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-IMDb_Fly_Away_Home_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMDb_Fly_Away_Home-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> The film critically examined the entanglement of politics and human suffering on the ground during the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>.
</p><p>As an Asian actress breaking through racial stereotypes, Alexandra was invited to speak out on the realities of Hollywood typecasting at venues such as the Philippine Film Festival, where she appeared with Robert Duvall in the Symposium on Film Acting.<sup id="cite_ref-Philiphine_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Philiphine-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Alexandra starred as reporter Jan Du Long in an <a href="/wiki/Aaron_Spelling" title="Aaron Spelling">Aaron Spelling</a> produced made-for-TV movie <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Three_Kings_(1987_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Three Kings (1987 film) (page does not exist)">The Three Kings</a></i> (1987).<sup id="cite_ref-the_three_kings_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-the_three_kings-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-IMDb_The_Three_Kings_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMDb_The_Three_Kings-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> That same year she starred opposite <a href="/wiki/Rod_Steiger" title="Rod Steiger">Rod Steiger</a> as Checkers Goldberg in the Kung Fu feature sendup, <i>Catch The Heat</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-watermelon_seeds_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-watermelon_seeds-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-IMDb_Catch_the_Heat_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMDb_Catch_the_Heat-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>With her martial arts finesse at top form in 1986, Alexandra produced a fitness program called Karatecize, combining elements of dance, combat art and original pop music.<sup id="cite_ref-Karatecize_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Karatecize-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup> Martial arts champion Eric Lee collaborated with Alexandra on the self-defense segments of the show.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music_career">Music career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tiana_Alexandra&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Music career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Between 1983 and 1985, Alexandra was managed by <a href="/wiki/Bill_Wyman" title="Bill Wyman">Bill Wyman</a> of <a href="/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones" title="The Rolling Stones">The Rolling Stones</a> and created numerous pop songs and music videos for radio and <a href="/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">MTV</a>. Her "Dumped On",<sup id="cite_ref-Dumped_on_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dumped_on-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> "Lust In The Jungle",<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> and "Free As I Want To Be"<sup id="cite_ref-Free_as_i_want_to_be_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Free_as_i_want_to_be-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> music videos were shot on location in New Zealand, Hong Kong, Yugoslavia and Los Angeles.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>Alexandra's music video of Bruce Lee, "Feel The Heat", was revamped in congruence with the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences 40th Anniversary Celebration of Bruce Lee's breakout film, <i>Enter the Dragon</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bruce_Lee_&amp;_me_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bruce_Lee_&amp;_me-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="From_Hollywood_to_Hanoi"><i>From Hollywood to Hanoi</i></span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tiana_Alexandra&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: From Hollywood to Hanoi">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 1988, Alexandra began pre-production on her first film, <i>From Hollywood to Hanoi</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FHTH_hbo_promo_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FHTH_hbo_promo-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup> Stemming from a trip taken earlier that year with a delegation of Vietnam veterans and filmmakers (in part on the advice of Alexandra's acting teacher <a href="/wiki/Sandra_Seacat" title="Sandra Seacat">Sandra Seacat</a>, who predicted  that a return to Alexandra's roots would prove enormously empowering), the feature-length documentary was written, produced and directed by Alexandra, and executive produced by <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Stone" title="Oliver Stone">Oliver Stone</a>—who had himself taken part in Alexandra's delegation to Hanoi, and strongly urged her to record the experience on film.<sup id="cite_ref-IHT_FHTH_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IHT_FHTH-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> <i>From Hollywood to Hanoi</i> was the first American film shot on location in Viet Nam.
</p><p>It was shown at top film festivals<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> and movie theaters across the U.S. and highlighted the plight of <a href="/wiki/Amerasian" title="Amerasian">Amerasians</a>, as well as the devastating effects of <a href="/wiki/Agent_Orange" title="Agent Orange">Agent Orange</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> It received acclaimed by New York Times and LA Times, Wall Street Journal, Variety, Hollywood Report, Boston Globe, Playboy, Washington Post and Time Magazine.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup> Notable personalities including <a href="/wiki/Allen_Ginsberg" title="Allen Ginsberg">Allen Ginsberg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Stone" title="Oliver Stone">Oliver Stone</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Moore" title="Michael Moore">Michael Moore</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Studs_Terkel" title="Studs Terkel">Studs Turkel</a> became Alexandra's fans. But distribution was non-existent at the time for award-winning documentaries so the film's volunteer team led by the poet Steven Kauffman distributed the film in theaters and with Alexandra touring across America's college campuses.
</p><p>Alexandra is focusing on her Viet Nam Trilogy after her husband Stirling launched her on a mission of a lifetime to return to her roots in Viet Nam and make films for healing and reconciliation. Together with Oliver Stone they formed IndoChina Film Arts Foundation, a nonprofit organization also known as Film Arts Foundation International. With over 30 years of filming in Viet Nam, Alexandra owns the world's most extensive library of footage shot in post-war Viet Nam over the last 3 decades.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Post production will resume in Europe and Viet Nam to premiere April 30th 2025, the 50th anniversary of the Fall of Saigon/ Liberation of Vietnam. Alexandra collaborates with distinguished writers and playwrights including Oscar winner Christopher Hampton and legendary composer, Philip Glass.
</p><p><i>From Hollywood To Hanoi</i> went into theatrical release in 1995, and was broadcast as part of the HBO Cinemax <i>Vanguard Cinema</i> series.<sup id="cite_ref-FHTH_hbo_promo_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FHTH_hbo_promo-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup> It was well received by critics: Kevin Thomas of the LA Times lauded it as "moving and engrossing",<sup id="cite_ref-LAT_FHTH_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LAT_FHTH-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup> and Vincent Canby of The New York Times hailed it as "an intense, personal, supremely self-confident feature."<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_FHTH_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_FHTH-37">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The film was named "Best of the Fest" at <a href="/wiki/Telluride_Film_Festival" title="Telluride Film Festival">Telluride Film Festival</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-LAT_vietnamese_woman_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LAT_vietnamese_woman-38">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup> and was nominated for "Best Non-Fiction Film" at Sundance International Festival,<sup id="cite_ref-FHTH_sundance_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FHTH_sundance-39">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> where it was presented by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Moore" title="Michael Moore">Michael Moore</a>. The film was also screened on Capitol Hill to help lift the trade embargo by then <a href="/wiki/Senator_John_Kerry" class="mw-redirect" title="Senator John Kerry">Senator John Kerry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-John_Kerry_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-John_Kerry-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Alexandra was invited to participate in the International Women's Day with Betty Friedan, Stevie Wonder and Barbara Trent.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> Tiana made feature guest appearances to talk about her film on <a href="/wiki/The_Today_Show" class="mw-redirect" title="The Today Show">The Today Show</a> with <a href="/wiki/Bryant_Gumbel" title="Bryant Gumbel">Bryant Gumbel</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Today_Show_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Today_Show-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> The PBS News Hour with Charlayne Hunter Gault,<sup id="cite_ref-PBS_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PBS-43">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> and The KTLA Morning News with <a href="/wiki/Regis_Philbin" title="Regis Philbin">Regis Philbin</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Filming_Vietnamese_leaders">Filming Vietnamese leaders</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tiana_Alexandra&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Filming Vietnamese leaders">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>During three years of filming in Vietnam,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (February 2014)">when?</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Alexandra interviewed several former enemies of the U.S., who occupied high seats of power. They included <a href="/wiki/Ph%E1%BA%A1m_V%C4%83n_%C4%90%E1%BB%93ng" title="Phạm Văn Đồng">Phạm Văn Đồng</a>, and <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_%C4%90%E1%BB%A9c_Th%E1%BB%8D" title="Lê Đức Thọ">Lê Đức Thọ</a>, a politician and diplomat who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize along with United States Secretary of State <a href="/wiki/Henry_Kissinger" title="Henry Kissinger">Henry Kissinger</a> in 1973. Lê Đức Thọ declined the award.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Alexandra also conducted interviews with General <a href="/wiki/V%C3%B5_Nguy%C3%AAn_Gi%C3%A1p" title="Võ Nguyên Giáp">Võ Nguyên Giáp</a>, the man Ho Chi Minh appointed to lead the North Vietnamese Army, which was victorious over the French and the Americans in the Indochina and Vietnam Wars.<sup id="cite_ref-General_Giap_&amp;_Me_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-General_Giap_&amp;_Me-45">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup> She was the first Westerner to interview Giáp after the Vietnam War, and returned to interview him several times, along with his wife, Co Ha, and their children over the next 25 years.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Indochina_Film_Arts_Foundation">Indochina Film Arts Foundation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tiana_Alexandra&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Indochina Film Arts Foundation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The aftermath of the war and trade embargoes left Vietnam the fifth poorest country in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-poor_country_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-poor_country-46">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> Despite travel restrictions and her father's admonitions not to go, Alexandra returned to Vietnam with film crews to shoot From Hollywood to Hanoi, and a series of follow up films.
</p><p>Alexandra co-founded the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indochina_Film_Arts_Foundation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indochina Film Arts Foundation (page does not exist)">Indochina Film Arts Foundation</a> with <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Stone" title="Oliver Stone">Oliver Stone</a> in 1993 to organize cooperative projects in the fine arts, theater, film, educational workshops, lectures and radio broadcast. Projects were presented at the Viet Nam Cinema Dept. &amp; Filmmakers Association in Hanoi, the Asian American Film Festivals in New York City and Los Angeles, the Cinéma Festival du Réel at the Centre Pompidou in Paris, the Directors Guild of America in Hollywood, and the Washington Project for the Arts in Washington DC. Alexandra has been a featured radio guest on NPR's Fresh Air Program with Terry Gross,<sup id="cite_ref-fresh_air_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fresh_air-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> as well as the Pacifica Network stations WBAI FM in New York, KFAI FM in Minneapolis and KPFK FM in Los Angeles.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Alexandra has lectured at Bennington College, Bryn Mawr College, Harvard University, Columbia University, Notre Dame University, University of Southern California, Berkeley, University of California, Santa Barbara and Stanford University.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> She was a panelist in the "My Lai 25 Years After" conference at <a href="/wiki/Tulane_University" title="Tulane University">Tulane University</a>. Alexandra was also appointed Visiting Assistant Professor in the Department of Film Studies at Dartmouth College in 1993.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>Since 1998, the Indochina Film Arts Foundation has conducted ongoing production workshops to advance the skills of aspiring Vietnamese filmmakers. Operations are based at Riva Studios in <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Ho Chi Minh City</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hanoi_Cinematique&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hanoi Cinematique (page does not exist)">Hanoi Cinematique</a>.
</p><p>In 2013, Indochina Film Arts Foundation began doing business as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Film_Arts_Foundation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Film Arts Foundation (page does not exist)">Film Arts Foundation</a>.
</p>
<h3><span id="Ongoing_documentary.2C_education.2C_and_feature_film"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Ongoing_documentary,_education,_and_feature_film">Ongoing documentary, education, and feature film</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tiana_Alexandra&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Ongoing documentary, education, and feature film">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 2000, Alexandra explored the Plain of Jars region of Laos to document the effects of carpet-bombing and unexploded ordnance on local populations. Her Bomb Art Project collected scraps of ordnance for artists to fashion into sculpture. The Bomb Art Project and <i>Bombs Away</i> mini-documentary were publicly presented at the Bergamot Station Art Center in Los Angeles.<sup id="cite_ref-bombs_away_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bombs_away-48">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Alexandra also documented the 30th Anniversary Reunion of Associated Press War Photographers in Ho Chi Minh City in 2005. Her documentary, Requiem, featured Pulitzer Prize–winning journalists and photojournalists <a href="/wiki/Peter_Arnett" title="Peter Arnett">Peter Arnett</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nick_Ut" title="Nick Ut">Nick Ut</a>, as well as the local Vietnamese youth culture that had moved on from the war.
</p><p>In 2007, Alexandra went on world tour with Oscar and Tony winning author <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Hampton" title="Christopher Hampton">Christopher Hampton</a> to help manage and promote his work on the feature film <i><a href="/wiki/Atonement_(film)" title="Atonement (film)">Atonement</a></i>. Hampton was subsequently nominated for an Oscar for Best Writing (Adapted Screenplay) on the film.<sup id="cite_ref-Atonement_oscar_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atonement_oscar-49">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Tony_Award" title="Tony Award">Tony Award</a> Celebration was organized by Alexandra in 2009 in conjunction with the successful run of <a href="/wiki/Yazmina_Reza" class="mw-redirect" title="Yazmina Reza">Yazmina Reza</a>'s Broadway play <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_Carnage" title="God of Carnage">God of Carnage</a></i>. The event celebrated the play's seven Tony nominations and three wins, and honored author <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Hampton" title="Christopher Hampton">Christopher Hampton</a>'s 50 plays and screenplays.<sup id="cite_ref-Tony_Award_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tony_Award-50">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/James_Gandolfini" title="James Gandolfini">James Gandolfini</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marcia_Gay_Harden" title="Marcia Gay Harden">Marcia Gay Harden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philip_Glass" title="Philip Glass">Philip Glass</a> and <a href="/wiki/Phillip_Noyce" title="Phillip Noyce">Phillip Noyce</a> participated in the short documentary that Alexandra created from the event.<sup id="cite_ref-NY_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY-51">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2009 Alexandra filmed an odyssey to find the spirit of <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson" title="Michael Jackson">Michael Jackson</a> in Beverly Hills and Viet Nam, with <a href="/wiki/Le_Ly_Hayslip" title="Le Ly Hayslip">Le Ly Hayslip</a> - the author and subject of Oliver Stone's feature film <i><a href="/wiki/Heaven_%26_Earth_(1993_film)" title="Heaven &amp; Earth (1993 film)">Heaven and Earth</a></i>. Le Ly and Tiana visited the site of Jackson's death and documented the throngs of impersonators carrying on his legacy in both the U.S. and Vietnam.<sup id="cite_ref-Tiana_Le_Ly_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tiana_Le_Ly-52">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As co-owner of Christopher Hampton's stage play <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Talking_Cure&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Talking Cure (page does not exist)">The Talking Cure</a></i>, Alexandra was instrumental in developing the project into a feature film directed by <a href="/wiki/David_Cronenberg" title="David Cronenberg">David Cronenberg</a>. The film, retitled <i><a href="/wiki/A_Dangerous_Method" title="A Dangerous Method">A Dangerous Method</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-ADM_trailer_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ADM_trailer-53">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup> starred <a href="/wiki/Michael_Fassbender" title="Michael Fassbender">Michael Fassbender</a> as Swiss psychotherapist <a href="/wiki/Carl_Jung" title="Carl Jung">Carl Jung</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Keira_Knightley" title="Keira Knightley">Keira Knightley</a> as his patient and mistress. Alexandra is credited as Associate Producer on the 2011 release.<sup id="cite_ref-ADM_cast_and_crew_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ADM_cast_and_crew-54">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2012, Alexandra and Christopher Hampton formed Hampton Silliphant Management &amp; Productions, which presented the play <i>Appomattox</i> at the <a href="/wiki/Guthrie_Theater" title="Guthrie Theater">Guthrie Theater</a> in Minneapolis, Minnesota.<sup id="cite_ref-Appomattox_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Appomattox-55">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> The play concerns itself with historic events in America, 100 years apart in time: the historic meeting between Generals Ulysses S. Grant and Robert E. Lee in 1865, and the 1965 shooting of a Baptist church deacon during a peaceful civil rights protest in Alabama.
</p><p>Alexandra's film <i>The General &amp; Me</i><sup id="cite_ref-General_Giap_&amp;_Me_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-General_Giap_&amp;_Me-45">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup> focuses on her 25-year relationship with <a href="/wiki/General_Vo_Nguyen_Giap" class="mw-redirect" title="General Vo Nguyen Giap">General Võ Nguyên Giáp</a>, Ho Chi Minh's trusted military strategist during the Indochina and Vietnam Wars.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Filmography">Filmography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tiana_Alexandra&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Filmography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<dl><dt>As actress</dt></dl>
<ul><li>1975: <i><a href="/wiki/The_Killer_Elite" title="The Killer Elite">The Killer Elite</a></i> (alternative title: <i>The agents elite</i>) - Tommie</li>
<li>1978: <i><a href="/wiki/Pearl_(miniseries)" title="Pearl (miniseries)">Pearl</a></i> (alternative title: <i>Pearl Harbor</i>) (TV Mini-Series) - Holly Nagata</li>
<li>1981: <i>Fly Away Home</i> (TV Movie) - Mai</li>
<li>1987: <i><a href="/wiki/Catch_the_Heat" class="mw-redirect" title="Catch the Heat">Catch the Heat</a></i> (video title in the Federal Republic of Germany: <i>Fire Game</i>) - Checkers Goldberg</li>
<li>1987: <i>The Three Kings</i> (TV Movie) - Jan DuLong (final film role)</li></ul>
<dl><dt>As director</dt></dl>
<ul><li>1992: <i>From Hollywood to Hanoi</i></li>
<li>2017: <i>The General and Me</i></li></ul>
<dl><dt>As producer</dt></dl>
<ul><li>1992: <i>From Hollywood to Hanoi</i></li>
<li>2011: <i><a href="/wiki/A_Dangerous_Method" title="A Dangerous Method">A Dangerous Method</a></i></li></ul>
<dl><dt>Other performances (e.g. herself)</dt></dl>
<ul><li>1986: <i>Karatix</i></li>
<li>1992: <i>From Hollywood to Hanoi</i></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nominations">Nominations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tiana_Alexandra&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Nominations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>1993: Nominated for the "Grand Jury Prize" in the<i> Category: Documentary</i> (<i> Documentary</i>) the <a href="/wiki/Sundance_Film_Festival" title="Sundance Film Festival">Sundance Film Festival</a> for the film<i> <a href="/w/index.php?title=From_Hollywood_to_Hanoi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="From Hollywood to Hanoi (page does not exist)">From Hollywood to Hanoi</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>

<li id="cite_note-Academy_in_the_heat-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Academy_in_the_heat_11-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1968">"The 40th Academy Awards (1968) Nominees and Winners"</a>. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+40th+Academy+Awards+%281968%29+Nominees+and+Winners&amp;rft.pub=The+Academy+of+Motion+Picture+Arts+and+Sciences&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oscars.org%2Foscars%2Fceremonies%2F1968&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATiana+Alexandra" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-34">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFCanby1993" class="citation web cs1">Canby, Vincent (July 21, 1993). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9F0CE2D7153EF932A15754C0A965958260">"From Hollywood To Hanoi (1992) Review/Film"</a>. <i>The New York Times</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-56"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-56">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104306/awards?ref_=tt_awd">"IMDB Awards - Sundance Film Festival 1993"</a>. <a href="/wiki/IMDb" title="IMDb">IMDb</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">May 2,</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=IMDB+Awards+-+Sundance+Film+Festival+1993&amp;rft.pub=IMDb&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.imdb.com%2Ftitle%2Ftt0104306%2Fawards%3Fref_%3Dtt_awd&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATiana+Alexandra" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
</ol></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tiana_Alexandra&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0018837/">Tiana Alexandra</a> on <a href="/wiki/IMDb" title="IMDb">IMDb</a></li></ul></div>
~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">November 2019</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <b>Alhambra Bioscope</b>, also known as the <b>Alhambra Theatre</b>, was a theatre that opened on Riebeek Street, <a href="/wiki/Cape_Town" title="Cape Town">Cape Town</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a> in 1929.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Alhambra_Theatre_(Cape_Town)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The Alhambra was built in 1928 for Harry Stodel's African Consolidated Theatres. It was called South Africa's best "atmospheric theatre."<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-esa-201_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-esa-201-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> It had a unique <a href="/wiki/Wurlitzer" title="Wurlitzer">Wurlitzer</a> <a href="/wiki/Theatre_organ" title="Theatre organ">theatre organ</a> that could produce many sound effects.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> It opened in 1929 and for years was one of Cape Town's greatest theaters.
</p><p>Plays and musicals were also presented for four decades in the theatre. Among the great entertainers to perform here were <a href="/wiki/Marlene_Dietrich" title="Marlene Dietrich">Marlene Dietrich</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nellie_du_Toit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nellie du Toit (page does not exist)">Nellie du Toit</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> Angelo Gobbato,<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Phyllis_Spira" title="Phyllis Spira">Phyllis Spira</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The only <a href="/wiki/Afrikaans_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Afrikaans language">Afrikaans language</a> theater company to perform here, according to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Andr%C3%A9_Huguenet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="André Huguenet (page does not exist)">André Huguenet</a>, was his company with its production of <i>Is Jy ’n Bokryer?</i> in the 1940s.<sup id="cite_ref-esa-201_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-esa-201-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> It was also sometimes used by <a href="/w/index.php?title=KRUIK&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="KRUIK (page does not exist)">KRUIK</a> (the Cape Performing Arts Council).
</p><p>The building closed in January 1972 and was sold in 1974.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Alhambra_Theatre_(Cape_Town)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">March 2013</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="box-Advert plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Advert" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article <b>contains content that is written like <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:What_Wikipedia_is_not#Wikipedia_is_not_a_soapbox_or_means_of_promotion" title="Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not">an advertisement</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=AlphaSphere_(instrument)&amp;action=edit">improve it</a> by removing <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Spam" title="Wikipedia:Spam">promotional content</a> and inappropriate <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:External_links#Advertising_and_conflicts_of_interest" title="Wikipedia:External links">external links</a>, and by adding encyclopedic content written from a <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Neutral_point_of_view" title="Wikipedia:Neutral point of view">neutral point of view</a>.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">December 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>AlphaSphere</b> is an <a href="/wiki/Electronic_musical_instrument" title="Electronic musical instrument">electronic musical instrument</a> that was designed and developed by <b>nu desine</b>, a British company. The primary concept of the AlphaSphere is to increase the level of expression available to electronic musicians,<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> by allowing for the playing style of a musical instrument. Even before the product had been fully developed it had appeared at many events worldwide including the <a href="/wiki/NAMM_Show" title="NAMM Show">NAMM Show</a>, <a href="/wiki/Musikmesse" class="mw-redirect" title="Musikmesse">Musikmesse</a>, <a href="/wiki/TED_(conference)" title="TED (conference)">TEDx</a> conferences, and the Future Everything Festival,<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> and received press from popular organisations such as <a href="/wiki/Sound_on_Sound" title="Sound on Sound">Sound on Sound</a>, <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wired_(magazine)" title="Wired (magazine)">Wired</a> and <a href="/wiki/MusicRadar" title="MusicRadar">MusicRadar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> There are currently two different AlphaSphere models - the <b>nexus series</b> and the <b>elite series</b>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=AlphaSphere_(instrument)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The initial concept of AlphaSphere was conceived while company founder Adam Place was studying at the <a href="/wiki/Nagoya_University_of_Arts" title="Nagoya University of Arts">Nagoya University of Arts</a> in Japan where he produced an initial prototype.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
In September 2010 Adam was commissioned by Media Sandbox, a development funding scheme which is part of Bristol's <a href="/wiki/Watershed_(Bristol)" title="Watershed (Bristol)">Watershed</a> subsidiary iShed, to further develop his concept by researching into smart materials.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> This spawned the birth of nu desine which soon developed into a team that specialise in <a href="/wiki/Music_technology" title="Music technology">music technology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electronics_engineering" class="mw-redirect" title="Electronics engineering">electronics engineering</a>, <a href="/wiki/Product_design" title="Product design">product design</a>, <a href="/wiki/Software_development" title="Software development">software development</a> and <a href="/wiki/User_interface_design" title="User interface design">user interface design</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2012 nu desine announced they had started taking pre-orders for a limited edition <b>elite series</b> AlphaSphere,<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> with the first batch of elite AlphaSphere's being shipped in March 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> In July 2013 nu desine announced the <b>nexus series</b>,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> the standard version of the AlphaSphere. This was shortly followed by the instrument being available in musical instrument retail stores in both United States and Japan, and then in November 2013 it became available to UK and <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> through the AlphaSphere website.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The AlphaSphere is currently being used by several high-profile artists such as <a href="/wiki/Talvin_Singh" title="Talvin Singh">Talvin Singh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Enter_Shikari" title="Enter Shikari">Enter Shikari</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Features">Features</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=AlphaSphere_(instrument)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Features">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The nexus series is the standard AlphaSphere model. Characteristics of this model are:
</p>
<ul><li>An ergonomic and modular spherical design.</li>
<li>48 tactile, elasticated pads that respond to touch, velocity, and pressure. The pressure sensitivity allows for real-time modulation of audio parameters of each played note/sound individually.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/USB" title="USB">USB</a> connectivity and power which communicates with software via the <a href="/wiki/Human_interface_device" title="Human interface device">HID</a> and <a href="/wiki/MIDI" title="MIDI">MIDI</a> protocols.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Light-emitting_diode" title="Light-emitting diode">LEDs</a> that react to touch and pressure input.</li>
<li>As a MIDI instrument the AlphaSphere is fully compatible with polyphonic <a href="/wiki/Keyboard_expression#Pressure_sensitivity" title="Keyboard expression">aftertouch</a> and multichannel MIDI.</li>
<li>Custom software called <b>AlphaLive</b> that can be used as the device's MIDI mapping editor, and also has its own <a href="/wiki/Sampler_(musical_instrument)" title="Sampler (musical instrument)">sampler</a> and <a href="/wiki/Music_Sequencer" class="mw-redirect" title="Music Sequencer">sequencer</a> capabilities, as well as allowing MIDI messages to be converted to <a href="/wiki/Open_Sound_Control" title="Open Sound Control">OSC</a>. Both the software and the <a href="/wiki/Firmware" title="Firmware">firmware</a> are <a href="/wiki/Open-source_software" title="Open-source software">open source</a>.</li>
<li>Infinitely programmable. Though there are a number of suggested notational arrangements, there is no set note or function for each pad - <a href="/wiki/Musical_note" title="Musical note">note</a> layouts and <a href="/wiki/Musical_scale" class="mw-redirect" title="Musical scale">scales</a> can be set over the pads as desired as well the mode of each pad and the parameters that the pressure modulates. This also lends itself to be useful for alternative notational layouts, such as the <a href="/wiki/Harmonic_table_note_layout" title="Harmonic table note layout">Harmonic table</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wicki-Hayden_note_layout" class="mw-redirect" title="Wicki-Hayden note layout">Wicki-Hayden</a> note layouts that are well suited to the <a href="/wiki/Hexagonal_lattice" title="Hexagonal lattice">Hexagonal lattice</a> pad layout.</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Limited_Edition_Elite_Model">Limited Edition Elite Model</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=AlphaSphere_(instrument)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Limited Edition Elite Model">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The elite series is the high-end AlphaSphere model. It comes with all the features of the AlphaSphere nexus, plus the following extra features:
</p>
<ul><li>Hardware MIDI-out port</li>
<li>Two freely assignable dials</li>
<li>Three freely assignable buttons</li>
<li>High-end, soft-touch finish</li>
<li>Available in black</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=AlphaSphere_(instrument)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/List_of_musical_instruments#Electronic_instruments" title="List of musical instruments">List of musical instruments#Electronic instruments</a></li></ul>

<table class="box-Unreliable_sources plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-unreliable_sources" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg" class="image"><img alt="Text document with red question mark.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/40px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/60px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/80px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="48" data-file-height="48" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">Some of this article's <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">listed sources</a> <b>may not be <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources">reliable</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help this article by looking for better, more reliable sources. Unreliable citations may be challenged or deleted.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">July 2015</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Anita Altman</b> (born June 2, 1945) is a social entrepreneur and city planner. She helped develop <a href="/wiki/Naturally_Occurring_Retirement_Communities" class="mw-redirect" title="Naturally Occurring Retirement Communities">Naturally Occurring Retirement Communities</a> (NORCs) into a federally funded program.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> She is the co-founder of <a href="/wiki/ReelAbilities" title="ReelAbilities">ReelAbilities</a>, US's largest film festival dedicated to showcasing films by, or about, people with disabilities.<sup id="cite_ref-wnyc.org_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wnyc.org-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> She is an active <a href="/wiki/Jewish_feminism" title="Jewish feminism">Jewish Feminist</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>  an important progressive voice in the Jewish community,<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> and a member of NYC's <a href="/wiki/B%27nai_Jeshurun_(Manhattan)" title="B&#39;nai Jeshurun (Manhattan)">B’Nai Jeshrun synagogue</a>. Altman is the mother of <a href="/wiki/Sascha_Altman_DuBrul" title="Sascha Altman DuBrul">Sascha Altman DuBrul</a>, co-founder of the <a href="/wiki/Icarus_Project" title="Icarus Project">Icarus Project</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anita_Altman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Altman was raised in a working-class Greek Jewish community in the East Bronx. Her grandparents, Anna and Zadick Coffino, were <a href="/wiki/Romaniote_Jews" title="Romaniote Jews">Romaniote Jews</a>, emigrated from what was then the Ottoman Empire to the Lower East Side of Manhattan, before settling in <a href="/wiki/Hunts_Point,_Bronx" title="Hunts Point, Bronx">Hunts Point</a><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
Her father, Jack Altman, an <a href="/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jews" title="Ashkenazi Jews">Ashkanazi Jew</a> who married Sarah their daughter, was a plumber. She has one older brother Stanley Altman, who is now a professor at <a href="/wiki/Baruch_College" title="Baruch College">Baruch College</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Altman attended the all-girls' <a href="/wiki/Hunter_College_High_School" title="Hunter College High School">Hunter College High School</a> and credits it with changing the course of her life.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> She received her B.A. in Political Science from <a href="/wiki/The_City_College_of_New_York" class="mw-redirect" title="The City College of New York">The City College of New York</a> in 1967, and a Master of Professional Studies in Health Services Administration from the <a href="/wiki/New_School_for_Social_Research" class="mw-redirect" title="New School for Social Research">New School for Social Research</a> in 1982. In 2014 Altman was awarded the City Colleges' Alumni Association's Townsend Harris medal for outstanding post-graduate achievement.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_career">Early career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anita_Altman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Early career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>While working at <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_City_Planning" title="New York City Department of City Planning">New York City's Planning Department</a>, Altman participated in developing the Master Plan for the city.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> In New York's Health Services Administration, she played a leading role in upgrading prison health services. As the Director of Community Development for Co-op City (hired by the residents in the aftermath of the largest rent strike in American history), she organized and directed human service providers and mounted a wide array of cultural programs.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> As Deputy Director of <a href="/wiki/Montefiore_Medical_Center" title="Montefiore Medical Center">Montefiore Medical Center's Building Program</a>, Altman worked with hospital administrators, architects, the City Planning Commission, and community representatives to help plan the reconstruction and expansion of its physical plant. For ten years (1973–83), Altman served on <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Community_Board_7" title="Manhattan Community Board 7">Manhattan's Community Board 7</a>, and was the co-chair of its Social and Health Care Services sub-committee, for a number of those years.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="AIDS.2FHIV_and_NORCs"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="AIDS/HIV_and_NORCs">AIDS/HIV and NORCs</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anita_Altman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: AIDS/HIV and NORCs">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In 1987, Altman began working at the <a href="/wiki/UJA-Federation_of_New_York" title="UJA-Federation of New York">UJA-Federation</a> and spearheaded the first grant proposal to fund “A Jewish Response to the AIDS Epidemic,” which helped establish training and educational programs and create service programs linking hospitals and community-based agencies. UJA-Federation became one of the five founding members of the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150530025428/http://www.nyhiv.com/policy_advocacy_state_ny_aids_coalition.html">New York AIDS Coalition</a>, which emerged as the largest AIDS advocacy organization in New York State.
</p><p>Altman also played an instrumental role in its embrace of <a href="/wiki/Naturally_Occurring_Retirement_Communities" class="mw-redirect" title="Naturally Occurring Retirement Communities">Naturally Occurring Retirement Communities</a> (NORCs), as environments in which to organize communities with substantial senior populations.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> As Altman herself puts it, an increasing number of seniors must be enabled “to age in place.”<sup id="cite_ref-thejewishweek.com_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thejewishweek.com-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-JPRO_Spring2006_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JPRO_Spring2006-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> Altman was instrumental in promulgating the program concepts pioneered at <a href="/wiki/Penn_South" title="Penn South">Penn South</a>, a union-sponsored, moderate-income housing co-op in Manhattan's Chelsea community,<sup id="cite_ref-thejewishweek.com_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thejewishweek.com-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> There, a program with the express goal of helping senior residents to remain living in their own home, even as they grew older and frailer, was organized. This supportive service program (SSP), mobilized the community and built partnerships between senior residents, housing management, and health and social service agencies to achieve that end.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>With the support of the Robert Wood Foundation, the program was successfully replicated and in 1994 the New York State Legislature passed the first NORC-SSP legislation in the country, providing matching grants to an original 10 programs. This was followed in 1999 by the establishment of the New York City NORC funded by its City Council. Today in New York State there are over 50 publicly funded NORC-SSP communities with over 60,000 senior residents living in supportive communities.<sup id="cite_ref-JPRO_Spring2006_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JPRO_Spring2006-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1993, Altman convened a group of authorities in related fields to address the question of domestic violence in the Jewish community. This resulted in her founding the professionally led UJA-Federation Task Force on Family Violence, which in 2001 received the New York State Governor's COURAGE award.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> Altman herself was honored for this work in 2008 when she received the Woman of Valor award from the New York Board of Rabbis.
</p><p>Altman also founded the UJA-Federation Task Force on People with Disabilities which became a vehicle for planning, learning and advocacy that has brought, in partnership with the J. E. &amp; Z.B. Butler Foundation and its agency network the transformation of services for people with disabilities and their families in many communities throughout the New York metro area.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="ReelAbilities_Film_Festival">ReelAbilities Film Festival</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anita_Altman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: ReelAbilities Film Festival">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>During her work with the UJA Task Force on People with Disabilities, Altman recognized that policy needed to go hand in hand with changes in public perception and culture: “We are in the midst of a civil rights movement. People with disabilities are increasingly making their voice and presence known and wanting us, the rest of the society, to step up to the plate.”<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> She believed that films could be an effective medium to help create wider public awareness about people with disabilities.<sup id="cite_ref-wnyc.org_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wnyc.org-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> In partnership with the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jccmanhattan.org/">Jewish Community Center in Manhattan</a>, she founded <a href="/wiki/ReelAbilities" title="ReelAbilities">ReelAbilities</a>: New York Disabilities Film Festival. As a UJA-Federation press release put it, it was and remains “the brainchild of Anita Altman.”<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/ReelAbilities" title="ReelAbilities">ReelAbilities</a> is now the largest film festival in the country dedicated to promoting awareness and appreciation of people with different disabilities, with 13 cities currently sponsoring festivals in their own communities. Altman herself has said, “It is a festival with a social mission, namely to change public perception and understanding of who are people with disabilities.”<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anita_Altman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">September 2012</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Takashi Amano (天野尚)</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Takashi_Amano.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Takashi Amano.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/19/Takashi_Amano.jpg/220px-Takashi_Amano.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="292" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/1/19/Takashi_Amano.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="264" data-file-height="350" /></a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td>July 18, 1954<br /><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace"><a href="/wiki/Niigata,_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Niigata, Japan">Niigata, Japan</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Died</th><td>August 4, 2015<span style="display:none">(2015-08-04)</span> (aged&#160;61)<br /><div style="display:inline" class="deathplace">Niigata, Japan</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Nationality</th><td class="category">Japanese</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Known&#160;for</th><td><a href="/wiki/Photographer" title="Photographer">Photographer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aquarist" title="Aquarist">aquarist</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Awards</th><td>Fuji Film Nature Photo Contest, Grand Prix, 1992</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Takashi Amano</b><span style="font-weight: normal"> (<span lang="ja" title="Japanese language text">天野尚</span>, <i lang="ja-Latn" title="Hepburn transliteration">Amano Takashi</i>, 18 July 1954 – 4 August 2015)</span> was a professional <a href="/wiki/Track_cycling" title="Track cycling">track cyclist</a>, <a href="/wiki/Photographer" title="Photographer">photographer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Designer" title="Designer">designer</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Aquarist" title="Aquarist">aquarist</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> His interest in <a href="/wiki/Aquarium" title="Aquarium">aquaria</a> led him to create the Japanese company Aqua Design Amano.
</p><p>Amano was the author of <i>Nature Aquarium World</i> (<a href="/wiki/TFH_Publications" title="TFH Publications">TFH Publications</a>, 1994), a three-book series on <a href="/wiki/Aquascaping" title="Aquascaping">aquascaping</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freshwater_aquarium_plant_species" class="mw-redirect" title="Freshwater aquarium plant species">freshwater aquarium plants</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_freshwater_aquarium_fish_species" title="List of freshwater aquarium fish species">fish</a>. He has also published the book <i>Aquarium Plant Paradise</i> (TFH Publications, 1997).
</p><p>A species of freshwater shrimp is named the “Amano shrimp” or "Yamato shrimp" (<i><a href="/wiki/Caridina_multidentata" title="Caridina multidentata">Caridina multidentata</a></i>; previously <i>Caridina japonica</i>) after him. After discovering this species' ability to eat large quantities of algae, Amano asked a local distributor to special order several thousand of them.<sup id="cite_ref-NAW1_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NAW1-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> They have since become a staple in the freshwater planted aquarium hobby.
</p><p>He also developed a line of aquarium components that are known as Aqua Design Amano (ADA), and his "Nature Aquarium" article series appeared monthly in both <i><a href="/wiki/Practical_Fishkeeping" title="Practical Fishkeeping">Practical Fishkeeping</a></i> magazine in the UK, and <i><a href="/wiki/Tropical_Fish_Hobbyist" title="Tropical Fish Hobbyist">Tropical Fish Hobbyist</a></i> magazine in the US. He died of pneumonia<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> in 2015 at the age of 61.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Aquarist"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Aquarist</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-2"><a href="#Amano_shrimp"><span class="tocnumber">1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Amano shrimp</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Forests_Underwater_at_Lisbon_Oceanarium"><span class="tocnumber">1.2</span> <span class="toctext">Forests Underwater at Lisbon Oceanarium</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Photography_career"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Photography career</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#G8_Hokkaido_Toyako_Summit"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">G8 Hokkaido Toyako Summit</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#Bibliography"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Bibliography</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Aquarist">Aquarist</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Takashi_Amano&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Aquarist">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Aquascaping#Nature_style" title="Aquascaping">Aquascaping §&#160;Nature style</a></div>
<p>Takashi Amano wrote about <a href="/wiki/Freshwater_aquarium" title="Freshwater aquarium">freshwater</a> <a href="/wiki/Aquascaping" title="Aquascaping">aquascaping</a>. He established a distinctive style of plant layout.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> He employed <a href="/wiki/Japanese_garden" title="Japanese garden">Japanese gardening</a> concepts such as <a href="/wiki/Wabi-sabi" title="Wabi-sabi">wabi-sabi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zen" title="Zen">Zen</a> rock arrangement. His tank compositions sought to  mimic nature in their appearance. Amano also made extensive use of <a href="/wiki/Phrymaceae" title="Phrymaceae"><i>Glossostigma elatinoides</i></a> and <i><a href="/wiki/Riccia_fluitans" title="Riccia fluitans">Riccia fluitans</a></i> as plant material.
</p><p>He founded Aqua Design Amano Co., Ltd. in 1982, providing aquatic plant growing equipment. His photo books of what he called the "Nature Aquarium", <i>Glass no Naka no Daishizen</i>, published in 1992, followed by <i>Mizu-Shizen eno kaiki</i>, were translated into seven languages.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Amano_shrimp">Amano shrimp</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Takashi_Amano&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Amano shrimp">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Amano2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Amano2.jpg/220px-Amano2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="126" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Amano2.jpg/330px-Amano2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Amano2.jpg/440px-Amano2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="586" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Amano2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Amano shrimp (<i>Caridina multidentata</i>)</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Caridina_multidentata" title="Caridina multidentata">Amano shrimp</a> (<i>Caridina multidentata</i>) was introduced to the aquatic hobby by Takashi Amano as a means of controlling the growth of <a href="/wiki/Algae" title="Algae">algae</a> in the 1980s. The shrimp was therefore named after him.<sup id="cite_ref-Amano_shrimp_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Amano_shrimp-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Forests_Underwater_at_Lisbon_Oceanarium">Forests Underwater at Lisbon Oceanarium</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Takashi_Amano&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Forests Underwater at Lisbon Oceanarium">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>This exhibit is one of Amano's major works. It features a tropical freshwater aquascape at the <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Oceanarium" title="Lisbon Oceanarium">Lisbon Oceanarium</a>. The aquarium is 40 metres (130&#160;ft) in length holding 160,000 litres (35,000&#160;imp&#160;gal; 42,000&#160;US&#160;gal) of water with more than 10,000 fish of 40 different species. The exhibit was opened on April 21, 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-Exhibit_at_Lisbon_Oceanarium_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Exhibit_at_Lisbon_Oceanarium-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-All_about_massive_40m_nature_aquarium_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-All_about_massive_40m_nature_aquarium-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Photography_career">Photography career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Takashi_Amano&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Photography career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Starting in 1975, Amano visited tropical rainforests in Amazon, Borneo and West Africa and pristine forests in Japan, creating a series of photos focusing on "untouched nature" with large-format cameras. He captured minute details of nature on extra large size films (up to 8 × 20 inches). His works have been introduced internationally through several exhibitions and publications.
</p><p>Amano gave lectures on his photographic expeditions and his experiences in nature around the world, and he advocated for the environmental importance of <a href="/wiki/Tree_planting" title="Tree planting">tree planting</a> programs. He was a member of the <a href="/wiki/Japan_Professional_Photographers_Society" title="Japan Professional Photographers Society">Japan Professional Photographers Society</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Japan_Advertising_Photographers%27_Association" title="Japan Advertising Photographers&#39; Association">Japan Advertising Photographers' Association</a>, the <a href="/wiki/International_Environment_Photographers_Association" title="International Environment Photographers Association">International Environment Photographers Association</a>, and the Society of Scientific Photography.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="G8_Hokkaido_Toyako_Summit">G8 Hokkaido Toyako Summit</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Takashi_Amano&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: G8 Hokkaido Toyako Summit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Two landscape photos of Takashi Amano were displayed at the <a href="/wiki/34th_G8_summit" title="34th G8 summit">34th G8 summit</a> Working Lunch / Outreach Working Session of Hokkaido Tokyo Summit held July 7–9, 2008. The photos of a cedar forest on Sado Island taken with an 8 × 20 inch large format camera were exhibited on the 4 × 1.5 m panels.
</p>
