</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_and_background">Early life and background</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nahid_Angha&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life and background">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Angha is the daughter of the 20th century Persian Sufi master Moulana Shah Maghsoud (d. 1980) of the Uwaiysi lineage.<sup id="cite_ref-MSM_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSM-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> Her mother, Mah Talat Etemad Moghadam (d. 2012), was from one of the prominent Persian families, and a descendant of Etemad Saltaneh<sup id="cite_ref-Sultaneh1_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sultaneh1-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> whose journals and memoirs remained as one of the important manuscripts on Qajar Dynasty, Iran.<sup id="cite_ref-Khatirat_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Khatirat-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> Her father appointed her to teach and lead Sufi gatherings when she was in her early twenties. She initially held gatherings at her father's Khaneghah in Sufi Abad, Iran, she continued to teach in the United States. Angha has studied at the University of Teheran, Iran; SW Missouri State University, US; and University of Exeter, UK, and has doctorate degrees in Psychology and in Islamic Studies. Angha has two daughters, Hamaseh and Sahar and she lives in California with her family. She began her humanitarian, interreligious collaboration and peace efforts in the US in the early 1980s and continues those efforts today.<sup id="cite_ref-HopeHealing_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HopeHealing-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Spiritual.2C_educational.2C_and_advocacy_initiatives"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Spiritual,_educational,_and_advocacy_initiatives">Spiritual, educational, and advocacy initiatives</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nahid_Angha&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Spiritual, educational, and advocacy initiatives">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Angha, together with her husband <a href="/wiki/Ali_Kianfar" title="Ali Kianfar">Ali Kianfar</a>, co-founded the International Association of Sufism(IAS), a California non-profit devoted to the teachings of Sufism and Sufi Masters of the past and present (1983).<sup id="cite_ref-IASAbout_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IASAbout-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> Historically, Sufis have made great contributions to the development of science, literature, poetic styles, astronomy, architectural designs, and more.<sup id="cite_ref-SufiScience_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SufiScience-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> The International Association of Sufism has as its mission to make known the interrelations between Sufi principles and scientific principles through lectures, publications, <i>Sufism An Inquiry Journal</i>, and creating a forum for a continuing dialogue among Sufis from around the world. Angha has said that it took her about ten years to gather Sufi schools and Sufi masters from around the globe for the first Annual Sufism Symposium, a weekend conversation in March 1994; she considers organizing that Symposium one of her greatest achievements.<sup id="cite_ref-AnghaReport_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AnghaReport-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup>  Her vision and tireless works brought together Sufis masters and schools from around the globe,<sup id="cite_ref-SFGate_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SFGate-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> an unprecedented effort that made the International Association of Sufism the first organization ever created to initiate a global intra-faith movement within the Sufi community, and she became one of the leading Sufi voices for women's rights.<sup id="cite_ref-WhiteFire_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WhiteFire-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> As a response to the need at the time, she expanded the IAS' roles to include humanitarian, interfaith collaboration,<sup id="cite_ref-WorldCouncil_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WorldCouncil-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> and human rights advocacy.<sup id="cite_ref-Clarion_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Clarion-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> Through her efforts IAS received a UN NGO/DPI status, in 1997, and her peace works have also made the IAS a Messenger of UNESCO's Manifesto 2000 for contributing to a Culture of Peace and Non-Violence. She serves as IAS main representative to the NGO/DPI.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>In 2015 she celebrated the twentieth anniversary of the Sufism Symposium, and published the history and the biography of over 140 Sufis masters and interfaith leaders who have participated and presented during those twenty years in Caravan: Biographies from Sufism Symposia 1994–2014.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>In support of and to advocate for expressive art and to honor the roles of sacred lyrics, hymns and songs of faith traditions in our social justice and civil rights movements,<sup id="cite_ref-BB2014_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BB2014-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> she organized the Songs of the Soul Poetry and Sacred Music Festival, 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-SotSMIC_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SotSMIC-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> and <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ias.org/buildingbridges/building-bridges-expressions-2014-session-2/">Building Bridges of Understanding: Expressions in 2014</a>, highlighting the beauty of poetry and sacred music in spirituality and faith traditions.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="International_Sufi_Women_Organization">International Sufi Women Organization</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nahid_Angha&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: International Sufi Women Organization">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Women have played important roles in the development of art, science, education, entertainment, politics and more, yet the field of religion remains one of the most challenging for women's leadership. It is important to also acknowledge women who, through their endeavors and perseverance, have made contributions towards equality<sup id="cite_ref-KingsCal_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KingsCal-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> and freedom in the field of religion and spirituality. Angha has been one of those pioneers whose vision of and works towards humanitarian efforts, inter-religious dialogue and intra-religious movement, equality,  peace, and freedom have played fundamental roles in creating the International Sufi Women Organization in 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-IASSWO_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IASSWO-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Breaking_gender_roles">Breaking gender roles</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nahid_Angha&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Breaking gender roles">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Angha has made a point in her work to redefine the social standard for gender roles in the Sufi religious context.<sup id="cite_ref-MuslimahSpeaks_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MuslimahSpeaks-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> At the 1994 Sufism Symposium, as the first Sufi woman sitting together with male leaders in the center circle of zikr, a position historically reserved for men, she led meditation and paved the way for other Muslim women to participate and lead in Sufi worship.<sup id="cite_ref-History_Sufism_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-History_Sufism-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup> Her efforts continue to create forums for harmonious, global, peaceful dialogue<sup id="cite_ref-WomenChange_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WomenChange-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> within Sufi communities as well as normalizing the leadership of Sufi women in the traditional Sufi gatherings.<sup id="cite_ref-WISE_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WISE-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Global_dialogue.2C_humanitarian_efforts.2C_women.27s_leadership"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Global_dialogue,_humanitarian_efforts,_women's_leadership">Global dialogue, humanitarian efforts, women's leadership</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nahid_Angha&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Global dialogue, humanitarian efforts, women&#039;s leadership">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Through her efforts and the works of many Sufi women from around the globe, the Sufi Women Organization was able to create a global dialogue among women of different cultures and spiritual backgrounds<sup id="cite_ref-NewParadigm_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NewParadigm-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> with the goals to promote women's rights, promote the right to education, and to create social awareness as a pathway towards peace. In 1999, it held its first international conference on Women's Wisdom, Women in Action<sup id="cite_ref-Womeninaction_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Womeninaction-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup> which hosted women leaders from diverse spiritual and cultural backgrounds for a weekend conversation in 1999. The Organization has also created a thirteen-article Code of Ethics to promote human rights, the right to education, equality, support those who are oppressed or abused, and promote equality of genders in both spiritual and secular domains. Angha organized a series of workshops and round table discussions on the prevention of domestic violence in 2004 and 2005 in California, as well as a round table research program series on cross-cultural study of Middle Eastern families recently migrated to the US, which studied and discussed how they were coping with the new culture, language, and environment, and sought how to learn the pressures of the new environment affect spousal relationships, parent/child relationships, parent/teen relationships, and sibling relationships.<sup id="cite_ref-SWOFamily_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SWOFamily-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Angha has organized a team of well-accomplished women to oversee the Sufi Women Organization's women's leadership series, begun in 1993. She has also initiated a youth organization with a multi-religious, multicultural unified voice to advocate for children's rights, Voice for Justice, which has earned ambassadorship status from UNICEF, created programs such as: Summer 2016 free breakfast for school children of low-income families<sup id="cite_ref-vfjfood_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vfjfood-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> and has partnered with several humanitarian organizations to support the well-being of all including social justice programs; and HIV/AIDs prevention; Aids Walk; Cancer Awareness; Education: Adopt a classroom, and more.<sup id="cite_ref-VFJAmbassadors_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VFJAmbassadors-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Partnerships:_humanitarian_and_peacemaking_efforts">Partnerships: humanitarian and peacemaking efforts</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nahid_Angha&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Partnerships: humanitarian and peacemaking efforts">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Angha says that globalization leads to partnership, and valuable partnership expands the mission of organizations, and following her own ideology, she has initiated partnerships with other like-minded organizations to establish greater possibilities to contribute towards humanitarian efforts. Through these partnerships, IAS and SWO and its Chapters, both local and international, were able to expand their charitable efforts to include care for children caught in refugee and migrant crises; providing basic medicine and clean water in refugee areas; educational scholarship; ending HIV through training local nurses; orphan care; health education; mobile health clinics in Africa; and in California, SWO was able to contribute towards medical case management, free testing, and free syringes in its work to end HIV by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-HRW_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HRW-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Her continual advocacy for non-violent solutions for women and children in conflict areas<sup id="cite_ref-HRW_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HRW-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SWOAchievements_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SWOAchievements-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup> has led her to participate in peace campaigns, including National Interreligious Leadership Initiative For Peace In The Middle East,<sup id="cite_ref-Bishops_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bishops-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup> "The Millennium World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders," and present talks<sup id="cite_ref-SAND_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SAND-37">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SpiritMatters_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SpiritMatters-38">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup> regarding women's rights and humanitarian intervention, such as: "Human rights, responsibilities and spirituality" at the 53rd Annual United Nations DPI/NGO Conference at the UN Headquarters; "Women in Islam: Sufi Women &amp; Human Rights," Cape Town 1999; "Human Dignity and the New Frontier of Science," Italy; she has also written many articles on those topics.<sup id="cite_ref-FUJI_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FUJI-39">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Interfaith_.28partial_list.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Interfaith_(partial_list)">Interfaith (partial list)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nahid_Angha&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Interfaith (partial list)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Her works in collaboration with inter-religious organizations and faith traditions began in the early 1980s. She has served in many-faith based organizations (1983–2016), including as a Board member as well as a President of the Board of Directors of the Interfaith Center at the Presidio, San Francisco; the Board of Directors of the Marin Interfaith Council; a Founding member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Religions_Initiative" title="United Religions Initiative">United Religions Initiative</a> (URI) Council for Women; the Board of Directors of Marin Museum of American Indian; a Member of the Assembly of the Parliament of the World Religions, Cape Town and Barcelona; a Member of the National Interreligious Leadership Delegation;<sup id="cite_ref-UCBPalestine_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UCBPalestine-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> a Member of the Assembly for UNESCO: Culture of Peace, Mexico; on the Advisory Board of the Mystic Heart Institute; on the Advisory Board of the Institute for World Religions; Scholar Advisor for Interfaith Sacred Space, presented at the CPWR conference in Spain, 2004;<sup id="cite_ref-CRSCPWRSpain2004_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CRSCPWRSpain2004-41">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> and she presented Bay Area faith communities to the Goldin Institute, in Manresa, Spain, and more.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Higher_education">Higher education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nahid_Angha&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Higher education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>First conceived by Angha, and highly supported by Harlan Stelmach, who was the Chair and Professor of Humanities at Dominican University of California in 2000, the Building Bridges series began with an interfaith forum to explore shared spiritual values<sup id="cite_ref-BBoU2002_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBoU2002-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> that could help the community respond to and heal from the crises of September 11, 2001. In 2002, Angha invited leaders of existing religions and traditions in northern California including Hinduism, Buddhism, Judaism, Christianity, Sikhism, Islam, Native American, Zoroastrian, Barahma Kumaris, and the Bahai to serve as the decision-making members of the Program Committee<sup id="cite_ref-BBoUCommittee_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBoUCommittee-43">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> for the Building Bridges of Understanding, or to lead presentations for the sake of peace and inter-religious dialogue. She also invited the members of academia and civil society, to join together in this pursuit, including street chaplaincy, community healing centers, abused women's services, youth leadership, and others.  Among the highlights of her work was inviting Shirin Ebadi to the Dominican Campus in 2006 to present a lecture on: Human Rights, Islam and the West.<sup id="cite_ref-MIJEbadi_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MIJEbadi-44">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>"Communities ensure the well being of their members through shared information, concerns, resolutions, awareness, active participation, appreciation, and creation of common ground, and beneficial goals and hope for the future of communities, societies and nations," she said in her closing remarks at the first Building Bridges of Understanding conference. For that very reason, she developed an educational series for understanding major religions of the world, and their roles in creating peace, encouraging dialogue, creating higher education and more. The series included: Understanding Native American Spirituality;<sup id="cite_ref-BBoUNative_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBoUNative-45">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup> Understanding Judaism;<sup id="cite_ref-BBoUJudaism_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBoUJudaism-46">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> Understanding Islam;<sup id="cite_ref-BBoUIslam_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBoUIslam-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> Understanding Hinduism;<sup id="cite_ref-BBoUHinduism_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBoUHinduism-48">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> Understanding Buddhism;<sup id="cite_ref-BBoUBuddhism_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBoUBuddhism-49">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> and Understanding Zoroastrian.<sup id="cite_ref-BBoUEthics_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBoUEthics-50">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> Angha has also extended the Building Bridges series to include the roles that compassion, tolerance, enlightenment, ethics and morality, care for the Earth, experiencing peace through healing arts, etc. have played in our lives, and the lives of cultures and nations. Through her efforts the program created scholarship award for a student of the Humanities, including Religion, whose scholarship or community service reflects the spirit of the Building Bridges of Understanding series.<sup id="cite_ref-BBoUAward_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBoUAward-51">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Angha's advocacy for women's leadership led her to initiate The Women's Leadership Series within the Building Bridges of Understanding series.  The Women's Leadership Series brought together women in leadership positions to share their experiences and endeavors with the younger generation. The series addressed topics such as women's leadership and global awareness; and navigating the language of power, as well as self-awareness and leadership.<sup id="cite_ref-WomensLeadership_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WomensLeadership-52">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Awards_and_recognitions_.28partial_list.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_and_recognitions_(partial_list)">Awards and recognitions (partial list)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nahid_Angha&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Awards and recognitions (partial list)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Recipient, Marin Visionary Award, Marin Interfaith Council
Certificate of Recognition: North American Pioneers of United Religions Initiative
Recognition, Encunetro Mundial Interreligioso, UNESCO, Monterrey, Mexico 
First Muslim Woman Inductee, Marin Women's Hall of Fame
Certificate of Recognition, California State Senate
Certificate of Recognition, California State Assembly
Certificate of Recognition, US House of Representatives
Resolution and Recognition, Marin County Board of Supervisors
</p>
<h2><span id="Publications_.28partial_list.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Publications_(partial_list)">Publications (partial list)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nahid_Angha&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Publications (partial list)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Angha has contributed to over one hundred articles ranging from human rights advocacy to translations of the old Sufi texts, poetry, biographies, Islamic philosophy and principles. She is the author and translator of over twenty books including: A Force Such as the World Has Never Known: Women Creating Change (co-author, co edited); Abdullah Ansari of Hirat (11th century Sufi): One Hundred Stations (first English translation with commentary); "Abdullah Ansari of Hirat," in Encyclopedia of Islam (publishing date 2017); Ecstasy: The World of Sufi Poetry and Prayers; The Nature of Miracle; A Meditation (translation); Principles of Sufism; Psalms of Gods (translation); The Journey.
</p>
<h2><span id="Lectures_.28partial_list.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Lectures_(partial_list)">Lectures (partial list)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nahid_Angha&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Lectures (partial list)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Angha has been giving lectures and presentations since 1980, including:
Women Gathering for Change, Egypt; International Conference: Annual Sufism Symposium, US, Egypt, Spain, Scotland; The Vision for the 21st Century, anniversary of the UN, UC Berkeley; International Conference on Global Ethics, Fremont, California; Global Peace and Solidarity, NGO/DPI annual conference, United Nations; Women in Islam, CPWR Cape Town, S. Africa; Humanitarian Intervention: A Way towards Global Peace, NGO/DPI annual conference UN; Millennium World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders, UN; The Role of Religion and Spiritual Leadership in the 21st Century, State of the World Forum, San Francisco; His Majesty Mohammad IV's Conference on Sufism: Shakir World Encounters, Morocco; Assembly member and presenter, CPWR, Barcelona, Spain; Women's Islamic Initiative in Spirituality and Equity, New York; Sufi Perspective on World Peace and Responsibility, Cairo, Egypt; International Interreligious Encounter, Forum Universal de la Culturas, Monterey, Mexico; Neuroscience and Spiritual Practice, Claremont School of Theology; Bridge over Troubled Water: Human Dignity and 21st Century, Cortona, Italy; Science and Non-duality, Neti Neti Media, Marin County; Position and Rights of Women in Islam, Starr King School for Ministry, Berkeley; Sufi Path and 21st Century, Edinburgh, Scotland; Songs of the Soul Festival, Marin County, California.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nahid_Angha&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<table class="infobox vcard plainlist" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;background-color: #f0e68c"><div style="display:inline;" class="fn">Shusmita Anis</div><div class="nickname" lang="English">Shusmita Anis</div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Birth name</span></th><td class="nickname">Shusmita Anis</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><a href="/wiki/Dhaka" title="Dhaka">Dhaka</a>, Bangladesh</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Genres</th><td><a href="/wiki/Nazrul_Sangeet" class="mw-redirect" title="Nazrul Sangeet">Nazrul Sangeet</a>, modern Bengali song</td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Occupation(s)</span></th><td class="role">Singer, designer, business executive</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Instruments</th><td class="note">Vocals, harmonium</td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Years active</span></th><td>1976 –present</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Labels</th><td><a href="/wiki/G-Series_(record_label)" title="G-Series (record label)">G-Series</a>, Gaanchill Music, <a href="/wiki/HMV" title="HMV">HMV</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saregama" title="Saregama">Saregama</a> RAGA, New Music Paradigm Company</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Website</th><td><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://shusmitaanis.com">shusmitaanis<wbr />.com</a></span></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Shusmita Anis</b> sings <a href="/wiki/Nazrul_Sangeet" class="mw-redirect" title="Nazrul Sangeet">Nazrul Sangeet</a> &amp; Modern Bengali songs covering a wide variety of genres of music including light classical. She is the niece and disciple of Legendary Nazrul Sangeet Artist <a href="/wiki/Firoza_Begum_(singer)" title="Firoza Begum (singer)">Firoza Begum</a>.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Shusmita_Anis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Shusmita Anis started her training in music from the age of five from her aunt. She specializes in Nazrul's songs and modern Bengali songs, especially songs those are tuned by her uncle and husband of Feroza Begum, <a href="/wiki/Kamal_Dasgupta" title="Kamal Dasgupta">Kamal Dasgupta</a>. Shusmita Anis has been performing regularly in state owned national broadcasting corporation, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Television" title="Bangladesh Television">Bangladesh Television</a> (BTV), from an early age. She won the first prize in Nazrul Sangeet in 1976 in the annual national competition on performing arts, <a href="/wiki/Notun_Kuri" title="Notun Kuri">Notun Kuri</a> , produced by BTV.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Singing_career">Singing career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Shusmita_Anis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Singing career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Firoza Begum directed Shusmita Anis' first three albums. Shusmita Anis' first album of modern Bengali songs, <i>A tribute to Kamal Das Gupta</i>, was released in 1998 by <a href="/wiki/Raga_Music" title="Raga Music">Raga Music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kolkata" title="Kolkata">Kolkata</a>, India. In 2006, HMV in Kolkata, India, released her second album of Nazrul Sangeet, <i>Chand Herichey Chand Mukh Tar</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Agniveena, a record company in <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>, released her third album, <i>Sei Gaan Sei Sur</i>, in 2007. This is an album of modern Bengali songs. In 2008, Gaanchill Music, a record company in Bangladesh, released her fourth album of original Bengali songs, <i>Ichche Nupur</i>. Lyricist Asif Iqbal contributed to the album, while music composition of two of the songs of the album was composed by Bangladeshi singers, Nakib Khan and <a href="/wiki/Kumar_Bishwajit" title="Kumar Bishwajit">Kumar Bishwajit</a>.
</p><p>Her fifth album titled, <i>Shishirer Sporshe Gatha / Sound of Seasons</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> was released in August 2015 by New Music Paradigm Company. Shusmita Anis dedicated the album to her aunt. The album was released both in Bangladesh and in West Bengal, India. Composer Ibrar Tipu was the music director of this album. The making of the album was supervised by tabla player, Syed Meher Hossain, son of <a href="/wiki/Ustad_Zakir_Hussain" class="mw-redirect" title="Ustad Zakir Hussain">Ustad Zakir Hussain</a>.
</p><p>Shusmita Anis conceptualized and designed the album cover art by herself. RED Dot Multimedia Ltd. and eMusic made the music videos of many of the songs of the album.
</p><p>On 9 September 2015, commemorating the first anniversary of Firoza Begum's death, Shusmita Anis published an online Extended Play (EP) titled, <i>Mémoire Firoza Begum</i>. The EP consists of original renditions of three songs, tuned by Firoza Begum.
</p><p>Shusmita Anis has performed in several solo television programs, nationally and internationally, including <a href="/wiki/Tara_Music" title="Tara Music">Tara Music</a>, BTV, <a href="/wiki/Channel_i" title="Channel i">Channel i</a>, <a href="/wiki/NTV_(Bangladesh)" class="mw-redirect" title="NTV (Bangladesh)">NTV</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ekushey_Television" title="Ekushey Television">ETV</a> She performs regularly on the national Radio Bangladesh and radio stations like Radio Aamar, Radio Today. She has performed several international tours across the US, India and Bangladesh.
Her recent Modern Bengali songs like "E Pran Amar Bangladesh", "Keo Januk Ar Nai Januk", "Tomar Akash" have been popular amongst the youth available in YouTube channel "Shusmita Anis".Shusmita Anis continues to perform with equal popularity in <a href="/wiki/Nazrul_Sangeet" class="mw-redirect" title="Nazrul Sangeet">Nazrul Sangeet</a> as well as Bengali Modern songs nationally and internationally.
</p><p>Her recent Modern Bengali songs like "E Pran Amar Bangladesh", "Keu Januk Ar Nai Januk", "Tomar Akash" have been popular amongst the youth available in YouTube channel: “Shusmita Anis”. Shusmita Anis continues to perform with equal popularity in Nazrul Sangeet as well as Bengali Modern songs nationally and internationally.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Feroza_Begum_Archive">Feroza Begum Archive</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Shusmita_Anis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Feroza Begum Archive">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>To commemorate the first anniversary of Feroza Begum's death,<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> her life and her works, on 9 September 2015, Shusmita Anis launched the Feroza Begum Archive.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> Fans have been preserving Begum's works, and recordings of her music and speech, including live performances, amongst other memorabilia. These collections have been released as downloads on Anis' website.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.banglanews24.com/fullnews/bn/423775.html">[1]</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.ittefaq.com.bd/print-edition/entertainment/2015/08/20/67400.html">[2]</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-13">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.priyo.com/articles/%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%BE%E0%A7%9F-%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%BE-%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%97%E0%A6%AE-%E0%A6%B8%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%B0%E0%A6%A3%E0%A7%87-%E0%A6%85%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%AE">"কলকাতায় ফিরোজা বেগম স্মরণে অ্যালবাম"</a>. <i>প্রিয়.কম</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">14 December</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=%E0%A6%AA%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%B0%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC.%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%AE&amp;rft.atitle=%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC+%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%8B%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%BE+%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%97%E0%A6%AE+%E0%A6%B8%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%B0%E0%A6%A3%E0%A7%87+%E0%A6%85%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%AE&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.priyo.com%2Farticles%2F%25E0%25A6%2595%25E0%25A6%25B2%25E0%25A6%2595%25E0%25A6%25BE%25E0%25A6%25A4%25E0%25A6%25BE%25E0%25A7%259F-%25E0%25A6%25AB%25E0%25A6%25BF%25E0%25A6%25B0%25E0%25A7%2587%25E0%25A6%25BE%25E0%25A6%259C%25E0%25A6%25BE-%25E0%25A6%25AC%25E0%25A7%2587%25E0%25A6%2597%25E0%25A6%25AE-%25E0%25A6%25B8%25E0%25A7%258D%25E0%25A6%25AE%25E0%25A6%25B0%25E0%25A6%25A3%25E0%25A7%2587-%25E0%25A6%2585%25E0%25A7%258D%25E0%25A6%25AF%25E0%25A6%25BE%25E0%25A6%25B2%25E0%25A6%25AC%25E0%25A6%25BE%25E0%25A6%25AE&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AShusmita+Anis" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-14">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFNation" class="citation web cs1">Nation, The New. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://thedailynewnation.com/news/63941/solo-album-of-shusmita-anis.html">"Solo album of Shusmita Anis"</a>. <i>The New Nation</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Shusmita_Anis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><span class="official-website"><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.shusmitaanis.com">Official website</a></span></span></li></ul>
<p><br />

<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</p>
<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Toby Anstis</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Toby_anstis.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Toby anstis.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Toby_anstis.jpg/220px-Toby_anstis.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="239" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Toby_anstis.jpg/330px-Toby_anstis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Toby_anstis.jpg/440px-Toby_anstis.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1268" data-file-height="1379" /></a><div>Toby Anstis in 2007</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><span style="display:none"> (<span class="bday">1970-12-14</span>) </span>14 December 1970<span class="noprint ForceAgeToShow"> (age&#160;49)</span><br /><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace"><a href="/wiki/Northampton" title="Northampton">Northampton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northamptonshire" title="Northamptonshire">Northamptonshire</a>, England</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Occupation</th><td class="role">Radio and television presenter</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Employer</th><td class="org"><a href="/wiki/Global_(company)" title="Global (company)">Global</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Toby Anstis</b> (born 14 December 1970) is an English radio and television presenter. He is a presenter on <a href="/wiki/Heart_(radio_network)" title="Heart (radio network)">Heart</a> and spin-off station <a href="/wiki/Heart_Dance" title="Heart Dance">Heart Dance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-RadioToday_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RadioToday-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Early_life"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Early life</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Career"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Career</span></a></li>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Toby_Anstis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Originally from <a href="/wiki/Northampton" title="Northampton">Northampton</a>, Anstis was educated at <a href="/wiki/Desborough_College" title="Desborough College">Desborough School</a>,  an all-boys school in <a href="/wiki/Maidenhead" title="Maidenhead">Maidenhead</a>, <a href="/wiki/Berkshire" title="Berkshire">Berkshire</a>. He graduated in psychology and business studies from the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Surrey_Roehampton" class="mw-redirect" title="University of Surrey Roehampton">University of Surrey Roehampton</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Toby_Anstis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<table class="box-More_citations_needed plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Toby_Anstis&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.<br /><small><span class="plainlinks"><i>Find sources:</i>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?as_eq=wikipedia&amp;q=%22Toby+Anstis%22">"Toby Anstis"</a>&#160;–&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbm=nws&amp;q=%22Toby+Anstis%22+-wikipedia">news</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?&amp;q=%22Toby+Anstis%22+site:news.google.com/newspapers&amp;source=newspapers">newspapers</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbs=bks:1&amp;q=%22Toby+Anstis%22+-wikipedia">books</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22Toby+Anstis%22">scholar</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/action/doBasicSearch?Query=%22Toby+Anstis%22&amp;acc=on&amp;wc=on">JSTOR</a></span></small></span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">April 2019</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Anstis' first break came when he appeared in <i>The Broom Cupboard</i> on <a href="/wiki/CBBC" title="CBBC">Children's BBC</a> from April 1992 to September 1995. He then hosted <i>The O-Zone</i> music show on <a href="/wiki/BBC_Two" title="BBC Two">BBC Two</a>. Highlights included a first interview with <a href="/wiki/Michael_Hutchence" title="Michael Hutchence">Michael Hutchence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Farriss" title="Andrew Farriss">Andrew Farriss</a> of <a href="/wiki/INXS" title="INXS">INXS</a> in Rome and an O Zone Special featuring Take That . He completed a world record with <a href="/wiki/Bon_Jovi" title="Bon Jovi">Bon Jovi</a>, flying around the UK on the band's private jet, filming with the band as they played live in Glasgow, Cardiff and London in a single day, He hosted a <a href="/wiki/Radiohead" title="Radiohead">Radiohead</a> special for BBC Two in Vancouver, and a special with <a href="/wiki/Guns_N%27_Roses" title="Guns N&#39; Roses">Guns N' Roses</a> in Athens, at the Olympic Stadium and on their private yacht.
</p><p>He went on to present on the National Lottery Live, began presenting cricket films for Grandstand and hosted live coverage of Party In The Park and Reading Festival for <a href="/wiki/ITV2" title="ITV2">ITV2</a>. He also hosted 3 series of Fan Tc with Dannii Minogue for BBC!, 5 series of Bright Sparks for BBC1 recorded in Scotland. Then The 11th Hour for BBC1 live every Sunday morning. Plus presented Children In Need for two successive years.
</p><p>Anstis then moved into radio, presenting for the <a href="/wiki/Liberty_Radio" title="Liberty Radio">Liberty Radio</a> breakfast show, and for various programmes on <a href="/wiki/Challenge_(TV_channel)" title="Challenge (TV channel)">Challenge</a> (such as <i><a href="/wiki/TV_Scrabble" title="TV Scrabble">TV Scrabble</a></i>), before moving to <a href="/wiki/Global_(company)" title="Global (company)">Global</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Heart_(radio_network)" title="Heart (radio network)">Heart</a> in 2002.
</p><p>In 2004, he appeared in the <a href="/wiki/Sky_Living" class="mw-redirect" title="Sky Living">Living TV</a> reality show, <i><a href="/wiki/I%27m_Famous_and_Frightened!" title="I&#39;m Famous and Frightened!">I'm Famous and Frightened!</a></i>. Anstis co-hosted <i><a href="/wiki/Children_in_Need" title="Children in Need">Children in Need</a></i>, <i>The National Lottery Live</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Grandstand_(TV_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="Grandstand (TV series)">Grandstand</a></i> on BBC One, as well as <i>Fan TC</i> with <a href="/wiki/Dannii_Minogue" title="Dannii Minogue">Dannii Minogue</a> and <i>Electric Circus</i> for <i><a href="/wiki/Live_%26_Kicking" title="Live &amp; Kicking">Live &amp; Kicking</a></i>, and Bright Sparks. He also presented <a href="/wiki/Trust_Me_%E2%80%93_I%27m_a_Holiday_Rep" title="Trust Me – I&#39;m a Holiday Rep">Trust Me – I'm a Holiday Rep</a> on <a href="/wiki/Channel_5_(UK)" class="mw-redirect" title="Channel 5 (UK)">Channel 5</a> .<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> In November 2006, he took part in the sixth series of the ITV show <i><a href="/wiki/I%27m_a_Celebrity...Get_Me_Out_of_Here!" title="I&#39;m a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!">I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!</a></i>  and was the first person to be voted out of the show<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>, although it was reported the next day in various tabloids including <a href="/wiki/The_Sun_(United_Kingdom)" title="The Sun (United Kingdom)">The Sun</a> that there had been a voting error and <a href="/wiki/Dean_Gaffney" title="Dean Gaffney">Dean Gaffney</a><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> should have gone. In 2007, he was a judge on <a href="/wiki/VH1_(UK_and_Ireland)" class="mw-redirect" title="VH1 (UK and Ireland)">VH1</a>'s <i>Wannabe</i> and featured on <i>The Killer In Me</i> for <a href="/wiki/ITV_(TV_channel)" title="ITV (TV channel)">ITV1</a> along with <a href="/wiki/Fiona_Phillips" title="Fiona Phillips">Fiona Phillips</a> (<a href="/wiki/GMTV" title="GMTV">GMTV</a>), footballer <a href="/wiki/John_Barnes_(footballer)" class="mw-redirect" title="John Barnes (footballer)">John Barnes</a> and political presenter <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Neil" title="Andrew Neil">Andrew Neil</a>. 
</p><p>In 2009, he featured on <i><a href="/wiki/Ready_Steady_Cook" title="Ready Steady Cook">Ready Steady Cook</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Alan_Titchmarsh_Show" title="The Alan Titchmarsh Show">The Alan Titchmarsh Show</a></i>. In 2011, he appeared on the <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> quiz show <i><a href="/wiki/Eggheads_(TV_series)" title="Eggheads (TV series)">Eggheads</a>.</i> He was the first ever honorary 'Loose Man' on <a href="/wiki/ITV_(TV_network)" title="ITV (TV network)">ITV</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Loose_Women" title="Loose Women">Loose Women</a></i> and made his stage debut as Teen Angel in the <a href="/wiki/West_End_theatre" title="West End theatre">West End</a> production of <i><a href="/wiki/Grease_(musical)" title="Grease (musical)">Grease</a></i> at the <a href="/wiki/Piccadilly_Theatre" title="Piccadilly Theatre">Piccadilly Theatre</a> on 25 January 2010.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>. Made acting appearance on cult hit BBC3 show "<a href="/wiki/Mongrels" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongrels">Mongrels</a>". Has been regularly involved in Adoption week on <a href="/wiki/This_Morning_(TV_programme)" title="This Morning (TV programme)">This Morning</a> and supports Asthma UK. 
</p><p>in 2019 Toby Anstis won "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Pointless_Celebrity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pointless Celebrity (page does not exist)">Pointless Celebrity</a>" for the third time with fellow Heart presenter <a href="/wiki/Lilah_Parsons" title="Lilah Parsons">Lilah Parsons</a>. Having won it previously with <a href="/wiki/Jenni_Falconer" title="Jenni Falconer">Jenni Falconer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kirsten_O%27Brien" title="Kirsten O&#39;Brien">Kirsten O'Brien</a>  
</p><p>After 17 years, Anstis left weekday mid-mornings on Heart on 5 April 2019.It had been officially the UK's most listened to commercial radio show with a peak of 4.1 millions listeners. Being a big fan of dance music and a busy dj,  he was very excited to move on to present <i>Heart's Club Classics</i> each Friday evening.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> 
</p><p>On 21 June 2019 Anstis launched a brand new national DAB radio station, <a href="/wiki/Heart_Dance" title="Heart Dance">Heart Dance</a>, where he presents weekday breakfast.<sup id="cite_ref-RadioToday_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RadioToday-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> His <i>Heart's Club Classics</i> show is simulcast with the spin-off station.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Charity_work">Charity work</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Toby_Anstis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Charity work">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In 1994 Anstis took part in an episode of <i><a href="/wiki/Challenge_Anneka" title="Challenge Anneka">Challenge Anneka</a></i>, where he contributed a <a href="/wiki/Spaghetti_bolognese" class="mw-redirect" title="Spaghetti bolognese">spaghetti bolognese</a> recipe to a book in aid of <a href="/wiki/Breakthrough_Breast_Cancer" title="Breakthrough Breast Cancer">Breakthrough Breast Cancer</a>. He is an ambassador for <a href="/wiki/The_Prince%27s_Trust" title="The Prince&#39;s Trust">The Prince's Trust</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>In 2016 he did a 'strawfie' (a <a href="/wiki/Selfie" title="Selfie">selfie</a> while breathing through a straw) to raise awareness of <a href="/wiki/Cystic_fibrosis" title="Cystic fibrosis">cystic fibrosis</a> at an event held by the Cystic Fibrosis Trust.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Filmography">Filmography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Toby_Anstis&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Filmography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<dl><dt>TV</dt></dl>

<ul><li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1075870/">Toby Anstis</a> on <a href="/wiki/IMDb" title="IMDb">IMDb</a></li></ul></div>

<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Richard Anuszkiewicz</div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><div style="display:inline" class="nickname">Richard Joseph Anuszkiewicz<sup id="cite_ref-nyt1_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></div><br /><span style="display:none">(<span class="bday">1930-05-23</span>)</span>May 23, 1930<br /><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace"><a href="/wiki/Erie,_Pennsylvania" title="Erie, Pennsylvania">Erie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Died</th><td>May 19, 2020<span style="display:none">(2020-05-19)</span> (aged&#160;89)<br /><div style="display:inline" class="deathplace"><a href="/wiki/Englewood,_New_Jersey" title="Englewood, New Jersey">Englewood</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Nationality</th><td class="category"><a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">American</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Education</th><td><a href="/wiki/Cleveland_Institute_of_Art" title="Cleveland Institute of Art">Cleveland Institute of Art</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Known&#160;for</th><td><a href="/wiki/Painting" title="Painting">Painting</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Movement</th><td class="category"><a href="/wiki/Op_Art" class="mw-redirect" title="Op Art">Op Art</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Richard Joseph Anuszkiewicz</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">ˌ</span><span title="/ɑː/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;father&#39;">ɑː</span><span title="&#39;n&#39; in &#39;nigh&#39;">n</span><span title="/ə/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;about&#39;">ə</span><span title="&#39;s&#39; in &#39;sigh&#39;">s</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="&#39;k&#39; in &#39;kind&#39;">k</span><span title="/eɪ/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;face&#39;">eɪ</span><span title="&#39;v&#39; in &#39;vie&#39;">v</span><span title="/ɪ/: &#39;i&#39; in &#39;kit&#39;">ɪ</span><span title="/tʃ/: &#39;ch&#39; in &#39;China&#39;">tʃ</span></span>/</a></span></span>; May 23, 1930 – May 19, 2020) was an American <a href="/wiki/Painting" title="Painting">painter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Printmaking" title="Printmaking">printmaker</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sculpture" title="Sculpture">sculptor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Selected_collections_holding_works"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Selected collections holding works</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Grants_and_awards"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Grants and awards</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life_and_work">Life and work</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Anuszkiewicz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Life and work">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Anuszkiewicz was born in Erie, Pennsylvania, the son of Victoria (Jankowski) and Adam Anuszkiewicz, who worked in a paper mill. His parents were Polish immigrants.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt1_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> Anuszkiewicz trained at the <a href="/wiki/Cleveland_Institute_of_Art" title="Cleveland Institute of Art">Cleveland Institute of Art</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cleveland" title="Cleveland">Cleveland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ohio" title="Ohio">Ohio</a> (1948–1953), and then with <a href="/wiki/Josef_Albers" title="Josef Albers">Josef Albers</a><sup id="cite_ref-AAA_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AAA-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> at the <a href="/wiki/Yale_University_School_of_Art" class="mw-redirect" title="Yale University School of Art">Yale University School of Art </a> in <a href="/wiki/New_Haven,_Connecticut" title="New Haven, Connecticut">New Haven, Connecticut</a> (1953–1955) where he earned his Masters of Fine Arts.
</p><p>He was one of the founders and foremost exponents of <a href="/wiki/Op_Art" class="mw-redirect" title="Op Art">Op Art</a>, a movement during the late 1960s and early 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-Cotter_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cotter-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Victor_Vasarely" title="Victor Vasarely">Victor Vasarely</a> in France and <a href="/wiki/Bridget_Riley" title="Bridget Riley">Bridget Riley</a> in England were his primary international counterparts. In 1964, <i><a href="/wiki/Life_(magazine)" title="Life (magazine)">Life</a></i> magazine called him "one of the new wizards of Op".<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> While reflecting on a New York City gallery show of Anuszkiewicz's from 2000, <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">New York Times</a></i> art critic <a href="/wiki/Holland_Cotter" title="Holland Cotter">Holland Cotter</a> described Anuszkiewicz's paintings: "The drama — and that feels like the right word — is in the subtle chemistry of complementary colors, which makes the <a href="/wiki/Geometry" title="Geometry">geometry</a> glow as if light were leaking out from behind it." <sup id="cite_ref-Cotter_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cotter-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> Anuszkiewicz exhibited at the <a href="/wiki/Venice_Biennale" title="Venice Biennale">Venice Biennale</a>, <a href="/wiki/Florence_Biennale" title="Florence Biennale">Florence Biennale</a> and <a href="/wiki/Documenta" title="Documenta">Documenta</a>, and his works are in permanent collections internationally. He was elected into the <a href="/wiki/National_Academy_of_Design" title="National Academy of Design">National Academy of Design</a> in 1992 as an Associate member, and became a full member in 1994.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Style">Style</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Anuszkiewicz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Style">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Considered a major force in the Op Art movement, Anuszkiewicz was concerned with the optical changes that occur when different high-intensity colors are applied to the same geometric configurations. Most of his work comprises visual investigations of formal structural and color effects, many of them nested square forms similar to the work of his mentor <a href="/wiki/Josef_Albers" title="Josef Albers">Josef Albers</a>. In his series, "Homage to the Square", Albers experimented with juxtapositions of color, and Anuszkiewicz developed these concepts further. Anuszkiewicz continued to produce works in the Op Art style over the subsequent decades of his career.
</p><p>In 1963, Anuszkiewicz summarized his approach to painting as: "My work is of an experimental nature and has centered on an investigation into the effects of complementary colors of full intensity when juxtaposed and the optical changes that occur as a result, and a study of the dynamic effect of the whole under changing conditions of light, and the effect of light on color."<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Selected_collections_holding_works">Selected collections holding works</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Anuszkiewicz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Selected collections holding works">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Albright-Knox_Art_Gallery" class="mw-redirect" title="Albright-Knox Art Gallery">Albright-Knox Art Gallery</a>, Buffalo</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Art_Institute_of_Chicago" title="Art Institute of Chicago">Art Institute of Chicago</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Blanton_Museum_of_Art" title="Blanton Museum of Art">Blanton Museum of Art</a>, University of Texas</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Boca_Raton_Museum_of_Art" title="Boca Raton Museum of Art">Boca Raton Museum of Art</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Museum_of_Art" title="Carnegie Museum of Art">Carnegie Museum of Art</a>, Pittsburgh</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Chicago_Museum_of_Contemporary_Art" class="mw-redirect" title="Chicago Museum of Contemporary Art">Chicago Museum of Contemporary Art</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Cleveland_Museum_of_Art" title="Cleveland Museum of Art">Cleveland Museum of Art</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Columbus_Museum_of_Art" title="Columbus Museum of Art">Columbus Museum of Art</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Denver_Art_Museum" title="Denver Art Museum">Denver Art Museum</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Detroit_Institute_of_Arts" title="Detroit Institute of Arts">Detroit Institute of Arts</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Flint_Institute_of_Arts" title="Flint Institute of Arts">Flint Institute of Arts</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Fogg_Museum" class="mw-redirect" title="Fogg Museum">Fogg Museum</a>, Harvard University</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Plaza#Art_collection" title="Empire State Plaza">The Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller Empire State Plaza Art Collection</a><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Hokkaido_Museum_of_Modern_Art" title="Hokkaido Museum of Modern Art">Hokkaido Museum of Modern Art</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Honolulu_Museum_of_Art" title="Honolulu Museum of Art">Honolulu Museum of Art</a><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Indiana_University_Art_Museum" class="mw-redirect" title="Indiana University Art Museum">Indiana University Art Museum</a>, Bloomington</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art" title="Metropolitan Museum of Art">Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>, New York</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Contemporary_Art_Jacksonville" title="Museum of Contemporary Art Jacksonville">Museum of Contemporary Art Jacksonville</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Modern_Art" title="Museum of Modern Art">Museum of Modern Art</a>, New York</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Museum_of_Art" title="Philadelphia Museum of Art">Philadelphia Museum of Art</a>, Philadelphia</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Solomon_R._Guggenheim_Museum" title="Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum">Guggenheim Museum</a>, New York</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Wadsworth_Atheneum" title="Wadsworth Atheneum">Wadsworth Atheneum</a>, Hartford</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Whitney_Museum_of_Art" class="mw-redirect" title="Whitney Museum of Art">Whitney Museum of Art</a>, New York</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Grants_and_awards">Grants and awards</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Anuszkiewicz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Grants and awards">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>1953: Pulitzer Traveling Fellowship</li>
<li>1963: Charles of the Ritz Oil Painting Award</li>
<li>1964: The Silvermine Guild Award for Oil Painting</li>
<li>1977: Cleveland Arts Prize</li>
<li>1980: Hassam Fund Purchase Award</li>
<li>1988: Hassam Fund Purchase Award</li>
<li>1994: New York State Art Teachers' Association Award</li>
<li>1995: Emil and Dines Carlson Award</li>
<li>1996: New Jersey Pride Award</li>
<li>1997: Richard Florsheim Fund Grant</li>
<li>2000: Lee Krasner Award</li>
<li>2005: Lorenzo dei Medici Career Award, awarded at the Florence Biennale</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Exhibitions">Exhibitions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Anuszkiewicz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Exhibitions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Anuskiewicz exhibited in many public collections around the world, including such New York galleries as Sidney Janis, The Contemporaries,<sup id="cite_ref-AAA_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AAA-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Crispo" title="Andrew Crispo">Andrew Crispo Gallery</a>.
</p>
<ul><li>1955: <a href="/wiki/Butler_Institute_of_American_Art" title="Butler Institute of American Art">Butler Institute of American Art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Youngstown,_Ohio" title="Youngstown, Ohio">Youngstown</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ohio" title="Ohio">Ohio</a></li>
<li>1966: <a href="/wiki/Cleveland_Museum_of_Art" title="Cleveland Museum of Art">Cleveland Museum of Art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cleveland" title="Cleveland">Cleveland</a>, Ohio</li>
<li>1967: <a href="/wiki/The_Hopkins_Center" class="mw-redirect" title="The Hopkins Center">The Hopkins Center</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hanover,_New_Hampshire" title="Hanover, New Hampshire">Hanover</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Hampshire" title="New Hampshire">New Hampshire</a></li>
<li>1968: <a href="/wiki/Kent_State_University" title="Kent State University">Kent State University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kent,_Ohio" title="Kent, Ohio">Kent</a>, Ohio</li>
<li>1972: <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Contemporary_Art_Jacksonville" title="Museum of Contemporary Art Jacksonville">Museum of Contemporary Art Jacksonville</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jacksonville,_Florida" title="Jacksonville, Florida">Jacksonville, Florida</a></li>
<li>1976: <a href="/wiki/La_Jolla_Museum_of_Contemporary_Art" class="mw-redirect" title="La Jolla Museum of Contemporary Art">La Jolla Museum of Contemporary Art</a>, <a href="/wiki/La_Jolla,_San_Diego,_California" class="mw-redirect" title="La Jolla, San Diego, California">La Jolla, California</a></li>
<li>1977: <a href="/wiki/Columbus_Museum_of_Art" title="Columbus Museum of Art">Columbus Museum of Art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Columbus,_Ohio" title="Columbus, Ohio">Columbus</a>, Ohio</li>
<li>1978: <a href="/wiki/Ringling_Museum" class="mw-redirect" title="Ringling Museum">Ringling Museum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sarasota,_Florida" title="Sarasota, Florida">Sarasota, Florida</a></li>
<li>1978: <a href="/wiki/Allentown_Art_Museum" title="Allentown Art Museum">Allentown Art Museum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Allentown,_Pennsylvania" title="Allentown, Pennsylvania">Allentown, Pennsylvania</a></li>
<li>1979: Alex Rosenberg Gallery, New York City, New York</li>
<li>1979: <a href="/wiki/Clark_Art_Institute" title="Clark Art Institute">Clark Art Institute</a>, <a href="/wiki/Williamstown,_Massachusetts" title="Williamstown, Massachusetts">Williamstown, Massachusetts</a></li>
<li>1980: <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Museum" title="Brooklyn Museum">Brooklyn Museum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a>, New York</li>
<li>1980: <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Museums_of_Pittsburgh" title="Carnegie Museums of Pittsburgh">Carnegie Museums of Pittsburgh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pittsburgh" title="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a>, Pennsylvania</li>
<li>1984: <a href="/wiki/Heckscher_Museum_of_Art" title="Heckscher Museum of Art">Heckscher Museum of Art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Huntington,_New_York" title="Huntington, New York">Huntington, New York</a></li>
<li>1984: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canton_Art_Institute&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canton Art Institute (page does not exist)">Canton Art Institute</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canton,_Ohio" title="Canton, Ohio">Canton</a>, Ohio</li>
<li>1986: <a href="/wiki/Tampa_Museum_of_Art" title="Tampa Museum of Art">Tampa Museum of Art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tampa,_Florida" title="Tampa, Florida">Tampa</a>, Florida</li>
<li>2005: <a href="/wiki/Florence_Biennale" title="Florence Biennale">Florence Biennale</a>, Fortezza da Basso, Firenze, Italy</li></ul>

<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Honolulu Museum of Art wall label, <i>Sol V</i>, 1968, acrylic on canvas, accession 3546.1</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Anuszkiewicz&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/11/arts/design/11galleries-003.html?scp=2&amp;sq=wigmore&amp;st=cse">"Op Out of Ohio" review</a> by Ken Johnson for the New York Times</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.forvo.com/word/richard_anuszkiewicz">Richard Anuszkiewicz Pronunciation</a></li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.richardanuszkiewicz.com/">www.richardanuszkiewicz.com</a></li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://rogallery.com/Anuszkiewicz_Richard/Anuszkiewicz-biography.htm">rogallery.com</a></li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.imj.org.il/en/search/site/Anuszkiewicz%20and%20+Richard">Richard Anuszkiewicz collection</a> at the Israel Museum. Retrieved September 2016.</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.picassomio.com/richard-anuszkiewicz.html">www.picassomio.com</a></li></ul>
<div role="navigation" class="navbox" aria-labelledby="Op_art" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks mw-collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th scope="col" class="navbox-title" colspan="3"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Op_art" title="Template:Op art"><abbr title="View this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template_talk:Op_art&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template talk:Op art (page does not exist)"><abbr title="Discuss this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Op_art&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Op_art" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Op_art" title="Op art">Op art</a></div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Artists</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

<div role="navigation" class="navbox authority-control" aria-labelledby="Authority_control_frameless_&amp;#124;text-top_&amp;#124;10px_&amp;#124;alt=Edit_this_at_Wikidata_&amp;#124;link=https&amp;#58;//www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q558505#identifiers&amp;#124;Edit_this_at_Wikidata" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks hlist navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th id="Authority_control_frameless_&amp;#124;text-top_&amp;#124;10px_&amp;#124;alt=Edit_this_at_Wikidata_&amp;#124;link=https&amp;#58;//www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q558505#identifiers&amp;#124;Edit_this_at_Wikidata" scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Help:Authority_control" title="Help:Authority control">Authority control</a> <a href="https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q558505#identifiers" title="Edit this at Wikidata"><img alt="Edit this at Wikidata" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8a/OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg/10px-OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg.png" decoding="async" width="10" height="10" style="vertical-align: text-top" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8a/OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg/15px-OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8a/OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg/20px-OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20" /></a></th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
