~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">July 2020</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Application Defined Network (ADN)</b> is an enterprise <a href="/wiki/Data_network" class="mw-redirect" title="Data network">data network</a> that uses <a href="/wiki/Virtualization" title="Virtualization">virtual</a> network and security components to provide a dedicated logical network for each application, with customized <a href="/wiki/Security_policy" title="Security policy">security</a> and network policies to meet the requirements of that specific application. ADN technology allows for a simple physical architecture with fewer devices, less device configuration and integration, reduced network administration and a lower tax on IT resources. ADN solutions simplify businesses' need to securely deploy multiple applications across the enterprise footprint and partner networks, regardless of where the application resides. ADN platforms provide policy-based, application-specific delivery to corporate data centers, cloud services and/or third-party networks securely and cost-effectively. Some ADN solutions integrate 3G/<a href="/wiki/4G" title="4G">4G</a> wireless backup services to enable a second internet connection automatically and instantly when connectivity is lost on the primary access connection. The ADN design provides an <a href="#A2A">application-to-application</a> (A2A) based model that evolves enterprise networks beyond the site-to-site (S2S) private model.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#ADN_fundamentals"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">ADN fundamentals</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-2"><a href="#A2A"><span class="tocnumber">1.1</span> <span class="toctext">A2A</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Security"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Security</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="ADN_fundamentals">ADN fundamentals</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Application_Defined_Network&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: ADN fundamentals">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>ADN solutions address the need to enable multiple different applications, such as guest <a href="/wiki/WiFi" class="mw-redirect" title="WiFi">WiFi</a> (hotspot) while strictly securing regulated applications such as payment on the same network. Traditionally, in site-to-site networks, having multiple applications introduces significant security policy conflicts.  Technologies, such as guest Wi-Fi, <a href="/wiki/Mobile_payment" title="Mobile payment">mobile payment</a> and/or <a href="/wiki/Cloud_services" class="mw-redirect" title="Cloud services">cloud services</a> open the traditional private network to outside security threats and create significant complexity in security policies and network administration. ADNs can be customized with specific security features that address specific application needs, and enhanced with performance and reliability features such as traffic management for application prioritization and <a href="/wiki/Fail-over" class="mw-redirect" title="Fail-over">fail-over</a> for back-up connection services.
</p><p>Complexity breeds vulnerability. Application Defined Networks (ADNs) significantly reduce complexity and the resulting costs of multiple device investment and management, configuration, integration, and problem isolation and resolution. ADNs are typically enabled on a secure appliance at the distributed enterprise locations that integrate with a cloud network to connect applications to corporate data centers, cloud services, payment gateways and partner networks. ADNs eliminate the potential for route conflicts, security cascade across applications, and problem cascade caused by one application misbehaving and affecting other applications on the same network.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li><b>Route Conflicts</b> – traditional site-to-site networks facilitate multiple applications over single connections (ex. <a href="/wiki/VPN" class="mw-redirect" title="VPN">VPNs</a>, <a href="/wiki/MPLS" class="mw-redirect" title="MPLS">MPLS</a> VPNs, and Ethernet) and require complex security rules to partition applications from one another. Simple errors in device configurations can create routing problems that can breach strict security and compliance-based applications such as  <a href="/wiki/PCI-DSS" class="mw-redirect" title="PCI-DSS">PCI-DSS</a><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/HIPAA" class="mw-redirect" title="HIPAA">HIPAA</a><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> certifications. The ability to completely segment these applications into their own discrete ADN removes that complexity of managing multiple security partitions across many locations.</li>
<li><b>Security Cascade </b>– traditional site-to-site networks are subject to security bleed when a network segment that is open to the Internet gets breached.  <a href="/wiki/Advanced_persistent_threat" title="Advanced persistent threat">Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs)</a> are becoming more frequent, effective and damaging.  The damage is occurring when the threat roots inside the breached segment and stealthily probes entry points into other network segments. Several security breaches have been the result of this security cascade where vulnerability between network segments is exploited.  ADNs eliminate the ability for a security breach to cascade between network segments and applications by compartmentalizing applications into secure and isolated networks.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><b>Problem Cascade</b> – On a traditional site-to-site network, when a specific problem in an individual application's configuration results in abnormal behaviors, the problem ends up affecting all other applications on the network.  Essentially, one application misbehaving results in all applications being affected and the entire network being compromised. Isolating the root of the problem becomes extremely difficult and time-consuming when a network is in chaos, or completely down.  On an Application Defined Network, problems are isolated to the specific application's network, allowing for simpler fault isolation and resolution.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<p>ADNs are logically defined virtual networks that extend from application enabler to <a href="/wiki/Application_gateway" class="mw-redirect" title="Application gateway">application gateways</a>. ADN solutions combine the ability to define specific <a href="/wiki/LAN_segment" class="mw-redirect" title="LAN segment">LAN segments</a> with an actual ADN. This provides the ability to extend the ADN through the LAN to a specific interface on the application enabler (<a href="/wiki/POS_system" class="mw-redirect" title="POS system">POS system</a>, server, etc.).  An assigned zone will lock down a specific <a href="/w/index.php?title=LAN_port&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="LAN port (page does not exist)">LAN port</a> to a specific use.  For example, serial port 1 would be assigned to the payment ADN/LAN segment only, and no other devices can use that specific LAN port, and if unauthorized device is plugged into zone 1, it will not work. This provides both physical and logical security protections against unauthorized use of a port.
</p><p>The ADN then facilitates the connection from the specific LAN port over the public <a href="/w/index.php?title=Broadband_connection&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Broadband connection (page does not exist)">broadband connection</a> independently of any public <a href="/wiki/IP_address" title="IP address">IP addressing</a>. The ADN is then <a href="/wiki/Authenticated" class="mw-redirect" title="Authenticated">authenticated</a> inside the cloud and transported to the destination application gateway. This provides an end-to-end application enabler to an application gateway network that is independently defined, both physically and logically. The application gateway can reside within the corporate office or <a href="/wiki/Data_center" title="Data center">data centers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cloud_service_provider" class="mw-redirect" title="Cloud service provider">cloud service providers</a>, partner networks or virtually anywhere.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="A2A">A2A</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Application_Defined_Network&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: A2A">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Application-to-application (A2A) networks remove site-to-site (S2S) limitations by defining the network architecture at the application level.  A2A networks open the enterprise network to be able to securely connect to any application, no matter where it resides. A2A networks free the enterprise network from burdensome controls and restricted hub and spoke traffic patterns, by facilitating any-to-any traffic pattern based on the specific needs to the application itself. Companies no longer have to overspend by purchasing application licenses and building the application within their data centers, and incur all the associated capital, network and IT resource costs. A2A networking allows companies to implement innovation, and efficiently deploy multiple applications using cloud services that address needs, such as, improved <a href="/wiki/Customer_value" class="mw-redirect" title="Customer value">customer value</a><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Use_plain_English#Buzzwords" title="Wikipedia:Use plain English"><span title="The material near this tag may use buzzwords designed solely to impress you or obscure meaning. (July 2020)">buzzword</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>, operational efficiencies and product differentiation.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Security">Security</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Application_Defined_Network&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Security">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>ADN network simplifies security by establishing discrete independent networks that do not require complex security rules to partition traffic types. ADNs reduce the risk of human error in maintaining complex <a href="/wiki/Access_control_list" class="mw-redirect" title="Access control list">Access Control Lists (ACLs)</a> across many sites which can create security vulnerabilities. For example, if an ADN with public Internet access is breached by an outside party, the ability of the breach to bleed between ADNs, such as a payment ADN, is eliminated.
</p><p>ADN standard security features include firewall, <a href="/wiki/Intrusion_detection" class="mw-redirect" title="Intrusion detection">intrusion detection</a>, logging, wireless scanning, <a href="/wiki/Content_filtering" class="mw-redirect" title="Content filtering">content filtering</a>, <a href="/wiki/Access_control_list" class="mw-redirect" title="Access control list">access control list</a>, <a href="/wiki/Multi-factor_authentication" title="Multi-factor authentication">multi-factor authentication</a>, <a href="/wiki/AES_encryption" class="mw-redirect" title="AES encryption">Advanced Encryption Standard (AES)</a> encryption and compartmentalization. Additional custom security features can also be easily deployed such as <a href="/wiki/HTTPS" title="HTTPS">HTTPS</a> filtering, <a href="/wiki/Security_information_and_event_management" title="Security information and event management">Security and Event Management (SIEM)</a>, or any best-of-breed security application hosted on virtual servers within the cloud.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Application_Defined_Network&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://cosine-security.blogspot.com/2011/02/pci-dss-you-gotta-keep-em-separated.html">http://cosine-security.blogspot.com/2011/02/pci-dss-you-gotta-keep-em-separated.html</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="https://www.pcisecuritystandards.org/security_standards/index.php">https://www.pcisecuritystandards.org/security_standards/index.php</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="https://www.hhs.gov/ocr/privacy/hipaa/understanding/index.html">https://www.hhs.gov/ocr/privacy/hipaa/understanding/index.html</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Cascading_failure" title="Cascading failure">Cascading failure</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Cascading_failure" title="Cascading failure">Cascading failure</a></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div></div>
~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">May 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"><caption class="fn org">Aquademics</caption><tbody><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Aquademics.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Aquademics.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e3/Aquademics.jpg/100px-Aquademics.jpg" decoding="async" width="100" height="106" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e3/Aquademics.jpg/150px-Aquademics.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e3/Aquademics.jpg/200px-Aquademics.jpg 2x" data-file-width="242" data-file-height="256" /></a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right:0.6em;">Motto</th><td class="note">Swimmers Make Better Learners</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right:0.6em;">Founded</th><td class="note">1990</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right:0.6em;">Type</th><td><a href="/wiki/Non-profit_organisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Non-profit organisation">Non-profit</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right:0.6em;">Focus</th><td>Increasing the number of <a href="/wiki/African_American" class="mw-redirect" title="African American">African American</a> children in competitive water sports and encouraging their academic achievement</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Aquademics</b> was a <a href="/wiki/Michigan" title="Michigan">Michigan</a> <a href="/wiki/Nonprofit_organization" title="Nonprofit organization">nonprofit organization</a> established in 1990 to increase the number and presence of African American children in competitive <a href="/wiki/Water_sport" class="mw-redirect" title="Water sport">water sports</a>. In addition to sponsoring a competitive swimming team, Aquademics operated an academic support program. Based in <a href="/wiki/Ann_Arbor,_Michigan" title="Ann Arbor, Michigan">Ann Arbor</a>, Aquademics programs were open to all youth of color children, ages seven to sixteen, living in <a href="/wiki/Washtenaw_County,_Michigan" title="Washtenaw County, Michigan">Washtenaw County</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> In operation throughout the 1990s, Aquademics formally disbanded at the turn of the 21st century.
</p><p>The Aquademics model resembled other athletics programs created in the late 1980s and 1990s, whose goal was to increase youth of color participation in sports lacking in diversity and with a history of racial exclusion.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> The Aquademics program was also guided by the precedent that sporting excellence is a means to teach children other forms of excellence, most importantly, academic excellence.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Aquademics model's impact can be measured by the number of former members currently in professions where credentials and opportunities require associate and college degrees. Aquademics alums are represented in the following professions: business, communications, nonprofit administration, computer science, law, and the military, including the U.S. Marine Corps and the U.S. Navy.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Moreover, a few Aquademics alums and former staff have volunteered or are working in water sport professions.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> Two head coaches, who started their water sport coaching with Aquademics, continued with their coaching careers. Aquademics' original coach, <b>Vicki Hames-Frazier</b> was a water sports instructor of children with special needs for the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.wash.k12.mi.us/index.php">Washtenaw Intermediate School District</a>. After Aquademics, <b>Hames-Frazier</b> became head coach of the co-ed swimming team at Ann Arbor <a href="/wiki/Greenhills_School" title="Greenhills School">Greenhills School</a>. She is one of the first African American women to coach a high school competitive swimming team in Michigan.
</p><p><b>Kelton Graham</b> was Aquademics' longest-serving coach. <b>Graham</b> was a student athlete on the men's swimming team at <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Michigan_University" title="Eastern Michigan University">Eastern Michigan University</a>. After Aquademics, <b>Graham</b> took head coaching positions at both the club and high school levels. In 2006, he was appointed head coach of the <a href="/wiki/Huron_High_School_(Ann_Arbor,_Michigan)" title="Huron High School (Ann Arbor, Michigan)">Huron High School (Ann Arbor, Michigan)</a> boys' swimming team.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> In 2008, <b>Graham</b> led the boys' swimming team to its first Class A championship in 19 years. That same year, <b>Graham</b> was named the Michigan Interscholastic Swim Coaches Association Coach of the Year, becoming the first African American to receive this award.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Beginnings"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Beginnings</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#The_Southeastern_Michigan_Competitive_Swimming_Culture_and_Community"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">The Southeastern Michigan Competitive Swimming Culture and Community</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Learning_from_History"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Learning from History</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Aquademics_in_the_Water"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Aquademics in the Water</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Swimmers_Make_Better_Learners"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Swimmers Make Better Learners</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#Family-Centered_Leadership"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Family-Centered Leadership</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#Challenges"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Challenges</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#Legacy"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">Legacy</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-10"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Beginnings">Beginnings</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Aquademics&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Beginnings">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In 1990, <b>Jeanine DeLay</b>, faculty member and first coach of the Ann Arbor Greenhills School co-ed swimming team, met with former colleague, <b>Wilma Allen</b>, then Assistant Director, Research Services at CPHA, a national health information services firm.  <b>DeLay</b> was interested in starting a swimming program for underserved kids whose access to swimming had been impeded by discrimination, inadequate resources and lack of coaching mentors.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> Cognizant and supportive of appeals for educational reform in athletics voiced at the time by tennis champion, humanitarian and activist <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Ashe" title="Arthur Ashe">Arthur Ashe</a>, <b>Allen</b> and <b>DeLay</b>, also committed the endeavor to a strong academic program.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> They were joined in forming Aquademics by three other educators and health care professionals to comprise the founding board: <b>Carmel Borders</b>, adjunct faculty member in health education at Eastern Michigan University, <b>Melvin Rhoden,</b> Admissions Director of Ann Arbor Greenhills School and health company executive, <b>Gloria Jackson</b>.
</p><p>Aquademics' name merged its two vital goals: <b>Aqua</b>(tics) and (aca)<b>Demics</b>. The motto served its mission: Swimmers Make Better Learners. The logo featured its goal: a Black swimmer smoothly churning through large waves.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Southeastern_Michigan_Competitive_Swimming_Culture_and_Community">The Southeastern Michigan Competitive Swimming Culture and Community</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Aquademics&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: The Southeastern Michigan Competitive Swimming Culture and Community">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Southeastern Michigan is a long-established training site for competitive swimmers and well- recognized in the competitive swimming world. It boasts top-ranked, championship and highly respected college teams, among them the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Michigan" title="University of Michigan">University of Michigan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oakland_University" title="Oakland University">Oakland University</a> and Eastern Michigan University.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Likewise, club programs, such as the Ann Arbor Swim Club and <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.clubwolverine.org/Home.jsp?team=czmscw">Club Wolverine</a> include on their annual rosters several regionally and nationally ranked swimmers. School programs, such as the Ann Arbor Pioneer High School boys' and girls' swimming and diving teams, have won over thirty state championships since 1977.
</p><p>Several southeastern Michigan water sport coaches are highly regarded, and swimmers come from across the nation and around the world to train and compete on the region's college teams.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Aquademics depended on the good will and generous support of this talent and resource-rich, experienced and close-knit swimming culture and community.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Learning_from_History">Learning from History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Aquademics&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Learning from History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Equally important, Aquademics learned from the enterprise of pioneers in African American swimming history who had established swimming programs in Detroit.
</p><p>Knowledge about African Americans and their place in swimming history has been burdened by racism and obstructed by persistent and inaccurate stereotypes.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> Water sports in America and the architecture of both private and public swimming pools represented a landscape set up for racial inequality and segregation. During the <a href="/wiki/New_Deal" title="New Deal">New Deal</a> in the 1930s, the construction of public pools expanded reasons and some opportunities for all ethnic and racial groups to learn how to swim. Nevertheless, Blacks were prohibited from "Whites only" facilities.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As a result, several communities with large numbers of African American citizens supported their own water sport recreation centers. One of the most visible in southeastern Michigan was the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://hall.michiganwomen.org/honoree.php?C=219&amp;A=20~114~96~172~79~2~62~238~113~46~80~3~152~167~74~138~63~92~196~4~242~32~121~84~229~153~48~231~192~41~129~82~69~109~42~93~97~56~175~103~13~249~207~21~126~104~230~5~98~131~27~53~38~195~139~239~219~106~57~22~147~58~107~127~6~173~144~85~17~148~250~47~208~228~49~221~251~43~205~135~168~181~33~115~232~176~23~14~75~169~130~162~44~198~204~99~7~118~119~8~136~222~50~227~15~157~65~150~108~24~154~170~163~76~9~209~110~140~70~59~51~155~16~158~156~241~60~182~191~116~190~28~164~243~125~160~197~86~193~223~29~134~39~159~111~61~177~132~87~52~199~54~35~210~211~64~112~200~183~165~245~100~10~122~71~240~77~94~120~11~36~25~244~224~151~178~55~88~45~184~128~72~246~78~171~233~141~180~206~189~73~235~123~83~89~145~18~66~26~237~30~212~188~142~220~90~19~40~161~218~133~81~247~225~67~37~248~146~217~91~143~12~236~31~68~1~213~101~117~214~174~102~226~137~185~124~234~95~216~166~187">Lucy Thurman</a> YWCA. The accomplishments of those who participated in the Lucy Thurman YWCA swimming programs in the first half of the 20th century are especially noteworthy.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>By the 1990s, when Aquademics swimmers jumped into the pool, the most pernicious structures of discrimination faced by Blacks in water sports had been dismantled. Evidence of these changes was affirmed by the fast times clocked by an upcoming generation of accomplished African American swimmers, trained under the farsighted leadership of <a href="/wiki/Jim_Ellis_(sports)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jim Ellis (sports)">Jim Ellis</a>, head coach of the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.phila.gov/recreation/index.html">Philadelphia Department of Recreation</a>, known in swimming circles as PDR.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> Further, a number of metropolitan swim teams with a majority of African American swimmers were expanding their reach into urban communities and sending their record-breaking and qualifying time swimmers to state, national and international events. Among them were teams from Atlanta, Detroit,  Baltimore, St. Louis, Washington, DC.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Aquademics_in_the_Water">Aquademics in the Water</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Aquademics&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Aquademics in the Water">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="floatright"><a href="/wiki/File:Aquademics-Photo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Aquademics-Photo.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/53/Aquademics-Photo.jpg/500px-Aquademics-Photo.jpg" decoding="async" width="500" height="314" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/53/Aquademics-Photo.jpg/750px-Aquademics-Photo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/5/53/Aquademics-Photo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="884" data-file-height="555" /></a></div><p>The <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.annarborymca.org/">Ann Arbor YMCA</a> was Aquademics' first pool. The founding team included four girls and two boys ranging in age from nine to fourteen. When the Aquademics team became too big for one lane instruction, the team obtained practice time at the Eastern Michigan University (EMU) pool, through the good offices of the EMU women's swimming coach. This was a temporary solution however, given the demands and expenses of training at a university facility. By 1993, Aquademics moved into its "home" pool at <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://clague.a2schools.org/clague.home/home">Clague Middle School</a>.
</p><p>The Aquademics team decided on team colors of black and gold. After the group purchased its first practice fins, swimming lessons, training and competitions with other local clubs followed. By 1993, the 'Aquademicsmobile,' a donated van, took Aquademics swimmers all over southeastern Michigan, accompanied by a caravan of family and friend supporters. Rival teams included: <a href="/wiki/University_Liggett_School" title="University Liggett School">University Liggett School</a>, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ypsi-otters.org/registration.html">Ypsilanti Otters</a>, Detroit Northside Seacolts and the Detroit Recreational Center. Aquademics was honored with the 1994 Award for its service to community youth by the Friends of the C.O.P.E. O'Brien Center for Youth Development, a group offering a wide range of treatment and counselling services to young people in Washtenaw County.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A few months before receiving this award, in February 1994, the Aquademics team and families travelled to and competed in the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.dpr.dc.gov/dpr/cwp/view,A,1239,Q,638886.asp">Black History Invitational</a>, then in its eighth year. The BHI, hosted by the Washington DC <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://dpr.dc.gov/dpr/site/default.asp">Department of Parks and Recreation</a>, is the premier gathering of competitive African American swimmers in the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> The Aquademics team participated in five Black History Invitationals.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> In 1999, inspired by the success of the BHI, Aquademics hosted a smaller competition, the Kwanzaa Invitational. It was held from December 17–19, 1999 at the University of Michigan <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mgoblue.com/facilities/canham-natatorium.html">Canham Natatorium</a>, and included teams from around the region.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Swimmers_Make_Better_Learners">Swimmers Make Better Learners</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Aquademics&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Swimmers Make Better Learners">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Scholastic achievement was central to Aquademics. To fulfill its mission, three initiatives were supported:
</p>
<ul><li>The program established an annual camp. The Aquademics Camp was at once a water sport clinic, a cultural experience and a summer school. In addition to the swimming practices and training common to all sport camps, the fundamental skills of other water sports, such as water polo, water skiing and scuba diving were introduced. Campers took field trips to several African American history and cultural institutions: the <a href="/wiki/Charles_H._Wright" title="Charles H. Wright">Charles Wright</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.maah-detroit.org/index.html">Museum of African American History</a>, the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.shrinebookstore.com/">Black Madonna Bookstore</a>, and the African art collections at the <a href="/wiki/Detroit_Institute_of_Art" class="mw-redirect" title="Detroit Institute of Art">Detroit Institute of Art</a>. In 1993, campers met with several Lucy Thurman YWCA alumna, who provided a cultural history lesson about their experiences as synchronized swimmers in the 1930s and 1940s. Finally, the camp incorporated study skill and time management instruction, learning style discussions and offered tutorials in specific subjects.</li>
<li>A college scholarship fund was launched to provide financial assistance to Aquademics members with stellar academic records during high school. Funded by former health care researcher <b>Linda Sprankle</b>, an advocate of programs committed to youth of color, the <b>Sprankle Scholarship</b> became synonymous with high academic achievement, and for Aquademics members, an honor as competitive and prestigious as getting medals in swimming.</li>
<li>The group engaged <b>Betty Springfield</b>, a volunteer program director, to sustain an effective academic program.  She joined the founding board to lend expertise for two ends: to strengthen the academic support and counselling programs; and to shift the program toward family-centered leadership.</li></ul>
<p>In 1995, Springfield increased and expanded the academic counselling staff, instituted after-practice tutorials and secured a flexible partnership with another academic group associated with the <a href="/wiki/Ann_Arbor_Public_Schools" title="Ann Arbor Public Schools">Ann Arbor Public Schools</a>, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.anotherannarbor.org/ed_academy.php">The African American Academy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Then in 1996, the founding Board approved a plan to transfer governing authority to parents and families of Aquademics members. To the 'Swimmers Make Better Learners' motto, another watchword was embraced: "Always Remember that the Children Are in the Water."
</p><p>This expression called to mind the power of water and charged everyone affiliated with Aquademics to      advance the promise and well-being of children and to promote life skills that keep children out of harm's way.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family-Centered_Leadership">Family-Centered Leadership</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Aquademics&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Family-Centered Leadership">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The transfer to a family-centered board in 1997 meant that the founders and nurturers of the organization turned governance over to the sustainers and legacy-builders of Aquademics. The shift had the immediate effect of increasing the number of children belonging to the program. Over the next two years, the group concentrated on educating area youth groups and on increasing awareness of Aquademics' mission to community leaders. In 1999, Aquademics was given a Community Recognition Award for 'Outstanding Service by an Organization' by the Trustees of <a href="/wiki/Washtenaw_Community_College" title="Washtenaw Community College">Washtenaw Community College</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Challenges">Challenges</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Aquademics&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Challenges">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Aquademics was a grass-roots nonprofit organization. As a result, the group obtained resources through several approaches and maintained its programs by relying on a combination of grants, business sponsorships, fund-raisers, annual giving and in-kind donations. Critical seed grants were awarded by the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.aaacf.org/AAACF%20Homepage.pdf">Ann Arbor Area Community Foundation</a> and the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.accesstorecreation.org/community-foundations/community-foundations---michigan/southeast-michigan-community-foundation.html">Southeastern Michigan Community Foundation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> Original corporate sponsors included two local banks. In-kind donations came from a range of sources, from swimming kickboards to donated coaching expertise. The programs, however, were not free. Each family contributed to the funding of camp and was assessed a participation fee every season.
</p><p>Fund-raising was all-consuming and required major time commitments by families and volunteers who worked with Aquademics. Scaling up the program, to provide financial security and a stable source of income, proved increasingly difficult. With no endowment, the organization had to survive from season to season. Likewise, the advantage of being in an area with abundant swimming resources, also meant that Aquademics as a development or bridge program encountered some turnover to other clubs, whose goals did not require academics and cultural components.
</p><p>Because of all of these challenges, the board of Aquademics determined to end operations at the beginning of the 21st century.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Aquademics&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Legacy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The history of Aquademics is emblematic of the success and obstacles that confront individuals and groups whose purposes are to diversify the face of an exclusive sport and to transform a sport establishment that has been neither welcoming nor accessible to large numbers of people because of discrimination. Swimming may have more to answer for. Swimming pools and beaches for water sport recreation were symbols of segregation. They became contested sites during the civil rights movement in the 1960s. But at the same time, the wade-ins, and brave calls to "come on in and swim" encouraged and strengthened the African American swimming movement.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Today, it is no longer as uncommon to see African Americans at the elite levels of swimming and other water sports. Over the last two decades, several elite African American swimmers have not only broken American records, but have displayed their willingness to be mentors to a new generation of Black swimmers.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> Soon after <a href="/wiki/Cullen_Jones" title="Cullen Jones">Cullen Jones</a>, an African American freestyler became the first African American to hold or share a world record in swimming at the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">Beijing Olympics</a> in 2008, he described his hopes that he would work to increase the number of African American children in swimming.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As a result of these promising changes, it might be said that programs like Aquademics are no longer important. Or that it is not surprising a program like Aquademics has disbanded, because it is no longer necessary. But lost and ignored knowledge about the heritage of African Americans in swimming and its importance as a life skill have taken a toll and create a perilous cultural undercurrent that continues to have fatal consequences. Alarmingly, over half of African Americans do not know how to swim today.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> Their encounters with water are therefore more likely to be life-threatening. The tragic statistics reveal that they are: African American children, ages 10 to 14 drown at five times the rate of other ethnic and racial groups in the United States.
</p><p>Fortunately, today, other organizations are advancing the legacy of Aquademics and programs similar to it. And simultaneously, they are rediscovering and reclaiming lost knowledge and heritage as well as documenting the reality that Black children always were, have been and always will be in the water.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Aquademics&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<li>Ahsanur Rahman Himel</li>
<li>Ishtiaq Hossain Jishan</li>
<li>Farhan Tanim</li>
<li>Muntasir Mamun Shuvo</li></ul>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Arbovirus</b> is a <a href="/wiki/Bangladeshi_rock" title="Bangladeshi rock">Bangladeshi rock</a> band formed in 2002 in <a href="/wiki/Dhaka" title="Dhaka">Dhaka</a>. Their current line-up consists of Sufi Maverick as the vocal, Suharto Sherif, and Asif Asgar Ranjan as teh guitarits, Aldnane Alam on bass, and Nafeez Al Amin on the drums.
</p><p>Till now they have released three Studio Albums, one EP, and twelve singles through various mixed albums.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#History"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">History</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-2"><a href="#Formation_and_early_years_(2002-2005)"><span class="tocnumber">1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Formation and early years (2002-2005)</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#64m_53s_(2006)"><span class="tocnumber">1.2</span> <span class="toctext"><i>64m 53s</i> (2006)</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#Struggle_with_the_line_up_(2007-2011)"><span class="tocnumber">1.3</span> <span class="toctext">Struggle with the line up (2007-2011)</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#Montobbo_Nishproyojon_(2012-2013)"><span class="tocnumber">1.4</span> <span class="toctext"><i>Montobbo Nishproyojon</i> (2012-2013)</span></a></li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span id="Formation_and_early_years_.282002-2005.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Formation_and_early_years_(2002-2005)">Formation and early years (2002-2005)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Formation and early years (2002-2005)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Suharto formed the band with Ranjan on 2002. The line consisted of Suharto and Ranjan on guitars, Shovon on vocal, Himel on drums. Bassist Salek from Reborn played as a guest member. 
Around mid-2003, Ishtiaq Jishan, and Farhan Tanim joined as a bassist, and drummer respectively.
On the same year Sufi joined as a vocal to complete the line up.
</p><p>Band's early releases includes singles like "আর্তনাদ (ARTONAD)" in the mixed album <i>"আগন্তুক (AGONTUK)"</i>, which earned them their first record deal with the label <a href="/wiki/G-Series_(record_label)" title="G-Series (record label)">G-Series</a>.
</p>
<h3><span id="64m_53s_.282006.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="64m_53s_(2006)"><i>64m 53s</i> (2006)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: 64m 53s (2006)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Band released their debut album <i>64m 53s</i> on July 20, 2006 under the banner of <a href="/wiki/G-Series_(record_label)" title="G-Series (record label)">G-Series</a>.
</p><p>On 26 January 2006, Arbovirus performed their first international show at the <a href="/wiki/Salt_Lake_Stadium" title="Salt Lake Stadium">Salt Lake Stadium</a> on the eve of <a href="/wiki/Indian_Republic_Day" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian Republic Day">Indian Republic Day</a> along with <a href="/wiki/Warfaze" title="Warfaze">Warfaze</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artcell" title="Artcell">Artcell</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Metal_Maze&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Metal Maze (page does not exist)">Metal Maze</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lakkhichhara" title="Lakkhichhara">Lakkhichhara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cactus_(Indian_band)" title="Cactus (Indian band)">Cactus (Indian band)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Insomnia_(band)" title="Insomnia (band)">Insomnia (band)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fossils_(band)" title="Fossils (band)">Fossils</a>.
</p>
<h3><span id="Struggle_with_the_line_up_.282007-2011.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Struggle_with_the_line_up_(2007-2011)">Struggle with the line up (2007-2011)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Struggle with the line up (2007-2011)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In early 2008 Jishan and Tanim moved abroad to pursue higher education. Aldnane Alam joined shortly after Jishan left. Shuvo (Ex <a href="/wiki/Aurthohin" title="Aurthohin">Aurthohin</a>) joined as a drummer, but he also left the band as he would permanently move to Australia.
</p><p>In 2011 - drummer Nafeez Al Amin joined the band, and the same year they started recording new materials.
</p>
<h3><span id="Montobbo_Nishproyojon_.282012-2013.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Montobbo_Nishproyojon_(2012-2013)"><i>Montobbo Nishproyojon</i> (2012-2013)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Montobbo Nishproyojon (2012-2013)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 2012 - partnering with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Livesquare&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Livesquare (page does not exist)">Livesquare</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Apex_Footwear_Sprint&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Apex Footwear Sprint (page does not exist)">Apex Footwear Sprint</a> as a sponsor - band signed a deal <sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> for the 2nd album.
</p><p>In December 2012 - the band performed in the "Urban Youth Festival".
</p><p>They made two collaborative tracks with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beatbaksho&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beatbaksho (page does not exist)">Beatbaksho</a>, rapper <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amewu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amewu (page does not exist)">Amewu</a> and one of the <a href="/wiki/The_Voice_of_Germany" title="The Voice of Germany">Voice of the Germany</a> producer <a href="/w/index.php?title=DJ_Werd&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DJ Werd (page does not exist)">DJ Werd</a>. They also performed the entire set on the <a href="/wiki/Ekushey_Television" title="Ekushey Television">Ekushey TV</a>, including their title track "Raise Your Voice", and "Grime Time".<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Arbovirus released their second album <i>Montobbo Nishproyojon</i> on 5 July 2013 at the Russian Cultural Center.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
The album consists of 8 tracks.
In order to bridge the 7 years gap with their audience – the band decided to give it away as a free <a href="/wiki/Digital_distribution" title="Digital distribution">Digital Download</a>, and never released any physical version of it until the release of <a href="/wiki/Bishesh_Droshtobbo" class="mw-redirect" title="Bishesh Droshtobbo">Bishesh Droshtobbo</a>.
</p>
<h3><span id="Bishesh_Droshtobbo_.282017.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Bishesh_Droshtobbo_(2017)"><i>Bishesh Droshtobbo</i> (2017)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Bishesh Droshtobbo (2017)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Their third album, <i>Bishesh Droshtobbo</i>, was initially planned as a B-side album of the 2nd album with the left over tracks from their second album. But later on the band decided to add more songs to it and release it as a full-length album which now consists of 9 tracks.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Band organized their first ever solo concert since their foundation to commemorate the 15 years of the journey and the launching of their third album. The concert was held on January 13, 2017 in Russian Cultural Center. The album was released on their YouTube channel, and double CD of both <i>Montobyo Nishproyojon</i> and <i>Bishesh Droshtobbo</i> was made available through pre-order home-delivery.
<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> 
Since the band didn't sign up wit any record label, they took over the CD production and packaging among the teammates. All the packaging were personally done by the band members and associated teammates.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Lyrics">Lyrics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Lyrics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Almost all of the lyrics are in Bangla, mostly written by Ranjan, except for 'Artonad' by Shobhon, 'Ja Ichhe Tai' by Sufi and 'Shopnadishto' by Rumman.
</p><p>The band's lyrics broadly covers various elements from self-recognition to the political disarray of <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>, from the 9–6 corporate life to middle-east peace politics, from the inner struggle to strong optimism, from the incoherent feeling of letting a loved one go to, although they portray a broader humane and optimistic view.
</p><p>Their later releases are more vocal about the moral bankruptcy and political hypocrisy that all the members experienced over time. Several of their songs contain elements of <a href="/wiki/Suicide" title="Suicide">Suicide</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=War_Crimes_in_Bangladesh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="War Crimes in Bangladesh (page does not exist)">War Crimes in Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Religion" title="Religion">Religion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">Atheism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>, <a href="/wiki/Identity_Crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="Identity Crisis">Identity Crisis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Exobiology" class="mw-redirect" title="Exobiology">Exobiology</a> and many other issues.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Associated_acts">Associated acts</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Associated acts">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Guitarist Ranjan has been contributing to different bands as a lyricist for quite a long time, even long before he formed the band. He has contributed lyrics to many prominent musicians including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Miles_Band&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Miles Band (page does not exist)">Miles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artcell" title="Artcell">Artcell</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Aurthohin" title="Aurthohin">Aurthohin</a>.
Besides – he has an experimental project named <a href="/w/index.php?title=Purple_Haze_Band&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Purple Haze Band (page does not exist)">Purple Haze</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lare_Lappa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lare Lappa (page does not exist)">Lare Lappa</a>.
</p><p>On January 15, 2015 - <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sufi_Maverick&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sufi Maverick (page does not exist)">Sufi</a> along with Polash from <a href="/wiki/Warfaze" title="Warfaze">Warfaze</a>, Shakib from <a href="/wiki/Cryptic_Fate" title="Cryptic Fate">Cryptic Fate</a>, Jamshed from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Powersurge_(Bangladeshi_band)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Powersurge (Bangladeshi band) (page does not exist)">Powersurge</a> performed at the curtain closing show of <a href="/wiki/Rockstrata" title="Rockstrata">Rockstrata</a>, one of the pioneering Heavy Metal bands of Bangladesh.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bassist Aldnane also have been playing and writing lyrics for the <a href="/wiki/Experimental_rock" title="Experimental rock">Experimental rock</a> band "Kral". He is also a part of the Progressive Instrumental super group <a href="/w/index.php?title=Air_and_Air&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Air and Air (page does not exist)">Air and Air</a> who has released their first studio album in 2014.
</p><p>Drummer Nafeez has been a regular session player; notable among them are Dethrow, Breach, Kronic, <a href="/wiki/Elita_Karim" title="Elita Karim">Elita Karim</a> and Friends, and Jazzy Chopsticks.
In 2019 Nafeez got the endorsement from <a href="/wiki/Soultone_Cymbals" title="Soultone Cymbals">Soultone Cymbals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Discography">Discography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Discography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Studio_albums">Studio albums</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Studio albums">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

<li><i>Montobbo Nishproyojon</i> (5 July 2013)</li>
<li><i>Bishesh Droshtobbo</i> (13 January 2017)</li>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Extended_Play">Extended Play</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Extended Play">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li><i>Otopor</i> (14 April 2019)</li></ul>
<h3><span id="Singles_.28in_various_mixed_albums.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Singles_(in_various_mixed_albums)">Singles (in various mixed albums)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Singles (in various mixed albums)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li><i>Aartonad</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agantuk_2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agantuk 2 (page does not exist)">Agantuk 2</a> (2003)</li>
<li><i>Obhishap</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Din_Bodol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Din Bodol (page does not exist)">Din Bodol</a> (2004)</li>
<li><i>Shopnadishto</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lokayot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lokayot (page does not exist)">Lokayot</a> (2004)</li>
<li><i>Shohor</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boka_Manushta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boka Manushta (page does not exist)">Boka Manushta</a> {ft. Sumon 'BassBaba' of <a href="/wiki/Aurthohin" title="Aurthohin">Aurthohin</a>} (2007)</li>
<li><i>Shurjo Shontan</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Live_Now&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Live Now (page does not exist)">Live Now</a> (2007)</li>
<li><i>Prayoshchitto</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bonno&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bonno (page does not exist)">Bonno</a> {ft. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fuad_Almuqtadir&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fuad Almuqtadir (page does not exist)">Fuad Almuqtadir</a>} (2007)</li>
<li><i>Addhek Kotha</i> in <a href="/wiki/Rock_101" class="mw-redirect" title="Rock 101">Rock 101</a> (2008)</li>
<li><i>Keu Karo Noy</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rock_202&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rock 202 (page does not exist)">Rock 202</a> (2009)</li>
<li><i>Prarthona</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rock_505&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rock 505 (page does not exist)">Rock 505</a> (2010)</li>
<li><i>Bangladesh Gori</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gorje_Uttho_Bangladesh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gorje Uttho Bangladesh (page does not exist)">Gorje Uttho Bangladesh</a> (2011)</li>
<li><i>Agontuk</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rock_606&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rock 606 (page does not exist)">Rock 606</a> (2011)</li>
<li><i>Goal</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rock_808&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rock 808 (page does not exist)">Rock 808</a> (2015)</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Band_members">Band members</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Band members">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Current_members">Current members</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Current members">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li>Suharto Sherif – Guitars, backing vocals, (2001–present)</li>
<li>Asif Asgar Ranjan – Lyrics, Guitars, (2001–present)</li>
<li>Sufi Maverick – Vocals (2003–present)</li>
<li>Aldnane Alam - Bass (2009–present)</li>
<li>Nafeez Al Amin – Drums (2011–present)</li>
<li>Mong Sai Marma - Bass (touring) (2017–present)</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Former_members">Former members</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Former members">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li>Ishtiaq Ahmed Shovon – Vocals (2002–2003)</li>
<li>Ahsanur Rahman Himel – Drums (2002–2003)</li>
<li>Ishtiaq Hossain Jishan – Bass (2003–2008)</li>
<li>Farhan Tanim – Drums (2003–2009)</li>
<li>Muntasir Mamun Shuvo – Drums (2010–2011)</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Timeline">Timeline</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbovirus_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Timeline">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

</li>

padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">Key people</div></th><td class="agent" style="line-height: 1.35em;">Sue Smaill, last general manager<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup><br />Michael Coburn, director<br /> Nicholas Scott, director<br />Trevor Scott, director<br /> Julian Smith, director<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right: 0.5em;">Products</th><td style="line-height: 1.35em;">apparel, cosmetics, accessories, homeware, furniture, general merchandise</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right: 0.5em;">Website</th><td style="line-height: 1.35em;"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.arthurbarnett.co.nz/">arthurbarnett.co.nz</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Arthur Barnett Ltd</b>, trading as <b>Arthur Barnett</b> and often referred to as <b>Arthur Barnett's</b>, was a <a href="/wiki/Department_store" title="Department store">department store</a> in <a href="/wiki/Dunedin" title="Dunedin">Dunedin</a>, New Zealand. Established in 1903 by <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Barnett_(businessman)" title="Arthur Barnett (businessman)">Arthur Barnett</a> the store first began as a drapery for men and boys, progressing over the years to become one of Dunedin's most successful department stores. As well as their flagship George Street store, Arthur Barnett had stores in <a href="/wiki/Balclutha,_New_Zealand" title="Balclutha, New Zealand">Balclutha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexandra,_New_Zealand" title="Alexandra, New Zealand">Alexandra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oamaru" title="Oamaru">Oamaru</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Christchurch" title="Christchurch">Christchurch</a>. They also briefly had a branch in <a href="/wiki/Melbourne" title="Melbourne">Melbourne</a> which operated from 1970 to 1977. This branch sold mainly carpeting and furniture. The final Arthur Barnett store (on site of its first on George Street in Dunedin) and its online store was taken over by <a href="/wiki/Invercargill" title="Invercargill">Invercargill</a>-based department store chain <a href="/wiki/H_%26_J_Smith" title="H &amp; J Smith">H &amp; J Smith</a> in 2015.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arthur_Barnett_Main_Entrance_angle_Meridian_Ground_Level_2013.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Arthur_Barnett_Main_Entrance_angle_Meridian_Ground_Level_2013.jpg/300px-Arthur_Barnett_Main_Entrance_angle_Meridian_Ground_Level_2013.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Arthur_Barnett_Main_Entrance_angle_Meridian_Ground_Level_2013.jpg/450px-Arthur_Barnett_Main_Entrance_angle_Meridian_Ground_Level_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Arthur_Barnett_Main_Entrance_angle_Meridian_Ground_Level_2013.jpg/600px-Arthur_Barnett_Main_Entrance_angle_Meridian_Ground_Level_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1450" data-file-height="799" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Arthur_Barnett_Main_Entrance_angle_Meridian_Ground_Level_2013.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Arthur Barnett as it appeared until the takeover by H &amp; J Smith</div></div></div>
