<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Barnett_Ltd&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Arthur Barnett opened his first drapery store in 1903, placing his first newspaper advertisement on 6 March of that year, and opening the next day.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> During this time his store became famous for its advertisements which were colourful and often relied heavily on gimmicks, such as naming a hat the 'King Dick' after the Prime Minister at the time <a href="/wiki/Richard_Seddon" title="Richard Seddon">Richard Seddon</a>. Jim Sullivan argues that "Arthur Barnett's reputation for innovation in retail was becoming well-established - he had a flair and brought colour and a touch of the side show to what was a staid occupation."<sup id="cite_ref-:0_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> 
</p><p>New buildings followed in 1909 and 1924. The 1924 Arthur Barnett building designed by <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Anscombe" title="Edmund Anscombe">Edmund Anscombe</a> was a landmark on the northern part of <a href="/wiki/George_Street,_Dunedin" title="George Street, Dunedin">George Street, Dunedin</a>. It was devastated by fire in 1959, with only the building shell and one major stained glass window surviving. It was rebuilt in 1960s modernist style behind the existing facades, the main retail floor being a soaring glass-roofed structure, inspiring the store's slogan of that era: "the Daylight Store." This was demolished progressively in 1995-7 and replaced by the Meridian Mall incorporating a reduced-size Arthur Barnett store across two levels.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="D.I.C._takeover">D.I.C. takeover</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Barnett_Ltd&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: D.I.C. takeover">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Arthur Barnett took over the ailing <a href="/wiki/D.I.C._(department_store)" title="D.I.C. (department store)">DIC</a> department store company in the 1980s. The D.I.C. had stores throughout <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a> and should have proven a good geographical match for Arthur Barnett. In particular, the D.I.C. had 4 stores in the <a href="/wiki/Auckland" title="Auckland">Auckland</a> market, New Zealand's biggest. In December 1987, Arthur Barnett bought the trading assets of the three South Island stores and 50% of the 13 North Island stores which were run as a joint venture with <a href="/wiki/Brierley_Investments" title="Brierley Investments">Brierley Investments</a> Ltd. Arthur Barnett Ltd bought the 16 D.I.C. stores outright in July 1988. The D.I.C. Stores were in <a href="/wiki/Invercargill" title="Invercargill">Invercargill</a>, Dunedin, Christchurch, <a href="/wiki/Lower_Hutt" title="Lower Hutt">Lower Hutt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palmerston_North" title="Palmerston North">Palmerston North</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wanganui" class="mw-redirect" title="Wanganui">Wanganui</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hastings,_New_Zealand" title="Hastings, New Zealand">Hastings</a>, <a href="/wiki/Napier,_New_Zealand" title="Napier, New Zealand">Napier</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gisborne,_New_Zealand" title="Gisborne, New Zealand">Gisborne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rotorua" title="Rotorua">Rotorua</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hamilton,_New_Zealand" title="Hamilton, New Zealand">Hamilton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakuranga" title="Pakuranga">Pakuranga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henderson,_New_Zealand" title="Henderson, New Zealand">Henderson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karangahape_Road" title="Karangahape Road">Karangahape Road</a> (Auckland), <a href="/wiki/Takapuna" title="Takapuna">Takapuna</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Whangarei" class="mw-redirect" title="Whangarei">Whangarei</a>.
</p><p>At its peak Arthur Barnett Ltd had over 1200 staff and 19 stores (the 16 former D.I.C. stores, along with its own branches in Alexandra, Balclutha, and Dunedin). However, the merger did not work well and all D.I.C. stores with the exception of <a href="/wiki/Christchurch" title="Christchurch">Christchurch</a> were closed within 2 years. By 1992 the majority of The D.I.C. assets were disposed of and the company was able to concentrate on its stores in Dunedin, Alexandra, Balclutha and Christchurch. In 1987 the Christchurch store in the Beaths Department Store Building was re-branded as Arthur Barnett<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> and refurbished within the High Street Mall development in the city's centre. The Alexandra and Balclutha stores were closed in 1995 and 2001 respectively. The Balclutha store was taken over by rival Invercargill-based department store chain H &amp; J Smith. The D.I.C. debacle cost Arthur Barnett around $NZ 20 million and as a result the company had to borrow heavily to help finance the <a href="/wiki/Meridian_Mall,_Dunedin" title="Meridian Mall, Dunedin">Meridian Mall</a> project in 1995.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:MeridianMallfacade.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/MeridianMallfacade.jpg/300px-MeridianMallfacade.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="225" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/MeridianMallfacade.jpg/450px-MeridianMallfacade.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/MeridianMallfacade.jpg/600px-MeridianMallfacade.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3456" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:MeridianMallfacade.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Arthur Barnett is located at 285 George Street, The Meridian Mall</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Meridian_Mall_and_a_single_store">Meridian Mall and a single store</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Barnett_Ltd&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Meridian Mall and a single store">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The Meridian Mall opened on 5 September 1997 with the final development costs close to $NZ 50 million. As the primary <a href="/wiki/Anchor_tenant" title="Anchor tenant">anchor tenant</a>, Arthur Barnett had the greatest floor space, spread across two levels, although this being only about half that of the old store.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> The main and lower floors are linked by escalators, with a more upmarket appearance than previous Arthur Barnett stores.
</p><p>The Meridian building was sold in 2003, with the proceeds used to retire debt. Finally in February 2006, the Christchurch store was closed. Many of the staff were able to be relocated to other retailers including Farmers and Ballantynes.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> From then on, the company only operated a single store, which acted as <a href="/wiki/Otago" title="Otago">Otago</a>'s luxury department store, specialising in cosmetics, fashion, homeware and school uniforms.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Recent_Ventures">Recent Ventures</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Barnett_Ltd&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Recent Ventures">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In mid-2011, a small Arthur Barnett outlet store was opened in Christchurch's <a href="/wiki/Hornby,_New_Zealand" title="Hornby, New Zealand">Hornby</a> Dress Smart discount shopping centre,<sup id="cite_ref-ODT_163250_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODT_163250-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> following the <a href="/wiki/2011_Christchurch_earthquake" title="2011 Christchurch earthquake">Christchurch earthquakes</a>. The temporary store was closed in 2012.
</p><p>Also in 2011, Arthur Barnett opened the 'Arthur Barnett Gift Shop' at the front of the Meridian, in the former Kimberleys store. The 'Gift Shop' was later changed to a 'Clearance Shop', and was closed by 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> Mid November 2012 saw the opening of a temporary cosmetics clearance shop in the upper level of the Meridian.
</p><p>During <a href="/wiki/Otago_University_Students%27_Association" title="Otago University Students&#39; Association">OUSA</a> <i>Orientation Week</i> ('O Week') in March, the company operated a branded marquee at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Otago" title="University of Otago">University of Otago</a>. The kiosk, staffed by two Clinique beauty consultants, promoted the store and Beauty department to new students. The marquee did not appear after 2012.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arthur_Barnett_logo.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/3a/Arthur_Barnett_logo.png/250px-Arthur_Barnett_logo.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="106" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/3/3a/Arthur_Barnett_logo.png 1.5x" data-file-width="328" data-file-height="139" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Arthur_Barnett_logo.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The former Arthur Barnett logo, used until 2013</div></div></div>
<p>In late 2012, Arthur Barnett began using a redesigned logo in their advertising. The new logo uses a lower case sans serif font, with a capitalised subtitle 'the department store'.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> <i>Absolutely Arthur Barnett, Absolutely Right</i> is still used on radio advertising. Early 2013 saw the company launch online shopping.
</p><p>On 16 April 2013 Arthur Barnett held an event 'Fashion and Food with Peta Mathias' hosted by celebrity <a href="/wiki/Peta_Mathias" title="Peta Mathias">Peta Mathias</a> at the recently-reopened <a href="/wiki/Toit%C5%AB_Otago_Settlers_Museum" title="Toitū Otago Settlers Museum">Toitū Otago Settlers Museum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> Janine Tindall-Morice commented "This event signals Arthur Barnett's desire to engage with our female customers in a fresh and dynamic new way."<sup id="cite_ref-ODTPeta_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODTPeta-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> 
In August 2013, the store launched a <a href="/wiki/Loyalty_programme" class="mw-redirect" title="Loyalty programme">loyalty programme</a>, 'Arthur Barnett REWARDS'.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The company followed up their Peta Mathias-hosted event in October with 'Fashion in the Chapel' hosted by model <a href="/wiki/Rachel_Hunter" title="Rachel Hunter">Rachel Hunter</a> at the <a href="/wiki/John_McGlashan_College" title="John McGlashan College">John McGlashan College</a> chapel. The event launched the store's spring and summer fashion collections.<sup id="cite_ref-ABEventRachel_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABEventRachel-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Departments">Departments</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Barnett_Ltd&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Departments">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Arthur Barnett held 14 departments<sup id="cite_ref-BrownBear_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BrownBear-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> across the ground and lower floors of the Meridian. Departments include Beauty; Lingerie; Men's Fashion (or Menswear); Women's Fashion (or Ladies' Wear); Lifestyle Apparel, Accessories (&amp; Hosiery); Children's Fashion; Luggage; Casual Living (or Homeware), from late 2011 with dedicated concept areas for Citta Design<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> and French Country; Home Linens; <a href="/wiki/Small_appliance" title="Small appliance">Small appliances</a>; Furnishings; and Schoolwear.<sup id="cite_ref-BrownBear_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BrownBear-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> Additionally, Reception and the Arthur Barnett Café were located on the lower level. Within the Home Linens department is the Wallace Cotton 'concession'.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Beauty">Beauty</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Barnett_Ltd&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Beauty">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The well-established <a href="/wiki/Cosmetics" title="Cosmetics">Beauty</a> department was the largest and most comprehensive south of Christchurch. <a href="/wiki/Cosmetics#Makeup_types" title="Cosmetics">Makeup</a> and <a href="/wiki/Skincare_products" class="mw-redirect" title="Skincare products">skincare</a> are available at serviced cosmetics counters for <a href="/wiki/Make-up_Art_Cosmetics" class="mw-redirect" title="Make-up Art Cosmetics">M·A·C</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yves_Saint_Laurent_(brand)" title="Yves Saint Laurent (brand)">Yves Saint Laurent</a>, and most recently, <a href="/wiki/Jurlique" title="Jurlique">Jurlique</a> (exclusive in the South Island), all exclusive to Arthur Barnett in <a href="/wiki/Otago" title="Otago">Otago</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southland_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Southland Region">Southland</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Perfume" title="Perfume">Fine Fragrance</a> counter is the largest in Dunedin.
Arthur Barnett formerly housed Dunedin's only Smashbox counter. In early-mid-2009, Smashbox was relocated to new rival <a href="/wiki/Pharmacybrands#Life_Pharmacy" class="mw-redirect" title="Pharmacybrands">Life Pharmacy</a>, in the new <a href="/wiki/Meridian_Mall,_Dunedin#Golden_Centre_Mall_and_Wall_Street" title="Meridian Mall, Dunedin">Wall Street Mall</a> nearby. Other former beauty counters include <a href="/wiki/Christian_Dior_S.A." class="mw-redirect" title="Christian Dior S.A.">Christian Dior</a>, and, until the brand's withdrawal from the New Zealand market in mid-2009, <a href="/wiki/Origins_(cosmetics)" title="Origins (cosmetics)">Origins</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-docstoc_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-docstoc-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arthur_Barnett_Entrance_Meridian_Lower_Level_2013.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Arthur_Barnett_Entrance_Meridian_Lower_Level_2013.jpg/300px-Arthur_Barnett_Entrance_Meridian_Lower_Level_2013.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Arthur_Barnett_Entrance_Meridian_Lower_Level_2013.jpg/450px-Arthur_Barnett_Entrance_Meridian_Lower_Level_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Arthur_Barnett_Entrance_Meridian_Lower_Level_2013.jpg/600px-Arthur_Barnett_Entrance_Meridian_Lower_Level_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1613" data-file-height="892" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Arthur_Barnett_Entrance_Meridian_Lower_Level_2013.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Arthur Barnett Lower Level entrance circa 2014</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Former_Departments">Former Departments</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Barnett_Ltd&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Former Departments">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Former departments include <a href="/wiki/Consumer_electronics" title="Consumer electronics">Electronics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Major_appliance" title="Major appliance">Large Appliances/Whiteware</a> featuring <a href="/wiki/Fisher_%26_Paykel" title="Fisher &amp; Paykel">Fisher &amp; Paykel</a>. From 2007, these departments were branded as the 'store-within-a-store', '100% Arthur Barnett' under the New Zealand <i>100% Electrical</i> franchise.<sup id="cite_ref-2009100cat_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2009100cat-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> 100% and its product areas were removed in mid-2010, with only Small Appliances retained as an independent department.
Also in 2007,<sup id="cite_ref-docstoc_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-docstoc-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> space was made within the Casual Living department for the <i>nest</i> [sic] homeware concept store<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> as a separate 'store-within-a-store'.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> The entire <i>nest</i> [sic] franchise collapsed into receivership in October 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup>
In mid-2010, the lower level of the Meridian Mall was reconfigured, considerably decreasing the store's floor space in what was originally its own mall.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id=".22Can.27t_stop.22"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="&quot;Can't_stop&quot;">"Can't stop"</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Barnett_Ltd&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: &quot;Can&#039;t stop&quot;">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_advertising_sign_%22Can%27t_Stop%22.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/The_advertising_sign_%22Can%27t_Stop%22.jpg/200px-The_advertising_sign_%22Can%27t_Stop%22.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/The_advertising_sign_%22Can%27t_Stop%22.jpg/300px-The_advertising_sign_%22Can%27t_Stop%22.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/The_advertising_sign_%22Can%27t_Stop%22.jpg/400px-The_advertising_sign_%22Can%27t_Stop%22.jpg 2x" data-file-width="515" data-file-height="420" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_advertising_sign_%22Can%27t_Stop%22.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>"Can't Stop"</div></div></div>
<p>The advertising sign for Arthur Barnett is a prominent feature on the Dunedin skyline. Named <i>Can't Stop</i>, this neon sign features a small man (representing the firm's founder) trying to control a large horse, possibly a <a href="/wiki/Clydesdale_horse" title="Clydesdale horse">Clydesdale</a>.
</p><p>The sign was designed by the New Zealand artist Heber Thompson for the 1924 Arthur Barnett building (designed by <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Anscombe" title="Edmund Anscombe">Edmund Anscombe</a>) which until 1995 stood on the site now occupied by the Meridian Mall. The sign still remains despite the change in ownership of the Meridian.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Ownership">Ownership</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Barnett_Ltd&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Ownership">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Arthur Barnett was listed on the New Zealand stock exchange until a NZ$9.5&#160;million internal takeover by company directors Julian Smith and Trevor Scott took the company private in 2002 through their company Belwash Holdings Ltd.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Barnett_Ltd&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<li><a href="/wiki/Kirkcaldie_%26_Stains" title="Kirkcaldie &amp; Stains">Kirkcaldie &amp; Stains</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ballantynes" title="Ballantynes">Ballantynes</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Farmers_Trading_Company" title="Farmers Trading Company">Farmers</a></li></ul>

<p><b>Arts-based training</b> is a form of employee training.
</p>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="In_the_workplace">In the workplace</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arts-based_training&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: In the workplace">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In recent years, there has been growth in the use of arts programs by corporations to meet a wide range of employee training and organizational development needs. In the United States alone, more than 400 of the <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500">Fortune 500</a> corporations and countless smaller firms employ arts-based learning in participatory <a href="/wiki/Workshop" title="Workshop">workshops</a>, skill-based training programs, hands-on consultancies with business units, individual and team coaching, case studies in-action, and lecture/demonstrations at leadership conferences.  Companies use these various programs to foster creative thinking, promote the development of new leadership models, and strengthen employee skills in critical areas such as collaboration, conflict resolution, change management, presentation/public performance, and intercultural communication. This represents a dramatic shift in the boundaries that traditionally defined experiences relevant to the business world – a shift triggered by profound technological and social changes that have transformed the culture of business over the past decade.
</p><p>Arts-based training can be defined as employee or staff development <a href="/wiki/Training" title="Training">training</a> (such as team building, communication/listening skills) which is delivered using the <a href="/wiki/Arts" class="mw-redirect" title="Arts">arts</a> (music, visual art, drama etc.).  It is used in many sectors in <a href="/wiki/Business" title="Business">business</a> from <a href="/wiki/Solicitors" class="mw-redirect" title="Solicitors">solicitors</a> and <a href="/wiki/Law_firms" class="mw-redirect" title="Law firms">law firms</a>, to local councils and community-based organisations.  In the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> it began to be used in the 1990s, primarily in <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>, and has now spread through the country. In the United States, arts organizations like <a href="/wiki/Orpheus_Chamber_Orchestra" title="Orpheus Chamber Orchestra">Orpheus Chamber Orchestra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Second_City_Theatre" class="mw-redirect" title="Second City Theatre">Second City Theatre</a>, along with individual practitioners such as visual artist <a href="/wiki/Todd_Siler" title="Todd Siler">Todd Siler</a> and jazz musician <a href="/wiki/Michael_Gold" class="mw-redirect" title="Michael Gold">Michael Gold</a> pioneered this field at about the same time.  "Orchestrating Collaboration at Work"<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> by Arthur Van Gundy and Linda Naiman, published in 2003 was one of the first books published for practitioners in the field. In recent years, organisations all over the world have begun to adopt arts based learning.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Worldwide">Worldwide</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arts-based_training&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Worldwide">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lotte_Dars%C3%B8&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lotte Darsø (page does not exist)">Lotte Darsø</a>, author of <i>Artful Creation: Learning-Tales of Arts-in-Business</i> was the first to map the interplay between arts and business in Europe and North America.  The key questions asked in her research were: "In what ways can business learn from artists," "What can be learned?," and "What kind of learning takes place?" Darsø proposes two approaches for Arts-in-Business: the Arts applied as an instrument for teambuilding, communication training, leadership development, problem-solving and innovation; and the Arts integrated as a strategic process of organisational transformation. Steven Taylor and Donna Ladkin offered a model of four different processes, skills transfer, projective techniques, illustration of essence, and making, used in arts-based learning in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> Schuima's 2012 book, "The Value of Arts for Business"<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> provides a comprehensive review of the use of arts in business. 
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Organizations">Organizations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arts-based_training&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Organizations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p><a href="/wiki/Terry_McGraw" class="mw-redirect" title="Terry McGraw">Terry McGraw</a>, chairman and CEO of The <a href="/wiki/McGraw_Hill" class="mw-redirect" title="McGraw Hill">McGraw Hill</a> Companies, characterizes creativity as a "business imperative", and puts his companies’ successful experiences with arts-based learning in a broad strategic context of "surfacing creativity" through engagement with the arts.
</p>
<blockquote><p>Creativity is essential because it is at the heart of innovation, and innovation is a growth driver and, therefore, a business imperative. That is why, for several years, The McGraw-Hill companies has been using arts-based learning as a training tool in several key leadership initiatives...the arts have served as a complementary vehicle to more traditional learning approaches. They have helped to change attitudes by letting employees confront their assumptions in a nontraditional and non-intimidating environment....The results of using arts-based learning and training have been very positive for The McGraw-Hill Companies…Arts-based training is part of an overall strategy and commitment of the corporation to help 'surface' creativity 
—<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> </p></blockquote>
<p><a href="/wiki/Keith_Weed" title="Keith Weed">Keith Weed</a>, Chairman, <a href="/wiki/Lever_Faberg%C3%A9" class="mw-redirect" title="Lever Fabergé">Lever Fabergé</a> sees employee involvement as a key part of developing and sustaining an innovative and creative business. Catalyst, their internal arts and creativity program "brings artists and arts organisations into the business to motivate, inspire, challenge and unlock the potential of our staff, on both a professional and personal level. Artists and arts organisations come into the workplace to tackle specific business issues, from creative thinking to leadership styles and writing skills."
</p><p>In reviewing <i>The Art of Business: Make All Your Work a Work of Art</i> (Davis, 2005) Tom Peters commented:
</p>
<blockquote>
<p>The authors persuasively argue that we are entering an economy which will value—insist upon!—a new way of looking at value creation. They call it moving from an emphasis on "economic flow" (input-output) to "artistic flow." The altered nature of enterprise, the "four elements" of new business thinking: "See yourself as an artist." "See your work as a work of art." "See your customers as an audience." "See your competition as teachers."
</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Professor P Vijayakumar, Chairperson,Centre for Social and Organisational Leadership (C SOL) at Tata Institute of Social Sciences (TISS), Mumbai,India uses art as a teaching tool extensively in the Organisation Development and Change course for masters students states  "Art facilitates reflection. Reflective practice needs to be an integral part of any management education".<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arts-based_training&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.today/20070707142113/http://www.personneltoday.com/Articles/2004/01/01/22038/The+art+of+inspiration.htm">Article about arts-based training</a></li></ul></div>

<table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" class="fn org" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;background-color: LightBlue">Asbestos Records</th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Founded</th><td>1996<span style="display:none">&#160;(<span class="bday dtstart published updated">1996</span>)</span></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Founder</th><td class="agent">Matt Flood<br />Dave Leone</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Genre</th><td class="category">Ska, punk</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Country of origin</th><td><a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">US</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Official website</th><td><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.asbestosrecords.com">www<wbr />.asbestosrecords<wbr />.com</a></span></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Asbestos Records</b> is an American <a href="/wiki/Independent_record_label" title="Independent record label">independent record label</a> in <a href="/wiki/Stratford,_Connecticut" title="Stratford, Connecticut">Stratford, Connecticut</a>, United States, founded in 1996 by Pastor Matthew Flood of the Church of the Perpetual Brackstone. It was started as a vehicle to release albums and compilations for local bands, and to book DIY shows at the Newtown Teen Center.
</p><p>Over the next eight years, Asbestos Records released albums from notable CT bands, such as: <a href="/wiki/Slackjaw" class="mw-redirect" title="Slackjaw">Slackjaw</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grover_Dill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grover Dill (page does not exist)">Grover Dill</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=West_Beverly_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="West Beverly (band) (page does not exist)">West Beverly</a>, whose members went on to join bands such as <a href="/wiki/Dropkick_Murphys" title="Dropkick Murphys">Dropkick Murphys</a>, <a href="/wiki/In_Pieces" title="In Pieces">In Pieces</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Staring_Back&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Staring Back (page does not exist)">Staring Back</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Punchline_(band)" title="Punchline (band)">Punchline</a>.
</p><p>The label was also home of the first four album covers by cult Artist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rob_Dobi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rob Dobi (page does not exist)">Rob Dobi</a>, known for his parody send up of emo fashion <i>How to Dress Emo</i> and his clothing company <a href="/w/index.php?title=Full_Bleed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Full Bleed (page does not exist)">Full Bleed</a>.
</p><p>In 2007 the label began a project to reissue popular 3rd Wave Ska albums from defunct labels. This series of reissues included by artists including:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/The_Mighty_Mighty_Bosstones" title="The Mighty Mighty Bosstones">The Mighty Mighty Bosstones</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/The_Suicide_Machines" title="The Suicide Machines">The Suicide Machines</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/The_Slackers" title="The Slackers">The Slackers</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Spring_Heeled_Jack_U.S.A." class="mw-redirect" title="Spring Heeled Jack U.S.A.">Spring Heeled Jack U.S.A.</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/The_Toasters" title="The Toasters">The Toasters</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mustard_Plug" title="Mustard Plug">Mustard Plug</a></li></ul>
<p>and many more.
</p><p>In a joint effort between Asbestos Records, Chicago, IL's <a href="/wiki/Underground_Communiqu%C3%A9_Records" class="mw-redirect" title="Underground Communiqué Records">Underground Communiqué Records</a> and Ska Is Dead, the three started a Ska Is Dead 7" Subscription Series made up of six split 7" records. Each 7" featured two currently active ska bands. Series 1 has been completely released with Series 2 on the way.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The label has also been involved in reissuing the portion of <a href="/wiki/They_Might_Be_Giants" title="They Might Be Giants">They Might Be Giants</a>' discography that was originally released on <a href="/wiki/Elektra_Records" title="Elektra Records">Elektra Records</a>.
</p><p>The Asbestos Records website previously hosted a message board for music fans from the southern New England area, which is now defunct.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Current_artists">Current artists</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Asbestos_Records&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Current artists">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Andrew_Jackson_Jihad" class="mw-redirect" title="Andrew Jackson Jihad">Andrew Jackson Jihad</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Suburban_Legends" title="Suburban Legends">Suburban Legends</a></li>

<li>The Flaming Tsunamis</li>
<li>The Heat Machine</li>

<ul><li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.asbestosrecords.com/">Asbestos Records Official Site</a></li></ul></div>
~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">January 2019</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Solomon Adun Asemota</div><br /><div class="honorific-suffix" style="font-size: 77%; font-weight: normal; display:inline;"><a href="/wiki/Senior_Advocate_of_Nigeria" title="Senior Advocate of Nigeria">SAN</a></div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><span style="display:none"> (<span class="bday">1938-12-08</span>) </span>8 December 1938<span class="noprint ForceAgeToShow"> (age&#160;81)</span><br /><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace"><a href="/wiki/Benin_City" title="Benin City">Benin City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edo_State" title="Edo State">Edo State</a>, Nigeria</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Nationality</th><td class="category">Nigerian</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Other&#160;names</th><td class="nickname">Agbonfioroh</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Alma&#160;mater</th><td><a href="/wiki/University_of_Benin_(Nigeria)" title="University of Benin (Nigeria)">University of Benin</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Occupation</th><td class="role"><a href="/wiki/Lawyer" title="Lawyer">Lawyer</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Years&#160;active</th><td>1970-present</td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Spouse(s)</span></th><td>Irene Asemota</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Children</th><td>2</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Solomon Adun Asemota</b> <a href="/wiki/Senior_Advocate_of_Nigeria" title="Senior Advocate of Nigeria">SAN</a> (born 8 December 1938) is a <a href="/wiki/Nigerian" class="mw-redirect" title="Nigerian">Nigerian</a> <a href="/wiki/Lawyer" title="Lawyer">lawyer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_activists" class="mw-redirect" title="Human rights activists">human rights activist</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> He is the Founder and Principal Partner of the Law Firm of Solomon Asemota &amp; Co., (since 1970), Barristers and Solicitors, with offices in Benin City, Lagos, Port Harcourt, Abuja and London.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> He has written several publications dedicated towards effecting a change in the state of the Nation.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> He became a <a href="/wiki/Senior_Advocate_of_Nigeria" title="Senior Advocate of Nigeria">Senior Advocate of Nigeria</a> (SAN) in 1986.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> As the Nation Chairman of the National Christian Elders’ Forum (NCEF),<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> he has made a lot of strides regarding  <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">Democracy</a> and freedom for Christians in Nigeria.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Early_life_and_education"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Early life and education</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Career"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Career</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_and_education">Early life and education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solomon_Adun_Asemota&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life and education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Solomon Adun Asemota was born on December 8, 1937 in <a href="/wiki/Benin_City" title="Benin City">Benin City</a>, the capital of <a href="/wiki/Edo_State" title="Edo State">Edo State</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Southern Nigeria</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> His early formal education began in 1945 at St. Luke School, Jos before he completed his <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education" title="Secondary education">secondary school education</a> in 1948 at Immaculate Conception College, Benin City.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> He attended Southern Police College, Ikeja, Lagos (1959 - 1960) (Cadet Sub-Inspectors’ Course) before going to Wakefield Police College, Yorkshire, England in 1962 for Advanced Police Training and Scottish Police College, Kincardine Aloa, Scotland in 1969 for Senior Officers Training in organisation and management.
</p><p>He attended the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Lagos" title="University of Lagos">University of Lagos</a> between 1964 and 1969 where he obtained his Bachelor of Law (Honours) degree in 1969. In 1970, he was called to bar and became a barrister at Law after completing the <a href="/wiki/Nigerian_Law_School" title="Nigerian Law School">Nigerian Law School</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solomon_Adun_Asemota&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p><i><b>The Nigerian Police Force</b></i><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>He was enlisted into the Nigeria Police Force as a Cadet Sub-Inspector: Course No.6 in 1959. After training, was posted to Ikeja Province where he served first, as prosecutor, at the Chief Magistrate’s Court Ikeja, in Chief Magistrate Mason Begho’s Court. Later, he was a Course Officer, Man O’ War Bay in Victoria Cameroons, 1961. He then became a prosecutor, Chief Magistrate’s Court Sapele in Chief Magistrates Olayinka Odumosu and Sikiru Abina Courts, as they then were, 1961 before becoming Inspector, Administration then Second-in-Command Traffic Division, and later Crime Branch at Ikeja provincial Police Department, also in 1961.
</p><p>In 1962, he was promoted to the rank of an Assistant Superintendent of Police, and designated Chief Officer Local Government Police Ondo North (Comprising, Ekiti, Akoko and Owo Divisions which now constitute about half of Ondo State), where he performed duties of Divisional Police Officer, in charge of 800 L.S. Police men &amp; 26 Police Stations. He was seconded (for 6 months in 1963) to the United Nations Operation (ONUC) in the Congo now Zaire. He served in Leopoldville now Kinshasa and later Second-in-Command (Police) at Luluaburg now Katanga.
</p><p>He became the Aide-de-Camp to the First Governor of Midwest Region, Chief <a href="/wiki/Jereton_Mariere" title="Jereton Mariere">Jereton Mariere</a> 1963 - 1964. Later left for the Southern Police College Ikeja and became the Course Officer, Cadet Sub-Inspector Course and Sergeants Promotion Courses at the Advanced Training Wing. 1964 - 1966. One of his students <a href="/wiki/Ibrahim_Coomassie" title="Ibrahim Coomassie">Ibrahim Coomassie</a> later became the <a href="/wiki/Inspector_General_of_Police" class="mw-redirect" title="Inspector General of Police">Inspector General of Police</a>, while five others got to the rank of Assistant Inspector General of Police (AIGs).
</p><p>He was the Second-in-Command 1966 – 1968 at the National Bureau of the Interpol, Central C.I.D. Alagbon Close, <a href="/wiki/Ikoyi" title="Ikoyi">Ikoyi</a>, Lagos, and was, at one time, the Investigator attached to Tribunals of Inquiry into E.C.N. and the Ports Authority. He was promoted to the rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police and was a member of the Nigeria Police Officers Delegation to Interpol Conference in <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a> in 1967. He was later transferred to the Crime Division as Second-in-Command.
</p><p>In 1969, he was promoted to the rank of Superintendent and was appointed Officer-in Charge, Detective Training School, Ikoyi, Lagos.
</p><p>He resigned from the Nigeria Police Force in October 1970, to practice Law.
</p><p><i><b>Law</b></i>
</p><p>He was appointed Secretary to the <a href="/wiki/Nigerian_Bar_Association" title="Nigerian Bar Association">Nigerian Bar Association</a>, Benin Branch, 1974 - 1978. He became the National Treasurer, <a href="/wiki/Nigerian_Bar_Association" title="Nigerian Bar Association">Nigerian Bar Association</a>. 1978 - 1980 then Secretary, Finance Committee, Sixth Commonwealth Law Conference - 1980. He was a Member of the General Council of the Bar 1978 - 1984. He became a Visiting Lecturer for Courses in Civil Procedure at the Institute of Advanced Legal Studies - 1985.
</p><p>Then he was a Member of the Council of Legal Education 1979 - 1985. He became a Member, Disciplinary Committee, of the General Council of the Bar, 1990 to 1995 and Member, Legal Practitioners Privileges Committee 1991 - 1993 (the committee that confers the rank of Senior Advocate of Nigeria on Lawyers).
</p><p>He became a <a href="/wiki/Senior_Advocate_of_Nigeria" title="Senior Advocate of Nigeria">Senior Advocate of Nigeria</a> (SAN) in 1986.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>At various points in his career he represented Elf Petroleum Nigeria Ltd, Dumez Nigeria Ltd., Elf Oil Nig. Ltd., Bight Engineering Ltd., Life Flour Mill Ltd. Sapele, <a href="/wiki/Nigeria_Police_Force" title="Nigeria Police Force">Nigeria Police Force</a>,  State Security Services, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Benin_(Nigeria)" title="University of Benin (Nigeria)">University of Benin</a>, Oil Mineral producing Area Development Commission (OMPADEC).
</p><p>He was also the personal lawyer to General <a href="/wiki/Yakubu_Gowon" title="Yakubu Gowon">Yakubu Gowon</a>, whom he still represents till date. Other notable mentions include Hon. <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Aniagolu" title="Anthony Aniagolu">Anthony Aniagolu</a>, retired Justice of the Supreme Court, Alhaji <a href="/wiki/Shehu_Shagari" title="Shehu Shagari">Shehu Shagari</a>, former President of Nigeria, Justice Ovie-Whiskey, 1983 Chairman, FEDECO, <a href="/wiki/Sunday_Adewusi" title="Sunday Adewusi">Sunday Adewusi</a>, former <a href="/wiki/Inspector-General_of_Police" class="mw-redirect" title="Inspector-General of Police">Inspector-General of Police</a> at the Judicial Inquiry into the activities of the Defunct FEDECO. Acted for Alhaji <a href="/wiki/Abubakar_Rimi" title="Abubakar Rimi">Abubakar Rimi</a>, former Governor of Kano State and Chief <a href="/wiki/Jim_Nwobodo" title="Jim Nwobodo">Jim Nwobodo</a> former Governor of <a href="/wiki/Anambra" class="mw-redirect" title="Anambra">Anambra</a> State for their release from prison 1986.
</p><p>He is the Founder and Principal Partner of the Law Firm of Solomon Asemota &amp; Co., (since 1970), Barristers and Solicitors, with offices in <a href="/wiki/Benin_City" title="Benin City">Benin City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lagos" title="Lagos">Lagos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_Harcourt" title="Port Harcourt">Port Harcourt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abuja" title="Abuja">Abuja</a> and <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Recognition">Recognition</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solomon_Adun_Asemota&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Recognition">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<table class="box-BLP_unsourced_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-BLP_unsourced" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section of a <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Biographies_of_living_persons" title="Wikipedia:Biographies of living persons">biography of a living person</a> <b>does not <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">include</a> any <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">references or sources</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help by adding <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources">reliable sources</a>. Contentious material about living people that is unsourced or poorly sourced <b>must be removed immediately</b>.<br /><small><span class="plainlinks"><i>Find sources:</i>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?as_eq=wikipedia&amp;q=%22Solomon+Adun+Asemota%22">"Solomon Adun Asemota"</a>&#160;–&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbm=nws&amp;q=%22Solomon+Adun+Asemota%22+-wikipedia">news</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?&amp;q=%22Solomon+Adun+Asemota%22+site:news.google.com/newspapers&amp;source=newspapers">newspapers</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbs=bks:1&amp;q=%22Solomon+Adun+Asemota%22+-wikipedia">books</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22Solomon+Adun+Asemota%22">scholar</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/action/doBasicSearch?Query=%22Solomon+Adun+Asemota%22&amp;acc=on&amp;wc=on">JSTOR</a></span></small></span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">April 2019</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul><li>Independence medal 1960.</li>
<li>ONUC Medal (Congo) 1962.</li>
<li>Republican Medal 1963.</li>
<li>Civil War Medal 1970.</li></ul>
<p><i><b>Honours</b></i>
</p>
<ul><li>Jubilee Alumnus Award, Law Faculty, University of Lagos for outstanding achievement in the society 1987.</li>
<li>Distinguished Merit Award, Edo State University, Ekpoma 1996.</li>
<li>CAN Merit Award November 1999.</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Publications">Publications</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Solomon_Adun_Asemota&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Publications">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>“Nigerian’s Securities and Exchange Commission Act 1979” (In the International Business Lawyer; Journal of the Section on Business Law of the International Bar Association, October, 1981 Vol.9);</li>
<li>“Free and Fair Election: Key to stability of party government in Nigeria” 4 and 5 above are published in “Current State of Affairs” an International Features Magazine June and October Editions 1992;</li>
<li>A Chapter in the Book - policing Nigeria Past, Present and Future. Policing under Civilian and Military Administrations 1993;</li>
<li>The struggle for Justice – 2001 publication;<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<p>nt of Nigeria at the meeting of the Representatives of the Laity, Archdiocese of Lagos at IWOPIN on Friday July 14, 2006;
</p>
<ul><li>Ojukwu and the Ethnic Nationalities Movement of Nigeria by Solomon Asemota SAN November 28, 2011;<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Constitutional Development Options for Sustainable Development in Nigeria, January 2017;<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>

<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">April 2020</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</p>
<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Syeda Ummehani Ashraf</div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><span style="display:none"> (<span class="bday">1949-12-26</span>) </span>26 December 1949<span class="noprint ForceAgeToShow"> (age&#160;70)</span><br /><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace">Kichaucha Sharif, Uttar Pradesh, India</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Nationality</th><td class="category"><a href="/wiki/India" title="India">Indian</a></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center">Academic background</th></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center">Academic work</th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Era</th><td>contemporary</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Discipline</th><td><a href="/wiki/Urdu_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Urdu language">Urdu language</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Institutions</th><td><a href="/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University" title="Aligarh Muslim University">Aligarh Muslim University</a>
  </td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background: #9BE89B; color: #000000;">Personal</th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Religion</th><td class="category"><a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a></td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Main interests</th><td><a href="/wiki/Qasida" title="Qasida">Urdu Qaseeda</a></td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Syeda Ummehani Ashraf</b><sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> is a senior Professor of <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a> at <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_College,_Aligarh" class="mw-redirect" title="Women&#39;s College, Aligarh">Women's College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University" title="Aligarh Muslim University">Aligarh Muslim University</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> She is the wife of Urdu poet and critic, <a href="/wiki/Syed_Amin_Ashraf" title="Syed Amin Ashraf">Syed Amin Ashraf</a>, who was a faculty member at the Department of English at the same university. The couple belongs to the family of <a href="/wiki/Hashemite" class="mw-redirect" title="Hashemite">Hashemite</a> Syeds of <a href="/wiki/Ashrafpur_Kichhauchha" title="Ashrafpur Kichhauchha">Kichhauchha Sharif</a> (known as the Ashrafi family). She is the first lady of the Ashrafi <a href="/wiki/Clan" title="Clan">clan</a> to earn a doctorate degree and a professorship in a university. Her PhD thesis title was <i>Shumaili Hind KE Qasaid Ki Farhang</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>  She has set a precedent for women of her clan to aspire for higher education.  She has written five books and a number of research articles and short stories.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biography">Biography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Syeda_Ummehani_Ashraf&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Biography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Ummehani Ashraf was born to Syed Aale Hasan and Syeda Khatoon on 26 December 1949 at Kichaucha Sharif, <a href="/wiki/Ambedkar_Nagar_District" class="mw-redirect" title="Ambedkar Nagar District">Ambedkar Nagar District</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>. Ummehani Ashraf is the third child out of five siblings.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Spouse">Spouse</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Syeda_Ummehani_Ashraf&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Spouse">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Ummehani Ashraf is married to Syed Amin Ashraf who is an <a href="/wiki/Ghazal" title="Ghazal">Urdu Ghazal</a> poet and critic. He earned his PhD in <a href="/wiki/English_Literature" class="mw-redirect" title="English Literature">English Literature</a> from <a href="/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University" title="Aligarh Muslim University">Aligarh Muslim University</a> and later served in the same Department. He has produced three poetic anthologies and a critical collection of essays in the form of a book. Several academic awards have been conferred on his poetic anthologies and numerous critical articles and books have come up extolling his poetic artistry.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Syeda_Ummehani_Ashraf&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Ummehani Ashraf did her primary schooling at the Village <a href="/wiki/Madrasa" title="Madrasa">madrasa</a> at Kichaucha Shariff. She passed High School as a private candidate in 1966. Encouraged and supported by her husband she went to obtain her B.A.(1973), M.A. (1975), and PhD (1981) degrees from <a href="/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University" title="Aligarh Muslim University">Aligarh Muslim University</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Professional_career">Professional career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Syeda_Ummehani_Ashraf&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Professional career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Soon after completing her PhD in 1986, she was appointed lecturer in Urdu in Women's College of her alma mater. From there she rose to the position of professor of Urdu in 2002.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Works">Works</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Syeda_Ummehani_Ashraf&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Works">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p><b>Books</b>
</p>
<ol><li>A study of Classicism and Romanism in Urdu, Publisher Educational Book House, Shamshad Market, Aligarh</li>
<li>Urdu Qaseeda Nigari, Publisher Educational Book House, Shamshad Market, Aligarh</li>
<li>Urdu Marsia Nigari, Publisher Educational Book House, Shamshad Market, Aligarh</li>
<li>A sociological study of Urdu Qaseeda, Publisher Educational Book House, Shamshad Market, Aligarh</li>
<li>A farhang of Urdu Qaseedas as written in North India, Publisher Educational Book House, Shamshad Market, Aligarh</li></ol>
<p><b>Published articles</b>
</p>
<ol><li>A glance at the creative journey of Iqbal ( Fikro Nazar, December 2008)</li>
<li>Iqbal love of Prophet (Mah Noor, Delhi, January 2009)</li>
<li>A study of Akhtarul Iman'sa poem, Ek Larka' ( Nai Kitab, Delhi, Volume:6)</li>
<li>An analysis of Quratul Ain’s, ‘Kohe Damavand’ (Ats Faculty Journal, 2009)</li>
<li>An analysis ‘Peetal ka Ghanta’ by Q. Haidar Published in Nai Kitab, Delhi, April 2009</li>
<li>A study of ‘Shahre Afsoas by Intizar Husain’ published in Tadrees Nama, Delhi, July 2009</li></ol>

<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Mai Atafo</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Mai_Atafo_at_AMVCA_2020.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Mai Atafo at AMVCA 2020.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Mai_Atafo_at_AMVCA_2020.jpg/220px-Mai_Atafo_at_AMVCA_2020.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="345" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Mai_Atafo_at_AMVCA_2020.jpg/330px-Mai_Atafo_at_AMVCA_2020.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Mai_Atafo_at_AMVCA_2020.jpg/440px-Mai_Atafo_at_AMVCA_2020.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1651" data-file-height="2588" /></a><div>Mai Atafo at <a href="/wiki/2020_Africa_Magic_Viewers_Choice_Awards" title="2020 Africa Magic Viewers Choice Awards">2020 Africa Magic Viewers Choice Awards</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace">Ile-Ife, Osun</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Alma&#160;mater</th><td><a href="/w/index.php?title=City_University_UK&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="City University UK (page does not exist)">City University UK</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Occupation</th><td class="role">tailor</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Mai Atafo</b> is a Nigerian fashion tailor, noted for his brand, Mai Atafo.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>. He attended the Leeds-based Savile Row Academy to train as a tailor.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">Personal life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mai_Atafo&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Personal life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Atafo was born in <a href="/wiki/Ile-Ife" class="mw-redirect" title="Ile-Ife">Ile-Ife</a>, Osun State to a family of 9 children.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> He is married to Christine Atafo. They have one child.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mai_Atafo&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Atafo, upon returning from the United Kingdom in 2002 worked in various positions in the marketing department at <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_American_Tobacco_Nigeria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British American Tobacco Nigeria (page does not exist)">British American Tobacco Nigeria</a>. In 2006 he left to <a href="/wiki/Guinness_Nigeria" title="Guinness Nigeria">Guinness Nigeria</a> where he sat as Brand Manager as of his resignation in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Before leaving <a href="/wiki/Guinness_Nigeria" title="Guinness Nigeria">Guinness Nigeria</a>, Atafo started the clothing label "Mai Atafo Inspired",<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> that gained attention from celebrities such as <a href="/wiki/Omowunmi_Akinnifesi" title="Omowunmi Akinnifesi">Omowunmi Akinnifesi</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Banky_W" class="mw-redirect" title="Banky W">Banky W</a>, <a href="/wiki/IK_Osakioduwa" title="IK Osakioduwa">IK Osakioduwa</a> and others. He sat briefly as Fashion Editor for Genevieve Magazine.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2011, Mai Atafo Inspired launched a wedding line called "Weddings by Mai".<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Afato is the Creative Director of Mai Atafo Inspired. He is Strategy Director for the advertising agency Firehouse Group, and is acted as [[emcee] for the Miss Nigeria Pageant in 2010. Atafo heads the Future Awards Central working committee.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>He headed Spice TV for six months and voiced commercials for <b>Glo</b>, a multi-communication network.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_and_nominations">Awards and nominations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mai_Atafo&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Awards and nominations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<table class="box-More_citations_needed_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mai_Atafo&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">September 2020</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Atafo has been recognized around Africa for his contributions to fashion design and style.
</p>
<ul><li>2009 City People Fashion and Style, Hottest New Male Designer</li>
<li>2010 City People Fashion and Style, Special Recognition.</li>
<li>2010 Mode Men Fashion Designer of the Year</li>
<li>2010 Mode Men, Best Dressed Man of the Year</li>
<li>2010 FAB Magazine, Fashion Brand of the Year</li>
<li>2010 Covenant University "Redefining Fashion Contribution"</li>
<li>2011 Allure, Most Stylish Man of the Year</li>
<li>2011 Thisday Style, Best Dressed Man</li>
<li>2013 GLITZ, Designer of the year<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>2015 Heineken Lagos Fashion and Design Week, Menswear Designer of the Year <sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Abryanz_Style_and_Fashion_Awards_2016" title="Abryanz Style and Fashion Awards 2016">2016</a> - <a href="/wiki/Abryanz_Style_and_Fashion_Awards_(ASFAs)" title="Abryanz Style and Fashion Awards (ASFAs)">Abryanz Style and Fashion Awards</a>, Fashion Designer of the year - West Africa</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Abryanz_Style_and_Fashion_Awards_2017" title="Abryanz Style and Fashion Awards 2017">2017</a> - <a href="/wiki/Abryanz_Style_and_Fashion_Awards_(ASFAs)" title="Abryanz Style and Fashion Awards (ASFAs)">Abryanz Style and Fashion Awards</a> Lifestyle/Style Fashion Icon Achievement Award<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-13">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://connectnigeria.com/articles/2017/12/fashion-designer-mai-atafo-wins-lifetime-style-and-fashion-icon-achievement/">"Fashion Designer, Mai Atafo Wins Lifetime Style and Fashion Icon Achievement"</a>. <i>Connect Nigeria</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Palace</i>&#160;<span style="font-size:97%;">(1972)</span></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Influences</th><td>Oktay Aslanapa</td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Nurhan Atasoy</b> (born 12 February 1934) is a <a href="/wiki/Turkish_women_in_academics" title="Turkish women in academics">Turkish art historian</a>. She specializes in history of Ottoman<sup id="cite_ref-Ådahl2006_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ådahl2006-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_art" title="Islamic art">Islamic art</a>. She served as a Department Chairman in the Department of Fine Arts, Archeology and Art History at <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_University" title="Istanbul University">Istanbul University</a> until 1999 and is now a resident scholar of the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Cultural_Foundation" title="Turkish Cultural Foundation">Turkish Cultural Foundation</a>. Since 2012 she sits as a permanent guest on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tarihin_Arka_Odas%C4%B1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tarihin Arka Odası (page does not exist)">Tarihin Arka Odası</a>, a TV program dedicated to history, with journalist <a href="/wiki/Murat_Bardak%C3%A7%C4%B1" title="Murat Bardakçı">Murat Bardakçı</a> and historian <a href="/wiki/Erhan_Afyoncu" title="Erhan Afyoncu">Erhan Afyoncu</a>.
</p><p>The author of over 120 books and publications, amongst them are <i>Iznik: Ottoman Pottery of Turkey</i> with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Julian_Raby&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Julian Raby (page does not exist)">Julian Raby</a> (1989), <i>The Art of Islam</i>, (with <a href="/wiki/Afif_Bahnassi" title="Afif Bahnassi">Afif Bahnassi</a>), (1990);  <i>1582 Surname-i Hümayun: An Imperial Celebration</i> (1997), <i>Otağı Hümayun: The Ottoman Imperial Tent Complex</i> (2000) and <i>IPEK: Imperial Ottoman Silks and Velvets</i> (2001), and <i>Impressions of Ottoman Culture in Europe: 1453-1699</i> (2012).<sup id="cite_ref-TCF_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TCF-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> She is the recipient of the Turkish <a href="/w/index.php?title=State_Award_for_Superior_Achievement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="State Award for Superior Achievement (page does not exist)">State Award for Superior Achievement</a> and numerous international awards for her achievements in the field of Islamic art history.<sup id="cite_ref-TCF_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TCF-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<p>•-This book was enlarged and re-published in 2012.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nurhan_Atasoy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">

<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">May 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Donald Attig</b> (born February 2, 1936 in <a href="/wiki/Pontiac,_Illinois" title="Pontiac, Illinois">Pontiac, Illinois</a>) is an inventor, boat designer, entrepreneur, yachtsman and adventurer.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886049878">.mw-parser-output .tocright{float:right;clear:right;width:auto;background:none;padding:.5em 0 .8em 1.4em;margin-bottom:.5em}.mw-parser-output .tocright-clear-left{clear:left}.mw-parser-output .tocright-clear-both{clear:both}.mw-parser-output .tocright-clear-none{clear:none}</style><div class="tocright" style=""><div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
