<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biography">Biography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Attig&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Biography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Attig attended St. Mary’s Grade School, <a href="/wiki/Pontiac_Township_High_School" title="Pontiac Township High School">Pontiac Township High School</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Flanagan,_Illinois" title="Flanagan, Illinois">Flanagan, Illinois</a> High School, and <a href="/wiki/Eureka_College" title="Eureka College">Eureka College</a>. He held a number of different jobs over the years.
</p><p>
While still in his twenties, Attig retired the first time to carry out a record setting voyage in a power cruiser, which he designed and built. Using it he became the first man from the area to make a water journey from <a href="/wiki/Seneca,_Illinois" title="Seneca, Illinois">Seneca, Illinois</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Illinois_River" title="Illinois River">Illinois River</a> to <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans" title="New Orleans">New Orleans</a>, the terminus of the <a href="/wiki/Mississippi_River" title="Mississippi River">Mississippi River</a>. From New Orleans, he moved around the Gulf Coast, eventually crossing the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico" title="Gulf of Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a> to <a href="/wiki/St._Petersburg,_Florida" title="St. Petersburg, Florida">St. Petersburg, Florida</a> and cruised for a period on the yacht.  </p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Schooner_under_full_sail_JPEG.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Schooner_under_full_sail_JPEG.JPG/220px-Schooner_under_full_sail_JPEG.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="215" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Schooner_under_full_sail_JPEG.JPG/330px-Schooner_under_full_sail_JPEG.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Schooner_under_full_sail_JPEG.JPG/440px-Schooner_under_full_sail_JPEG.JPG 2x" data-file-width="921" data-file-height="900" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Schooner_under_full_sail_JPEG.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Attig's Schooner under full sail</div></div></div>
<p>Donald Attig established three sets of World Class Benchmark records in the Adventure and Endurance Challenge categories. In the late sixties, he developed a system for assembly line production of panelized, all molded homes.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> Attig also created a Research Foundation, which he funded from his own resources.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Toward_the_International_Benchmark_records">Toward the International Benchmark records</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Attig&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Toward the International Benchmark records">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 1968, by permission of the Honorable Brian O’Kelly, he became the first person to build a 3 mast sailing ship from the keel up in the US under the Irish Flag.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> For ten years Attig and his family lived and voyaged on the 3 mast sailing ship. Attig skippered the vessel over 5,000 miles on rivers and the inland waterways system before putting out to sea.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>  During this 5,000 mile voyage on inland waterways, Attig developed and honed the skills which decades later would carry him through the World Class Benchmark record establishing efforts.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> Attig sailed with his wife and new born son to <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> in 1977 and traveled to many other places.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> Two of his five children, Omar Brendan and John Paul, were born on the vessel.  For years, Attig and his son Omar operated free sailing excursions, on the Schooner, for at risk youth, with children of any religion from <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> during the troubles, and others in need.  After his eldest son, Omar, who had been born on the ship, was involved in a fatal car crash, Attig turned the ship over to the VEC Youth Reach Program.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Benchmark_Records_in_his_seventies">Benchmark Records in his seventies</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Attig&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Benchmark Records in his seventies">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Between the ages of 71 and 73 he was involved in establishing International Benchmark records in the fields of Endurance Challenge and Adventure Challenge:
</p><p>In 2007, he organized and co-crewed in the first transit of the Shannon Navigation and beyond to the Seaport of <a href="/wiki/Tarbert,_County_Kerry" title="Tarbert, County Kerry">Tarbert, County Kerry</a>, in a live aboard boat without an engine. Experienced boaters who understood the hazards involved in such a project thought it impossible. The <a href="/wiki/River_Shannon" title="River Shannon">River Shannon</a> is the longest river in Ireland.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2012)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>In 2008, he traveled the entire Shannon Navigation and beyond to the Seaport of <a href="/wiki/Foynes" title="Foynes">Foynes</a>, County Limerick, using the same live aboard boat without an engine.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2012)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>In 2008, he was the first person to transit the entire <a href="/wiki/River_Erne" title="River Erne">River Erne</a> Navigation in a live aboard boat without an engine.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2012)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>These three distinct and different World Class Benchmark establishing record efforts, when combined, involved moving over one ton of live aboard boat and gear over 600 miles (almost 1,000 kilometers) without an engine. Most of the distance was accomplished by <a href="/wiki/Coastal_and_offshore_rowing" title="Coastal and offshore rowing">rowing</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>Additional Benchmark records he established include the total of miles transited in the combined efforts—a total of 600+ miles (960+ kilometers) over the bottom in the three contiguous years in an engineless live aboard boat. Also each record benchmark established over the three years has the additional claim of having a person over 70 involved in its establishment.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2012)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Shannon_Benchmark_records">Shannon Benchmark records</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Attig&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Shannon Benchmark records">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The engineless transit, from the start of the Shannon Navigation at the Inishmagrath marker, on <a href="/wiki/Lough_Allen" title="Lough Allen">Lough Allen</a>, in County Leitrim  to the end of Shannon Navigation at <a href="/wiki/Killaloe,_County_Clare" title="Killaloe, County Clare">Killaloe, County Clare</a> and beyond to the Port of Tarbot in the Sea Estuary, required dealing with 33 bridges, 6 locks, and nine lakes, without mechanical power.  One of the locks, <a href="/wiki/Ardnacrusha_(village)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ardnacrusha (village)">Ardnacrusha</a> has a descent of over 100 feet (30&#160;m).<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> Guides warn boaters, using large full powered cruisers, to only cross the larger lakes in company.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> The very strong flow through many of the bridges often throws full powered boats out of control, causing them to smash into the bridge piers. For example, the water flow through <a href="/wiki/Killaloe_Bridge" title="Killaloe Bridge">Killaloe Bridge</a> can be 600 to 700 Tonnes per second.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> This hazard of losing control in or approaching bridges can result in major damage and an occasional sinking.  Each of the 4 turbines at the <a href="/wiki/Ardnacrusha_power_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Ardnacrusha power plant">Ardnacrusha</a> power station, which is running, dumps 100 tons of water per second into the narrow, constricted, tail race.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>  This maelstrom must be negotiated for the transit to the estuary. Powerboats are advised to remain in the center of the tail race and maintain high power.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> The prevailing wind is from the south west and funnels up the Shannon channel. This is a great impediment to an un-powered cabin boat proceeding down stream.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="2007_Benchmark">2007 Benchmark</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Attig&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: 2007 Benchmark">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:CHALLENGE_BOAT_AT_KILLALOE.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/CHALLENGE_BOAT_AT_KILLALOE.JPG/220px-CHALLENGE_BOAT_AT_KILLALOE.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/CHALLENGE_BOAT_AT_KILLALOE.JPG/330px-CHALLENGE_BOAT_AT_KILLALOE.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/CHALLENGE_BOAT_AT_KILLALOE.JPG/440px-CHALLENGE_BOAT_AT_KILLALOE.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="804" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:CHALLENGE_BOAT_AT_KILLALOE.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Berths for a family, enclosed toilet room, cast iron heating stove – not your standard rowboat!</div></div></div><p> During the 2007 record establishing effort, Jack Donovan of <a href="/wiki/Ballincollig" title="Ballincollig">Ballincollig</a>, Co. Cork (who was 60 at the time and had been living with full blown <a href="/wiki/Multiple_sclerosis" title="Multiple sclerosis">Multiple sclerosis</a> for over 2 decades) and Donnacha <sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> rowed well over 90% of the time. Most of that was in a zig-zag pattern due to the wind resistance of the large topside area and almost flat box type bow of the one ton plus of live-aboard boat and gear.  When they reached Tarbert their <a href="/wiki/Satellite_navigation" title="Satellite navigation">Satellite navigation</a> device indicated that the pair had traveled more than 268 miles (431&#160;km).
</p><h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Shannon_navigation_attempt">Shannon navigation attempt</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Attig&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Shannon navigation attempt">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Donald Attig and Jack Donovan started their benchmark establishing effort on June 29, 2007 at Cormongan beach on <a href="/wiki/Lough_Allen" title="Lough Allen">Lough Allen</a> at 10 A.M. They rowed from that spot to the Inismagrath "end of navigation" marker at the top of Lough Allen to begin the first ever attempt to make an engineless transit of the Shannon in a boat equipped with live aboard accommodations. Mr. Stephan Haeni, a Swiss National living at Cleighran More, witnessed their arrival and departure at the Inismagrath Marker. They completed the Shannon Navigation on Saturday, July 28, 2007, entering the Killaloe canal at 4:20 P.M. At that point, the official Shannon Navigation had been transited in and engineless live-aboard boat.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Beyond_the_Shannon_navigation">Beyond the Shannon navigation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Attig&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Beyond the Shannon navigation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Irish_Coast_Guard" title="Irish Coast Guard">Irish Coast Guard</a> attempted to dissuade the pair from continuing on past the end of navigation marker at the Killaloe Bridge. Jack and Donald left the Killaloe Canal at 4:20 P.M. on July 28, 2007. They dropped anchor in the bay of the sea port of Tarbert, <a href="/wiki/County_Kerry" title="County Kerry">County Kerry</a> at 8 P.M. on August 8, establishing the final Benchmark records of their effort. <a href="/wiki/Senior_Citizens" class="mw-redirect" title="Senior Citizens">Senior Citizens</a> Jack Donovan and Donald Attig were the first crew to transit the entire <a href="/wiki/River_Shannon" title="River Shannon">River Shannon</a> Navigation and beyond in an engineless boat with full live aboard capability.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup>  Their record setting efforts were carried out during the wettest summer on the Shannon since 1947 and 48. The vessel and gear which they used in the benchmark record establishing effort weighed over one ton.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="2008_Single-handed_feat">2008 Single-handed feat</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Attig&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: 2008 Single-handed feat">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Donald Attig established more Adventure Challenge and Endurance Challenge records by making the same basic trip <a href="/wiki/Single-handed_sailing" title="Single-handed sailing">single handed</a> in the same vessel, Omar’s River Bird. RTÉ's Nationwide produced a segment about Shannon Challenge 2008 which aired June 6, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>At 1:30 A.M. June 26, Donald Attig started at Cormongan beach on Lough Allen, in County Leitrim. He was driven back by the wind and had to anchor 30 metres (98&#160;ft) from the beach. It was over two days before he could lift anchor and start for the marker at Inismagrath. At 12:05 A.M. on August 16, 2008, he reached the Seaport of <a href="/wiki/Foynes" title="Foynes">Foynes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="2009_More_Benchmark_Records">2009 More Benchmark Records</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Attig&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: 2009 More Benchmark Records">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:After_600_miles.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/After_600_miles.JPG/220px-After_600_miles.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/After_600_miles.JPG/330px-After_600_miles.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/After_600_miles.JPG/440px-After_600_miles.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="900" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:After_600_miles.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Belleek and the finish of 960+ kilometers (600+ miles) without an engine in 3 years</div></div></div><p> Donald Attig became the first person to complete the entire <a href="/wiki/River_Erne" title="River Erne">River Erne</a> Navigation single-handed in an engineless live aboard boat<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>. He used the same boat for this effort as was used in 2007 and 2008. There are enough hazards on the Erne Navigation to make passage in an engineless boat large enough to be live aboard a world class challenge<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>. The Northern Ireland tourist site warns that Upper Lough Erne is a shallow maze and that waves on Lower Lough Erne can reach open-sea dimensions.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup> Violent wind shears from the cliffs of Mago can create grave difficulties for full powered cruisers at any time. All this combines to create a formidable challenge for an engineless boat that has the windage connected with live-aboard accommodations. This Benchmark Record Establishing effort started at <a href="/wiki/Belturbet" title="Belturbet">Belturbet</a>, Co Cavan August 6, at 6:30 P.M.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> It was attended by a number of dignitaries. The effort was completed Sunday August 30 at 7:45 P.M. at the Public dock in <a href="/wiki/Belleek,_County_Fermanagh" title="Belleek, County Fermanagh">Belleek, County Fermanagh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup>
</p><h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Efforts_witnessed_and_supported">Efforts witnessed and supported</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Attig&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Efforts witnessed and supported">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>All three of the above Benchmark establishing efforts were witnessed by thousands of persons and recorded at length in the media and press. The members of the <a href="/wiki/Inland_Waterways_Association_of_Ireland" title="Inland Waterways Association of Ireland">Inland Waterways Association of Ireland</a> supported, followed and chronicled the efforts. In 2007 the Lough Derg branch of IWAI awarded the boat and crew honorary membership in their annual Lough Derg rally.  In the same year, the IWAI Cruising Club formally welcomed the boat into Foynes harbor, as it returned after completing the Benchmark establishing efforts at Tarbert. The club also made the crew and boat officially part of the 2007 Killaloe to Killrush Cruise in Company.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Fabricated_housing">Fabricated housing</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Attig&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Fabricated housing">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Installing_roof_on_panelized_plastic_house.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8b/Installing_roof_on_panelized_plastic_house.JPG/220px-Installing_roof_on_panelized_plastic_house.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8b/Installing_roof_on_panelized_plastic_house.JPG/330px-Installing_roof_on_panelized_plastic_house.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8b/Installing_roof_on_panelized_plastic_house.JPG/440px-Installing_roof_on_panelized_plastic_house.JPG 2x" data-file-width="969" data-file-height="703" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Installing_roof_on_panelized_plastic_house.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Installing roof on panelized plastic house</div></div></div><p> From 1968 to 1971 Attig developed the world’s first all molded conventional appearing housing system. Attig designed the system and produced the first small panels in his plastic company located on Route 66 at Pontiac, Illinois. He then produced full sized molds, and directed production of the prototype in the Dura Plex Industries Plant located in Herrin Illinois. This received attention within the industry<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup>  22 national governments sent representatives to the grand opening of the <a href="/wiki/Prototype" title="Prototype">prototype</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Du_Quoin,_Illinois" title="Du Quoin, Illinois">Du Quoin, Illinois</a> State Fairgrounds.
</p><h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Attig&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<p><b>Azzedine Bousseksou</b> (born 2 December 1964 in <a href="/wiki/Kouba,_Algeria" title="Kouba, Algeria">Kouba</a> - <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a>) is a Franco-Algerian physico-<a href="/wiki/Chemist" title="Chemist">chemist</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<ul>

</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Azzedine_Bousseksou&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Azzedine Bousseksou attended high school in <a href="/wiki/Algiers" title="Algiers">Algiers</a>, where he also received a diploma in Material Physics from the Université de Bab Ezzouar.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> He received a DEA in Materials Science from the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Nantes" title="University of Nantes">University of Nantes</a> in 1988, then obtained a PhD in Materials Science from the <a href="/wiki/Pierre_and_Marie_Curie_University" title="Pierre and Marie Curie University">Pierre and Marie Curie University</a> in Paris in 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> He did a doctoral internship at the <a href="/wiki/Johannes_Gutenberg_University_of_Mainz" class="mw-redirect" title="Johannes Gutenberg University of Mainz">Johannes Gutenberg University of Mainz</a>, at the Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory of Professor Gütlich.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bousseksou began his career at the <a href="/wiki/French_National_Centre_for_Scientific_Research" title="French National Centre for Scientific Research">CNRS</a> in 1993, as a research fellow at the CNRS Coordination Chemistry Laboratory in Toulouse (LCC-CNRS).<sup id="cite_ref-:1_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> In January 2003, then in charge of Research at the LCC-CNRS Toulouse, he created and directed the scientific team "Switchable Molecular Materials" of the LCC.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> At the same time, between 2005–2009, he directed the GDR Magnétisme et Commutation Moléculaires (32 Laboratories)<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> and co-coordinated between 2006 and 2010 the GDRI France-Japan on multifunctional molecular materials. Between 2011 and 2013, he is Deputy Director of the LCC-CNRS Toulouse, then Director since 2013. The LCC is a CNRS unit with nearly 300 members. Azzedine Bousseksou was a member of the CNRS national committee for the evaluation of researchers and research laboratories over the periods 2000-2004 and 2010-2015 and has coordinated and/or led several European (COST, ANR international, ...), national (ANR) or regional (CEPER) projects. It has organised/co-organised several national and international congresses. He has been a member of the European Network of Excellence on Molecular Magnetism, REX MAGMANET<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> and is a member of the European Institute on Molecular Magnetism (EIMM).<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Scientific_research">Scientific research</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Azzedine_Bousseksou&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Scientific research">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Azzedine Bousseksou developed 3 complementary conceptual approaches alongside his team, which today represent the main threads of the evolution of his field (Molecular Bistability) at the global level. These are&#160;:
</p>
<ul><li>&#160;&#160; The transition from spin &amp; nanoelectronic transport (molecular spintronics) with the setting up of the very first molecular devices allowing the coupling of a spin state with electronic transport in a nanometric junction,</li>
<li>&#160;&#160; The transition from spin &amp; optics: towards high-performance photonic devices with the implementation of nano-thermometric sensors (patented) that surpass current commercial devices,</li>
<li>&#160;&#160; Spin transition &amp; reversible variation of molecular volume with the realization of the first nano-actuators with controlled direction whose chemical combination with polymers allowed the implementation of active materials "artificial muscles" with advanced applications in robotics and micro-nano-mechanics.</li></ul>
<p>With his research team made up of 3 other permanent staff members (Gabor Molnar, DR-CNRS, Lionel Salmon DR-CNRS and William Nicolazzi, MCF-Université Paul Sabatier), among his most remarkable achievements are the following:
</p>
<ul><li>&#160;&#160; <b>The development of the Ising-type model with two electronic levels</b> for one- and two-step spin transition with prediction of symmetry breaks, currently used worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>&#160;&#160; <b>The discovery of the first magneto-switching</b> by the application of an intense magnetic field (32 Tesla) pulsed into the hysteresis cycle of a spin transition molecule (Fe(Phen)2(NCS)2) allowing the information to be addressed from the high spin (HS) state to the low spin (BS) state, by a nucleation growth phenomenon whose dynamic effects are the subject of particular attention at the experimental and theoretical levels.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>&#160;&#160; <b>The discovery of the first hysteresis of the dielectric constant in spin-transition complexes</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-double1_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-double1-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>&#160;&#160; <b>The discovery of the first double photo-switching in binuclear spin-transition compounds</b><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>&#160;&#160; <b>The first photo-switching at room temperature</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>&#160;&#160; <b>The first synthesis of spin-transition thin films at room temperature (new layer-by-layer concept for spin transition)</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-double1_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-double1-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>&#160;&#160; <b>The first nano-structuring of bistable materials with spin transition at room temperature</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>&#160;&#160; <b>The synthesis of the smallest spin-transition coordination nanoparticles (4&#160;nm) with hysteresis around room temperature</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>&#160;&#160; <b>The original synthesis of a hybrid system combining spin transition and fluorescence</b> for the purpose of detecting the spin transition property on the single nano-object.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>&#160;&#160; <b>The development of a new generation of active devices</b> based on phothonic/plasmonic spin-transition materials,<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> diffractive gas sensors,<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> nano-thermometers<sup id="cite_ref-:0_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> and also nano-electronics,<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> and spintronic devices.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>&#160;&#160; <b>The recent development of switchable molecular materials for direction-controlled micro- and nano-actuation</b> by exploiting the reversible volume variation of spin-transition molecules (development of the first artificial muscle prototypes) with thermo- or photo-induced actuation for robotic applications (ERC 2019 project under evaluation).<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<p>Its research team is therefore considered today as a world leader in the field of Molecular Bistability.
</p><p>Azzedine Bousseksou's numerous recognitions and distinctions testify to its scientific influence in France and internationally, giving it an undeniable world leadership position.
</p><p>He has supervised about twenty post-doctoral students and more than thirty theses.
</p><p>He has registered 12 patents, 2 of which are being exploited, and one Startup in incubation.
</p><p>He is a member of 4 academies: the <a href="/wiki/French_Academy_of_Sciences" title="French Academy of Sciences">French Academy of sciences</a> (2013),<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> founding member of the Algerian Academy of sciences and technologies -AAST- (2015), member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts" title="European Academy of Sciences and Arts">European Academy of sciences and arts</a> (2012) and member of the European Academy of sciences (2014).
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Azzedine_Bousseksou&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Awards">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prizes">Prizes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Azzedine_Bousseksou&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Prizes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li>Korean Magnetic Society Award, 2012</li>
<li>Prix la Recherche, Chemistry section, 2011</li>
<li>Langevin Prize of the French Academy of sciences (FR), 2009</li>
<li>SCF Co-ordination Chemistry Division Award, 2003</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Honours">Honours</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Azzedine_Bousseksou&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Honours">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li>Winner of the national Smart Grids ERDF 2016 competition</li>
<li>Medal of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Montpellier" title="University of Montpellier">University of Montpellier</a>, 2014</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/CNRS_Silver_Medal" class="mw-redirect" title="CNRS Silver Medal">CNRS Silver Medal</a>, 2010</li>
<li>Visiting Professor, Lecturer <a href="/wiki/University_of_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="University of Mexico">University of Mexico</a> City, Mexico (1 month), 2017</li>
<li>Visiting Professor (18 months) at Queen's University of Belfast, UK, 1997</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Scholarly_Associations_-_Academies">Scholarly Associations - Academies</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Azzedine_Bousseksou&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Scholarly Associations - Academies">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li>Member of the French Academy of sciences, 2013</li>
<li>Member of the European Academy of sciences, 2014</li>
<li>Member of the European Academy of sciences and arts, 2012</li>
<li>Founding member of the Algerian Academy of science and technology, 2015</li>
<li>Member of the National Committee of the National Research Council, Section 14 (200-2004) and (2012-2016)</li>
<li>Member of the European Institute on Molecular Magnetism (EIMM)</li>
<li>Guest Editor, Coordination Chemistry Reviews, Elsevier, 2016</li>
<li>Guest Editor, <a href="/wiki/International_Journal_of_Molecular_Sciences" title="International Journal of Molecular Sciences">International Journal of Molecular Sciences</a>, MDPI, 2011</li>
<li>Guest Editor, <a href="/wiki/New_Journal_of_Chemistry" title="New Journal of Chemistry">New journal of Chemistry</a>, RCS, 2008</li>
<li>Coordination of the special issue of the Comptes Rendus Rendus of the Académie des sciences on the phenomenon of spin transition, 2018</li></ul>

Ed.</i>, 56 (2017), <abbr>p.</abbr> 8074-8078</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-28">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.academie-sciences.fr/fr/Liste-des-membres-de-l-Academie-des-sciences-/-B/azzedine-bousseksou.html">"Académie des sciences"</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Acad%C3%A9mie+des+sciences&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.academie-sciences.fr%2Ffr%2FListe-des-membres-de-l-Academie-des-sciences-%2F-B%2Fazzedine-bousseksou.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAzzedine+Bousseksou" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>

<p>www.lcc-toulouse.fr

<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">June 2012</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

Please <a href="/wiki/Help:Link" title="Help:Link">introduce links</a> to this page from <span class="plainlinks"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special%3ASearch&amp;redirs=1&amp;search=Marcus+Baby&amp;fulltext=Search&amp;ns0=1&amp;title=Special%3ASearch&amp;advanced=1&amp;fulltext=Marcus+Baby">related articles</a></span>; try the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//edwardbetts.com/find_link?q=Marcus_Baby">Find link tool</a> for suggestions.  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">June 2012</span>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Marcus Baby</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Marcus_Baby_by_Dayse_Barreto_2012.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Marcus Baby by Dayse Barreto 2012.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Marcus_Baby_by_Dayse_Barreto_2012.jpg/220px-Marcus_Baby_by_Dayse_Barreto_2012.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="331" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Marcus_Baby_by_Dayse_Barreto_2012.jpg/330px-Marcus_Baby_by_Dayse_Barreto_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Marcus_Baby_by_Dayse_Barreto_2012.jpg/440px-Marcus_Baby_by_Dayse_Barreto_2012.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2848" data-file-height="4288" /></a><div>Marcus Baby and his dolls</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><div style="display:inline" class="nickname">Marcus Vinicius da Silva Bernardo</div><br /><span style="display:none"> (<span class="bday">1969-11-23</span>) </span>November 23, 1969<span class="noprint ForceAgeToShow"> (age&#160;50)</span><br /><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace"><a href="/wiki/Natal,_Rio_Grande_do_Norte" title="Natal, Rio Grande do Norte">Natal, Rio Grande do Norte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Occupation</th><td class="role">Plastic artist</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Website</th><td><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.marcusbaby.com">www<wbr />.marcusbaby<wbr />.com</a></span></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Marcus Vinícius da Silva Bernardo</b>, best known by his nickname <b>Marcus Baby</b>, is a Brazilian "plastic artist." In the 1990s he decided to create his own sculptures using child dolls and action figures (such as <a href="/wiki/Barbie" title="Barbie">Barbie</a>) as a base.
</p><p>In November 2005, he started creating dolls in the likeness of celebrities. These dolls, which are not for sale,<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> are displayed on his website.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> The first doll to attract media attention was a wheelchair doll, inspired by a character from <i><a href="/wiki/Viver_a_Vida" title="Viver a Vida">Viver a Vida</a></i>, a well-known Brazilian <a href="/wiki/Telenovela" title="Telenovela">telenovela</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> He also made news when he refused to sell a doll he had created in the likeness of <a href="/wiki/Hebe_Camargo" title="Hebe Camargo">Hebe Camargo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>His doll of <a href="/wiki/Dilma_Rousseff" title="Dilma Rousseff">Dilma Rousseff</a>, the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Brazil" title="President of Brazil">President of Brazil</a>, was released right after her January 2011 inauguration. Affectionately dubbed "Barbie Dilma,"<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> it has become the best-known of his dolls.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

</p>
<table class="metadata plainlinks stub" role="presentation" style="background:transparent"><tbody><tr class="noresize"><td><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil"><img alt="Brazil" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/22px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png" decoding="async" width="22" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/33px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/43px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="504" /></a></span></td><td><i>This article about a Brazilian artist is a <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Stub" title="Wikipedia:Stub">stub</a>. You can help Wikipedia by <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Marcus_Baby&amp;action=edit">expanding it</a>.</i><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="position: absolute; right: 15px; display: none;"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Brazil-artist-stub" title="Template:Brazil-artist-stub"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Brazil-artist-stub" title="Template talk:Brazil-artist-stub"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Brazil-artist-stub&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table></div>
~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">June 2012</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="box-Orphan plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style ambox-Orphan" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w.svg" class="image"><img alt="Wiki letter w.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6c/Wiki_letter_w.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6c/Wiki_letter_w.svg/60px-Wiki_letter_w.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6c/Wiki_letter_w.svg/80px-Wiki_letter_w.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="44" data-file-height="44" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article <b>is an <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Orphan" title="Wikipedia:Orphan">orphan</a>, as no other articles <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:Whatlinkshere&amp;target=Vivian_Bales&amp;namespace=0">link to it</a></b>. Please <a href="/wiki/Help:Link" title="Help:Link">introduce links</a> to this page from <span class="plainlinks"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special%3ASearch&amp;redirs=1&amp;search=Vivian+Bales&amp;fulltext=Search&amp;ns0=1&amp;title=Special%3ASearch&amp;advanced=1&amp;fulltext=Vivian+Bales">related articles</a></span>; try the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//edwardbetts.com/find_link?q=Vivian_Bales">Find link tool</a> for suggestions.  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">September 2012</span>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Vivian Bales</div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td>January 1909<br /><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace"><a href="/wiki/Florida" title="Florida">Florida</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Died</th><td>December 2001<br /><div style="display:inline" class="deathplace"><a href="/wiki/Albany,_Georgia" title="Albany, Georgia">Albany, Georgia</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Other&#160;names</th><td class="nickname">Vivian Bales Faison</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Occupation</th><td class="role">Dance instructor, seamstress and stunt rider</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Known&#160;for</th><td>First motorcycle magazine cover girl</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Vivian Bales</b> (married name Faison, January 1909–December 2001) was the first motorcycle <a href="/wiki/Cover_girl" title="Cover girl">cover girl</a> and was known for several long-distance motorcycle rides around the US, and motorcycle stunt riding, in the 1920s and 1930s.
</p><p>Bales was born in <a href="/wiki/Florida" title="Florida">Florida</a> in and raised in <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)" title="Georgia (U.S. state)">Georgia</a>. After leaving school, she worked as a <a href="/wiki/Seamstress" class="mw-redirect" title="Seamstress">seamstress</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dance_education" title="Dance education">dance instructor</a>, and in 1926 bought her first <a href="/wiki/Motorcycle" title="Motorcycle">motorcycle</a>, a new <a href="/wiki/Harley-Davidson" title="Harley-Davidson">Harley-Davidson</a> Model B. She taught herself to ride on this motorcycle, and took her first long tour of 300 miles with a female friend from her home in <a href="/wiki/Albany,_Georgia" title="Albany, Georgia">Albany, Georgia</a> to <a href="/wiki/St._Petersburg,_Florida" title="St. Petersburg, Florida">St. Petersburg, Florida</a>, Florida.<sup id="cite_ref-Mullins2008_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mullins2008-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> The Model B  was a <i>350&#160;cc</i>,  <a href="/wiki/Single_cylinder" class="mw-redirect" title="Single cylinder">single cylinder</a>, <a href="/wiki/Side-valve" class="mw-redirect" title="Side-valve">side-valve</a>, with a manually shifted three speed engine with a battery, and not a <a href="/wiki/Magneto_ignition" class="mw-redirect" title="Magneto ignition">magneto ignition</a>, and a fully floating seat. It was brought out to compete with the successful <a href="/wiki/Indian_(motorcycle)" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian (motorcycle)">Indian</a> Prince model and was called "the peashooter" for the sound of its exhaust.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> One of the first 'streamline' models, it sold for around $235.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A Florida Harley-Davidson dealer heard the adventure, leading to a  feature about it in the <a href="/wiki/St._Petersburg,_Florida" title="St. Petersburg, Florida">St. Petersburg, Florida</a> newspaper, and then in the <i><a href="/wiki/Atlanta_Journal" class="mw-redirect" title="Atlanta Journal">Atlanta Journal</a></i>. Bales, planning longer journeys, traded in her Model B for a 1929 <a href="/wiki/Flathead_engine" title="Flathead engine">flathead engine</a> D-series, Harley-Davidson's first <i>45&#160;cu&#160;in (740&#160;cc)</i> motorcycle. She wrote to Hap Jameson, then editor of <i>The Harley-Davidson Enthusiast</i> magazine, telling him about her plans to make a longer solo trip. The <i>Enthusiast</i> motorcycle magazine was first published in 1916, 13 years after the first Harley-Davidson motorcycles built.
</p><p>Despite Bales only being 5 feet 2 inches and 95 pounds and unable to <a href="/wiki/Kick_start" title="Kick start">kickstart</a> the bike on her own, Jameson appointed Bales as the official goodwill "Enthusiast Girl" and while Harley-Davidson did not finance her journey, arrangements were made for Harley-Davidson dealers, <a href="/wiki/Rotary_Clubs" class="mw-redirect" title="Rotary Clubs">Rotary Clubs</a> and others on the route to provide accommodation, fuel, and maintenance.
</p><p>Having only been riding for 3 years and aged 20 years old, Bales started on 1 June 1929, taking 78 days to cover about 5,000 miles alone from <a href="/wiki/Albany,_Georgia" title="Albany, Georgia">Albany, Georgia</a> to the Harley-Davidson factory in Milwaukee. On the way back, she traveled through Canada, <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Carolinas" class="mw-redirect" title="The Carolinas">the Carolinas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> In Washington, Senator <a href="/wiki/William_J._Harris" title="William J. Harris">William J. Harris</a> arranged for her to meet President <a href="/wiki/Herbert_Hoover" title="Herbert Hoover">Herbert Hoover</a> wearing her trademark all white <a href="/wiki/Riding_breeches" class="mw-redirect" title="Riding breeches">riding breeches</a>, shirt, helmet, socks and sweater with "The Enthusiast Girl" across its chest. On the way, as a goodwill ambassador, she met many local dignitaries.<sup id="cite_ref-Trailblazers_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Trailblazers-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bales became the first motorcycle magazine cover girl on the May and November 1929 editions, and her journeys were well documented in the December 1929 issue and by local papers all over the USA. She later became a <a href="/wiki/Motorcycle_stunt_riding" title="Motorcycle stunt riding">stunt rider</a> at <a href="/wiki/Motorcycle_racing" title="Motorcycle racing">motorcycle races</a> in <a href="/wiki/Tallahassee" class="mw-redirect" title="Tallahassee">Tallahassee</a>, Florida. At her 23 December 2001 funeral, aged 92, she was honored by a procession of Harley-Davidsons.
</p><p>To <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Davidson_(motorcycling)" title="Arthur Davidson (motorcycling)">Arthur Davidson</a> she was "The Georgia Peach". For Bales, the motorcycle was a "key to the whole United States". Her adventurous spirit reacted against the <a href="/wiki/Received_wisdom" class="mw-redirect" title="Received wisdom">received wisdom</a> of the day that no woman should ride one. She married William Faison and adopted 3 children. Her last ride was at the age of 86.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vivian_Bales&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Notes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<li><cite id="CITEREFHowell1987" class="citation cs2">Howell, Esther (July 11, 1987), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GEJDAAAAIBAJ&amp;sjid=Q60MAAAAIBAJ&amp;pg=1394,1617057&amp;dq=vivian–faison&amp;hl=en">"Held the needle, thread as a child"</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Albany_Herald" title="The Albany Herald">The Albany Herald</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">June 6,</span> 2012</span></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Albany+Herald&amp;rft.atitle=Held+the+needle%2C+thread+as+a+child&amp;rft.date=1987-07-11&amp;rft.aulast=Howell&amp;rft.aufirst=Esther&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.google.com%2Fnewspapers%3Fid%3DGEJDAAAAIBAJ%26sjid%3DQ60MAAAAIBAJ%26pg%3D1394%2C1617057%26dq%3Dvivian%E2%80%93faison%26hl%3Den&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AVivian+Bales" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></li></ul>
</div></div>
~~~~
</p><p>Ballenger was a member of the Flint Board of Education for six years and made generous<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="Unverified descriptions (April 2018)">peacock&#160;term</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> bequests to Flint Junior College, later renamed <a href="/wiki/Mott_Community_College" title="Mott Community College">Mott Community College</a>. The main athletic facility on the campus, the William S. Ballenger <a href="/wiki/Field_house" title="Field house">Field house</a>, was named in his honor.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> The Ballenger Eminent Persons Lecture Series, endowed by Ballenger for the College, has been one of the most prestigious<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="Unverified descriptions (April 2018)">peacock&#160;term</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> forums for visiting speakers in <a href="/wiki/Michigan" title="Michigan">Michigan</a> during the past six decades.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Ballenger established two privately owned parks within the City of Flint, Memorial Park and Ballenger Park.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> Ballenger Highway, which forms most of the western city limits of Flint, is named after him, largely because he was the principal benefactor of a major hospital, now part of <a href="/wiki/McLaren_Health_Care_Corporation" title="McLaren Health Care Corporation">McLaren Health Care Corporation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> He was also chairman of the board of directors of the Citizens Commercial &amp; Savings Bank (now part of <a href="/wiki/FirstMerit_Corporation" title="FirstMerit Corporation">FirstMerit Corporation</a>). A year before he died in 1951, Ballenger was named president of the Flint Public Trust.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=William_S._Ballenger_Sr.&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">

<table class="box-More_footnotes plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style ambox-More_footnotes" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/40px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/60px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/80px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="48" data-file-height="48" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article includes a list of general <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">references</a>, but it remains largely unverified because <b>it lacks sufficient corresponding <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#Inline_citations" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">inline citations</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help to <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Fact_and_Reference_Check" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:WikiProject Fact and Reference Check">improve</a> this article by <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:When_to_cite" title="Wikipedia:When to cite">introducing</a> more precise citations.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">May 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Tom Barabas</b> is an American-Hungarian pianist/keyboardist. He studied <a href="/wiki/Classical_music" title="Classical music">classical music</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caracas_Conservatory&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caracas Conservatory (page does not exist)">Caracas Conservatory</a> in <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> before developing a taste for rock, jazz, and New Age. 
He died in San Diego, California in the spring of 2020. While he was over 70 years old, his kept his exact age secret.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Childhood"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Childhood</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Live_performance"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Live performance</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Critical_and_commercial_success"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Critical and commercial success</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Childhood">Childhood</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tom_Barabas&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Childhood">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Barabas spent his childhood in <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a>, and emigrated to the US in the 1960s, living and composing in <a href="/wiki/San_Diego,_California" class="mw-redirect" title="San Diego, California">San Diego, California</a>.  In the classic style of great, onstage performers, Barabas delivers a musically eloquent experience that builds rapport with his audience and invites them to fall in love with his graceful streams of sound.
</p><p>An Early Start - Barabas began playing music at the age of four in Budapest, Hungary. By age 12, he had attracted the interest and praise of his piano instructors and he made his public debut at the Liszt Conservatory of Music. In 1949 his family emigrated to Venezuela where he studied classical piano and composition at the Venezuela Conservatory of Music in Caracas, Venezuela's "<a href="/wiki/Juilliard" class="mw-redirect" title="Juilliard">Juilliard</a>". He earned his Master's Degree in 1957.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Live_performance">Live performance</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tom_Barabas&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Live performance">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The Live Experience - The classical training of the conservatory, the vibrant Latin and Caribbean pop music of Venezuela, and the raw energy of North American rock-n-roll all have contributed to the fresh compositional style that has come to be Barabas's signature.
</p><p>Barabas has had a lifelong love-affair with live performance. After a successful career performing daily on stage, radio and television in Venezuela, Barabas moved to San Diego in 1966 seeking greater opportunities. The Southern California music scene inspired and cultivated his interest in jazz and soon he was opening for such jazz greats as Oscar Peterson, Bill Evans and Ramsey Lewis. He later became the house pianist for a five-star resort and it was during his tenure there that his creativity and innovation flourished and he began playing his own compositions.
</p><p>A seasoned professional dedicated to originality, Barabas's career has been built on his unique blend of personal composition and trademark style. His sensitive and passionate relationship to his music is a true dance of the heart.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Critical_and_commercial_success">Critical and commercial success</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tom_Barabas&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Critical and commercial success">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Barabas has a nationwide following. He's released 12 CD's, three of which have made the Billboard Charts. Sedona Suite, perhaps his best loved album, charted #12 and held that position for 29 weeks! Other albums of note include Wind Dancer (with Dean Evenson), reaching Billboard's Top-15, and Classica Nouveau, which reached #18 on Billboard's Top-20. He has also released Journey Back to Sedona, Mosaic, Piano Impressions, Magic in December, Soaring and Back To The Garden (both with Dean Evenson), It's a New Life, Romantic Rhapsodies and Tom Barabas Live.
</p><p>Barabas and <a href="/wiki/Dean_Evenson" title="Dean Evenson">Dean Evenson</a> have enjoyed a long friendship and musical collaboration on several Soundings albums including Soaring, WindDancer, Back to the Garden and Healing Suite.
</p><p>"With just a solo grand piano, Tom Barabas has created an absolutely glorious album that highlights his virtuosity as a performer and allows his unique artistry as a composer to shine through." — Ted Cox, TOWER RECORDS, NAR Reviewer.
</p><p>Barabas has enjoyed the spotlight across the country. He is sought by corporations, cruise lines, production companies, concert and program planners, hotels, spas and resorts to bring a level of quality and beauty to any event. He wrote and performed an original composition for the Heartkeys AIDS Benefit Concert and the Heartkeys album and has performed for the American Cancer Society and the AIDS Foundation of America. Some of his better known performance venues have been with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Red Rocks Amphitheater, Delta Airlines and Princess Cruise Lines.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Reviews">Reviews</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tom_Barabas&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Reviews">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>"Tom's performance was sensational. The artistry of his music and his personal charm enriched the evening for everyone. We thank him for sharing his exceptional talents with us." — Nancy Mulligan, ASPEN Productions, Inc.
</p><p>National reviewer, P.J. Birosik's response to Barabas's music echoes the sentiments of his fans across the country – "Barabas composes richly harmonic and well-articulated pieces that satisfy the soul and stir the imagination." He performs with an intimacy, spontaneity and living warmth that sets him apart from other instrumentalists. His technique combines classical, Latin and jazz traditions in an unmistakably personal and joyful style.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="List_of_albums">List of albums</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tom_Barabas&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: List of albums">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

Magic In December (1991)<br />
Sedona Suite (1992)<br />
Piano Impressions (1994)<br />
Classica Nouveaux (1994)<br />
Mosaic (1995)<br />
Journey Back To Sedona (1996)<br />
It's a New Life (1998) <br />
Romantic Rhapsodies (1998) <br />
Tom Barabas Live (1999) <br />
Wedding in Heaven (1999) <br />
Classical Healing (2000) <br />
Goodnight My Angel (2001) <br />
The Very Best Of (2004)
</p><p>Tom Barabas and <a href="/wiki/Dean_Evenson" title="Dean Evenson">Dean Evenson</a> <br />
Wind Dancer (1992) <br />
Soaring (1996) <br />
Back to the Garden (1997) <br />
Healing Suite (2009)
</p>

href="/wiki/Lifetime_achievement_awards" class="mw-redirect" title="Lifetime achievement awards">Life Time Achievement Award</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Khadgajeet Baral</b> (<a href="/wiki/Nepali_language" title="Nepali language">Nepali</a>: <span lang="ne"><b><a href="https://ne.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E0%A4%96%E0%A4%A1%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%97%E0%A4%9C%E0%A5%80%E0%A4%A4_%E0%A4%AC%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%B2" class="extiw" title="ne:खड्गजीत बराल">खड्गजीत बराल</a></b></span><b>)</b> <a href="/wiki/Order_of_Gorkha_Dakshina_Bahu" title="Order of Gorkha Dakshina Bahu">OGDB</a>, <a href="/wiki/Order_of_Tri_Shakti_Patta" title="Order of Tri Shakti Patta">OTSP</a> (born April 17, 1928) is a <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepalese</a> politician and <a href="/wiki/Social_worker" class="mw-redirect" title="Social worker">social worker</a>. After serving as the <a href="/wiki/Inspector_General_of_Nepal_Police" class="mw-redirect" title="Inspector General of Nepal Police">Inspector General of Nepal Police</a><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> he also served as the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Nepal" title="Foreign relations of Nepal">Ambassador of Nepal</a> to <a href="/wiki/Burma" class="mw-redirect" title="Burma">Burma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> and <a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">French Indochina</a> (<a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
as a <a href="/wiki/Liaison_Officer" class="mw-redirect" title="Liaison Officer">Chief Liaison Officer</a>  of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Transitional_Authority_in_Cambodia" title="United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia">United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia</a> (UNTAC),<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> 
<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
and also as a <a href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Member of Parliament">Member of Parliament</a> (MP) of <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</ul>
