<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Olivetti-logos-58-bellini.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Olivetti-logos-58-bellini.jpg/220px-Olivetti-logos-58-bellini.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Olivetti-logos-58-bellini.jpg/330px-Olivetti-logos-58-bellini.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Olivetti-logos-58-bellini.jpg/440px-Olivetti-logos-58-bellini.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2126" data-file-height="2126" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Olivetti-logos-58-bellini.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>calculator Logos 58 for <a href="/wiki/Olivetti" class="mw-redirect" title="Olivetti">Olivetti</a>, 1972</div></div></div>
<p><b>Mario Bellini </b> (born February 1, 1935, <a href="/wiki/Milan" title="Milan">Milan</a>) is an Italian architect and designer. He graduated from the <a href="/wiki/Politecnico_di_Milano" class="mw-redirect" title="Politecnico di Milano">Milan Polytechnic - Faculty of Architecture</a> in 1959 and began working as an architect himself in the early 1960s. He is the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://driventowrite.com/2014/12/17/designer-mario-bellini/">winner</a> among others of 8 Compasso d’Oro and prestigious architecture awards including the Medaglia d’Oro conferred on him by the President of the Italian Republic.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Like many other Italian architects, his activities range from architecture and urban planning to product and furniture design.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Design"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Design</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Architecture"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Architecture</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Design">Design</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Bellini&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Design">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>His career as a product and furniture designer began in 1963, and from 1963 to 1991 he was chief design consultant for <a href="/wiki/Olivetti" class="mw-redirect" title="Olivetti">Olivetti</a>.
For many years he designed furnishing products and systems for B&amp;B Italia and <a href="/wiki/Cassina_S.p.A." title="Cassina S.p.A.">Cassina</a>, TV sets for <a href="/wiki/Brionvega" title="Brionvega">Brionvega</a>, and hi-fi systems, headphones and electric organs for Yamaha.
</p><p>For five years he worked as an automobile design consultant with Renault.
</p><p>In 1972 he was commissioned to design and build the prototype of the Kar-a-Sutra mobile environment for the exhibition “Italy: the New Domestic Landscape” at the <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Modern_Art" title="Museum of Modern Art">Museum of Modern Art</a> in New York<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>.
</p><p>He has also designed for Fiat and Lancia (notably the interior of the 1980 <a href="/wiki/Lancia_Trevi" title="Lancia Trevi">Lancia Trevi</a>), lamps for <a href="/wiki/Artemide" title="Artemide">Artemide</a>, Erco and Flos, and office furniture for <a href="/wiki/Vitra_(furniture)" title="Vitra (furniture)">Vitra</a>.
</p><p>Other firms for whom he has designed and/or continues to design products include (in Italy) Acerbis, Bras, Driade, Candy, Castilia, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Flou_(company)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flou (company) (page does not exist)">Flou</a>, Kartell, Marcatrè, Meritalia, <a href="/wiki/Natuzzi" title="Natuzzi">Natuzzi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Poltrona_Frau" title="Poltrona Frau">Poltrona Frau</a>; (in Belgium) <a href="/wiki/Ideal_Standard" title="Ideal Standard">Ideal Standard</a>; (in Germany) <a href="/wiki/Lamy" title="Lamy">Lamy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rosenthal_(company)" title="Rosenthal (company)">Rosenthal</a>; (in Japan) Fuji and Zojirushi; and (in the USA) Heller.
</p><p>His early international success grew rapidly during the first two decades, especially in the design sector, and reached its peak in 1987 with a personal retrospective exhibition at the <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Modern_Art" title="Museum of Modern Art">Museum of Modern Art</a> of New York. At the time the museum already included 25 of his works in its Permanent Collection, including a remarkable set of Olivetti machines as well as the furniture for B&amp;B and Cassina - such as the famous "Cab" chair - and the innovative office chairs designed for Vitra.
</p><p>MBA's headquarters of 1,500 square metres in Milan were designed by Mario Bellini himself in the early 1990s, and today an average of 30 to 35 architects.
</p><p>In 1999, MBA obtained ISO 9001 quality certification.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Bellini&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Architecture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Since the ‘80s, he has been increasingly successful in the field of architecture in Europe, Japan, the United States, Australia and the Arab Emirates.
</p><p><b>Projects built</b>
</p>
<ul><li>Milan Convention Centre (<a href="/wiki/Fiera_Milano" title="Fiera Milano">MICO</a>), Europe’s largest convention centre, 2008-2012</li></ul>
<ul><li>Museum of Islamic Arts at Louvre Museum, Paris, 2005-2012</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Palazzo_Pepoli_Vecchio" title="Palazzo Pepoli Vecchio">Museum of the City of Bologna</a>, Italy, 2004-2012</li>
<li>Urban redevelopment “Verona Forum”, Verona, Italy, 2004–2011</li>
<li>Radical refurbishment of the <a href="/wiki/Deutsche_Bank_Twin_Towers" title="Deutsche Bank Twin Towers">Deutsche Bank</a> in Frankfurt, Germany, 2007–2011</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Victoria" title="National Gallery of Victoria">National Gallery of Victoria</a> extension and redevelopment, Melbourne, Australia, 1996–2003</li>
<li>Essen International Fair Extension, Germany, 1998–2001</li>
<li>Natuzzi Americas Headquarters, High Point, North Carolina, USA, 1996–1998</li>
<li>Arsoa Co./Cosmetics- Headquarters, Yamanashi, Japan, 1996–1998</li>
<li>New fair district of the Milan Trade Fair, 1987–1997</li>
<li>Risonare Vivre Club Complex, Kobuchizawa, Japan, 1989–1992</li>
<li>Tokyo Design Center, Tokyo, Japan, 1988–1992</li>
<li>Yokohama Business Park, Yokohama, Japan, 1987–1991</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Villa_Erba" title="Villa Erba">Villa Erba Exhibition and Congress Centre</a>, Cernobbio (Como), 1986–1990</li>
<li>Thermoelectric power plant of Cassano d’Adda-Office building, 1985–1990</li></ul>
<p><b>Projects under construction</b>
</p>
<ul><li>Architectural project of a large Scientific-Technological Park at Erzelli Hill, Genoa, Italy, 2005</li>
<li>Extension and redevelopment of the Pinacoteca di Brera Milan (one of the major Italian Art Gallery), 2009</li>
<li>New Cultural Centre of Turin, 2001 (to be started)</li></ul>
<p><b>Among the best architectural creations</b>
</p>
<ul><li>New Museum of the city of Berlin, Germany, 2008</li>
<li>Sheikh Zayed National Museum International Competition, Abu Dhabi, UAE, 2007</li>
<li>European Patent Office, L’Aja, Holland, 2004</li>
<li>Cittanova 2000, Modena, Italy, 2003</li>
<li>Redevelopment of the City Centre of Tian Jin, China, 2003</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Banca_CR_Firenze" title="Banca CR Firenze">Banca CR Firenze</a>-New H.Q., Italy, 2003</li>
<li>New International Trade Fair of Milan – Rho/Pero, Milan, 2002</li>
<li>Multifunctional Complex “MAB. Zeil Project”, Frankfurt, Germany, 2002</li>
<li>Stolitza Towers, Moscow, 1996</li>
<li>Dubai Creek Complex, Dubai, United Arab Emirates, 1994</li>
<li>Goshikidai Marine Resort, Japan, 1993</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Exhibitions">Exhibitions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Bellini&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Exhibitions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Avid art lover and collector, he has been responsible for the exhibition design of many art exhibitions, among which:
</p>
<ul><li>"The Treasure of St. Marco in Venice", Grand Palais, Paris, and  the major museums around the world, 1984–87</li>
<li>"Italian Art in the 20th Century", Royal Academy of Arts, London, 1989</li>
<li>"The Renaissance from Brunelleschi to Michelangelo. The Representation of Architecture", <a href="/wiki/Palazzo_Grassi" title="Palazzo Grassi">Palazzo Grassi</a>, Venice, then in Paris and Berlin, 1994–95</li>
<li>"The Triumphs of Baroque. Architecture in Europe 1600-1750", Stupinigi Hunting Palace, Turin, 1999</li>
<li>"Christopher Dresser. A designer at the Court of Queen Victoria", Triennale, Milan, 2001</li>
<li>“Annisettanta. Il decennio lungo del secolo breve”, Triennale, 2007–2008</li>
<li>“Magnificenza e Progetto” Palazzo Reale, Milan, 2008–2009</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Major_personal_exhibitions">Major personal exhibitions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mario_Bellini&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Major personal exhibitions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>In 1987, the Museum of Modern Art in New York organised the exhibition “Mario Bellini: designer”, the first great retrospective on a living artist</li>
<li>In 1996, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Institute_of_British_Architects" title="Royal Institute of British Architects">Royal Institute of British Architects</a> (RIBA) held an exhibition of Bellini’s work as an architect</li>
<li>In 2000, the Municipal Gallery of Contemporary Art of Trento, Italy held a personal show “Mario Bellini: a path between architecture, furniture and cars”</li>
<li>In December 2003, the <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Victoria" title="National Gallery of Victoria">National Gallery of Victoria</a> in Melbourne reopened with a major exhibition on his work.</li></ul>

<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">February 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="box-Self-published plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-self-published" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article <b>may contain excessive or inappropriate references to <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published_sources" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">self-published sources</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Warren_Berger&amp;action=edit">improve it</a> by removing references to unreliable <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources">sources</a> where they are used inappropriately.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">February 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Warren Berger</b> (born October 20, 1958) is an American journalist and host of the website "AMoreBeautifulQuestion.com."<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> Questioning is the topic of his two most recent books, <i>The Book of Beautiful Questions</i> (2018) and <i>A More Beautiful Question</i> (2014), both published by <a href="/wiki/Bloomsbury_Publishing" title="Bloomsbury Publishing">Bloomsbury</a>. Berger has written five other books (two as co-author) <sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> and numerous articles, primarily on innovation, creativity, design, mass media, and popular culture.<sup id="cite_ref-warrenberger.com_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-warrenberger.com-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_and_education">Early life and education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Warren_Berger&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life and education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Warren Berger grew up in <a href="/wiki/Whitestone,_New_York" class="mw-redirect" title="Whitestone, New York">Whitestone, New York</a>, the youngest of seven children. He graduated from Syracuse University's <a href="/wiki/S._I._Newhouse_School_of_Public_Communications" title="S. I. Newhouse School of Public Communications">S. I. Newhouse School of Public Communications</a> in 1980.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Warren_Berger&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>After working as a newspaper journalist in Dallas, Berger moved back to New York and worked for several years as a magazine editor for CBS.
</p><p>In 1990, Berger founded his independent writing business, with <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a> as one of the main outlets for his writing. He wrote a business column for the Sunday Times,<sup id="cite_ref-warrenberger.com_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-warrenberger.com-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> and also contributed culture articles regularly to the Arts &amp; Leisure section as well as <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times_Magazine" title="The New York Times Magazine">The New York Times Magazine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-warrenberger.com_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-warrenberger.com-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> His feature stories also appeared in <i>GQ</i>, <i>The Los Angeles Times Magazine</i>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_magazine" class="mw-redirect" title="New York magazine">New York magazine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reader%E2%80%99s_Digest" class="mw-redirect" title="Reader’s Digest">Reader’s Digest</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Business_2.0" title="Business 2.0">Business 2.0</a>. He served as a contributing editor at <a href="/wiki/Wired_(magazine)" title="Wired (magazine)">Wired</a> magazine from 1999 to 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-warrenberger.com_3-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-warrenberger.com-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Berger pursued his interest in advertising by writing articles for <i>Ad Age’s Creativity</i>, <i>Communication Arts</i>, <i>Graphis</i>, and <i>Metropolis</i>. In the mid-1990s, he formed an association with <a href="/wiki/The_One_Club" title="The One Club">The One Club</a> for Art &amp; Copy, helping them launch the bimonthly publication <i>ONE</i>, about creativity in advertising, and then in 2007 launching the quarterly <i>One: Design.</i> In 2001, he wrote his first book <b>Advertising Today</b>, published by <a href="/wiki/Phaidon_Press" title="Phaidon Press">Phaidon Press</a>. The book was included on <a href="/wiki/Barnes_%26_Noble" title="Barnes &amp; Noble">Barnes &amp; Noble</a>’s best books of the year list, and was later included in a list of the “50 all time best books about media” compiled by <i>The Independent of London.</i><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Bibliography">Bibliography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Warren_Berger&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Bibliography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<li><span class="nowrap"> <a href="/wiki/WorldCat_Identities_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="WorldCat Identities (identifier)">WorldCat Identities</a>: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n96041686">lccn-n96041686</a></span></li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div>
~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">August 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">A. R. Bernard</div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><div style="display:inline" class="nickname">Alfonso R. Bernard</div><br /><span style="display:none"> (<span class="bday">1953-08-10</span>) </span>August 10, 1953<span class="noprint ForceAgeToShow"> (age&#160;67)</span><br /><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace"><a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a><sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Occupation</th><td class="role">Evangelist, pastor, businessman, television personality, life coach, <i>formerly</i>: banker</td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Spouse(s)</span></th><td>Karen, 1972-present</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Children</th><td>7 children</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Parent(s)</th><td>Adelina Fleming</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Religion</th><td><a href="/wiki/Pentecostal_Christianity" class="mw-redirect" title="Pentecostal Christianity">Pentecostal Christianity</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">Offices held</div></th><td>A. R. Bernard Ministries (founder and president)</td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Alfonso R. Bernard, Sr.</b> (born August 10, 1953) is the pastor of the <a href="/wiki/Christian_Cultural_Center" title="Christian Cultural Center">Christian Cultural Center</a> Megachurch in <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn,_New_York" class="mw-redirect" title="Brooklyn, New York">Brooklyn, New York</a>. In November 1979, A. R. Bernard, Sr. left a 10-year career with a major New York banking institution and together with his wife, Karen, went into full-time ministry.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>  What started as a small storefront church in <a href="/wiki/Williamsburg,_Brooklyn" title="Williamsburg, Brooklyn">Williamsburg, Brooklyn</a> has grown into a 37,000+ member church that sits on an &#x200b;<span class="frac nowrap">11<span class="visualhide">&#160;</span><sup>1</sup>&#8260;<sub>2</sub></span>-acre campus in Brooklyn, New York.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>  He is founder and CEO of the Christian Cultural Center.
</p><p>Bernard has served as the president of the Council of Churches of the City of New York representing 1.5 million Protestants, Anglicans and Orthodox Christians. Bernard founded the Christian Community Relations Council<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> (CCRC, a NY based not-for-profit that will serve as a central resource and coordinating body for congregations and community organizations. He is currently on the board of directors for the Commission of Religious Leaders (CORL).
</p><p>Bernard served on the NYC Economic Development Corporation Board for current mayor Bill de Blasio and former mayor Michael R. Bloomberg; NYC School Chancellor's Advisory Cabinet and on Mayor Michael Bloomberg's 2001 Transition Team and Mayor Bill de Blasio's 2014 Transition Team.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bernard is the founder of the Cultural Arts Academy Charter School<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> established in February 2010.
</p><p>Bernard has a master's degree in urban studies and a Master of Divinity from Alliance Theological Seminary. He has been awarded an honorary Doctor of Divinity degree from Wagner College and an honorary Doctor of Divinity degree from Nyack College/Alliance Theological Seminary.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biography">Biography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._R._Bernard&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Biography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Bernard was born in <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a>, the son of a black Panamanian mother and a father who was a Castilian <a href="/wiki/Spaniard" class="mw-redirect" title="Spaniard">Spaniard</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Charisma_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Charisma-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> His father disowned him and in 1957, he and his mother moved to the <a href="/wiki/Bedford-Stuyvesant" class="mw-redirect" title="Bedford-Stuyvesant">Bedford-Stuyvesant</a> neighborhood of <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn,_New_York" class="mw-redirect" title="Brooklyn, New York">Brooklyn, New York</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Charisma_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Charisma-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> As part of the 1960s desegregation movement in the public school system, he was bused to school in Ridgewood, Queens and then attended Grover Cleveland High School. Bernard worked after school in the garment district pushing racks for $2.00 per hour to assist his mother in their single parent household. He landed a clerk position with Bankers Trust Company during his senior year of high school. Bernard earned a number of promotions leading to a position as Operations Specialist in the Consumer Lending Division.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Establishment_of_church">Establishment of church</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._R._Bernard&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Establishment of church">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Prior to becoming a <a href="/wiki/Born_again" title="Born again">born again</a> Christian in January 1975, Bernard was a part of the Muslim American movement. In 1978 he and his wife, Karen started a bible study in the kitchen of their Brooklyn railroad apartment. Bernard left his 10-year banking career in 1979 to go into ministry full-time. As the bible study group grew, so did the need for a facility. The Bernards took their savings and rented a small storefront in the <a href="/wiki/Greenpoint,_Brooklyn" title="Greenpoint, Brooklyn">Greenpoint</a> section of Brooklyn. Later that year Household of Faith Ministries was incorporated. In 1988, Household of Faith purchased and renovated an abandoned Brooklyn supermarket into a 1000-seat sanctuary, complete with administrative offices and a bookstore. Household of Faith was renamed Christian Life Center and formally moved into its property in June 1989 with a membership of 625.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_growth">Further growth</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._R._Bernard&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Further growth">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>As Christian Life Center began experiencing exponential growth&#160;— four Sunday services, lines forming at 4:00am, and overflow rooms filled to capacity, the ministry was quickly outgrowing its home on Linden Boulevard. The need for a larger facility was evident and in 1995 a vacant lot adjacent to <a href="/wiki/Starrett_City,_Brooklyn" title="Starrett City, Brooklyn">Starrett City</a> was purchased and construction followed immediately. On December 31, 2000, under the leadership of Bernard, Christian Cultural Center took its new name and moved into its new home. The 6.5-acre (26,000 m2) sanctuary and conference center also includes a chapel, bookstore, television production facilities and state of the art youth center. Christian Cultural Center, one of the largest independent churches in the United States, exemplifies a new paradigm in the worship experience. Bernard remains a highly sought after speaker, teacher and community leader. He has traveled extensively throughout the United States and internationally addressing religious organizations, businessmen and political dignitaries.
</p><p>Future expansion and development is anticipated on a 4.5-acre (18,000 m2) of land adjacent to the current CCC campus.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="International_Christian_Brotherhood">International Christian Brotherhood</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._R._Bernard&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: International Christian Brotherhood">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Bernard was asked to serve on the board of directors for the Christian Men's Network (CMN) to help restructure the organization. During his six years on the board, CMN grew to an organization with 74 international offices and with a presence in approximately 150 nations. In addition to serving as treasurer for the board, Bernard was one of their most requested speakers. With the death of Dr. Edwin Louis Cole in 2002, he became the president of CMN. International Christian Brotherhood (ICB) began as an assigned project under the leadership of Ed Cole, but after a separation from CMN, Bernard re-launched ICB as his own Men's Ministry.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Controversy">Controversy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._R._Bernard&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Controversy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>During the campaigning for the 2016 presidential elections, Bernard joined the board of Donald Trump's "Evangelical Executive Advisory Board".<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> The purpose of the board was to "provide advisory support to Mr. Trump on those issues important to Evangelicals and other people of the faith in America,” the campaign said in a statement. Bernard then stepped down in 2017 quoting a "deepening conflict in values between myself and the administration."<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> Bernard had submitted his letter of resignation on 15 August 2017, the same day Trump made controversial remarks about the <a href="/wiki/Charlottesville_car_attack" title="Charlottesville car attack">events</a> that took place in <a href="/wiki/Charlottesville,_Virginia" title="Charlottesville, Virginia">Charlottesville</a>.
</p><p>Since 1999, A. R. Bernard has been visiting the controversial <a href="/wiki/City_Harvest_Church" title="City Harvest Church">City Harvest Church</a> in Singapore and maintains a close friendship with the church's founder <a href="/wiki/Kong_Hee" title="Kong Hee">Kong Hee</a>. Kong was convicted of conspiracy to commit criminal breach of trust, for misusing his church's building fund on his wife's singing career, masked through a series of bond investments.
</p><p>A. R. Bernard has been the chairman of <a href="/wiki/City_Harvest_Church" title="City Harvest Church">City Harvest Church</a>’s advisory panel and vouched for the integrity of <a href="/wiki/Kong_Hee" title="Kong Hee">Kong Hee</a> in 2010, when he was first arrested and sought to exert pressure on the Singapore government by political means and the press media.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Involvement_in_education">Involvement in education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._R._Bernard&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Involvement in education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Bernard is also the founder of <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Preparatory_School" title="Brooklyn Preparatory School">Brooklyn Preparatory School</a> in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a> and Cultural Arts Academy Charter School. Formed in 1993, BPS is a premiere early education institution dedicated to serving young children, ages 3–6. Their June 1999 first grade graduates ranked 91st in the national percentile in reading and 96th in the national percentile in mathematics.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family">Family</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._R._Bernard&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Family">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Bernard is married to his wife Karen since 1972. Bernard and Karen met in high school in East New York, when he was 15 and she 16.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> In an interview, he revealed that they were once headed for divorce because of some decisions that he had made and that he had made his "ministry his mistress".<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> In the early 1980s, Ms Bernard miscarried twins with Bernard was on the road and she blamed him for being absent and stayed bitter for a decade before he finally apologised.
</p><p>They have 7 sons and several grandchildren together.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>His eldest son Alfonso R. Bernard Jr. died from an asthma attack on 4 February 2015 at the age of 39 and is survived by his wife Janel and four children.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Published_works">Published works</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._R._Bernard&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Published works">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><i>Happiness Is</i><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> (Touchstone, 2011)</li>
<li><i>Four Things Women Want from a Man</i><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> (Howard Books, 2017)</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Honors_and_awards">Honors and awards</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._R._Bernard&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Honors and awards">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<table class="box-Unreferenced_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Unreferenced" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>does not <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">cite</a> any <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">sources</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=A._R._Bernard&amp;action=edit">improve this section</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">removed</a>.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">August 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul><li>The Ebony Power 100, Ebony Magazine, December 2010/January 2011</li>
<li>Crain's Business Publication, 2008, 25 Leaders Reshaping New York</li>
<li>New York Daily News, 2008, 2007, Most Influential Clergy</li>
<li>New York Post 2008 Most Influential African-American New Yorker</li>
<li>New York Daily News, 2008, 2007, Top 30 Most Influential Black New Yorker</li>
<li>New York Post 2007, Top 30 Most Influential Black New Yorker</li>
<li>Consulate General of Israel in New York 2007, Lifetime Achievement Award</li>
<li>New York Magazine, 2006  One of the City's Most Influential New Yorkers</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="A._R._Bernard_broadcasts">A. R. Bernard broadcasts</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._R._Bernard&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: A. R. Bernard broadcasts">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Bernard is the host of two weekly television programs. <i>A R Bernard</i> and <i>Faith In Practice</i> – airing nationally on <a href="/wiki/FamilyNet" class="mw-redirect" title="FamilyNet">FamilyNet</a> Television, <a href="/wiki/Daystar_(TV_network)" title="Daystar (TV network)">Daystar Television</a> and The <a href="/wiki/Trinity_Broadcasting_Network" title="Trinity Broadcasting Network">Trinity Broadcasting Network</a>. Bernard's radio broadcasts can be heard nationwide on Salem Communication stations, on FamilyNet Radio SIRIUS Channel 161, and locally within New York's tri-state area on WMCA and WLIB.
</p>

<li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.amazon.com/Four-Things-Women-Want-Man/dp/1501146718/">"Four Things Women Want from a Man: A. R. Bernard: 9781501146718: Amazon.com: Books"</a>. <i>www.amazon.com</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2018-12-12</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.amazon.com&amp;rft.atitle=Four+Things+Women+Want+from+a+Man%3A+A.+R.+Bernard%3A+9781501146718%3A+Amazon.com%3A+Books&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FFour-Things-Women-Want-Man%2Fdp%2F1501146718%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AA.+R.+Bernard" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._R._Bernard&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.cccinfo.org">Christian Cultural Center's official website</a></li>

~~~~

</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Anna Berndtson</b> (born 1972 in <a href="/wiki/Malm%C3%B6" title="Malmö">Malmö</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a>) is a <a href="/wiki/Performance_art" title="Performance art">performance artist</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Biography"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Biography</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Career"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Career</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Exhibitions_and_awards"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Exhibitions and awards</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Education"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Education</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biography">Biography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anna_Berndtson&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Biography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Anna Berndtson attended <a href="/wiki/Dartington_College_of_Arts" title="Dartington College of Arts">Dartington College of Arts</a> in <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> 1996-1999, where she graduated with a <a href="/wiki/Bachelor_of_Arts" title="Bachelor of Arts">Bachelor of Arts</a> in Theatre, then studied performance under Professor <a href="/wiki/Marina_Abramovi%C4%87" title="Marina Abramović">Marina Abramović</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Hochschule_f%C3%BCr_Bildende_K%C3%BCnste" class="mw-redirect" title="Hochschule für Bildende Künste">Hochschule für Bildende Künste</a> in <a href="/wiki/Braunschweig" title="Braunschweig">Braunschweig</a> from 2001-2005, here she graduated with a <a href="/wiki/Diplom" title="Diplom">Diplom</a> (equal to a <a href="/wiki/Master_of_Fine_Arts" title="Master of Fine Arts">Master of Fine Arts</a>) in Visual Arts. Anna Berndtson has taught <a href="/wiki/Performance_Art" class="mw-redirect" title="Performance Art">Performance Art</a>, among others at Fachhochschule Ottersberg and in the Sverigefinska folkhögskolan, <a href="/wiki/Haparanda" title="Haparanda">Haparanda</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anna_Berndtson&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Berndtson began her artistic career in the late 1990s. She incorporates her own body into her art, for example in her performance piece "Churned", where she immersed herself in a tub of cream, which she over several hours churns into butter.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> Berndtson works mainly with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Long_Duration_Live_Performance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Long Duration Live Performance (page does not exist)">Long Duration Live Performance</a> but has since the mid <a href="/wiki/2000s_(decade)" class="mw-redirect" title="2000s (decade)">2000s</a> also started to produce <a href="/wiki/Photography" title="Photography">photography</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Video_work&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Video work (page does not exist)">video work</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>2003 Anna Berndtson co-funded the Swedish/German performance duo <a href="/w/index.php?title=TBL_(TallBlondLadies)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TBL (TallBlondLadies) (page does not exist)">TBL (TallBlondLadies)</a>, together with her collaborative partner <a href="/w/index.php?title=Irina_Runge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Irina Runge (page does not exist)">Irina Runge</a>. The duo works with gender and female clichés.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Exhibitions_and_awards">Exhibitions and awards</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anna_Berndtson&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Exhibitions and awards">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Anna Berndtson has performed and exhibited work, amongst others, at; <a href="/wiki/Fondation_Beyeler" class="mw-redirect" title="Fondation Beyeler">Fondation Beyeler</a>, Riehen/Basel, <sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> Bergmancenter, <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A5r%C3%B6" title="Fårö">Fårö</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> Liljevalchs, <a href="/wiki/Stockholm" title="Stockholm">Stockholm</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Haus_der_Kulturen_der_Welt" title="Haus der Kulturen der Welt">Haus der Kulturen der Welt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> The LAB Gallery, <a href="/wiki/Dublin" title="Dublin">Dublin</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Artists_Space" title="Artists Space">Artists Space</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kulturhuset" class="mw-redirect" title="Kulturhuset">Kulturhuset</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stockholm" title="Stockholm">Stockholm</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hebbel_am_Ufer" title="Hebbel am Ufer">Hebbel am Ufer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/MoMA_PS1" title="MoMA PS1">MoMA PS1</a> i <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh" title="Vincent van Gogh">Van Gogh Museum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amsterdam" title="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a> and VV2 at the <a href="/wiki/Venice_Biennale" title="Venice Biennale">Venice Biennale</a>.
</p><p>She has received Residence Grants from renowned institutions such as Bergman Estate on <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A5r%C3%B6" title="Fårö">Fårö</a> in Sweden (2013), Nordic Artists' Centre Dalsåsen, Norway (2012),<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> Fire Station Artists' Studios and Arts &amp; Disability Ireland Studio Award, <a href="/wiki/Dublin" title="Dublin">Dublin</a>  (2010) <sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> and Künstlerhäuser Worpswede (2006) <sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> as well as Working Grants from amongst others Konstnärsmämden in Sweden (2016 – 2017, 2010 – 2011, 2007) and Aase &amp; Richard Björklunds fond, <a href="/wiki/Malm%C3%B6" title="Malmö">Malmö</a> (2014 and 2006).
</p><p><br />
She is a member of Abramovic Foundation founded by <a href="/wiki/Marina_Abramovic" class="mw-redirect" title="Marina Abramovic">Marina Abramovic</a> in 2008.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anna_Berndtson&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>1994 - 1996, <a href="/wiki/Business_and_Technology_Education_Council" title="Business and Technology Education Council">BTEC</a> in Performing Art at the <a href="/wiki/City_of_Bath_College" class="mw-redirect" title="City of Bath College">City of Bath College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bath,_Somerset" title="Bath, Somerset">Bath</a>, <a href="/wiki/UK" class="mw-redirect" title="UK">UK</a>. Here she in 1996 received the "Student of the year award".</li>
<li>1996 - 1999, <a href="/w/index.php?title=BA_(Honours)_Degree&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BA (Honours) Degree (page does not exist)">BA (Honours) Degree</a> in Theater at <a href="/wiki/Dartington_College_of_Arts" title="Dartington College of Arts">Dartington College of Arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dartington" title="Dartington">Dartington</a>, <a href="/wiki/UK" class="mw-redirect" title="UK">UK</a></li>
<li>1998 - 1999, acting at <a href="/wiki/Hochschule_der_K%C3%BCnste" class="mw-redirect" title="Hochschule der Künste">Hochschule der Künste</a>, <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> as well as <a href="/wiki/Scenography" title="Scenography">scenography</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kunsthochschule_f%C3%BCr_Gestaltung&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kunsthochschule für Gestaltung (page does not exist)">Kunsthochschule für Gestaltung</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wei%C3%9Fensee_(Berlin)" class="mw-redirect" title="Weißensee (Berlin)">Weissensee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a></li>
<li>2001 - 2005, Performance, Diplom in Fine Arts by Professor <a href="/wiki/Marina_Abramovic" class="mw-redirect" title="Marina Abramovic">Marina Abramovic</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Hochschule_f%C3%BCr_Bildende_K%C3%BCnste" class="mw-redirect" title="Hochschule für Bildende Künste">Hochschule für Bildende Künste</a> i <a href="/wiki/Braunschweig" title="Braunschweig">Braunschweig</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>.</li></ul>

no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-subscription,.mw-parser-output .cs1-registration{color:#555}.mw-parser-output .cs1-subscription span,.mw-parser-output .cs1-registration span{border-bottom:1px dotted;cursor:help}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px </li>

</li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anna_Berndtson&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.annaberndtson.com/">annaberndtson.com</a></li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.tallblondladies.com/">tallblondladies.com</a></li></ul></div>
~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">June 2011</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Ellen S. Berscheid</b> (born 1936)<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> is an American <a href="/wiki/Social_psychology" title="Social psychology">social psychologist</a> who is currently a Regents professor at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Minnesota" title="University of Minnesota">University of Minnesota</a>, where she earlier had earned her PhD in 1965. Berscheid conducted research on <a href="/wiki/Interpersonal_relationship" title="Interpersonal relationship">interpersonal relationships</a>, emotions and moods, and <a href="/wiki/Social_cognition" title="Social cognition">social cognition</a>. Berscheid wrote books, articles and other publications to contribute to the field of Social Psychology. She was involved in controversy surrounding the funding for her research on why people <a href="/wiki/Falling_in_love" title="Falling in love">fall in love</a>. Berscheid has not only held a position at the University of Minnesota as a Psychology and Business professor; she has also held a position at <a href="/wiki/Pillsbury_Company" title="Pillsbury Company">Pillsbury</a>. She has been presented with many different awards in honor of her contributions to social psychology including: The Presidential Citation and the Distinguished Scientific Contribution Award from the <a href="/wiki/American_Psychological_Association" title="American Psychological Association">American Psychological Association</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Minnesota2010_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Minnesota2010-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellen_S._Berscheid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Berscheid started her academic career as an Education major at Beloit College in Wisconsin, before transferring to University of Nevada, Reno.<sup id="cite_ref-Not_by_Chance_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Not_by_Chance-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>There she was given a research assistant grant by her professor, Paul Secord. <sup id="cite_ref-Awards_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Awards-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> Berscheid picked up psychology as her second major and graduated with honors. After graduation Berscheid applied for and received PHS Predoctoral Research Fellowship, at the University of Minnesota to work with <a href="/wiki/Harold_Kelley" title="Harold Kelley">Harold Kelley</a>.  However, Berscheid decided to decline the offer and became a research administrator for Pillsbury. Berscheid later applied for a research assistantship at the University of Minnesota, working with <a href="/wiki/Elliot_Aronson" title="Elliot Aronson">Elliot Aronson</a>. Under the direction of Elliot Aronson she obtained her PhD in social psychology.<sup id="cite_ref-Not_by_Chance_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Not_by_Chance-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Berscheid accepted a job teaching research methods in the business department at the University of Minnesota. Through the business department, Berscheid met <a href="/wiki/Elaine_Hatfield" title="Elaine Hatfield">Elaine (Walster) Hatfield</a>.   Hatfield convinced Berscheid to join her in researching equity and <a href="/wiki/Interpersonal_attraction" title="Interpersonal attraction">attraction</a>.  At the time, women conducting research was rare and may have been stopped if too many people had taken notice, therefore Hatfield and Berscheid conducted their research quietly through a federal grant.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> Berscheid's main research interest was interpersonal relationships. Ellen Berscheid looked at why people fall in love, the meaning of love, and attraction in close relationships.<sup id="cite_ref-Psychology_Network_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Psychology_Network-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1983 Berscheid introduced the <a href="/wiki/Emotion-in-Relationships_Model" class="mw-redirect" title="Emotion-in-Relationships Model">Emotion-in-Relationships Model</a> (ERM), a theory designed to predict individual's experiences towards <a href="/wiki/Emotion" title="Emotion">emotions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Controversy">Controversy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellen_S._Berscheid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Controversy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In 1974, Berscheid was the center of a controversy regarding federal funding of research. Senator <a href="/wiki/William_Proxmire" title="William Proxmire">William Proxmire</a> of Wisconsin used her as an example when he awarded the National Science Foundation his first <a href="/wiki/William_Proxmire#Golden_Fleece_Award" title="William Proxmire">Golden Fleece</a> award, which was presented monthly between 1975 and 1988, in order to focus media attention on projects Proximire viewed as self-serving and wasteful of taxpayer dollar. Berscheid had been granted $84,000 by the foundation to research why people fall in love. The scandal "called into question use of public funds in scientific research." <sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A few years later, Hatfield left the business department and Berscheid took over Hatfield's job as Student Activities Bureau.  Due to an all male faculty, Berscheid expected an early retirement but then was offered a professorship in the psychology department.<sup id="cite_ref-Awards_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Awards-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> Berscheid still remains on the Psychology Faculty at the University of Minnesota. <sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Significant_Publications">Significant Publications</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellen_S._Berscheid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Significant Publications">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Books:
</p>
<ul><li>Berscheid, E., &amp; Regan, P. (2005). The psychology of interpersonal relationships. New York: Prentice-Hall.<sup id="cite_ref-Minnesota2010_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Minnesota2010-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<p>Journal Articles<b>:</b>
</p>
<ul><li>Berscheid, E. (2006). Notes on the social psychological study of love. Impulse, 60, 5–13.<sup id="cite_ref-Psychology_Network_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Psychology_Network-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><cite id="CITEREFBerscheid1999" class="citation journal cs1">Berscheid, E (1999). <p>Other Publications:
</p>
<ul><li>Berscheid, E. (2006). Searching for the meaning of "love." In R. J. Sternberg &amp; K. Weis (Eds.), The psychology of love (2nd ed., pp. 171–183). <li>Berscheid, E., &amp; Reis, H. T. (1998). Attraction and close relationships. In D. T. Gilbert, S. T. Fiske, &amp; G. Lindzey (Eds.), The handbook of social psychology (4th ed., pp. 193–281). New York: McGraw-Hill.<sup id="cite_ref-Minnesota2010_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Minnesota2010-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellen_S._Berscheid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Legacy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Ellen Berscheid has been presented with many different awards in honor of her contributions to social psychology.
Some of Berscheid's notable awards include the Presidential Citation and Distinguished Scientific Contribution Award presented by the American Psychological Association, Distinguished Scientist Award from the Society of Experimental Social Psychology, and the Distinguished Career Award by International Society for the Study of Personal Relationships. Ellen Berscheid also has held presidency of the International Society for the Study of Interpersonal Relationships (1991–1992) and the Society of Personality and Social Psychology (1983–1985). <sup id="cite_ref-Minnesota2010_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Minnesota2010-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellen_S._Berscheid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Interpersonal_attraction" title="Interpersonal attraction">Interpersonal attraction</a></li></ul>

Please <a href="/wiki/Help:Link" title="Help:Link">introduce links</a> to this page from <span class="plainlinks"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special%3ASearch&amp;redirs=1&amp;search=Valda+Berzins&amp;fulltext=Search&amp;ns0=1&amp;title=Special%3ASearch&amp;advanced=1&amp;fulltext=Valda+Berzins">related articles</a></span>; try the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//edwardbetts.com/find_link?q=Valda_Berzins">Find link tool</a> for suggestions.  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">August 2015</span>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Valda Berzins</b> is an Australian business woman, entrepreneur and award-winning general manager who has held senior high-profile executive roles in Australian organisations including <a href="/wiki/Australia_Post" title="Australia Post">Australia Post</a>, <a href="/wiki/Victoria_police" class="mw-redirect" title="Victoria police">Victoria Police</a> and <a href="/wiki/Foster%27s_Group" title="Foster&#39;s Group">Foster's Group</a>.
</p><p>In 2008, she founded the interior and exterior design house, Valdasigns, and currently holds the position of director of the business.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biography">Biography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Valda_Berzins&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Biography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Valda Berzins was born in <a href="/wiki/East_Melbourne" class="mw-redirect" title="East Melbourne">East Melbourne</a>, Victoria on the 26th of January (Australia Day), to Latvian parents who migrated to Australia in their efforts to escape communism. 
Berzins’ parents originally arrived at Port Melbourne by ship during the <a href="/wiki/Post_war_immigration_to_Australia" class="mw-redirect" title="Post war immigration to Australia">post-war immigration boom</a> and were transferred to the <a href="/wiki/Bonegilla_Migrant_Reception_and_Training_Centre" title="Bonegilla Migrant Reception and Training Centre">Bonegilla Migrant Reception and Training Centre</a> in the north east of Victoria. Prior to his arrival in Australia, Berzins’ father pursued a degree in mechanical engineering. Due to the ongoing war in Latvia, he was forced to abandon the final year of the degree.
</p><p>Despite the fact that Berzins’ father had almost completed his degree and her mother being a fully qualified nursing Sister, they had to work in unskilled jobs to support themselves. During this time, Berzins’ father held a day job and attended night school. After years of hard work, he finally attained an accounting diploma from the <a href="/wiki/RMIT" class="mw-redirect" title="RMIT">Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT)</a>.
As a child, Valda grew up in the suburb of <a href="/wiki/Glenroy,_Victoria" title="Glenroy, Victoria">Glenroy</a>, along with her parents and sister, Nora. Later on, her family relocated to <a href="/wiki/Pascoe_Vale" class="mw-redirect" title="Pascoe Vale">Pascoe Vale</a> where the family lived for numerous years. It is also in this same suburb that Berzins purchased her first house at the age of 22, a large seven bedroom house on a 1,000m² block of land.
</p><p>Her love for gardening and <a href="/wiki/Home_renovation" class="mw-redirect" title="Home renovation">home renovation</a> began to blossom during this period as Berzins personally redesigned and decorated the house in her own vision. Berzins spent only a small sum on renovations but managed to sell the house 7 years later at triple the sum of her initial investment.
</p><p>After that, Berzins relocated to North Balwyn and lived there for many years. She currently resides in Mount Martha, Victoria, with her husband of 23 years, Brian.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Valda_Berzins&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Prior to 1995, Berzins held various accounting positions and strategic planning roles with Carlton &amp; United Breweries (Foster's). She was promoted to Assistant Company Secretary and Finance Manager in a short span. During her time at Foster's Berzins directed significant mergers and acquisitions that helped propel the business. Later on, she became the Executive Director of Information Systems for Foster's Group.
</p><p>From July to November 1995, Berzins worked as Finance Director for the American-based toy manufacturing company, <a href="/wiki/Mattel" title="Mattel">Mattel, Inc</a>.
</p><p>Berzins career came to prominence as she took on the role of Group Manager of IT Services with Australia Post. After a few years, Australia Post specifically created the role of <a href="/wiki/Chief_information_officer" title="Chief information officer">Chief Information Officer (CIO)</a> for Berzins. She served as CIO for Australia Post from 1996 to 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After an illustrious career with Australia Post, Berzins stepped into the role of CIO with Victoria Police from 2004 to 2008. During her time with Victoria Police, Berzins successfully implemented innovative tech policies as well as transforming the set up of major IT contracts.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2008 Berzins left Victoria Police under a cloud after being heavily criticised in a Victorian Ombudsmans's report into mismanagement of the IT contracts for the police.
</p><p>In November 2008, Berzins reignited her dreams of becoming an interior and exterior home designer/renovator and established her own company, Valdasigns. She has been widely applauded for her ability to recognise and fuse the personal style of her clients with innovative designs whilst working on home renovation projects.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Valda_Berzins&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Berzins has successfully obtained numerous credentials and tertiary qualifications.
</p>
<ul><li>Bachelor of Commerce - <a href="/wiki/University_Of_Melbourne" class="mw-redirect" title="University Of Melbourne">University of Melbourne</a></li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li>Bachelor of Science-University of Melbourne</li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li>Diploma of Professional Interior Design – The Interior Design Academy (Double Bay, New South Wales)</li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li>Fellow of Australian Computer Society (FACS)</li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Certified_Practising_Accountant" title="Certified Practising Accountant">Certified Practising Accountant (CPA)</a></li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li>Registered Tax Agent</li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li>Real Estate Agents’ Representatives’ Qualification</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Valda_Berzins&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Awards">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>Winner of Scholarship to the Australian Graduate School of Management. ( 1993)</li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li>One of Australia's 30 top leaders in IT in Robert Williams’ book “Success in IT” ( 2000)</li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li>Awarded prestigious Computerworld Fellow ( 2001)</li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li>IT &amp;T's CIO of the Year (2002) (Equivalent to the Financial Review's CFO of the Year<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li>CIO's Executive Council Top 20 Asia Pacific CIOs (2007)</li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li>Committee member of various University IT Boards and CPA Working Groups</li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li>Keynote Speaker at select Australian and overseas seminars<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li></ul>

<li><a href="/wiki/Assam_Province" title="Assam Province">Assam Province</a></li></ul></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left">Contemporary</div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Assam_Movement" title="Assam Movement">Assam Movement</a></li></ul></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><th style="padding:0.1em;border-top: #FFDFDF 1px solid; background:#FFEDED">
Categories</th></tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<div class="hlist hlist-separated">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Category:Architecture_of_Assam" title="Category:Architecture of Assam">Architecture</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Category:Palaces_in_Assam" title="Category:Palaces in Assam">Palaces</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Category:Forts_in_Assam" title="Category:Forts in Assam">Forts</a></li></ul>
</div></td>
</tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Assam_History" title="Template:Assam History"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Assam_History" title="Template talk:Assam History"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Assam_History&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Bhaskaravarman</b> (<span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">bʱaːskərə'vərmən</span>) (600–650), the last of the <a href="/wiki/Varman_dynasty" title="Varman dynasty">Varman dynasty</a>, was perhaps the most illustrious of the kings of the medieval <a href="/wiki/Kamarupa" title="Kamarupa">Kamarupa</a>.  After being captured by the Gauda king during the reign of his father, he was able to re-establish the rule of the Varman's. He made political alliances with <a href="/wiki/Harshavardhana" class="mw-redirect" title="Harshavardhana">Harshavardhana</a> of Thaneswar, against the alliance of the Gauda and East <a href="/wiki/Malwa" title="Malwa">Malwa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sen_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sen-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>  He was visited by <a href="/wiki/Xuanzang" title="Xuanzang">Xuanzang</a> and Li Yi-piao, the envoy of the <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a> who have left accounts of the king and the kingdom.
</p><p>Bhaskaravarman came to power after his brother <a href="/wiki/Supratisthitavarman" title="Supratisthitavarman">Supratisthitavarman</a> had died. He was the first Kamarupa king to claim descent from the mythical <a href="/wiki/Narakasura" title="Narakasura">Narakasura</a>, Bhagadatta and Vajradatta.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>  After his death Salasthambha, who established the <a href="/wiki/Mlechchha_dynasty" title="Mlechchha dynasty">Mlechchha dynasty</a>, acquired power in Kamarupa Kingdom.
</p><p>He issued the Dubi and <a href="/wiki/Nidhanpur_copperplate_inscription" title="Nidhanpur copperplate inscription">Nidhanpur</a> copper plate grants, re-issued after his ancestor Bhutivarman, and a clay seal found in <a href="/wiki/Nalanda" title="Nalanda">Nalanda</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
