<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Background">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>After <a href="/wiki/Susthitavarman" title="Susthitavarman">Susthitavarman</a> was defeated by Mahasenagupta, his son <a href="/wiki/Supratisthitavarman" title="Supratisthitavarman">Supratisthitavarman</a> came to power, who built Kamarupa's elephant army but died prematurely without an heir. Thus, the younger son, Bhaskaravarman, came to power in Kamarupa.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (June 2019)">better&#160;source&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Even after he succeeded to the throne <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;600 CE</span>, Bhaskaravarman was known as <i>kumara</i> (prince), probably because he was a bachelor throughout his life.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarua193358_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarua193358-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (June 2019)">better&#160;source&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Rivals">Rivals</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Rivals">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Mahasenagupta, in alliance with Shashanka, had defeated on Susthitavarman and took control over north and central Bengal. After the death of Mahasenagupta Shashanka became the ruler of this portion.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (June 2019)">better&#160;source&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>   On ascending the throne Bhaskaravarman found two strong rival powers growing in <a href="/wiki/North_India" title="North India">northern India</a>, viz. one in central and northern Bengal under Shashanka and the other in <a href="/wiki/Central_India" title="Central India">mid-India</a> under Prabhakaravardhana, the father of <a href="/wiki/Harshavardhana" class="mw-redirect" title="Harshavardhana">Harshavardhana</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarua193358_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarua193358-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (June 2019)">better&#160;source&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>When Shashanka murdered Rajyavardhana who had succeeded Prabhakaravardhana as the king at Thaneswar, Bhaskaravarman sent an envoy, Hangsavega, to form an alliance. This incident by both Bana and Xuanzang.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarua193362_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarua193362-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (June 2019)">better&#160;source&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Alliance_with_Harsha">Alliance with Harsha</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Alliance with Harsha">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The Harsha Charita of Bana gives a detailed account of Hangsavega's meeting with Harsha. Plying him with gifts and praise, the diplomat was able to effect an offensive and defensive alliance between the two kings.
</p><p>The Nidhanpur copper-plate grant was issued from Bhaskaravarman's victorious camp at Karnasuvarna,<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> the erstwhile capital of Shashanka.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Alliance_with_Chinese">Alliance with Chinese</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Alliance with Chinese">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>After 648 CE, the Chinese invaded India to avenge the insult done to Chinese representatives at the court of <a href="/wiki/Harsha" title="Harsha">Harshavardhana</a> by the minister who usurped the throne of Harshavardhana after his death. The minister was defeated and captured. In the conflict, Bhaskaravarman aided the Chinese with supplies of cattle, horse and accoutrement.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Xuanzang.27s_account"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Xuanzang's_account">Xuanzang's account</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Xuanzang&#039;s account">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The Chinese traveller, <a href="/wiki/Xuanzang" title="Xuanzang">Xuanzang</a>, visited Bhaskaravarman in his court on his invitation, noting the King patronised Buddhism though a non-Buddhist.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> According to the text of the Si-yu-ki, the circumference of the capital of Kamarupa was thirty li and the king who was Bhaskaravarman, a Brahman by caste.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Xuanzang translated  into sanskrit  the Taoist text, Daodejing at the request of Bhaskar Varman.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Kamarupa_of_Bhaskaravarman">Kamarupa of Bhaskaravarman</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Kamarupa of Bhaskaravarman">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Xuanzang, in his travelogue, noted that he crossed a great river <a href="/wiki/Karatoya_river" class="mw-redirect" title="Karatoya river">Karatoya</a> before entering the Kamarupa. The eastern boundary was a line of hills close to the <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">Chinese</a> frontier. He also said Kamarupa was nearly 1700 miles in circumference. The climate was genial. He mentioned that the people were are short height and of yellow complexion and Bhaskar Varman was Hindu and not Buddhist. The people were honest. Their speech differed a little from that of mid-India. They were of violent disposition but were persevering students. They worshipped the Devas and did not believe in Buddhism. The Deva-temples were some hundreds in number and the various systems had some myriads of professed adherents. The few Buddhists in the country performed their acts of devotion in secret. The pilgrim ascertained from the people that to the east of the country was a series of hills which reached as far as the confines of China. The inhabitants of these hills were akin to the "Man of the Lao". In the south-east of the country elephants were plentiful.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Description">Description</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Description">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Xuanzang notes that Kamarupa was low and moist, and that the crops were regular. <a href="/wiki/Cocoa_bean" title="Cocoa bean">Cocoa-nuts</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jackfruit" title="Jackfruit">jackfruits</a> grew abundantly and were appreciated by the people.  The description provided is around the present-day <a href="/wiki/Guwahati" title="Guwahati">Guwahati</a>.
</p><p>According to the account given in the <i>Si-yu-ki,</i> the circumference of Kamarupa was about 1,700 miles (2,700&#160;km). As Edward Albert Gait has pointed out, this circumference must have included the whole of the <a href="/wiki/Brahmaputra_Valley" title="Brahmaputra Valley">Assam valley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Surma_River" title="Surma River">Surma</a> valley, parts of <a href="/wiki/North_Bengal" title="North Bengal">North Bengal</a>, and parts of <a href="/wiki/Mymensingh" title="Mymensingh">Mymensingh</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Religion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Bhaskaravarman was a worshiper of <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a>, though he had great reverence for learned Buddhist priests and professors of his time, and was distinctly inclined towards <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>.  The general populace worshiped the <i>Devas</i> worshiped in many temples, and adherents of Buddhism practised devotion secretly.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Culture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>According to Xuanzang, the people of Kamarupa were honest, albeit with a violent disposition, but were persevering students.  The people were are short in height and of yellow complexion. Their speech differed from that of mid-India. The Nidhanpur grant issued from Karnasuvarna, contained local literary forms and offices not found in subsequent Kamarupa inscriptions
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art_and_industry">Art and industry</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Art and industry">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The gifts from Bhaskaravarman to Harshavardhana contained mostly products of the land—royal umbrella of exquisite workmanship studded with valuable gems, <a href="/wiki/Puthi" title="Puthi">puthis</a> written on Sachi-bark, dyed cane-mats, Agar-essence, musk in silk-bags, liquid <a href="/wiki/Molasses" title="Molasses">molasses</a> in earthen-pots, utensils, paintings, a pair of <a href="/wiki/Ruddy_shelduck" title="Ruddy shelduck">Brahmini ducks</a> in a cage made of cane and overlaid with gold, and a considerable quantity of silk-fabrics indicating industry was rudimentary.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nidhanpur_inscription">Nidhanpur inscription</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Nidhanpur inscription">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nidhanpur_Inscription_of_Bhaskar_Varman.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Nidhanpur_Inscription_of_Bhaskar_Varman.jpg/180px-Nidhanpur_Inscription_of_Bhaskar_Varman.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="99" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Nidhanpur_Inscription_of_Bhaskar_Varman.jpg/270px-Nidhanpur_Inscription_of_Bhaskar_Varman.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Nidhanpur_Inscription_of_Bhaskar_Varman.jpg/360px-Nidhanpur_Inscription_of_Bhaskar_Varman.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1293" data-file-height="708" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Nidhanpur_Inscription_of_Bhaskar_Varman.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><div style="text-align: center;"><small><i><a href="/wiki/Nidhanpur" title="Nidhanpur">Nidhanpur</a> inscription of Bhaskaravarman</i></small></div></div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Nidhanpur_copperplate_inscription" title="Nidhanpur copperplate inscription">Nidhanpur copperplate inscription</a></div>
<p>Bhaskaravarman praises himself in his Nidhanpur copper-plate inscription, saying that <i>"he has revealed the light of the <a href="/wiki/Arya" class="mw-redirect" title="Arya">Arya</a> religion by dispelling the accumulated darkness of <a href="/wiki/Kali_Yuga" title="Kali Yuga">Kali age</a>, by making a judicious application of his revenues; who has equalled the prowess of the whole ring of his feudatories by the strength of his own arm, who has derived many a way of enjoyment for his hereditary subjects whose loyal devotion to him was augmented by his steadiness, modesty and affability, who is adorned with a wonderful ornament of splendid fame made of the flowery words of praise variously composed by hundreds of kings vanquished by him in battle; whose virtuous activities, like those of Sivi, were applied in making gifts for the benefit of others; whose powers, as of a second preceptor of the Gods (Brihaspati), was recognised by others on account of his skill in devising and applying the means of politics that appear in suitable moments; whose own conduct was adorned by learning, valour, patience, prowess and good actions"</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nalanda_seal">Nalanda seal</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Nalanda seal">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:149px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Seal_of_Bhaskar_Varman_Found_at_Nalanda_dated_643_A.D.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Seal_of_Bhaskar_Varman_Found_at_Nalanda_dated_643_A.D.jpg/147px-Seal_of_Bhaskar_Varman_Found_at_Nalanda_dated_643_A.D.jpg" decoding="async" width="147" height="180" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Seal_of_Bhaskar_Varman_Found_at_Nalanda_dated_643_A.D.jpg/220px-Seal_of_Bhaskar_Varman_Found_at_Nalanda_dated_643_A.D.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Seal_of_Bhaskar_Varman_Found_at_Nalanda_dated_643_A.D.jpg/293px-Seal_of_Bhaskar_Varman_Found_at_Nalanda_dated_643_A.D.jpg 2x" data-file-width="597" data-file-height="733" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Seal_of_Bhaskar_Varman_Found_at_Nalanda_dated_643_A.D.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><div style="text-align: center;"><small><i>The Nalanda seal of Bhaskaravarman dated 643</i></small></div></div></div></div>
<p>Bhaskaravarman's close connection with Harsha and Xuanzang led to his association with the famous Buddhist university of Magadha, for his seal has been discovered at the site of <a href="/wiki/Nalanda" title="Nalanda">Nalanda</a> in the company of two fragmentary seals of Harsha. The seals were found by Dr. Spooner during the excavation of the ruins of Nalanda in the year 1917–18. The text of the seal is as follows:<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r960796168">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><div class="poem">
<p>Sri Ganapati Varma Sri Yajnavatyam Sri Mahendra Varma.<br />
Sri Suvratayam Sri Narayanavarma Sri Devavatyam Sri Mahabhuta Varma. <br />
Sri Vijnana Vatyam Sri Chandramukha Varma Sri Bhogavatyam. <br />
Sri Sthitavarma tena Sri Nayana Sobhayam (Sri Susthitavarma) <br />
(Sri Syama Lakshmyam) Sri Supratisthita Varma.<br />
Sri Bhaskara Varmeti.
</p>
</div></blockquote>
<p>K.N. Dikshit, in his "Epigraphical notes of the Nalanda finds", thinks that the seal probably accompanied Bhaskaravarman's letter to Silabhadra inviting Xuanzang.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#What_information_to_include" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="A complete citation is needed (September 2018)">full citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> As however it was found in the company of the two Harsha seals the probability is that both Harsha and Bhaskaravarman, on their march from Rajmahal to Kanauj, visited Nalanda together with the Chinese pilgrim and, to commemorate their visit, left their respective seals at the university.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarua193398_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarua193398-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Death">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>It is not known how or when Bhaskaravarman died, but it is estimated that his reigned ended about 650.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Legacy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p><a href="/wiki/Kumar_Bhaskar_Varma_Sanskrit_and_Ancient_Studies_University" title="Kumar Bhaskar Varma Sanskrit and Ancient Studies University">Kumar Bhaskar Varma Sanskrit and Ancient Studies University</a> of <a href="/wiki/Nalbari" title="Nalbari">Nalbari</a>, Assam has been named after him.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhaskaravarman&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Pala_dynasty_(Kamarupa)" title="Pala dynasty (Kamarupa)">Pala Dynasty</a></li></ul>

Contentious material about living persons that is unsourced or poorly sourced <b>must be removed immediately</b>, especially if potentially <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Libel" title="Wikipedia:Libel">libelous</a> or harmful.<br /><small><span class="plainlinks"><i>Find sources:</i>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?as_eq=wikipedia&amp;q=%22Miguel+%C3%81ngel+Biazzi%22">"Miguel Ángel Biazzi"</a>&#160;–&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbm=nws&amp;q=%22Miguel+%C3%81ngel+Biazzi%22+-wikipedia">news</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?&amp;q=%22Miguel+%C3%81ngel+Biazzi%22+site:news.google.com/newspapers&amp;source=newspapers">newspapers</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbs=bks:1&amp;q=%22Miguel+%C3%81ngel+Biazzi%22+-wikipedia">books</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22Miguel+%C3%81ngel+Biazzi%22">scholar</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/action/doBasicSearch?Query=%22Miguel+%C3%81ngel+Biazzi%22&amp;acc=on&amp;wc=on">JSTOR</a></span></small></span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">October 2010</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Miguel Angel Biazzi</b> was a contemporary Argentine painter, sculptor, <a href="/wiki/Installation_art" title="Installation art">installation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sketch_artist" class="mw-redirect" title="Sketch artist">sketch artist</a> born in the province of <a href="/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba,_Argentina" title="Córdoba, Argentina">Córdoba, Argentina</a>.  He spent 20 years in <a href="/wiki/Salta" title="Salta">Salta</a>, a city in northwestern <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>. He settled in Buenos Aires, in the district of San Telmo, where he created a studio remaining there until his death.  Biazzi was a <a href="/wiki/Latin_American" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin American">Latin American</a> artist indebted to the use of earthy colors and mythical images of <a href="/wiki/Native_America" class="mw-redirect" title="Native America">Native America</a> to represent his recurring theme of "other with integrity."<sup id="cite_ref-Branco,_Nuno._Biazzi&#39;s_Mission_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Branco,_Nuno._Biazzi&#39;s_Mission-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Miguel_%C3%81ngel_Biazzi&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Art">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Throughout his career Biazzi has created works that appear to recover ideas and feelings which seem to be frozen in the past.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>  As described by Portuguese anthropologist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuno_Branco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuno Branco (page does not exist)">Nuno Branco</a>, 
"He (Biazzi) goes further. He lets his mind wander through a number of variations…He is a <a href="/wiki/Guarani_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Guarani people">Guaraní</a>, he is a <a href="/wiki/Tehuelche_people" title="Tehuelche people">Tehuelche</a>, he becomes a <a href="/wiki/Mataco" class="mw-redirect" title="Mataco">Mataco</a>.  No doubt his art is a process of becoming.  The way he has found of becoming someone else, of generously forgetting about himself.  The art of invocation: to invoke, to enchant, to seduce, to laugh together, united by an element of softness, are verbs featuring in his grammar and imagery, only deceptively naïve."<sup id="cite_ref-Branco,_Nuno._Biazzi&#39;s_Mission_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Branco,_Nuno._Biazzi&#39;s_Mission-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
Having crossed paths with <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Luis_Borges" title="Jorge Luis Borges">Jorge Luis Borges</a>, acclaimed Argentine writer, essayist, and poet, one can see clear influences in Biazzi's work of an attempt to elevate quotidian life to a much deserved, yet mostly ignored, prominent hierarchical status.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Recent_exhibitions">Recent exhibitions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Miguel_%C3%81ngel_Biazzi&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Recent exhibitions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>1999: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Centro_Cultural_Borges&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Centro Cultural Borges (page does not exist)">Centro Cultural Borges</a>, Buenos Aires.</li>
<li>2001: Museo Histórico "Casa de la Mondeda", Buenos Aires. Museo de Arte "Casa de la Colonia", Esperanza, Santa Fe.</li>
<li>2002: Embajada de Cuba, Homenaje a Félix Coluccio, Buenos Aires.</li>
<li>2003:Arte Córdoba, Feria Internacional de Arte Contemporáneo, Córdoba. Mural Club Gimnasia y Esgrima, Buenos Aires.</li>
<li>2003: Xunta de Galicia, Casa de Galicia, Madrid, España.</li>
<li>2006: Galería de Arte Revale, Buenos Aires, Argentina</li>
<li>2007: Museo de Arte Contemporáneo de Salta "M.A.C", Salta, Argentina.</li>
<li>2007: Casa de Cultura de San Lorenzo del Escorial, Madrid, España.</li></ul>

<table class="box-Orphan plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style ambox-Orphan" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w.svg" class="image"><img alt="Wiki letter w.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6c/Wiki_letter_w.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6c/Wiki_letter_w.svg/60px-Wiki_letter_w.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6c/Wiki_letter_w.svg/80px-Wiki_letter_w.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="44" data-file-height="44" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article <b>is an <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Orphan" title="Wikipedia:Orphan">orphan</a>, as no other articles <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:Whatlinkshere&amp;target=Stanford_Blade&amp;namespace=0">link to it</a></b>. <table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Stanford Blade</div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace"><a href="/wiki/Wetaskiwin" title="Wetaskiwin">Wetaskiwin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alberta" title="Alberta">Alberta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Occupation</th><td class="role"><a href="/wiki/Dean_(education)" title="Dean (education)">Dean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Professor" title="Professor">professor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Author" title="Author">author</a>, <a href="/wiki/Public_speaker" class="mw-redirect" title="Public speaker">public speaker</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Spouse(s)</span></th><td>Linda</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Children</th><td>Daniel, Savanna</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Website</th><td><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://ales.ualberta.ca/">ales.ualberta.ca</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Dr. Stanford Blade, P.Ag.</b> currently serves as Dean of the Faculty of Agricultural, Life and Environmental Sciences (ALES) at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Alberta" title="University of Alberta">University of Alberta</a>. The faculty is made up of 500 faculty members and staff, 1600 undergraduate students and 550+ graduate students. The six areas of education and research within the Faculty are: i) helping feed the world ii) improving human health through food iii) ensuring a healthy environment iv) nurturing biorefining innovation and v) improving personal and community well-being as well as the University of Alberta Botanic Garden. The ALES annual budget of $85m includes $43m+ of industrial research investment. Dr. Blade previously served as CEO of Alberta Innovates - Bio Solutions Corporation. He was formerly the Executive Director (2006–2009) of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alberta_Agricultural_Research_Institute&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alberta Agricultural Research Institute (page does not exist)">Alberta Agricultural Research Institute</a> (Government of <a href="/wiki/Alberta" title="Alberta">Alberta</a>). He was previously employed as the Deputy Director General (Research) for the <a href="/wiki/International_Institute_of_Tropical_Agriculture" title="International Institute of Tropical Agriculture">International Institute of Tropical Agriculture</a> (IITA) which is a research organization that is part of the <a href="/wiki/Consultative_Group_on_International_Agricultural_Research" class="mw-redirect" title="Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research">Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research</a>. Dr. Blade serves as a Trustee on the Board of the <a href="/wiki/International_Institute_of_Tropical_Agriculture" title="International Institute of Tropical Agriculture">International Institute of Tropical Agriculture</a> and previously served as Vice-Chair on the Board of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=African_Agricultural_Technology_Foundation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="African Agricultural Technology Foundation (page does not exist)">African Agricultural Technology Foundation</a>. He is also a Board Member of the following research organizations: Livestock Gentec, Phytola, Genome Alberta and the Alberta Biodiversity Monitoring Institute. He is also an Associate Editor of the American Society of Agronomy's peer-reviewed international journal of agriculture and natural resource sciences-Agronomy Journal. In 2016 Dr. Blade was requested by the Government of Macedonia to serve as a Board Member of the Macedonia Fund for Innovation. In 2012 Dr. Blade was named one of Alberta's 50 most influential people by Alberta Venture magazine.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2018, Dr. Blade was elected as an International Fellow of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Swedish_Academy_of_Agriculture_and_Forestry" title="Royal Swedish Academy of Agriculture and Forestry">Royal Swedish Academy of Agriculture and Forestry</a>. Dr. Blade is a Trustee on the Board of the <a href="/wiki/International_Institute_of_Tropical_Agriculture" title="International Institute of Tropical Agriculture">International Institute of Tropical Agriculture</a>.
</p>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_and_education">Early life and education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Stanford_Blade&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life and education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Blade was born in Alberta where he was raised on a dairy and grain farm.  He attended the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Alberta" title="University of Alberta">University of Alberta</a> for his first degree (B.Sc.) in genetics.  He obtained his M.Sc. (Crop Science) from the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Saskatchewan" title="University of Saskatchewan">University of Saskatchewan</a> for a breeding/physiology study on <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">wheat</a>.  Blade’s doctorate was awarded by <a href="/wiki/McGill_University" title="McGill University">McGill University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Montreal" title="Montreal">Montreal</a> for work done at the <a href="/wiki/International_Institute_of_Tropical_Agriculture" title="International Institute of Tropical Agriculture">International Institute of Tropical Agriculture</a> on a Canadian International Development Agency Ph.D. Scholarship.  The thesis topic was a plant breeding/farming systems approach to improving an indigenous grain legume (Vigna unguiculata L.) for use within the complex cereal-legume cropping systems of the West African <a href="/wiki/Savanna" title="Savanna">savanna</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Stanford_Blade&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Blade has served in a number of leadership roles in Canada, such as the Director of the Crop Division of Alberta Agriculture, Food and Rural Development (AAFRD), and Research Director of the Alberta <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">Barley</a> Commission.  Dr. Blade provided direction for 200 staff people and four major research centers, as well as working with universities and the private sector to develop innovative technologies.  Dr. Blade has also worked in the private sector as Research Director for the Alberta Barley Commission.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Research">Research</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Stanford_Blade&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Research">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Blade’s own research successes have included the development and release of the high-performing Cutlass field pea. Blade has participated in the release of several field <a href="/wiki/Pea" title="Pea">pea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lentil" title="Lentil">lentil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cowpea" title="Cowpea">cowpea</a> and fenugreek lines.  In addition, his research activities in crop diversification, such as his pioneering work on several new crops (low-THC hemp, medicinal plants, industrial crops, grain legumes) has created demand for Blade to serve as a global consultant and speaker. Blade has been invited to write and speak on crop diversification across Canada, the United States, Mexico, Argentina, Scotland, Germany, Poland, Sri Lanka, Australia, Libya and several other countries. Blade currently serves as an Associate Editor for the <i>Agronomy Journal</i>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Publications">Publications</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Stanford_Blade&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Publications">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Blade has published 70+ research articles, ten book chapters, 120+ conference abstracts, and has edited four books. He has been the winner of several awards from the American Society of Agronomy and the Crop Science Society of America. Blade is a member of several professional societies and international committees.  He has served on evaluation committees for the European Union, Canadian Foundation for Innovation and Food and Agriculture Organization. Blade published an article on his interaction with Nobel Prize winner Norman Borlaug in The Globe and Mail-Canada's national newspaper.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Stanford_Blade&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">

<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Public secondary school in Bladensburg, Maryland, United States</div><table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" class="fn org" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;background-color: lavender">Bladensburg High School</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:BladensburgHSMDlogo.png" class="image"><img alt="BladensburgHSMDlogo.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/e/e0/BladensburgHSMDlogo.png" decoding="async" width="126" height="141" data-file-width="126" data-file-height="141" /></a></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:lavender">Address</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a class="mw-kartographer-map mw-kartographer-container center" style="width: 270px; <p><b>Bladensburg High School</b> is a <a href="/wiki/Public_high_school" class="mw-redirect" title="Public high school">public high school</a> located in <a href="/wiki/Bladensburg,_Maryland" title="Bladensburg, Maryland">Bladensburg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maryland" title="Maryland">Maryland</a>, United States. The school, which serves grades 9 through 12, is a part of the <a href="/wiki/Prince_George%27s_County_Public_Schools" title="Prince George&#39;s County Public Schools">Prince George's County Public Schools</a> district.
</p><p>The school serves:<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> the towns of Bladensburg,<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Colmar_Manor,_Maryland" title="Colmar Manor, Maryland">Colmar Manor</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Cottage_City,_Maryland" title="Cottage City, Maryland">Cottage City</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> as well almost all of the <a href="/wiki/Cheverly,_Maryland" title="Cheverly, Maryland">Town of Cheverly</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-CheverlyMap_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CheverlyMap-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> portions of the towns of <a href="/wiki/Edmonston,_Maryland" title="Edmonston, Maryland">Edmonston</a> and <a href="/wiki/Riverdale_Park,_Maryland" title="Riverdale Park, Maryland">Riverdale Park</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> a small section of the <a href="/wiki/Hyattsville,_Maryland" title="Hyattsville, Maryland">City of Hyattsville</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> and sections of <a href="/wiki/East_Riverdale,_Maryland" title="East Riverdale, Maryland">East Riverdale</a> and <a href="/wiki/Landover,_Maryland" title="Landover, Maryland">Landover</a> <a href="/wiki/Census-designated_place" title="Census-designated place">census-designated places</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> In addition the school serves students from all across the county that are selected to enroll in its prestigious Biomedical Program.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bladensburg_High_School&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In 1950 a permanent building was constructed,<sup id="cite_ref-LylesKabranreadying_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LylesKabranreadying-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> in phases. Beginning in the 1980s the district made plans to renovate or replace the building, but delays occurred as PGCPS resources were devoted to schools that needed to be built or ones that had more serious problems in their facilities. In 1999 PGCPS decided that Bladensburg High would get a new building instead of a renovation.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> Prior to 2001 the school building became infested with insects and rats, prompting PGCPS officials to make its replacement a priority.<sup id="cite_ref-MorrisAyeshaBowie_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MorrisAyeshaBowie-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The $45 million project was scheduled to begin in January 2001 and was originally to last until circa 2003. In 2000 officials were looking for a campus to temporarily house the students. The first plan was to send the students to the former <a href="/wiki/Northwestern_High_School_(Hyattsville,_Maryland)" title="Northwestern High School (Hyattsville, Maryland)">Northwestern High School</a> building, but the <a href="/wiki/Hyattsville,_Maryland" title="Hyattsville, Maryland">Hyattsville</a> city council disapproved of this as it felt the Bladensburg students would be too close to the Northwestern students, already occupying the current school building. The second choice was a building in <a href="/wiki/Bowie,_Maryland" title="Bowie, Maryland">Bowie</a>, but around 100 Bowie residents protested against this plan in a city hall meeting;<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> Several Bowie city council members stated that the controversy gave Bowie a negative image.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bladensburg High was temporarily relocated to the Belair Annex in Bowie, a former school building that was used by PGCPS to house excess students from other schools;<sup id="cite_ref-FurfariBelairegrowing_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FurfariBelairegrowing-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> Bowie residents hoped to use the annex to relieve area schools that had excess students.<sup id="cite_ref-LylesJeff_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LylesJeff-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> By 2002 the district planned to install 18 trailers at Belair to house additional students.<sup id="cite_ref-FurfariBelairegrowing_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FurfariBelairegrowing-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> The trailers were later 22, then 38. The opening of the new Bladensburg High was pushed back from 2004 to 2005, and the swelling student population that was far larger than the capacity of the original school necessitated additional construction, eroding the patience of the residents of surrounding Bowie neighborhoods who felt impacted by the additional buildings and traffic. In addition Bladensburg students wished for the new campus to be complete as they perceived the temporary facilities to be inadequate.<sup id="cite_ref-MorrisAyeshaBowie_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MorrisAyeshaBowie-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> The new Bladensburg High opened in August 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-LylesKabranreadying_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LylesKabranreadying-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2011, Bladensburg High School won three first-place awards, placing the schools in Bladensburg as the number-one contender in Communication, Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math.
</p><p>In 2011, Bladensburg High School appeared in several media showcases for its work with the <a href="/wiki/DREAM_Act" title="DREAM Act">DREAM Act</a>; Communication, Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math awards; Secondary School Reform courses; <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Laureate" class="mw-redirect" title="Nobel Laureate">Nobel Laureate</a> <a href="/wiki/William_Daniel_Phillips" title="William Daniel Phillips">William Daniel Phillips</a>' physics presentation at the school; and winning the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Foundation" class="mw-redirect" title="Grammy Foundation">Grammy Foundation</a> Award for Excellence in Music.
</p><p>Bladensburg High School graduated a <a href="/wiki/Gates_Millennium_Scholar" class="mw-redirect" title="Gates Millennium Scholar">Gates Millennium Scholar</a> in 2009 and its first <a href="/wiki/Posse_Foundation" title="Posse Foundation">Posse Foundation</a> scholar in 2011.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bladensburg_High_School&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Demographics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<table class="box-Unreferenced plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Unreferenced" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>does not <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">cite</a> any <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">sources</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bladensburg_High_School&amp;action=edit">improve this section</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">removed</a>.<br /><small><span class="plainlinks"><i>Find sources:</i>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?as_eq=wikipedia&amp;q=%22Bladensburg+High+School%22">"Bladensburg High School"</a>&#160;–&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbm=nws&amp;q=%22Bladensburg+High+School%22+-wikipedia">news</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?&amp;q=%22Bladensburg+High+School%22+site:news.google.com/newspapers&amp;source=newspapers">newspapers</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbs=bks:1&amp;q=%22Bladensburg+High+School%22+-wikipedia">books</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22Bladensburg+High+School%22">scholar</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/action/doBasicSearch?Query=%22Bladensburg+High+School%22&amp;acc=on&amp;wc=on">JSTOR</a></span></small></span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">September 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Bladensburg has had significant historical changes in the demographics of its students.  When Bladensburg High School opened in the mid-1930s, all students were white. Due to the <a href="/wiki/Brown_v._Board_of_Education" title="Brown v. Board of Education">desegregation of public schools nationwide in 1954</a> and, later, the changing population of Prince George's County overall, student enrollment is now 49% African-American and 49% Hispanic/Latino.  
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Programs">Programs</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bladensburg_High_School&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Programs">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In 2011 the school was one of two in the county with an on-site daycare; it also had classes for new parents.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Curriculum">Curriculum</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bladensburg_High_School&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Curriculum">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<p>Bladensburg High School offers programs of study in <a href="/wiki/Biomedicine" title="Biomedicine">biomedicine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culinary_arts" title="Culinary arts">culinary arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cosmetology" title="Cosmetology">cosmetology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nursing" title="Nursing">nursing</a>.  Over the last two years, the school, along with its feeder middle school and elementary school, participated in the national <a href="/wiki/Science,_technology,_engineering,_and_mathematics" title="Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics">Communication, Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math</a> competition in Houston.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notable_alumni">Notable alumni</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bladensburg_High_School&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Notable alumni">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Thurl_Bailey" title="Thurl Bailey">Thurl Bailey</a>, former NBA player</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Wayne_K._Curry" title="Wayne K. Curry">Wayne K. Curry</a>, former Prince George's County Executive/</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Brian_Davis_(basketball)" title="Brian Davis (basketball)">Brian Davis</a>, former professional basketball player</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ebenezer_Ekuban" title="Ebenezer Ekuban">Ebenezer Ekuban</a>, former National Football League player</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mike_Holston" title="Mike Holston">Mike Holston</a>, former National Football League player</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/John_P._McDonough" title="John P. McDonough">John P. McDonough</a>, former Secretary of State of Maryland</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Steve_Rochinski" title="Steve Rochinski">Steve Rochinski</a>, bebop jazz guitarist and educator</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Jason_Williams_(Radford_basketball)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jason Williams (Radford basketball)">Jason Williams</a>, former professional basketball player</li></ul>

<li id="cite_note-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-17">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFHollingsworth,_Catherine2000" class="citation news cs1">Hollingsworth, Catherine (2000-08-04). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180908151034/http://www.gazette.net/gazette_archive/2000/200031/montgomerycty/education/21269-1.html">"High school relocation spat fans racial flames in Bowie"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Gazette_(Maryland)" title="The Gazette (Maryland)">The Gazette</a></i>. </div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Carl Oscar (Oskar) Boije af Gennäs</b> (7 July 1849 – 1923), was a Swedish collector of guitar sheet music.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Carl_Oscar_Boije_af_Genn%C3%A4s&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Boije af Gennäs was born in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hassl%C3%B6vs_socken&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hasslövs socken (page does not exist)">Hasslövs socken</a>, <a href="/wiki/Halland_County" title="Halland County">Halland County</a>, Sweden. He was descended from the Swedish-Finnish noble family Boije af Gennäs<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> and worked as a mathematician at the life insurance company <a href="/w/index.php?title=Victoria_(Life_insurance_company)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Victoria (Life insurance company) (page does not exist)">Victoria</a> in Stockholm.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Boije af Gennäs was an amateur guitarist and composer. He composed Marcia Funebre in memory of Otto Hammerer. The piece was published in Freie Vereinigung zur Förderung guter Guitarmusik, eingetragener Verein, Sitz i Augsburg, (Free Society for the promotion of good Guitar-music, seat at Augsburg), April 1905, volume 8.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Boije af Gennäs was a guitar music collector, mainly of music from the 19th century. His collection included nearly 1,000 works, including sheet music by <a href="/wiki/Dionisio_Aguado_y_Garc%C3%ADa" title="Dionisio Aguado y García">Dionisio Aguado</a>, <a href="/wiki/Matteo_Carcassi" title="Matteo Carcassi">Matteo Carcassi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ferdinando_Carulli" title="Ferdinando Carulli">Ferdinando Carulli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mauro_Giuliani" title="Mauro Giuliani">Mauro Giuliani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luigi_Legnani" title="Luigi Legnani">Luigi Rinaldo Legnani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Sor" title="Fernando Sor">Fernando Sor</a>.
</p><p>The collection also contained original manuscripts by J. K. Mertz. The collection, which only contained music for guitar, was donated to <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Music_and_Theatre_Library_of_Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Music and Theatre Library of Sweden (page does not exist)">The Music and Theatre Library of Sweden</a> (formerly The Music Library of Sweden and earlier The Library of The Swedish Academy of Music) in Stockholm. The collection is digitized and is available online via Boijes collection at the Music and Theatre Library of Sweden.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Carl_Oscar_Boije_af_Genn%C3%A4s&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<p><b>Susanne Boll-Westermann</b> is a Professor for <a href="/wiki/Multimedia" title="Multimedia">Multimedia</a> and Internet in the Department of Computing Science at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Oldenburg" title="University of Oldenburg">University of Oldenburg</a>, Germany. Her main research interests are semantic <a href="/wiki/Information_retrieval" title="Information retrieval">information retrieval</a>, intelligent <a href="/wiki/User-interface" class="mw-redirect" title="User-interface">user-interfaces</a> and mobile systems. Susanne Boll is an active member of <a href="/wiki/SIGMM" class="mw-redirect" title="SIGMM">SIGMM</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Association_for_Computing_Machinery" title="Association for Computing Machinery">ACM</a> and is a member of the board at the research institute <a href="/wiki/OFFIS" title="OFFIS">OFFIS</a>.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Research">Research</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Susanne_Boll&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Research">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Boll's early works on Semantic Multimedia Models have been published in the IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering in 2001. She has developed her research area from multimedia models into interactive multimedia systems and interactive systems. She organized the first ACM Workshop on Social Media at ACM Multimedia 2009 and the first Workshop on Multimedia for Personal Health and Health Care at ACM Multimedia in 2017 and just run the WISH Symposium at CHI 2019.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Susanne_Boll&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Boll received her PhD in 2001 from the <a href="/wiki/Vienna_University_of_Technology" class="mw-redirect" title="Vienna University of Technology">Vienna University of Technology</a>. Core elements of her scientific work in the field multimedia document modeling was published.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>She graduated in computer science (<a href="/wiki/Diplom" title="Diplom">Diplom</a> with distinction) from the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Computer_Science_of_TU_Darmstadt" title="Department of Computer Science of TU Darmstadt">Department of Computer Science</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Technische_Universit%C3%A4t_Darmstadt" title="Technische Universität Darmstadt">Technische Universität Darmstadt</a>, Germany.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Susanne_Boll&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Boll has been a Member at Large in the Executive Committee of SIGMM for several years. She has taken over the organization and support for many events at ACM conferences, panels, workshops. She was the organizer of several international retreats at prestigious Dagstuhl Castle to which she invited international researchers to join her in discussing trends, challenges and future directions in multimedia and human computer interaction. She has taken over leading roles for major ACM conferences: Program Co-Chair of ACM Multimedia in 2017, General Co-Chair of ACM Multimedia, Program Chair of MobileHCI in 2019, and will be General Chair of MobileHCI in 2020.
</p><p>She is an elected member (Fachkollegiatin) of the German Science Foundation (DFG) board of reviewers in Computer Science since 2016 and has just been re-elected for four more years. She is also the deputy spokesperson of this board since 2019.
</p><p>Boll has been championing equal opportunities and diversity. She is particularly interested in the factors and environments inspiring young girls to choose STEM subjects in their higher education and leads a research project that explores role models and curricula in Computer Science for high school girls (Smile Smart Future Me). In 2019, Boll washas been appointed as the Director of Diversity and Outreach in the Executive Committee of ACM SIGMM.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> She initiated the 25 in 25 strategy in which ACM SIGMM wants to overcame is relatively low representation of women in all activities of SIGMM and has decided on 10 actions to achieve at least 25% female participation at all levels of its organization and for all roles on all levels in its conferences and other scientific events by the year 2025.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Selected_research_papers">Selected research papers</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Susanne_Boll&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Selected research papers">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>Andrii Matviienko, Swamy Ananthanarayan, Abdallah El Ali, Wilko Heuten, and Susanne Boll. 2019. NaviBike: Comparing Unimodal Navigation Cues for Child Cyclists. In Proc. of the 2019 CHI Conf. on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI '19). ACM, New York, NY, USA, Paper 620, 12 pages.</li>
<li>Larbi Abdenebaoui, Benjamin Meyer, Anton Bruns and Susanne Boll, "UNNA: A Unified Neural Network for Aesthetic Assessment,"&#160;2018 International Conference on Content-Based Multimedia Indexing (CBMI), La Rochelle, 2018, pp.&#160;1–6.</li>
<li>Torben Wallbaum, Andrii Matviienko, Swamy Ananthanarayan, Thomas Olsson, Wilko Heuten, and Susanne C.J. Boll. 2018. Supporting Communication between Grandparents and Grandchildren through Tangible Storytelling Systems. In Proceedings of the 2018 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI '18). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 12 pages.</li>
<li>Abdallah El Ali, Tim C. Stratmann, Souneil Park, Johannes Schöning, Wilko Heuten, and Susanne Boll. Measuring, Understanding, and Classifying News Media Sympathy on Twitter after Crisis Events. In Proceedings of the 2018 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI '18). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 13 pages.</li>
<li>Uwe Grünefeld, Andreas Löcken, Yvonne Brück, Susanne Boll, Wilko Heuten. “Where to Look: Exploring Peripheral Cues for Shifting Attention to Spatially Distributed Out-of-View Objects”. AutomotiveUI 2018: 221-228</li>
<li>Andrii Matviienko, Swamy Ananthanarayan, Shadan Sadeghian Borojeni, Yannick Feld, Wilko Heuten, Susanne Boll. Augmenting bicycles and helmets with multimodal warnings for children. MobileHCI 2018: 15:1-15:13</li>
<li>Andreas Löcken, Sarah Blum, Tim Claudius Stratmann, Uwe Gruenefeld, Wilko Heuten, Susanne Boll, and Steven van de Par. Effects of location and fade-in time of (audio-)visual cues on response times and success-rates in a dual-task experiment. In&#160;Proceedings of the ACM Symposium on Applied Perception&#160;(SAP '17). ACM, New York, NY, USA, Article 12, 4 pages.</li>
<li>Jochen Meyer, Merlin Wasmann, Wilko Heuten, Abdallah El Ali, and Susanne C.J. Boll Identification and Classification of Usage Patterns in Long-Term Activity Tracking. In&#160;Proc. of the 2017 CHI Conf. on Human Factors in Computing Systems&#160;(CHI '17). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 667–678.&#160;</li>
<li>Andres. L. Kun, Orit Shaer, Albrecht Schmidt and Susanne Boll, "Ubicomp without Borders: International Experiences in Pervasive Computing," in&#160;IEEE Pervasive Computing, vol. 16, no. 4, pp.&#160;17–21, October–December 2017.</li>
<li>Andreas Löcken, Sarah Blum, Tim Claudius Stratmann, Uwe Gruenefeld, Wilko Heuten, Susanne Boll, Steven van de Par. Effects of location and fade-in time of (audio-)visual cues on response times and success-rates in a dual-task experiment. SAP 2017: 12:1-12:4</li>
<li>Uwe Gruenefeld, Abdallah El Ali, Wilko Heuten, and Susanne Boll. 2017. Visualizing out-of-view objects in head-mounted augmented reality. In&#160;Proceedings of the 19th International Conference on Human-Computer Interaction with Mobile Devices and Services&#160;(MobileHCI '17). ACM, New York, NY, USA, Article 81, 7 pages.</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Susanne_Boll&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering, 13(3): 361 – 382, 2001</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" <table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">February 2011</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Kopil Bora</div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><span style="display:none"> (<span class="bday">1977-03-30</span>) </span>March 30, 1977<span class="noprint ForceAgeToShow"> (age&#160;43)</span><br /><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace"><a href="/wiki/Assam,_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Assam, India">Assam, India</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Other&#160;names</th><td class="nickname">
<ul><li><b>Kiku</b></li>
<li><b>Mr. Perfectionist of Jollywood</b></li></ul>
</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Occupation</th><td class="role">Actor, anchor, voice artist</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Years&#160;active</th><td>2002 - present</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Kopil Bora</b> (<a href="/wiki/Assamese_language" title="Assamese language">Assamese</a>: <span lang="as"><b>কপিল বৰা</b></span>) is an <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Assam" class="mw-redirect" title="Cinema of Assam">Assamese</a> actor, anchor and <a href="/wiki/All_India_Radio" title="All India Radio">All India Radio</a> voice artist. He debuted in Bidyut Chakravarty's 2002 Assamese film <i>Gun Gun Gane Gane</i> and known for his performance in <i>Mon</i> (2002), <i><a href="/wiki/Ahir_Bhairav_(film)" title="Ahir Bhairav (film)">Ahir Bhairav</a></i> (2008), <i><a href="/wiki/Jetuka_Pator_Dore" title="Jetuka Pator Dore">Jetuka Pator Dore</a></i> (2011) and <i><a href="/wiki/Dwaar" title="Dwaar">Dwaar</a></i> (2013).
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kopil_Bora&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Kopil Bora<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> was born on 30 March. He went to high school at <a href="/wiki/Don_Bosco_High_School,_Guwahati" title="Don Bosco High School, Guwahati">Don Bosco High School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guwahati" title="Guwahati">Guwahati</a> and later attended college at <a href="/wiki/Cotton_College,_Guwahati" class="mw-redirect" title="Cotton College, Guwahati">Cotton College</a>, Guwahati. He currently lives in Guwahati.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kopil_Bora&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Feature_films">Feature films</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kopil_Bora&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Feature films">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Kopil has acted in a host of <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Assam" class="mw-redirect" title="Cinema of Assam">Assamese films</a>. He debuted in Bidyut Chakravarty's <i>Gun Gun Gane Gane</i>, released in 2002. Later in the same year his another film Bani Das' <i>Mon</i> got released. His other film credit includes <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bidhata&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bidhata (page does not exist)">Bidhata</a></i> (2003), <i>Kadambari</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Ahir_Bhairav_(film)" title="Ahir Bhairav (film)">Ahir Bhairav</a></i> (2008), <i><a href="/wiki/Jeevan_Baator_Logori" title="Jeevan Baator Logori">Jeevan Baator Logori</a></i> (2009), <i><a href="/wiki/Jetuka_Pator_Dore" title="Jetuka Pator Dore">Jetuka Pator Dore</a></i> (2011), <i><a href="/wiki/Dwaar" title="Dwaar">Dwaar</a></i> (2013), <i><a href="/wiki/Raag:_The_Rhythm_of_Love" class="mw-redirect" title="Raag: The Rhythm of Love">Raag: The Rhythm of Love</a></i> (2014) etc. Critics praised his acting in 2013 film <i><a href="/wiki/Dwaar" title="Dwaar">Dwaar</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-7sisReview_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7sisReview-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> In that film he portrayed a mentally unstable character older to his actual age, named Dwijen Bhattacharya.<sup id="cite_ref-7sis2_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7sis2-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Stage_and_television">Stage and television</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kopil_Bora&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Stage and television">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Suryasta.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cb/Suryasta.jpg/220px-Suryasta.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cb/Suryasta.jpg/330px-Suryasta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cb/Suryasta.jpg/440px-Suryasta.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="608" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Suryasta.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kopil Bora (second from left) in a drama with his co-stars <a href="/wiki/Zerifa_Wahid" title="Zerifa Wahid">Zerifa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ravi_Sarma" title="Ravi Sarma">Ravi Sarma</a> and Mayuri</div></div></div>
<p>Kopil Bora has acted in many plays. One of the notable ones is <i>Narakor Gopan Kakhyat</i> with <a href="/wiki/Zerifa_Wahid" title="Zerifa Wahid">Zerifa Wahid</a>, staged in Rabindra Bhawan, Guwahati. It was an adaptation of the French play "<a href="/wiki/No_Exit" title="No Exit">In Camera</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Jean-Paul_Sartre" title="Jean-Paul Sartre">Jean-Paul Sartre</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-assam2007_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-assam2007-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> In another play with Zerifa Wahid, <i>Pancharatna</i>, staged in Rabindra Bhawan, he played a bold theme of <a href="/wiki/Homosexual" class="mw-redirect" title="Homosexual">gay</a> boy troubled by his alternate sexuality. He was also associate director of a play called <i>Agnibristi</i> where he plays the lead role too, under Zerifa Wahid production, staged in Rabindra Bhawan. It was an adaptation of <a href="/wiki/Girish_Karnad" title="Girish Karnad">Girish Karnad</a>'s play <i>The Fire and the Rain</i>.
</p><p>In television, Kopil acted in an eight-episode <a href="/wiki/Hindi_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindi language">Hindi</a> mini-series titled <i>Manushi</i> (with seven stories by <a href="/wiki/Sahitya_Akademi" title="Sahitya Akademi">Sahitya Akademi</a> award winner <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sneha_Devi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sneha Devi (page does not exist)">Sneha Devi</a>), directed by Sanjib Hazarika for <a href="/wiki/Doordarshan" title="Doordarshan">Doordarshan</a>. His other television credit includes <i>Niyoror Phool</i> on <a href="/wiki/News_Live" title="News Live">News Live</a>. He also hosted a spelling contest for children on <a href="/wiki/Rang_(TV_Channel)" class="mw-redirect" title="Rang (TV Channel)">Rang</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mobile_theatre">Mobile theatre</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kopil_Bora&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Mobile theatre">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>He debuted in <a href="/wiki/Assam" title="Assam">Assam</a>'s roaming theatre with <i>Ashirbad Theatre</i>. He also acted in <i>Rajmahal Theatre</i>. The list of plays includes "Surongor Xekhot", a drama which was aired in the <a href="/wiki/All_India_Radio" title="All India Radio">All India Radio</a> in the 1980s, "Surjyo" and "Bhai".<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_interests">Other interests</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kopil_Bora&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Other interests">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Compering_and_social_causes">Compering and social causes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kopil_Bora&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Compering and social causes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kopil_Bora_-_TeachAIDS_Recording_Session.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Kopil_Bora_-_TeachAIDS_Recording_Session.png/220px-Kopil_Bora_-_TeachAIDS_Recording_Session.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="189" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Kopil_Bora_-_TeachAIDS_Recording_Session.png/330px-Kopil_Bora_-_TeachAIDS_Recording_Session.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Kopil_Bora_-_TeachAIDS_Recording_Session.png/440px-Kopil_Bora_-_TeachAIDS_Recording_Session.png 2x" data-file-width="1132" data-file-height="974" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Kopil_Bora_-_TeachAIDS_Recording_Session.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kopil Bora records his voice for the Axomiya language version of <a href="/wiki/TeachAIDS" title="TeachAIDS">TeachAIDS</a> at Auditek Digital Recording Studio in Guwahati, Assam</div></div></div>
<p>Kapil had compered for Axom Idol - a Musical Talent search programme hosted in NE TV, Sur-Taal-Loy another Musical talent programme impressively anchored by Kapil Bora in association with <a href="/wiki/Barsha_Rani_Bishaya" title="Barsha Rani Bishaya">Barsha Rani Bishaya</a> and Surajit Malakar Guwahati - and various News years eve celebrations hosted in <a href="/wiki/DD_North-East" title="DD North-East">DD NE</a> and participated in the cultural extravaganza in the closing function of the 33rd National games, held at Guwahati.<sup id="cite_ref-assam2007_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-assam2007-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Kapil Bora and Nishita Goswami, co-hosted the 3rd Darpan Mrs India North East title, the highly coveted beauty pageant for the married women in the North East, during a glittering function at the Pragjyotika ITA Centre auditorium for performing Arts.
</p><p>In 2010, Kapil Bora provided the background narration for a 21-minute documentary film, <i>Friends of Kaziranga</i>, which pays tribute to the forest guards of the Kaziranga National Park.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bora also inaugurated a clothes bank at a function held at Hotel Brahmaputra Ashok, Guwahati. The bank, which redistributes discarded clothes to the poor and needy, was launched by a city-based NGO, Xavier's Foundation, with the support of North Eastern Development Finance Corporation Limited (NEDFi), which is a financial and development institution formed under the DoNER ministry.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Endorsements">Endorsements</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kopil_Bora&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Endorsements">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Kapil Bora is the brand ambassador of CEC - an educational trust based in Guwahati. He has also done modelling for different assignments.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Filmography">Filmography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kopil_Bora&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Filmography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<ul><li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.imdb.com/name/nm6757897/">Kopil Bora</a> on <a href="/wiki/IMDb" title="IMDb">IMDb</a></li></ul></div>
