<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">December 2013</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

style="text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;"><hr /><b><a href="/wiki/File:Books-aj.svg_aj_ashton_01.svg" class="image"><img alt="Books-aj.svg aj ashton 01.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Books-aj.svg_aj_ashton_01.svg/16px-Books-aj.svg_aj_ashton_01.svg.png" decoding="async" width="16" height="14" class="noviewer" href="/wiki/Portal:Literature" title="Portal:Literature">Literature&#32;portal</a></b></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Nirmal Prabha Bordoloi</b> (1932/1933 – 1 June 2004) was an eminent Indian poet, lyricist and folklorist associated with <a href="/wiki/Assamese_literature" title="Assamese literature">Assamese literature</a>. She was the president of the <a href="/wiki/Asam_Sahitya_Sabha" title="Asam Sahitya Sabha">Asam Sahitya Sabha</a> in 1991 held at <a href="/wiki/Dudhnoi" title="Dudhnoi">Dudhnoi</a> in <a href="/wiki/Goalpara_district" title="Goalpara district">Goalpara district</a> of Assam.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> She was honoured with many notable awards like <a href="/wiki/Sahitya_Akademi_Award" title="Sahitya Akademi Award">Sahitya Akademi Award</a> in 1983 for her poetry book <i>Sudirgha Din Aru Ritu</i>, President award in 1957 for children's literature and the Asam Sahitya Sabha award twice in 1977 and 1989 for her scholarly non-fiction books `Dinar Pisat Din' and `Debi', respectively. She was conferred the `Saraswati Sanman' title in 1987.<sup id="cite_ref-outlookindia_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-outlookindia-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life_and_career">Life and career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nirmal_Prabha_Bordoloi&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Life and career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Bordoloi was <a href="/wiki/Child_marriage" title="Child marriage">married as a child</a> at the age of 11. She acquired her degrees after that. She became a mother at the age of 13 to a daughter. Bordoloi wrote over 54 Assamese and English books and thousands of songs. Prominent among the books are `Kabita: Mon Faringar Rong', `Samipesu', `Antarang', `Asamar Luko Sangonskriti', `Siba', `Asamar Luko Kabita'. She was the head of the Assamese department of <a href="/wiki/Gauhati_University" title="Gauhati University">Gauhati University</a>. Bordoloi died on 1 June 2004 at the age of 71.<sup id="cite_ref-outlookindia_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-outlookindia-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Robert_Boury.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Robert_Boury.jpg/220px-Robert_Boury.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="331" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/81/Robert_Boury.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="299" data-file-height="450" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Robert_Boury.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Robert Boury</div></div></div>
<p><b>Robert Boury</b> (born December 28, 1946) is an American composer and pianist. Boury was part of the revival of <a href="/wiki/Ragtime" title="Ragtime">Ragtime</a> led by <a href="/wiki/William_Albright_(musician)" title="William Albright (musician)">William Albright</a> and <a href="/wiki/William_Bolcom" title="William Bolcom">William Bolcom</a> in the late sixties. Boury has composed many types of instrumental works and in a variety of medias and genres, such as solo/duet piano works, art songs, both comic opera/opera seria, choral works, ragtime works, orchestral works and elect acoustic pieces.<sup id="cite_ref-faculty_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-faculty-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>
As a professor of music and resident composer at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Arkansas_at_Little_Rock" title="University of Arkansas at Little Rock">University of Arkansas at Little Rock</a>, he is an active musician and a devoted teacher, who hosts a "Songwriters Showcase" for his students each semester. Boury's commissioned work, <i>To Dream Again</i>, which contains four songs from <a href="/wiki/Shakespeare" class="mw-redirect" title="Shakespeare">Shakespeare</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tempest" title="The Tempest">The Tempest</a></i>, was given its first performance in the summer of 2003 at the 100th Anniversary Convention of <a href="/wiki/Sigma_Alpha_Iota" title="Sigma Alpha Iota">Sigma Alpha Iota</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Dearborn,_Michigan" title="Dearborn, Michigan">Dearborn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michigan" title="Michigan">Michigan</a>. In 2004, his university commissioned him to create a work in honor of the opening of the Clinton Library in Little Rock and he continues to volunteer in schools and churches to share his music.<sup id="cite_ref-faculty_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-faculty-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bourydream.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Bourydream.jpg/170px-Bourydream.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="246" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Bourydream.jpg/255px-Bourydream.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4f/Bourydream.jpg 2x" data-file-width="332" data-file-height="480" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bourydream.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>To Dream Again</i>, op. 56 (S, pf), 2002. Song cycle.Published by Peters</div></div></div><p> Boury has composed music for his university's <a href="/wiki/Alma_mater" title="Alma mater">alma mater</a>, as well as for opera and theater events, produced at <a href="/wiki/University_of_Arkansas_at_Little_Rock" title="University of Arkansas at Little Rock">University of Arkansas at Little Rock</a>. His many art songs and chamber music pieces have been performed regionally, nationally and internationally as well.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> Robert Boury is known for his beautiful art songs and cycles. His renowned songs are well thought of and are sung by students and professionals nationwide. Boury also composed many solo piano pieces along with piano ensemble works such as two pianos, four hands pieces (<i>Two Beguines, op. 4, Duelin' Pianos, op. 10d</i>) and one piano, eight hands piece (<i>The Mice Will Play, op. 19</i>).
</p><p>Like many composers before him, Boury was influenced by different eras and musical styles. Having been born in the middle of the 20th century, he was exposed to a variety of compositional styles. His works combine elements of tonal and non-tonal classical music with a touch of American music and non-Western music. For instance, some of his piano works exhibit a Romantic style while others consist of Rag style influences. His recent piano works show his interest in a Medieval compositional technique called <a href="/wiki/Soggetto_cavato" title="Soggetto cavato">soggetto cavato</a> (Italian: Carved-out subject), which is an innovation that Renaissance composer <a href="/wiki/Josquin_des_Prez" title="Josquin des Prez">Josquin des Prez</a> used.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> In this technique, the vowels of words are transformed into a musical theme by matching them to the corresponding pitches. The details of his compositional styles will be discussed later in this document, along with his piano solo pieces. His solo piano pieces are also listed in chronological order.
</p><p>Despite the fact that Boury is a well-established composer,<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;Note 1&#93;</a></sup> it appears that no written analyses of his piano works exist. His piano works indicate that Boury has absorbed a number of influences, for instance <a href="/wiki/J._S._Bach" class="mw-redirect" title="J. S. Bach">J. S. Bach</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chopin" class="mw-redirect" title="Chopin">Chopin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Debussy" class="mw-redirect" title="Debussy">Debussy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ross_Lee_Finney" title="Ross Lee Finney">Ross Lee Finney</a>. The variety of styles in Boury's piano pieces reveal music history itself in that they connect to the music of an earlier age, such as <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">Baroque</a> eras to <a href="/wiki/Romantic_music" title="Romantic music">Romantic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Contemporary_music" class="mw-redirect" title="Contemporary music">Contemporary</a> eras. This characteristic is crucial to the understanding and appreciation of Boury's style/compositions, and is in need of research and analysis for those who desire to explore Boury's piano works.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life">Life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Boury&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biographical_background">Biographical background</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Boury&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Biographical background">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Robert Wade Boury was born in <a href="/wiki/Wheeling,_West_Virginia" title="Wheeling, West Virginia">Wheeling, West Virginia</a>, in 1946. His father, Michael Boury, and uncles operated the <a href="/wiki/Big_Boy_Restaurants#Elbys" title="Big Boy Restaurants">Elby's restaurant chain</a>, Michael managing the commissary, while Boury's mother, Pearl Mickey, was a stay at home mother.<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> He describes his father as the master of "money and business"<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> and narrates that his father was always bringing home new food recipes to try out on Boury, mother, and sister. He remembers his mother as "a good pianist with wonderful touch in her piano playing".<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> However, she turned down a full scholarship to the <a href="/wiki/Cincinnati_Conservatory" class="mw-redirect" title="Cincinnati Conservatory">Cincinnati Conservatory</a> to get married.<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> Even though she chose to be a wife and mother, she kept playing the piano for Boury and his sister every day. He describes her sound as follows: "My mother had the most beautiful touch of anyone I've ever heard up close. She only taught me by example. I've been trying to recreate it ever since."<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Boury was influenced by his mother's beautiful piano playing and later began his piano study at age ten with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dorothy_Ackerman_Zoeckler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dorothy Ackerman Zoeckler (page does not exist)">Dorothy Ackerman Zoeckler</a>. She was a student of <a href="/wiki/Robert_Goldsand" title="Robert Goldsand">Robert Goldsand</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_School_of_Music" title="Manhattan School of Music">Manhattan School of Music</a>, who was also an author, a published composer, and a member of <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_National_League_of_American_Pen_Women&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The National League of American Pen Women (page does not exist)">The National League of American Pen Women</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;Note 2&#93;</a></sup> She recognized Boury's talent in music and encouraged him to explore not just music, but also <a href="/wiki/Poetry" title="Poetry">poetry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Art" title="Art">art</a>. Boury took piano lessons and composition lessons from Ackerman for seven years. He talks about memories of his early musical study with her: "...&#160;she had books on Art and Literature that we, her students could take home. I would go to her house every day after school and sight-read downstairs where parents and students waited for their lesson—hoping for a cancellation so I could have an extra lesson."<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<blockquote><p>She sensed that my brain was growing faster than my technique so she gave me a set of Rossini Overtures conducted on 78s by Arturo Toscanni ... I had no idea there was such beauty in the world. The music was poignant and funny, traits I would continue to cherish in music. I determined that day, not to become a performer of such music but rather to compose music like that.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Teachers_and_Influences">Teachers and Influences</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Boury&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Teachers and Influences">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 1964, Boury continued further music education at <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_School_of_Music" title="Manhattan School of Music">Manhattan School of Music</a> where he studied with <a href="/wiki/David_Diamond_(composer)" title="David Diamond (composer)">David Diamond</a> in the junior level composition class. Boury still remembers what Diamond said in the class: "...&#160;you can write anything you want, so long as it's a <a href="/wiki/Fugue" title="Fugue">fugue</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>David Diamond (born 1915 – died 2005) studied composition with <a href="/wiki/Bernard_Rogers" title="Bernard Rogers">Bernard Rogers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roger_Sessions" title="Roger Sessions">Roger Sessions</a>. He met <a href="/wiki/Maurice_Ravel" title="Maurice Ravel">Maurice Ravel</a> in 1928, and took Ravel's suggestion to study with <a href="/wiki/Nadia_Boulanger" title="Nadia Boulanger">Nadia Boulanger</a> who taught Diamond <a href="/wiki/Counterpoint" title="Counterpoint">counterpoint</a> predominantly. In 1937, Diamond had an opportunity to receive tutorial instruction from <a href="/wiki/Stravinsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Stravinsky">Stravinsky</a> in <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> Diamond's works are characterized as a complex polyphonic approach with strong rhythmic pattern and seemingly innate formal logic.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> Boury followed Diamond's instructions during his study with him and wrote a song cycle which contains three movements in fugal style. Diamond believed that counterpoint study would make music pour out of his students after that work was done.<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>When Boury was in his senior year at <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_School_of_Music" title="Manhattan School of Music">Manhattan School of Music</a>, he enrolled in private lessons with <a href="/wiki/Mario_Davidovsky" title="Mario Davidovsky">Mario Davidovsky</a>. Mario Davidovsky came originally from <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>, and immigrated to the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>. Davidovsky's composition study began at age thirteen under <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.guillermograetzer.com/">Guillermo Graetzer</a>, and later with <a href="/wiki/Aaron_Copland" title="Aaron Copland">Aaron Copland</a>, who was not interested in <a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">electronic music</a>. Despite Copland's preference to the contrary, Davidovsky continued composing electronic music.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> With <a href="/wiki/Milton_Babbitt" title="Milton Babbitt">Milton Babbitt</a>'s encouragement, Davidovsky specialized in live-electronic mixtures in which he explored the possibilities of dialogues between taped music and various performing forces, ranging from a single instrument to full orchestra and chorus.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup>  Boury respected Davidovsky musical style and him as a great pedagogue, as a result Boury took Davidovsky's advice to apply to the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Michigan" title="University of Michigan">University of Michigan</a> for graduate school.<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Born in <a href="/wiki/Minnesota" title="Minnesota">Minnesota</a> State, <a href="/wiki/Ross_Lee_Finney" title="Ross Lee Finney">Ross Lee Finney</a> (born 1906 – died 1997) was another teacher who also influenced Boury while he was at the University of Michigan. Finney was exposed to piano and cello at young age, and by age twelve he was performing in small communities in the Midwest.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> He studied with <a href="/wiki/Nadia_Boulanger" title="Nadia Boulanger">Nadia Boulanger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edward_Burlingame_Hill" title="Edward Burlingame Hill">Edward Burlingame Hill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alban_Berg" title="Alban Berg">Alban Berg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roger_Sessions" title="Roger Sessions">Roger Sessions</a>. His style has a wide range from Romantic style, twelve tone, American/Midwestern roots to complex serial techniques.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> In the fall of 1968, Boury enrolled in the School of Music at the University of Michigan for his graduate degree. He mentions that he was influenced a great deal by just being around Finney and his <a href="/wiki/Second_Viennese_School" title="Second Viennese School">Second Viennese School</a> works. The inspiration led Boury to compose an orchestra piece "Summer Music 1968", which amazed his Music Theory teacher, Richmond Browne, who asked Boury how he could know so much about Vienna in 1935.<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>While Boury was a graduate student at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Michigan" title="University of Michigan">University of Michigan</a>, he also received instruction from <a href="/wiki/Leslie_Bassett" title="Leslie Bassett">Leslie Bassett</a>, who studied with <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Honegger" title="Arthur Honegger">Arthur Honegger</a>, a member of <a href="/wiki/Les_Six" title="Les Six">Les Six</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;Note 3&#93;</a></sup> Bassett also studied <a href="/wiki/Roberto_Gerhard" class="mw-redirect" title="Roberto Gerhard">Roberto Gerhard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mario_Davidovsky" title="Mario Davidovsky">Mario Davidovsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ross_Lee_Finney" title="Ross Lee Finney">Ross Lee Finney</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nadia_Boulanger" title="Nadia Boulanger">Nadia Boulanger</a>. Many of Bassett's works are very short, ranging from two minutes to twenty-eight minutes.<sup id="cite_ref-Johnson_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Johnson-18">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> They are clearly constructed and convey a strong spiritual content. Bassett used conventional pitch materials within his unique manner.<sup id="cite_ref-Johnson_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Johnson-18">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bassett taught Composition Seminar and Private Composition courses at the graduate level at the University of Michigan. Boury describes the time studying with Bassett as follows: "...&#160;Mr. Bassett was and is a master orchestral thinker. My lessons with him were largely quiet affairs, him looking for about a half an hour at a page of 30 line full score, then saying, 'Aren't the trombones a little high?' Seemed like nothing was happening—yet I look at my own instrumental music and have to say, it looks like Bassett. Very clean, not many doublings..."<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bassett remembers Boury as "...&#160;a good man and an interesting composer, dedicated to music and working hard...."<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Musical_career">Musical career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Boury&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Musical career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Boury served as a teaching fellow at <a href="/wiki/University_of_Michigan" title="University of Michigan">University of Michigan</a> while he was pursuing his <a href="/wiki/Doctor_of_Musical_Arts" title="Doctor of Musical Arts">Doctor of Musical Arts</a> degree (D.M.A.). After Boury graduated from the University of Michigan he took a break from teaching and moved to Indianapolis. There, he worked in a sixteen track studio called "Tape Masters" as a jingle writer as well as a documentary film scores writer.<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> He later held a job at <a href="/wiki/Capitol_Records" title="Capitol Records">Capitol Records</a> in Los Angeles to produce lead sheets, song transcriptions before returning to his hometown in <a href="/wiki/Wheeling,_West_Virginia" title="Wheeling, West Virginia">Wheeling, West Virginia</a>, to open a piano/composition studio.<sup id="cite_ref-faculty_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-faculty-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1977, Boury moved to <a href="/wiki/Lansing,_Michigan" title="Lansing, Michigan">Lansing, Michigan</a>, after Lansing Community College invited him to create a new music program for an <a href="/wiki/Associate_degree" title="Associate degree">Associate degree</a>. This new degree program consisted of Pop Rock Bands, Pop Rock Voice, Pop Rock Keyboard and Pop Rock Guitar, Business in Music along with Boury's courses, three levels of Pop Rock Theory and Songwriting courses. This new degree program attracted nationwide attention and enhanced enrollment at Lansing Community College. Boury mentioned that the experience at Lansing Community College changed his life tremendously as well as the career opportunity that led him to be at the current position at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock.<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Boury joined <a href="/wiki/University_of_Arkansas" title="University of Arkansas">University of Arkansas</a> in 1981 as a resident composer and a professor of music theory and composition. He teaches courses such as; Analyses, Songwriting, as well as private sessions, which he enjoys. Boury also hosts a Songwriters Showcase for his students every semester. He believes that this event is a great opportunity for his students to present their works as composers. Students are asked to find other musicians to perform in the event rather than playing their own composition projects. When Boury was asked for the reason, he said that those students are all composers and should attend as a composer, not as a performer.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> Later when the author requested to know about his philosophy of teaching, Boury said, "A friend of mine challenged me to create a philosophy of Teaching in six words. Mine is, 'I'm a composer—so are you.'"<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Boury's devotion toward teaching and being a resident composer can be seen just by talking to him. Boury says that he loves to teach and explains, "The teaching philosophy is my message whether children, adults, hospital patients, university students bother general education students and music majors and minors...."<sup id="cite_ref-email_5-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-email-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Compositions">Compositions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Boury&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Compositions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Piano">Piano</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Boury&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Piano">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Boury comments that he was in love with his first instrument, piano by age thirteen. Although his piano solo works constitute a substantially few number within his overall output, his piano pieces illustrate an interesting diversity of style tendencies in his music.
</p>
<ul><li><b>WoO 1</b> <i>Sonata for Piano</i> (1965)</li>
<li><b>WoO 4</b> <i>Fantasy, Ostinato and Fugue for Piano</i> (1968)</li>
<li><b>Op. 1</b> <i><a href="/wiki/Blues,_Rags_and_Stomps_(Robert_Boury)" class="mw-redirect" title="Blues, Rags and Stomps (Robert Boury)">Blues, Rags and Stomps</a></i> (1970–1973), Book I &amp; II</li>
<li><b>Op. 2a</b> <i>Suite for Piano</i> (1974)</li>
<li><b>Op. 3</b> <i>Hats'n Horns</i> (1974)</li>
<li><b>Op. 4</b> <i>Two Beguines</i> (1975) for two pianos, four hands</li>
<li><b>Op. 10d</b> <i>Duelin' Pianos</i> (1973) for two pianos, four hands</li>
<li><b>Op. 15</b> <i>Beautiful Ohio</i> (1980)</li>
<li><b>Op. 19</b> <i>The Mice Will Play</i> (1981) for one piano, eight hands</li>
<li><b>Op. 20</b> <i>Portrait of Chopin</i> (1985)</li>
<li><b>Op. 53</b> <i>Sonatina</i> (2000)</li>
<li><b>Op. 60</b> <i>12 Secret Designs for Piano</i> (2006)</li>
<li><b>Op. 61</b> <i>Three Poetics</i> (2006)</li>
<li><b>Op. 62</b> <i>Cherokee Months</i> (2007)</li>
<li><b>Op. 63</b> <i>Three Lost Waltzes</i> (2008)</li>
<li><b>Op. 64</b> <i>From Dictionary of Angels</i> (2009)</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vocal">Vocal</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Boury&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Vocal">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li><b>WoO 2</b> <i>Four Songs on Death</i> (1966) for mezzo-soprano and piano</li>

<li><b>Op. 18</b> <i>Two Prayers</i> (1984) for voice</li>
<li><b>Op. 23</b> <i>Just Before Dawn</i> (1985) for voice, cello and piano, Song cycle</li>
<li><b>Op. 24</b> <i>Two Peace Songs</i> (1985) for voice and piano</li>
<li><b>Op. 25</b> <i>Spring Songs</i> (1985) for voice and piano/guitar</li>
<li><b>Op. 26</b> <i>Song of the Silver Pine</i> (1986) for voice and piano</li>
<li><b>Op. 26a</b> <i>Song of the Silver Pine</i> (1986) for voice, clarinet, strings and piano</li>
<li><b>Op. 27</b> <i>A Bowlful of Rhinos</i> (1985) for voice and piano, Song cycle</li>
<li><b>Op. 28</b> <i>Two Love Songs</i> (1985) for voice, flute, clarinet and piano</li>
<li><b>Op. 29</b> <i>The American Sublime</i> (1987) for voice and piano, Song cycle</li>
<li><b>Op. 30</b> <i>Sleeping in the Forest</i> (1987) for voice and piano, Song cycle</li>
<li><b>Op. 31</b> <i>The Region November</i> (1987) for voice and piano, Song cycle</li>
<li><b>Op. 32</b> <i>Carnations</i> (1988) for voice and piano, Song cycle</li>
<li><b>Op. 33 </b> <i>In the Midst of Winter</i> (1988) for voice and piano, Song cycle</li>

<li><b>Op. 40</b> <i>November by the Sea</i> (1991) for voice and piano, Song cycle</li>
<li><b>Op. 44</b> <i>Three Love Songs</i> (1996) for baritone and piano</li>
<li><b>Op. 46</b> <i>New Folk Songs</i> (1998) for soprano and piano/guitar, Collection of songs</li>
<li><b>Op. 47</b> <i>The Tree of Night</i> (1998) for voice and piano, Two songs</li>
<li><b>Op. 49</b> <i>Chinese Songs</i> (1998) for mezzo-soprano and piano, Three songs</li>
<li><b>Op. 50</b> <i>Three Wishes</i> (1999) for soprano and piano, Three songs</li>
<li><b>Op. 56</b> <i>To Dream Again</i> (2002) for soprano and piano, Song cycle</li>
<li><b>Op. 57</b> <i>Domination of Black</i> (2003) for mezzo-soprano and piano, Song cycle</li>
<li><b>Op. 58</b> <i>Of History and Hope</i> (2004) for mezzo-soprano, choir and piano, Song cycle</li>
<li><b>Op. 59</b> <i>Nativity Songs</i> (2009) for soprano and piano, Song cycle</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Choral">Choral</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Boury&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Choral">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Electroacoustic">Electroacoustic</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Boury&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Electroacoustic">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li><b>WoO 8</b> <i>Honk for Piano and Tape</i> (1970)</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Boury&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Notes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In 1971, Boury was awarded the Joseph H. Bearnes Prize from Columbia University for his orchestral work, <i>Grilli</i>, which was performed at the Pan-American Festival of Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-faculty_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-faculty-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The National League of American Pen Women is made up of women who have demonstrated creative talents in art, letters, and music composition.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-17">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">French group of composers: Auric, Durey, Honegger, Milhaud, Poulenc and Tailleferre. Their music is often seen as a reaction against the musical style of Richard Wagner and impressionist music.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<p><b>Karen Boustany</b> (born June 4), known professionally as <b>Karen R. Boustany</b>, is a Lebanese international Media Personality, Author, Businesswoman, Director &amp; Producer.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life">Life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Karen_Boustany&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Born in <a href="/wiki/Ain_El_Rihane" class="mw-redirect" title="Ain El Rihane">Ain El Rihane</a>, a village in <a href="/wiki/Mount_Lebanon" title="Mount Lebanon">Mount Lebanon</a>, Karen Boustany studied at <a href="/wiki/St_Joseph_%E2%80%93_Antoura_College" class="mw-redirect" title="St Joseph – Antoura College">St Joseph – Antoura College</a> where she started writing poetry at a very early age. She consecrated all her free time to writing, She traveled to Paris where she attained her BA in French Literature from <a href="/w/index.php?title=La_Sorbonne_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="La Sorbonne University (page does not exist)">La Sorbonne University</a>, Paris. She graduated also from the <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_American_University" title="Lebanese American University">Lebanese American University</a> in Byblos (LAU), specialising in a double major: Communication Arts and Political Sciences. Having acquired 12 years of experience in advertising, she established in 2005 her own advertising and marketing company “Eyestrategy Business Communication sarl”, conciliating literature, know-how and Creativity. For two consecutive years, she had her own socio-political column, ”Poing à la ligne”, in <i>Al Balad</i>newspaper in its French publication.
</p><p>In April 2009 and with the reopening of the Lebanese TV channel <a href="/wiki/MTV_(Lebanon)" title="MTV (Lebanon)">MTV (Lebanon)</a>, Karen prepared and animated a daily live cultural show: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kitab_(TV_programme)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kitab (TV programme) (page does not exist)">Kitab</a>. She presented and analysed new books releases, best sellers, interviewed Lebanese and international authors<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> in the studio or through Skype. she is the first <a href="/wiki/TV_presenter" class="mw-redirect" title="TV presenter">TV presenter</a> to use this technology in a cultural show. She has received more than 1800 writers from which 250 international writers such as the great Lebanese French writer <a href="/wiki/Amin_Maalouf" title="Amin Maalouf">Amin Maalouf</a> as well as the best-selling writer in the world <a href="/wiki/Marc_Levy" title="Marc Levy">Marc Levy</a> and others.
From 2010 until 2013, Karen covered the Salon du Livre Francophone in Beirut hosting more than 80 writers each year in less than ten days. On May 16, 2012 Karen Boustany started a new show, "écrire l'Histoire", in which she hosted famous international personalities of the 21st century. International writers like Marc Levy, <a href="/wiki/Eric-Emmanuel_Schmitt" class="mw-redirect" title="Eric-Emmanuel Schmitt">Eric-Emmanuel Schmitt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Venus_Khoury-Ghata" class="mw-redirect" title="Venus Khoury-Ghata">Venus Khoury-Ghata</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amin_Maalouf" title="Amin Maalouf">Amin Maalouf</a>. On April 6, 2013 she started <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ecrire_l%27Histoire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ecrire l&#39;Histoire (page does not exist)">Ecrire l'Histoire</a> Season 2 from Detroit, Los Angeles and Hollywood with personalities from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lebanese_Origins&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lebanese Origins (page does not exist)">Lebanese Origins</a>. Film makers, film directors and film producers, as well as music compositors, writers, politicians and CEOs are interviewed in the USA and Paris such as Mr. <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Ghosn" title="Carlos Ghosn">Carlos Ghosn</a>, CEO of Nissan and Renault worldwide and Dr Charles El Achi,<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> Director of JPL Nasa in LA.
</p><p>In February 2014, she started a new TV series on LBCI Asmaa Min al Tarikh that she produces and presents, and in which
she hosted very famous Brazilian personalities from Lebanese descent such as President
of Brazil HE Michel Temer. Since, it has become a trade mark worldwide.
In 2015, she traveled to UAE and film more than 15 episodes with outstanding Lebanese
success stories in Dubai, Abu Dhabi and Sharjah.
In October 2016, she traveled to Australia and film more than 12 interviews with
prominent Lebanese politicians and businessmen such as Former Premiere of Victoria
HE Steve Brax.
In February 2017, she traveled to South Africa and film more than 35 interviews with
prominent Lebanese politicians and businessmen in Africa during the Lebanese
Diaspora Energy.
Since 2014, Karen is a founding member of the Lebanese Energy Diaspora Conference
organised by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Immigration. This conference takes
place in Beirut each year in May or June and features more than 5000 Lebanese
successful expats.
In May 2017 she was the master of Ceremony of the Lebanese Diaspora Energy
Conference in Beirut in the presence of HE President Michel Aoun and the Prime
Minister Saad Hariri as well as all Lebanese ministers, deputies, ambassadors and
5000 VIP Lebanese expats. A great event that was covered live by all Lebanese
channels.
In September 2018, Karen Boustany filmed her 8th season of Asmaa Min Al Tarikh in Las
Vegas and San Francisco with pioneers in the ICT field.
In November 2018, she represented Lebanon amongst 35 countries in Madrid <sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> during 'Les Jeunes Du Monde Unis" Forum where she was a guest of honor and moderator.
In June 2019, Karen Boustany represented Lebanon amongst 42 countries in The International Business Forum Portugal <sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> as a speaker talking about sustainable business and women entrepreneurship. She was rewarded for her successful career.
on July 6, 2019, Karen Boustany was appointed CEO of The Luxury Network in Lebanon.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Books">Books</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Karen_Boustany&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Books">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<table class="box-BLP_unsourced_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-BLP_unsourced" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section of a <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Biographies_of_living_persons" title="Wikipedia:Biographies of living persons">biography of a living person</a> <b>does not <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">include</a> any <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">references or sources</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help by adding <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources">reliable sources</a>. Contentious material about living people that is unsourced or poorly sourced <b>must be removed immediately</b>.<br /><small><span class="plainlinks"><i>Find sources:</i>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?as_eq=wikipedia&amp;q=%22Karen+Boustany%22">"Karen Boustany"</a>&#160;–&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbm=nws&amp;q=%22Karen+Boustany%22+-wikipedia">news</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?&amp;q=%22Karen+Boustany%22+site:news.google.com/newspapers&amp;source=newspapers">newspapers</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbs=bks:1&amp;q=%22Karen+Boustany%22+-wikipedia">books</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22Karen+Boustany%22">scholar</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/action/doBasicSearch?Query=%22Karen+Boustany%22&amp;acc=on&amp;wc=on">JSTOR</a></span></small></span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">May 2019</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Karen has published two books: a poetry book &quot;Au-delà de la Faute&quot; published in
December 2007 and &quot;Mon père le Roi du monde&quot;, an homage to her father Raymond
published in November 2012.
She is preparing her third book which will be full of true stories and another one about
her mother who passed away recently.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Founding_of_Als_Lebanon">Founding of Als Lebanon</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Karen_Boustany&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Founding of Als Lebanon">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In June 2015, she co-founded and presides the Lebanese ALS association, first ALS
Association in the Arab World. the LALS takes care of ALS patients in Lebanon medically,
financially, psychologically and socially. Karen organised many activities in Lebanon and Dubai for fundraising and to spread awareness. With  the support of Notre Dame University NDU she produces a movie about Dr Jamil Zogheib founder of the LALS, paediatrician and ALS patient who wrote 10 books with his eyes.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Karen_Boustany&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Awards">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>Asmaa Min Al Tarikh Best TV Show for 2016-2017 by the Beirut Golden Awards.</li>
<li>Best media Personality Lebanon 2017<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Media Ambassador to the Lebanese Diaspora - Ministry of Tourism</li>
<li>Award for her achievements with the Lebanese Diaspora - Ministry of Foreign Affairs</li></ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Karen_Boustany&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<table role="presentation" class="mbox-small plainlinks sistersitebox" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000">

<table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;font-size: 100%;"><div style="display:inline-block; font-size:130%;" class="fn">Stuart Bowen</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Stuart_Bowen.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Stuart Bowen.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/47/Stuart_Bowen.jpg" decoding="async" width="130" height="196" data-file-width="130" data-file-height="196" /></a></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:lavender;line-height:normal;padding:0.2em 0.2em"><a href="/wiki/Special_Inspector_General_for_Iraq_Reconstruction" title="Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction">Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction</a></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;border-bottom:none"><span class="nowrap"><b>In office</b></span><br />January 20, 2004&#160;–&#32;October 2013</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="text-align:left">President</th><td><a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. </td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:lavender">Personal details</th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><span style="display:none"> (<span class="bday">1958-03-24</span>) </span>March 24, 1958<span class="noprint ForceAgeToShow"> (age&#160;62)</span><br /><a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, U.S.</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Education</th><td><a href="/wiki/Sewanee:_The_University_of_the_South" title="Sewanee: The University of the South">University of the South</a> (<a href="/wiki/Bachelor_of_Arts" title="Bachelor of Arts">BA</a>)<br /><a href="/wiki/Vanderbilt_University" title="Vanderbilt University">Vanderbilt University</a><br /><a href="/wiki/St._Mary%27s_University,_Texas" title="St. Mary&#39;s University, Texas">St. Mary's University, Texas</a> (<a href="/wiki/Juris_Doctor" title="Juris Doctor">JD</a>)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Stuart W. Bowen Jr.</b> (born March 24, 1958), is an <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">American</a> lawyer who served as the <a href="/wiki/Special_Inspector_General_for_Iraq_Reconstruction" title="Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction">Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction</a> (SIGIR) from October 2004 to October 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> He previously served as the Inspector General for the <a href="/wiki/Coalition_Provisional_Authority" title="Coalition Provisional Authority">Coalition Provisional Authority</a> (CPA-IG), a position to which he was appointed in January 2004. Mr. Bowen's mission includes ensuring effective oversight of the $63 billion appropriated for <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>'s relief and reconstruction.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Texas_Health_and_Human_Services_Commission_Inspector_General"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Texas Health and Human Services Commission Inspector General</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Stuart_Bowen&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Background">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Born in <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, on March 24, 1958, Mr. Bowen attended the Episcopal High School in Alexandria, Virginia, earned a <a href="/wiki/Bachelor_of_Arts" title="Bachelor of Arts">B.A.</a> from the <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_South" class="mw-redirect" title="University of the South">University of the South</a>/Sewanee, attended <a href="/wiki/Vanderbilt_University_Law_School" title="Vanderbilt University Law School">Vanderbilt University Law School</a>, and received a <a href="/wiki/Juris_Doctor" title="Juris Doctor">J.D.</a> from <a href="/wiki/St._Mary%27s_University_School_of_Law" title="St. Mary&#39;s University School of Law">St. Mary's University School of Law</a> in San Antonio, where he served on the Law Journal's Editorial Board. He spent four years on active duty as an intelligence officer in the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Air_Force" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Air Force">U.S. Air Force</a>, earning the rank of <a href="/wiki/Captain_(United_States)" title="Captain (United States)">Captain</a> and the Air Force Commendation Medal.  From 1991 to 1992, Mr. Bowen was Briefing Attorney to Texas Supreme Court Justice <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raul_Gonzalez_(judge)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raul Gonzalez (judge) (page does not exist)">Raul Gonzalez</a>; and from 1992 to 1994, he was an Assistant Attorney General of Texas, with a litigation practice focused on the  civil prosecution of state licensee regulatory violations and appellate work in state and federal court.
</p><p>From 1994 to 2000, Mr. Bowen held a variety of positions on Texas Governor <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a>'s staff, including Deputy General Counsel, Deputy General Counsel for Litigation, and Assistant General Counsel. He was part of President Bush's legal team handling the post-election litigation in Florida during November–December 2000; his work helped ensure that overseas military ballots were properly counted. Mr. Bowen subsequently served as Counsel to the Bush-<a href="/wiki/Dick_Cheney" title="Dick Cheney">Cheney</a> transition team.
</p><p>From 2001 to 2003, Mr. Bowen served President Bush as Deputy Assistant to the President and Deputy Staff Secretary and Special Assistant to the President and Associate Counsel.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2007)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> In 2003, he became a partner at the law firm of Patton Boggs LLP, working out of its <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> office.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Special_Inspector_General_for_Iraq_Reconstruction">Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Stuart_Bowen&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>As <i>Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction</i>, Mr. Bowen is tasked with auditing and investigating the use of taxpayer funds appropriated for the Iraq reconstruction effort.  Since 2004, he has managed the production of 390 audits and inspections, producing financial benefits in excess of $1.5 billion; his investigations have yielded over 83 convictions, with recoveries in excess of $192 million via forfeiture orders, fines, and seizures.
</p><p>Mr. Bowen has supervised the production of 35 quarterly reports to the Congress, travelled to Iraq 34 times, and testified before the Congress on 35 occasions.  He managed the compilation of seven lessons learned reports, including HARD LESSONS (Government Printing Office February 2009), a  book-length report on the entire Iraq reconstruction enterprise, which provides 13 recommendations for improving the US approach to overseas stabilization and reconstruction operations. All of these reports are available at www.sigir.mil.
</p><p>Mr. Bowen's work has earned a number of awards, including: The David Walker Excellence in Government Award for Performance and Accountability from the National Intergovernmental Audit Forum; Outstanding Inspector General's Report to Congress from the Council of Inspectors General for Integrity and Efficiency (CIGIE);Outstanding Investigative Task Force Award (CIGIE); Outstanding Inspection Report Award (CIGIE); Outstanding Investigative Case Accomplishment Award (CIGIE); Outstanding Audit Team Award from the President’s Council on Integrity and Efficiency (PCIE); Outstanding Inspection Team Award (PCIE); Gaston Gianni Special Award for Outstanding Inspector General’s Office (PCIE); Newsmaker of the Year Award from the Engineering News-Record; St. Thomas More Award for Distinguished Public Service from The St. Mary’s University School of Law/San Antonio; and a Best and Brightest Award from Esquire Magazine. Because of the nature of its subject matter, Mr. Bowen's work has required media engagement, including appearances on CSPAN, NPR, PBS, CNN, CBS, NBC, ABC, FOX, CNBC, and BBC, as well as numerous interviews with international and local print journalists. Mr. Bowen's writings have appeared in a variety of  publications including <a href="/wiki/The_Fletcher_Forum_of_World_Affairs" title="The Fletcher Forum of World Affairs">The Fletcher Forum of World Affairs</a>, National Defense University's Prism Quarterly, The Journal of International Peace Operations, and books published by King's College London and The National Defense University.
</p><p>The SIGIR mission in Baghdad has not been without tragedy.  On March 24, 2008, a rocket impacted the Embassy grounds killing Paul Converse, a SIGIR auditor.  Paul was posthumously awarded the Jefferson Star by the State Department, its highest honor.  Five other SIGIR staff members have been wounded while serving in Iraq.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Texas_Health_and_Human_Services_Commission_Inspector_General">Texas Health and Human Services Commission Inspector General</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Stuart_Bowen&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Texas Health and Human Services Commission Inspector General">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In January 2015, Texas Governor <a href="/wiki/Greg_Abbott" title="Greg Abbott">Greg Abbott</a> named Bowen as the Inspector General for the <a href="/wiki/Texas_Health_and_Human_Services_Commission" title="Texas Health and Human Services Commission">Texas Health and Human Services Commission</a>.  The appointment is subject to Senate confirmation.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Brought in as an outsider to clean up a contracting scandal, Bowen also had to contend with hundreds of millions of questionable fraud allegations made by his predecessor.  By September he had settled cases totaling $9 million.  In addition, Bowen faced repairing ties with the Medicaid provider community and with HHSC.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup>   As Inspector General, Bowen is charged with preventing, detecting, and deterring fraud, waste, and abuse in the Texas Health and Human Services System. 
<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On October 22, 2015, Bowen accused Planned Parenthood of misconduct and informed them all of the state's Planned Parenthood affiliates were being dropped as a Medicaid health care provider.  He cited videos showing misconduct and sent investigators with letters to Planned Parenthood offices in San Antonio, Dallas, and the Houston area, requesting records.   His letters cited the authority of Health and Human Services Commission to investigate allegations of potential fraud involving Medicaid payments.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bowen was forced to resign by Gov. Greg Abbott on May 10, 2017, after the governor discovered Bowen had been moonlighting for <a href="/wiki/Brownstein_Hyatt_Farber_Schreck" title="Brownstein Hyatt Farber Schreck">Hyatt Farber Schreck</a>, a lobbying firm that represents the Iraqi government.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
Bowen said he had consulted with a state ethics advisor and was told that his moonlighting "fully complied" with the health commission's policy.  However, the health agency's policies explicitly bar employees from having an "economic or monetary interest in a lobbying firm".<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
<cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150904024424/https://www.hhsc.state.tx.us/news/presentations/2015/oig-review.pdf">"Office of Inspector General"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. Texas Health and Human Services. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2015-10-24</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Office+of+Inspector+General&amp;rft.pub=Texas+Health+and+Human+Services&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.hhsc.state.tx.us%2Fnews%2Fpresentations%2F2015%2Foig-review.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AStuart+Bowen" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Pierrick Boyer</div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><span style="display:none"> (<span class="bday">1974-07-22</span>) </span>July 22, 1974<span class="noprint ForceAgeToShow"> (age&#160;46)</span><br /><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace"><a href="/wiki/Valognes" title="Valognes">Valognes</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Nationality</th><td class="category"><a href="/wiki/France" title="France">French</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Occupation</th><td class="role"><a href="/wiki/Pastry_chef" title="Pastry chef">Pastry chef</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Pierrick Boyer</b> (born 22 July 1974 in <a href="/wiki/Valognes" title="Valognes">Valognes</a>) is a <a href="/wiki/French_people" title="French people">French</a> <a href="/wiki/Pastry_chef" title="Pastry chef">pastry chef</a>. He moved to <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a> in 2003 and was appointed Pastry Chef at <a href="/wiki/Royal_Automobile_Club_of_Victoria" title="Royal Automobile Club of Victoria">RACV</a> new landmark headquarters, the RACV City Club at 501 Bourke St in <a href="/wiki/Melbourne" title="Melbourne">Melbourne</a> in August 2004. This subsequently led to the opening of Le Petit Gateau Patisserie in July 2007 and a decade later, he left this high achievement position and successfully opened his first self-titled eatery in May 2018 at 31 Izett Street in <a href="/wiki/Prahran" class="mw-redirect" title="Prahran">Prahran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Victoria_(Australia)" title="Victoria (Australia)">Victoria</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Charity_work"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Charity work</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pierrick_Boyer&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>He has experience of over 27 years in <a href="/wiki/Hospitality" title="Hospitality">hospitality</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dining" class="mw-redirect" title="Dining">dining</a>. He has worked alongside some of the world renowned <a href="/wiki/Chef" title="Chef">chefs</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Alain_Ducasse" title="Alain Ducasse">Alain Ducasse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christophe_Michalak" title="Christophe Michalak">Christophe Michalak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Marcolini" title="Pierre Marcolini">Pierre Marcolini</a> and Stephane Leroux. In 1997, Pierrick was headhunted from a French <a href="/wiki/Patisserie" class="mw-redirect" title="Patisserie">patisserie</a> in Palm Springs to establish the business, manage and deliver the most <a href="/wiki/Dessert" title="Dessert">dessert</a> creations for the market. Boyer joined the <a href="/wiki/Ritz_Carlton" class="mw-redirect" title="Ritz Carlton">Ritz Carlton</a> in <a href="/wiki/Boston" title="Boston">Boston</a>, in 2002 as second in charge of the Pastry Department. Before joining the RACV City Club in Melbourne, Boyer worked for 14 months at the <a href="/wiki/Plaza_Athenee" class="mw-redirect" title="Plaza Athenee">Plaza Athenee</a> in <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a> as <a href="/wiki/Sous_chef" class="mw-redirect" title="Sous chef">Sous Pastry Chef</a>, under Christophe Michalak.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> His latest appearance was at the Cake Bake &amp; Sweets Show 2015 in <a href="/wiki/Sydney" title="Sydney">Sydney</a> and <a href="/wiki/Melbourne" title="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> Pierrick appeared at Regional Tastes Festival at <a href="/wiki/Eynesbury,_Victoria" title="Eynesbury, Victoria">Eynesbury</a> in 2016.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pierrick_Boyer&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Awards">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Boyer has received many awards and recognition through his career. In 1996, Pierrick won the honorary award for the most creative sugar work in well renowned South Western Regional Pastry Chef competition. In 2002, he was awarded by the Palm Springs' Les Dames Escofier for the most original dessert, chocolate and <a href="/wiki/Passion_fruit" class="mw-redirect" title="Passion fruit">passion</a> cake, it was the first hit of his renowned <a href="/wiki/Chocolate_brownie" title="Chocolate brownie">Brownie</a> Passion Chocolate Gateau, since then, he has improved the recipe and has been voted by The Foodies Guide in Melbourne as amazing from 2007 to 2009. In 2006, Boyer was awarded 2 Gold and 1 Silver medal at the Fine Food Show in Melbourne and 1 Gold medal at the Perth Food Show.
</p><p>In 2010-2011, Boyer's creation, the <a href="/wiki/Peanut" title="Peanut">Peanut</a> Chocolate <a href="/wiki/Mousse" title="Mousse">Mousse</a> and Raspberry Jam Crunchy <a href="/wiki/Gateau" class="mw-redirect" title="Gateau">Gateau</a> won the Best Cake. In 2017, he was awarded the Gault &amp; Millau Pastry Chef of the Year award.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Charity_work">Charity work</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pierrick_Boyer&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Charity work">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Boyer supports various charity projects. He is an ambassador of <a href="/wiki/Royal_Society_for_the_Prevention_of_Cruelty_to_Animals" title="Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals">RSPCA</a> Victoria.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> He was featured in the inaugural Asia In <a href="/wiki/South_Australia" title="South Australia">South Australia</a> 2015 Charity Dinner<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Sakai" title="Sakai">Sakai</a> in Ginza Miyako Charity Dinner.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

</li>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Inside South Australia <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://insidesouthaustralia.com.au/iron-chef-french-to-cook-south-australian-seafood-feast-for-guests-in-adelaide/">"Iron Chef French to cook South Australian seafood feast for guests in Adelaide"</a>. ~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">February 2010</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Brandchannel</b> is a website about <a href="/wiki/Brand" title="Brand">branding</a> that launched in 2001 with the goal of offering a global perspective on brands.<sup id="cite_ref-about_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-about-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> Brandchannel offers a platform that features a dynamic newsfeed, articles, global conference listings, industry debates, a directory of agencies, and other branding resources. The website is produced by <a href="/wiki/Interbrand" title="Interbrand">Interbrand</a>, but maintains <a href="/wiki/Editorial_independence" title="Editorial independence">editorial independence</a>. Brandchannel is based in New York City.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brandchannel&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">Svend Brinkmann</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Svend_Brinkmann.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Svend Brinkmann.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Svend_Brinkmann.jpg/220px-Svend_Brinkmann.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Svend_Brinkmann.jpg/330px-Svend_Brinkmann.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Svend_Brinkmann.jpg/440px-Svend_Brinkmann.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1000" /></a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><span style="display:none"> (<span class="bday">1975-12-23</span>) </span>December 23, 1975<span class="noprint ForceAgeToShow"> (age&#160;44)</span><br /><div style="display:inline" class="birthplace">Herning, Denmark</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Nationality</th><td class="category"><a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Danish</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Citizenship</th><td class="category"><a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Education</th><td>PhD in psychology, 2006, Aarhus University</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Alma&#160;mater</th><td>Aarhus University</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Known&#160;for</th><td>Orcid: <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://orcid.org/0000-0001-7579-1212">http://orcid.org/0000-0001-7579-1212</a></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><b>Scientific career</b></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Fields</th><td class="category">Psychology, philosophical psychology, moral psychology, ethics and cultural critique</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Institutions</th><td>Aalborg University, Aalborg, Denmark</td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Svend Brinkmann</b> is a <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Danish</a> <a href="/wiki/Professor" title="Professor">Professor</a> of Psychology in the Department of Communication and Psychology at <a href="/wiki/Aalborg_University" title="Aalborg University">Aalborg University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a>. He serves as a co-director of the Center for Qualitative Studies. His research is particularly concerned with <a href="/wiki/Philosophy" title="Philosophy">philosophical</a>, <a href="/wiki/Morality" title="Morality">moral</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Methodology" title="Methodology">methodological</a> issues in <a href="/wiki/Psychology" title="Psychology">psychology</a> and other human and social sciences. In recent years, Svend Brinkmann has been studying the impact of psychiatric diagnoses on individuals and society.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-google1_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google1-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Education"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Education</span></a></li>
