<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Svend_Brinkmann&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Svend Brinkmann received his BA in philosophy in 1999 from <a href="/wiki/Aarhus_University" title="Aarhus University">Aarhus University</a>. In 2000, he received his BSc in psychology. In 2002, Svend Brinkmann graduated as an MSc in psychology, and in 2006 he was awarded a PhD degree in psychology from Aarhus University.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Past_and_current_positions">Past and current positions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Svend_Brinkmann&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Past and current positions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<table class="box-Cleanup_rewrite plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg" class="image"><img alt="Crystal Clear app kedit.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg/40px-Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg/60px-Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg/80px-Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="128" data-file-height="128" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article may need to be <b>rewritten</b> to comply with Wikipedia's <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style">quality standards</a>, as section.<span class="hide-when-compact"> <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Svend_Brinkmann&amp;action=edit">You can help</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Talk:Svend_Brinkmann" title="Talk:Svend Brinkmann">talk page</a> may contain suggestions.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">September 2016</span>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>From 2006 to 2009, Svend Brinkmann was employed as an assistant professor in social and personality psychology at the Department of Psychology and Behavioral Science at <a href="/wiki/Aarhus_University" title="Aarhus University">Aarhus University</a>. Following his tenure at Aarhus University, Svend Brinkmann became a Professor with specific responsibilities at the Department of Communication and Psychology at <a href="/wiki/Aalborg_University" title="Aalborg University">Aalborg University</a>. In 2010 he was appointed professor in general psychology and qualitative methods, which is his current position.<sup id="cite_ref-blaabog1_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-blaabog1-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During his career, Svend Brinkmann has been a visiting professor at the New School for Social Research, New York, King's College, London, and Universita Cattolica, Milan, Italy. In addition to his position at Aalborg University, Svend Brinkmann works as a book reviewer (2012-) and columnist (2015-) at the Danish newspaper Politiken.<sup id="cite_ref-blaabog1_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-blaabog1-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> Svend Brinkmann was involved in the Danish radio programme "Netværket på P1" from 2009-2016 and as a TV presenter in the Danish television show "Lev Stærkt" on DRK in 2014.
</p><p>Svend Brinkmann has been a member of the forum “Advancing sociocultural psychology in Europe” since 2008. In 2015, Svend Brinkmann received two Danish communication awards, the Rosenkjær prize and Gyldendal's communication prize.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> Gyldendal's communication prize was shared with his colleague Lene Tanggaard, and was awarded for their many publications from Hans Reitzel Publishers.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> In 2016 Svend Brinkmann was awarded the Hadsten Højskole Prize 2016.[8]
During his career as a professor, Svend Brinkmann has acted the supervisor of nine different PhD theses.
</p><p>Svend Brinkmann has written or edited more than 25 books and more than 150 scientific articles and book chapters in seven different languages.<sup id="cite_ref-google1_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google1-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Books">Books</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Svend_Brinkmann&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Books">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Svend Brinkmann has been author or co-author on several books, many of which have been translated into English. A list of his books is presented below:
</p>

<p><b>British International School of Chicago, Lincoln Park</b> (BISC Lincoln Park) is a private international school for Pre Nursery to Year 6 students (ages 2 to 11) located in the <a href="/wiki/Clybourn_Corridor" title="Clybourn Corridor">Clybourn Corridor</a> of <a href="/wiki/Cook_County,_Illinois" title="Cook County, Illinois">Cook County</a>, Illinois.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> In September 2001, BISC Lincoln Park was the fourth school to open in the United States by the <a href="/wiki/British_Schools_of_America" title="British Schools of America">British Schools of America</a> and first campus to open in the Midwest. BISC Lincoln Park is now operated by <a href="/wiki/Nord_Anglia_Education" title="Nord Anglia Education">Nord Anglia Education</a> and is part of a network of 66 schools located in 29 countries around the world, with more than 64,000 students. Nord Anglia has more than 13,000 teachers and support staff globally and have a total capacity of more than 93,400 school places. The private elementary school is divided into three learning stages: <a href="/wiki/Early_Years_Foundation_Stage" title="Early Years Foundation Stage">Early Years Foundation Stage</a> (pre nursery, nursery school and Pre-K, ages 2 to 5), <a href="/wiki/Key_Stage_1" title="Key Stage 1">Key Stage 1</a> (primary school, ages 5 to 7), and <a href="/wiki/Key_Stage_2" title="Key Stage 2">Key Stage 2</a> (primary school, ages 7 to 11).
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>British International School of Chicago, Lincoln Park (originally British School of Chicago) opened its door in the <a href="/wiki/Edgewater,_Chicago" title="Edgewater, Chicago">Edgewater</a> community area on the north side of the city in 2001 nearby the <a href="/wiki/Manor_House_(Chicago)" title="Manor House (Chicago)">Manor House</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bryn_Mawr_Historic_District" title="Bryn Mawr Historic District">Bryn Mawr Historic District</a> for parents seeking an alternative to the public school model.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> In 2008, the school relocated to a newly constructed building in the <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Park" title="Lincoln Park">Lincoln Park</a> neighborhood designed by a firm from award-winning architect <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160412161516/http://www.buildordie.com/people/joseph-valerio/">Joseph Valerio</a>. Appointed in January 2015, Principal Mel Curtis moved from the Ecole des Roches in France<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> and took over the leadership role at the Lincoln Park campus from founding headmaster Mike Horton (2001 to 2014) who now leads the South Loop campus.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> In her new role, Curtis (2015 to 2017) led a series of renovations that took place over the summer of 2015,<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> followed by a ribbon cutting ceremony attended by <a href="/wiki/Jesse_White_(politician)" title="Jesse White (politician)">Jesse White</a><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> and a sidewalk mural commissioned by the school designed by local Chicago artist, Nancy Pochis Bank.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> During March 2017, Nord Anglia Education CEO Andrew Fitzmaurice announced that Head of Primary at British School of Guangzhou Ed Pearce (2017 - ) would be succeeding Principal Curtis in August, marking the third time someone has assumed this role in the school's history.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Campus">Campus</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Campus">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BISC_Lincoln_Park_Campus_Exterior.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/BISC_Lincoln_Park_Campus_Exterior.png/220px-BISC_Lincoln_Park_Campus_Exterior.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/BISC_Lincoln_Park_Campus_Exterior.png/330px-BISC_Lincoln_Park_Campus_Exterior.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c3/BISC_Lincoln_Park_Campus_Exterior.png 2x" data-file-width="340" data-file-height="226" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BISC_Lincoln_Park_Campus_Exterior.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The five-story, 75,000 square foot British International School of Chicago, Lincoln Park campus</div></div></div>
<p>The 75,000 square foot, five-story campus<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> for British International School of Chicago, Lincoln Park was designed for an enrollment of up to 650 students and a 70-person staff.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> The campus features an architectural framework of columns and beams, a curving exterior, prominently placed bay windows, and high-ceiling gym on the upper floors. The building features more than 40 learning spaces, including an indoor and outdoor physical development space, robotics and science labs, a maker space, dance studio, library, a STEAM corridor meant to bridge different areas of learning,<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> and roof deck with views of the downtown Chicago skyline. It is located in the 60642 area code and part of the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/about/wards/27.html">27th Ward</a> represented by Alderman <a href="/wiki/Walter_Burnett,_Jr." class="mw-redirect" title="Walter Burnett, Jr.">Walter Burnett, Jr</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Students">Students</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Students">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>British International School of Chicago, Lincoln Park serves Pre Nursery through Year 6 students ages 2 to 11. The majority of pupils are Americans but with many dual nationals and heritages, has over 40 nationalities in the school who help populate Chicago's large foreign-born population.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> BISC Lincoln Park students follow Nord Anglia's "Be Ambitious" philosophy to develop intellectual, cultural, and emotional skills.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> As learners at a Nord Anglia Education international school, students have access to the Juilliard-Nord Anglia Performing Arts Program and the Global Campus.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> In addition, students often take field trips off campus to nearby Lincoln park destinations such as the <a href="/wiki/Chicago_History_Museum" title="Chicago History Museum">Chicago History Museum</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Second_City" title="The Second City">The Second City Theater</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Park_Zoo" title="Lincoln Park Zoo">Lincoln Park Zoo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_beaches_in_Chicago" title="List of beaches in Chicago">North Avenue Beach</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_and_recognition">Awards and recognition</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Awards and recognition">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Curriculum">Curriculum</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Curriculum">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BISC_Lincoln_Park_3D_Printer.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/BISC_Lincoln_Park_3D_Printer.jpg/220px-BISC_Lincoln_Park_3D_Printer.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/BISC_Lincoln_Park_3D_Printer.jpg/330px-BISC_Lincoln_Park_3D_Printer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/BISC_Lincoln_Park_3D_Printer.jpg/440px-BISC_Lincoln_Park_3D_Printer.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7360" data-file-height="4912" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BISC_Lincoln_Park_3D_Printer.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>BISC Lincoln Park students participate in school's STEAM program: Science, Technology &amp; Design, Engineering, Arts, and Math.</div></div></div>
<p>British International School of Chicago, Lincoln Park bases its values-based, global education learning goals on the International Primary Curriculum (IPC)<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Curriculum_(England,_Wales_and_Northern_Ireland)" class="mw-redirect" title="National Curriculum (England, Wales and Northern Ireland)">National Curriculum</a>. The school teaches art, entrepreneurship and innovation, information and computing technology, literacy, math, modern foreign languages, music, physical and health education, and science.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> In particular, the Chicago school emphasizes the benefits of a <a href="/wiki/STEAM_fields" title="STEAM fields">STEAM</a> program,<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> collaborates with the <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology" title="Massachusetts Institute of Technology">Massachusetts Institute of Technology</a> (MIT) to implement a STEAM program based on a multi-disciplinary approach pioneered by MIT,<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> is part of the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.juilliard.edu/nordanglia">Juilliard-Nord Anglia Performing Arts Program</a>, operates its own music school, and participates in the <a href="/wiki/Nord_Anglia_Education" title="Nord Anglia Education">Nord Anglia Education</a> Global Campus program.
</p>
<h2><span id="Sports.2C_Clubs.2C_and_Traditions"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports,_Clubs,_and_Traditions">Sports, Clubs, and Traditions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Sports, Clubs, and Traditions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Sports">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3><p>
British International School of Chicago, Lincoln Park offers competitive team sports in soccer, basketball, track and field and club sports in cricket, rugby, golf, tennis, and skiing. The teams are referred to as the BISC Lincoln Park Bulldogs. The school's mascot is Barkley the Bulldog, a British reference to the popular English <a href="/wiki/Bulldog" title="Bulldog">Bulldog</a>. </p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BISC_Lincoln_Park_Mascot.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/BISC_Lincoln_Park_Mascot.jpg/220px-BISC_Lincoln_Park_Mascot.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/BISC_Lincoln_Park_Mascot.jpg/330px-BISC_Lincoln_Park_Mascot.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/BISC_Lincoln_Park_Mascot.jpg/440px-BISC_Lincoln_Park_Mascot.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="839" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BISC_Lincoln_Park_Mascot.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>BISC Lincoln Park's mascot, Barkley the Bulldog.</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Clubs">Clubs</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Clubs">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>BISC Lincoln Park runs an average of over 40 clubs each school year. The most popular clubs include <a href="/wiki/Taekwondo" title="Taekwondo">Taekwondo</a>, chess, <a href="/wiki/CrossFit" title="CrossFit">CrossFit</a>, Mandarin, cooking, STEM Scouts and a variety of performing arts focused options. In addition the school offers a newspaper and journalism club whose students produce the campus newspaper, <i>The Bulldog Bugle</i>, as well as the newscast, <i>The Bulldog Bugle TV</i>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Traditions">Traditions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Traditions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>According to English private school traditions, BISC Lincoln Park introduced its own <a href="/wiki/House_system" title="House system">House</a> system to help younger students to mix with older students.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> The private school campus is divided into four houses, all based on the streets surrounding the school's perimeters:
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Blackhawk_House.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Blackhawk_House.jpg/220px-Blackhawk_House.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Blackhawk_House.jpg/330px-Blackhawk_House.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Blackhawk_House.jpg/440px-Blackhawk_House.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1650" data-file-height="1275" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Blackhawk_House.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Blackhawk house</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Blackhawk">Blackhawk</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Blackhawk">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>

<li>Color: Orange</li></ul>

<h2><span id="Global_Initiatives_.26_Collaborations"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Global_Initiatives_&amp;_Collaborations">Global Initiatives &amp; Collaborations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Global Initiatives &amp; Collaborations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Juilliard_Nord-Anglia_Performing_Arts_Program">Juilliard Nord-Anglia Performing Arts Program</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Juilliard Nord-Anglia Performing Arts Program">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BISC_Lincoln_Park_Juilliard_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/BISC_Lincoln_Park_Juilliard_1.jpg/220px-BISC_Lincoln_Park_Juilliard_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="330" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/BISC_Lincoln_Park_Juilliard_1.jpg/330px-BISC_Lincoln_Park_Juilliard_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/BISC_Lincoln_Park_Juilliard_1.jpg/440px-BISC_Lincoln_Park_Juilliard_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2232" data-file-height="3348" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BISC_Lincoln_Park_Juilliard_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>BISC Lincoln Park student participating in the Juilliard-Nord Anglia Performing Arts Program.</div></div></div>
<p>In February 2015, Nord Anglia Education and <a href="/wiki/Juilliard_School" title="Juilliard School">The Juilliard School</a> selected British International School of Chicago, Lincoln Park as one of ten Nord Anglia schools to pilot the launch of the Juilliard Nord Anglia-Performing Arts Program.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> The campus officially implemented the program in the fall term of 2015. Since then, The Juilliard School has been named the world's best university for the study of performing arts,<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> and BISC Lincoln Park and students have received visits and performed for Juilliard President Dr. <a href="/wiki/Joseph_W._Polisi" title="Joseph W. Polisi">Joseph W. Polisi</a> and Juilliard faculty member and Grammy-award winning artist <a href="/wiki/Itzhak_Perlman" title="Itzhak Perlman">Itzhak Perlman</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> Studies have shown that a performing arts program improves test scores, reading proficiency, and overall academic achievement.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> The learning-model program is built around the key works of music, dance, and drama with special visits and workshops led by various Juilliard alumni.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Corporate_Media_%26_TV_Awards" title="Cannes Corporate Media &amp; TV Awards">Cannes Corporate Media &amp; TV Awards</a> festival held in October 2016 showcased a Silver Dolphin winning short film featuring Juilliard alumni the Peter and Will Anderson Trio workshopping and performing with students at BISC Lincoln Park's campus.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology_Collaboration">Massachusetts Institute of Technology Collaboration</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Massachusetts Institute of Technology Collaboration">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:MIT_News_article.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/MIT_News_article.png/220px-MIT_News_article.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/MIT_News_article.png/330px-MIT_News_article.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/MIT_News_article.png/440px-MIT_News_article.png 2x" data-file-width="680" data-file-height="414" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:MIT_News_article.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>British International School of Chicago, Lincoln Park collaborates with Massachusetts Institute of Technology</div></div></div><p>In early summer of 2016, British International School of Chicago, Lincoln Park announced it will become one of the 13 inaugural Nord Anglia Education schools to collaborate with Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) to enhance science, technology, engineering, arts and maths (STEAM) teaching and learning for K-12 students.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> Launching in September 2016, the program includes the development of a series of in-school challenges for students which focus on the juncture between the five STEAM disciplines. Nord Anglia CEO Fitzmaurice believes the collaboration will ensure students are equipped with the skills to succeed in the future workplace.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup>
</p><h2><span id="Awards_.26_Accreditation"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_&amp;_Accreditation">Awards &amp; Accreditation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Awards &amp; Accreditation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Awards">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 2006, British International School of Chicago, Lincoln Park (then British School of Chicago) won the British Consul General Award from the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.babcc.org/">British American Business Council</a> for advancing relations between the U.K. and the U.S. as well as increasing the company's international exposure.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:199px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BISC_Lincoln_Park_CIS_Credited.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/86/BISC_Lincoln_Park_CIS_Credited.png" decoding="async" width="197" height="143" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="197" data-file-height="143" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BISC_Lincoln_Park_CIS_Credited.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>BISC Lincoln Park is Council of International Schools accredited.</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Accreditation">Accreditation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Accreditation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>British International School of Chicago, Lincoln Park is accredited by the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160503220412/http://www.greatlearning.com/ipc/">International Primary Curriculum</a> (IPC) and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Council_of_International_Schools&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Council of International Schools (page does not exist)">Council of International Schools</a> (CIS). In 2010, the private school was the fourth only in the world to achieve "mastering" level in all areas in delivering the IPC. As of March 2016, the school is applying for <a href="/wiki/Council_of_British_International_Schools" title="Council of British International Schools">Council of British International Schools</a> (COBIS) accreditation.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Parent_Company">Parent Company</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Parent Company">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>British International School of Chicago, Lincoln Park is owned by <a href="/wiki/Nord_Anglia_Education" title="Nord Anglia Education">Nord Anglia Education</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_International_School_of_Chicago_Lincoln_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.cois.org/page.cfm?p=1">Council of International Schools</a></li></ul>

href="http://www.brockington.leics.sch.uk">http://www.brockington.leics.sch.uk</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Brockington College</b> is a <a href="/wiki/Church_of_England" title="Church of England">Church of England</a> <a href="/wiki/Mixed-sex_education" title="Mixed-sex education">mixed</a> <a href="/wiki/Secondary_school" title="Secondary school">secondary school</a> in <a href="/wiki/Enderby,_Leicestershire" title="Enderby, Leicestershire">Enderby</a>, Leicestershire, England. It is in the district of <a href="/wiki/Blaby_(district)" class="mw-redirect" title="Blaby (district)">Blaby</a>. The school became an academy on 1 August 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brockington_College&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In 1957 Brockington College was erected using an intergrid prefabricated construction. Four other Leicestershire schools also used this method of construction and due to the high maintenance costs and physical degradation of the buildings each of these schools has now been replaced. Brockington College was part of a £19m project from September 2006 to September 2007. Being a voluntary-aided school, funding was not directly through the Building Schools for the Future scheme but shared between HM Government and the Partnership for Church Schools scheme. As such the Church of England made a significant investment in the college and its local community. The current building boasts modern and state-of-the-art facilities, especially information technology equipment. A full size artificial grass pitch was added in 2009, funded and sponsored by the FA,<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> Next and a number of other local sponsors.
</p><p>The school converted to <a href="/wiki/Academy_(English_school)" title="Academy (English school)">academy status</a> in August 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> Previously a <a href="/wiki/Middle_school" title="Middle school">middle school</a> for pupils aged 11 to 14, in September 2015 the school changed to become an 11 to 16 secondary school.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Features_of_the_college">Features of the college</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brockington_College&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Features of the college">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Admissions">Admissions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brockington_College&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Admissions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Brockington admits children aged 11–16 and in recent years has drawn significant numbers of pupils from beyond its traditional catchment area. The current informal catchment extends in excess of 8 miles, centred on Enderby and Narborough and including Croft, Huncote and Thurlaston - but reaching to Stoney Stanton, Whetstone and Blaby, Braunstone and Leicester Forest East as families have elected to apply to Brockington rather than their local secondary schools. Ofsted noted Brockington's pastoral support as being one of the many outstanding features of the college in 2010.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Spiritual_reflection">Spiritual reflection</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brockington_College&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Spiritual reflection">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The school speaks of its "uniquely Christian ethos" and has been assessed as an "Outstanding" school as part of its Section 48 inspection.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> Children and staff from a number of faith backgrounds are part of the Brockington community and all beliefs are respected and considered. Local clergy host assemblies once a fortnight for each year and there is a strong Spiritual Reflection programme designed to prompt reflection among all, irrespective of their faith. There is also a Christmas and Easter service held at the local church for years 7-10.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="House_system">House system</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brockington_College&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: House system">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>There are four Houses within the school (Plantagenet, Stuart, Tudor, and Windsor) and pupils frequently participate in extracurricular and enrichment activities representing their House.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="ICT_facilities">ICT facilities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brockington_College&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: ICT facilities">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>All classrooms are equipped with LED projectors and have interactive whiteboards. There are currently five ICT rooms located on-site.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="School_values">School values</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brockington_College&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: School values">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The school has eight key values ('Compassion', 'Forgiveness', 'Justice', 'Koinonia’, 'Perseverance’, ‘Wisdom’, ‘Learning’ and ‘Respect’) that inform the school's assembly programme; Collective Worship Programme and are the cornerstones for teaching within the school.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Student_voice">Student voice</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brockington_College&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Student voice">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Each tutor group has elected representatives who meet once a term, decide priorities and liaise with the senior leadership team. Student Voice pupils also play a significant role in staff recruitment (forming formal interview panels) and the promotion of the school.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Facilities">Facilities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brockington_College&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Facilities">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The College offers bookable rooms and facilities for outside groups.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> Regular sporting events are hosted using the College's facilities, including the 3G Artificial Grass Football Pitch (AGP), main indoor sports hall, and Multi Use Games Area (MUGA).<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notable_former_pupils">Notable former pupils</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brockington_College&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Notable former pupils">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Richard_Armitage_(actor)" title="Richard Armitage (actor)">Richard Armitage</a>, actor.</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Joe_Corby&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joe Corby (page does not exist)">Joe Corby</a>, greenkeeper.</li></ul>

</li>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180325171425/http://www.brockington.leics.sch.uk/2014/08/our-values/">"Brockington School Values"</a>. <table class="box-Notability plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Notability" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">The topic of this article <b>may not meet Wikipedia's <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Notability" title="Wikipedia:Notability">general notability guideline</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help to establish notability by citing <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources">reliable secondary sources</a> that are <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_and_using_independent_sources" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:Identifying and using independent sources">independent</a> of the topic and provide significant coverage of it beyond a mere trivial mention. If notability cannot be established, the article is likely to be <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Merging" title="Wikipedia:Merging">merged</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Redirect" title="Wikipedia:Redirect">redirected</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Deletion_policy" title="Wikipedia:Deletion policy">deleted</a>.<br /><small><span class="plainlinks"><i>Find sources:</i>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?as_eq=wikipedia&amp;q=%22Bronzeville%22+play">"Bronzeville"&#160;play</a>&#160;–&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbm=nws&amp;q=%22Bronzeville%22+play+-wikipedia">news</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?&amp;q=%22Bronzeville%22+play+site:news.google.com/newspapers&amp;source=newspapers">newspapers</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbs=bks:1&amp;q=%22Bronzeville%22+play+-wikipedia">books</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22Bronzeville%22+play">scholar</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/action/doBasicSearch?Query=%22Bronzeville%22+play&amp;acc=on&amp;wc=on">JSTOR</a></span></small></span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">January 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bronzeville_Flyer.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Bronzeville Flyer." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1e/Bronzeville_Flyer.jpg/220px-Bronzeville_Flyer.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="284" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/1/1e/Bronzeville_Flyer.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="277" data-file-height="358" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bronzeville_Flyer.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A flyer announcing the world premiere of <i>Bronzeville</i>.</div></div></div>
<p><i><b>Bronzeville</b></i> is an original play written by <a href="/wiki/Tim_Toyama" title="Tim Toyama">Tim Toyama</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aaron_Woolfolk" title="Aaron Woolfolk">Aaron Woolfolk</a>. It was developed and produced by the <a href="/wiki/Robey_Theatre_Company" title="Robey Theatre Company">Robey Theatre Company</a>. The original production and two subsequent revivals were directed by <a href="/wiki/Ben_Guillory" title="Ben Guillory">Ben Guillory</a>. The play had its world premiere at the <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Theatre_Center" title="Los Angeles Theatre Center">Los Angeles Theatre Center</a> in Los Angeles, California on April 17, 2009 and enjoyed an extended, sold-out run. Woolfolk and Toyama were subsequently nominated for an <a href="/wiki/Ovation_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="Ovation Award">Ovation Award</a>, and they and Guillory were nominated for <a href="/wiki/NAACP_Theatre_Awards" title="NAACP Theatre Awards">NAACP Theatre Awards</a>.
</p><p><br />
The play is named after the nickname given to the <a href="/wiki/Little_Tokyo,_Los_Angeles" title="Little Tokyo, Los Angeles">Little Tokyo, Los Angeles</a> neighborhood from 1942 to 1945 when Japanese Americans were taken from their homes and put into <a href="/wiki/Internment_camps" class="mw-redirect" title="Internment camps">internment camps</a>. During that time, many African Americans migrating to California from the southern United States settled in Little Tokyo, which became known as Bronzeville.
</p><p>The play is about an African American family from Mississippi that moves to Los Angeles. When they find a Japanese American man hiding in the attic, the family must confront their own values as they struggle to both protect themselves and do what is right. The timeline of the play runs from the spring of 1942 to the spring of 1945.
</p><p><i>Bronzeville</i> had its first revival as an abridged version in May, 2011 at the <a href="/wiki/Manzanar_National_Historic_Site" class="mw-redirect" title="Manzanar National Historic Site">Manzanar National Historic Site</a> in Independence, California. It was produced by The Robey Theatre Company in association with Manzanar National Historic Site and Inyo Council for the Arts. A second revival production, this time of the full play, was produced by The Robey Theatre Company in association with the <a href="/wiki/Latino_Theater_Company" title="Latino Theater Company">Latino Theater Company</a> and Kathie Foley Meyer and was staged at the Los Angeles Theatre Center in June and July 2013 as part of the Project Bronzeville festival.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> On March 28, 2014, a staged reading of the play was presented by <a href="/wiki/The_Lorraine_Hansberry_Theatre" title="The Lorraine Hansberry Theatre">The Lorraine Hansberry Theatre</a> in San Francisco, California.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Plot">Plot</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bronzeville_(play)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Plot">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<table class="box-Unreferenced_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Unreferenced" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>does not <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">cite</a> any <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">sources</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bronzeville_(play)&amp;action=edit">improve this section</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">removed</a>.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">January 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>As Japanese Americans in the Los Angeles neighborhood of Little Tokyo are loaded onto buses that will take them to various internment camps, Hide "Henry" Tahara lets camera shop proprietor Sam Teraoka in on a secret: He plans to hide in his home. Citing the 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, Henry says the rounding up of Japanese Americans is illegal, and he refuses to go along with it. Sam wishes Henry luck.
</p><p>Several weeks later, the Goodwin Family -- Mama Janie, her oldest grandson Jodie, Jodie's wife Alice, their daughter Princess, and Jodie's younger brother Felix -- enters their new house, having just arrived in Los Angeles from Mississippi. While the women talk of exploring the neighborhood, Jodie argues with his brother over whether Felix should get a 9 to 5 job or find a jazz club to perform in. Just then a weak and hungry Henry comes down the stairs, surprising the Goodwins. Jodie quickly subdues him.
</p><p>Under questioning, Henry explains that this is his family's home and that he has been hiding in the attic. He becomes upset when he learns the house was illegally rented out. Jodie expresses concern that the family could suffer dire consequences if they are discovered harboring someone who should be in government custody. He demands Henry come to the police station with him, until Mama Janie reminds the family how, as a child during slavery, she witnessed her uncle's brutal execution after he was caught trying to escape to freedom. Over Jodie's objections the family agrees to protect Henry.
</p><p>The Goodwins and Henry quickly warm to each other. Moreover, Henry and Princess develop a strong mutual attraction. It also becomes clear that some tensions have accompanied the family from Mississippi. In particular, Jodie is upset that Felix refuses to join the first group of African Americans being trained for the United States Marine Corps in North Carolina. Felix quickly finds work playing saxophone at the Sahara, a newly opened jazz club in the neighborhood. When he learns the owner, Tubby, needs a photographer to help promote the club, he remembers some of Henry's photos that he saw and recommends his "Chinese friend" for the job. 
</p><p>Using an old <a href="/wiki/Time_Magazine" class="mw-redirect" title="Time Magazine">Time Magazine</a> article on how to tell the difference between Japanese and Chinese, Felix coaches Henry to act like the latter so he can work at the Sahara. Princess goes with Henry on a fun excursion to <a href="/wiki/Chinatown" title="Chinatown">Chinatown</a> to test his new "Chinese" mannerisms. After they return, Alice takes Princess aside and says she and Jodie have noticed the budding romance with Henry, and orders Princess to put an end to it. Overhearing the conversation, Mama Janie invites Princess to help her in the garden, then encourages her great-granddaughter to live her life the way she sees fit.
</p><p>A few nights later at the Sahara, Felix plays with the band while Henry takes photographs. Princess comes and quickly gains the attention of several men, but she ignores them and flirts with Henry. When they start dancing together, Henry is attacked, causing Felix to leave the stage to defend him. A huge brawl ensues. Back at the house, Jodie and Alice scold Princess and Felix for her being at the club. Jodie also admonishes Henry for causing the fight, especially when Henry is supposed to be in hiding.
</p><p><br />
Jodie tells Alice he's decided to turn Henry in before the authorities discovers the family is hiding him. After getting resistance from Alice, Jodie goes to a bar to consider what to do. The bartender, Hamp, talks about the changing neighborhood, then tells Jodie how everyone is talking about a brawl that started at the Sahara "over an Oriental man being sweet on a colored woman." Fearing his family's secret will be exposed, Jodie goes to the police station and tells them about Henry. Later that night, the police and FBI come to the house and take Henry away.
</p><p>In federal detention, Henry undergoes days of intense interrogation that nearly breaks him. A kind FBI agent, Larry, offers Henry a way out: enlistment in a new unit of Japanese American soldiers that will fight in the war. Henri reluctantly agrees and joins the <a href="/wiki/442nd_Infantry_Regiment" class="mw-redirect" title="442nd Infantry Regiment">442nd Infantry Regiment</a>. As he sees action in Europe, Henry writes letters to the Goodwins detailing his exploits. Princess writes several letters back, updating Henry about life in the neighborhood. A telegram later arrives from the War Department, addressed to Henry's father: Henry has been killed in action. The news devastates the Goodwins, and Princess accuses Jodie of being responsible for his death.
</p><p>As Japanese Americans fill the streets after the end of internment, the Goodwins pack in preparation for their move to the Crenshaw area of Los Angeles. Henry's father Naoma, a neighborhood leader who was taken away by federal authorities the night of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, comes to meet the family. He thanks them for sheltering Henry and showing him love and kindness. The family joins Naoma in reciting a Buddhist prayer for Henry's soul.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History_of_the_Play">History of the Play</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bronzeville_(play)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History of the Play">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<table class="box-Unreferenced_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Unreferenced" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>does not <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">cite</a> any <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">sources</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bronzeville_(play)&amp;action=edit">improve this section</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">removed</a>.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">January 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Tim Toyama had already shown an interest in the interaction between Japanese Americans and African Americans with his play <i>Yuri and Malcolm</i>, about the friendship between Japanese American <a href="/wiki/Civil_Rights" class="mw-redirect" title="Civil Rights">Civil Rights</a> activist <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Kochiyama" title="Yuri Kochiyama">Yuri Kochiyama</a> and Civil Rights icon and Black Nationalist leader <a href="/wiki/Malcolm_X" title="Malcolm X">Malcolm X</a>. When he learned from a friend about Little Tokyo's Bronzeville period, he felt it provided a wonderful subject for a play.
</p><p>Coincidentally, at around the same time Aaron Woolfolk helped to paint the Little Tokyo Mural as a volunteer activity with his <a href="/wiki/Japan_Exchange_and_Teaching_Programme" class="mw-redirect" title="Japan Exchange and Teaching Programme">Japan Exchange and Teaching Programme</a> alumni group, the JET Alumni Association of Southern California. Curious about an image on the mural depicting jazz legend <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Parker" title="Charlie Parker">Charlie Parker</a>, Woolfolk was told about the neighborhood's Bronzeville period and how Parker had been one of its residents. Woolfolk wrote down the basic information with plans to someday explore writing a screenplay on the subject.
</p><p>In 2007 Toyama approached Robey Theatre Company artistic director Ben Guillory and told him he wanted to do a play about Little Tokyo’s Bronzeville period in a way that intertwined the Japanese American and African American experiences. Guillory was enthusiastic about the idea, and said he would like to see such a play as a Robey Theatre Company production. Toyama said he felt he needed to create, develop, and write the play with an African American writer, and asked Guillory if he could recommend anyone. Guillory told him he had the ideal person in mind: Woolfolk, who at the time was developing his feature film <a href="/wiki/The_Harimaya_Bridge" title="The Harimaya Bridge">The Harimaya Bridge</a> -- about an African American man in Japan -- with Guillory cast in the lead role.
</p><p>Guillory introduced Toyama and Woolfolk, and they agreed to move forward on the project together. Over the next two years Toyama and Woolfolk came up with the plot and characters, developed the story, and wrote the play under Guillory's tutelage.
</p><p>Both writers drew heavily on their personal experiences when creating the plot and characters. Toyama was inspired by a friend who had known of an instance in which an African American family had hidden a Japanese American man during internment in the 1940s. He also called on his upbringing and experiences as a member of the Japanese American community, including having several close relatives and friends who were in internment camps. Woolfolk drew on his lifelong friendships with Japanese Americans, his experiences living and working in <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, family stories of black migration from the Deep South to California in the 1940s, the murder of a Japanese friend in New York City and his subsequent visit to see her parents in Japan, a longtime interest in the <a href="/wiki/Montford_Point_Marines" class="mw-redirect" title="Montford Point Marines">Montford Point Marines</a>, and his love of jazz music. Toyama and Woolfolk also did a lot of research, viewing old documents from the era and interviewing experts on Little Tokyo and its Bronzeville period. Some of the Robey Theatre Company's early marketing materials erroneously stated that the play was based on a true story. This resulted from a misunderstanding, as the plot, situations, and characters were entirely created by Woolfolk and Toyama.
</p><p>In 2008 Toyama entered the play into the <a href="/wiki/East_West_Players" title="East West Players">East West Players</a> David Henry Hwang Writer’s Institute, under which he and Woolfolk further developed the play and where it was performed for the first time in a staged reading.
</p><p><i>Bronzeville</i> premiered on April 17, 2009 as a Robey Theatre Company production at the Los Angeles Theatre Center. It enjoyed a sold-out run and was extended by two weeks.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Reception">Reception</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bronzeville_(play)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Reception">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p><i>Bronzeville</i> received rave reviews, with Toyama and Woolfolk getting praise for the story, characterizations, and dialogue; and Guillory drawing raves for his innovative staging.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> The cast was also heralded for its performances.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> Upon its premiere the play made the Los Angeles Times Critics Choice list.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> The 2013 revival also garnered strong critical notices. The LA Stage Times called it "a revelation" and described it as having "a fine-grained consistency" that "packs a powerful punch."<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_Recognition">Awards Recognition</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bronzeville_(play)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Awards Recognition">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Woolfolk and Toyama were nominated for an Ovation Award in the category Best Playwrighting for an Original Play.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Bronzeville</i> was also nominated for four NAACP Theater Awards: Toyama and Woolfolk for Best Playwright, Guillory for Best Director, the cast for Best Ensemble Cast, and Luke Moyer for Best Lighting, for which he won.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Characters_in_the_Play">Characters in the Play</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bronzeville_(play)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Characters in the Play">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>Hide "Henry" Tahara (Original cast member: Jeff Manabat)</li>
<li>Jodie Goodwin (Original cast member: Dwain A. Perry)</li>
<li>Alice Goodwin (Original cast member: Adenrele Ojo)</li>
<li>Mama Janie (Original cast member: CeCe Antoinette)</li>
<li>Felix Goodwin (Original cast member: Larry Powell)</li>
<li>Jane "Princess" Goodwin (Original cast member: Candice Afia)</li>
<li>Joseph Cardell "Tubby" Griffin (Original cast member: Robert Clements)</li>
<li>Theodus "Hamp" Hampton (Original cast member: Landon H. Lewis, Jr.)</li>
<li>June Bug (Original cast member: Anthony B. Phillips)</li>
<li>Naoma Tahara (Original cast member: Dana Lee)</li>
<li>FBI Agent Frank Morgan (Original cast member: Benjamin Fitch)</li>
<li>Officer Smith (Original cast member: Darrell Phillip)</li>
<li>FBI Agent Larry Powell (Original cast member: Darrell Phillip)</li>
<li>Sam Teraoka (Original cast member: Michael Yama)</li></ul>
<p>In the 2013 full revival, all of the roles were reprised by the original cast members except for Alice Goodwin (played by Kellie Dantzler), Felix Goodwin (Aaron Jennings), Jane "Princess" Goodwin (Iman Milner), FBI Agent Frank Morgan (Mark L. Colbenson), and Sam Teraoka (Vladimir Velasco). The character June Bug was edited out of the story.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bronzeville_(play)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2018-01-12</span></span>.</cite><span </li>
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2009/04/review-bronzeville-at-new-los-angeles-theatre-center.html">"Review: 'Bronzeville' at New Los Angeles Theatre Center"</a>. <i>LA Times Blogs - Culture Monster</i>. 2009-04-30<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2018-01-12</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=LA+Times+Blogs+-+Culture+Monster&amp;rft.atitle=Review%3A+%27Bronzeville%27+at+New+Los+Angeles+Theatre+Center&amp;rft.date=2009-04-30&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Flatimesblogs.latimes.com%2Fculturemonster%2F2009%2F04%2Freview-bronzeville-at-new-los-angeles-theatre-center.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABronzeville+%28play%29" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFIII2009" class="citation news cs1">III, Lovell Estell (2009-04-30). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.laweekly.com/calendar/bronzeville-2159605">"Bronzeville"</a>. <i>L.A. Weekly</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2018-01-12</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=L.A.+Weekly&amp;rft.atitle=Bronzeville&amp;rft.date=2009-04-30&amp;rft.aulast=III&amp;rft.aufirst=Lovell+Estell&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.laweekly.com%2Fcalendar%2Fbronzeville-2159605&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABronzeville+%28play%29" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://thisstage.la/2013/07/la-chronicles-bronzeville-revolver-sweet-karma/">"LA Chronicles: Bronzeville, revolver, Sweet Karma ‹&#160;@ This Stage"</a>. <i>thisstage.la</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2018-01-12</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=thisstage.la&amp;rft.atitle=LA+Chronicles%3A+Bronzeville%2C+revolver%2C+Sweet+Karma+%E2%80%B9+%40+This+Stage&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fthisstage.la%2F2013%2F07%2Fla-chronicles-bronzeville-revolver-sweet-karma%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABronzeville+%28play%29" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFDesk" class="citation news cs1">Desk, BWW News. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.broadwayworld.com/los-angeles/article/2009-LA-Stage-Alliance-Ovation-Award-Nominees-Announced-Center-Theatre-Group-Geffen-Playhouse-Lead-20091020">"2009 L.A. Stage Alliance Ovation Award Nominees Announced; Allison Janney, Dolly Parton, Leslie Uggams Recognized"</a>. <i>BroadwayWorld.com</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2018-01-12</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=BroadwayWorld.com&amp;rft.atitle=2009+L.A.+Stage+Alliance+Ovation+Award+Nominees+Announced%3B+Allison+Janney%2C+Dolly+Parton%2C+Leslie+Uggams+Recognized&amp;rft.aulast=Desk&amp;rft.aufirst=BWW+News&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.broadwayworld.com%2Flos-angeles%2Farticle%2F2009-LA-Stage-Alliance-Ovation-Award-Nominees-Announced-Center-Theatre-Group-Geffen-Playhouse-Lead-20091020&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABronzeville+%28play%29" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://thisstage.la/2009/11/ovation-nominee-profile-aaron-woolfolk/">"Ovation Nominee Profile:  Aaron Woolfolk ‹&#160;@ This Stage"</a>. <i>thisstage.la</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2018-01-12</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=thisstage.la&amp;rft.atitle=Ovation+Nominee+Profile%3A++Aaron+Woolfolk+%E2%80%B9+%40+This+Stage&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fthisstage.la%2F2009%2F11%2Fovation-nominee-profile-aaron-woolfolk%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABronzeville+%28play%29" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>
