<ul><li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li>
<li class="mw-empty-elt"></li></ul></div>
~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">October 2012</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Playhouseatdusk.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Playhouseatdusk.jpg/220px-Playhouseatdusk.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Playhouseatdusk.jpg/330px-Playhouseatdusk.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Playhouseatdusk.jpg/440px-Playhouseatdusk.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1800" data-file-height="1198" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Playhouseatdusk.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Opening Night at the Bucks County Playhouse July 2012</div></div></div>
<p>The <b>Bucks County Playhouse</b> is located in <a href="/wiki/New_Hope,_Pennsylvania" title="New Hope, Pennsylvania">New Hope, Pennsylvania</a>.
</p><p>When the <i>Hope Mills</i> burned in 1790, the <a href="/wiki/Grist_mill" class="mw-redirect" title="Grist mill">grist mills</a> were rebuilt as the <i>New Hope Mills</i> by Benjamin Parry. The town was renamed for the mills.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bucks_County_Playhouse,_1934.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Bucks County Playhouse, 1934" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/db/Bucks_County_Playhouse%2C_1934.jpg/300px-Bucks_County_Playhouse%2C_1934.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="201" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/d/db/Bucks_County_Playhouse%2C_1934.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="386" data-file-height="258" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bucks_County_Playhouse,_1934.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bucks County Playhouse, 1934</div></div></div>
<p>The building was saved from demolition in the 1930s and purchased and run by a group including playwrights <a href="/wiki/Moss_Hart" title="Moss Hart">Moss Hart</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kenyon_Nicholson" title="Kenyon Nicholson">Kenyon Nicholson</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> Renovations converting the building into a theatre began in 1938. The first show opened there on 1 July 1939, <i>Springtime for Henry</i> featuring <a href="/wiki/Edward_Everett_Horton" title="Edward Everett Horton">Edward Everett Horton</a>.
</p><p>The Bucks County Playhouse became a summer <a href="/wiki/Theater" class="mw-redirect" title="Theater">theater</a>. It was the starting point for many actors and became a place where plays slated for <a href="/wiki/Broadway_theatre" title="Broadway theatre">Broadway</a> were tried out. <a href="/wiki/Neil_Simon" title="Neil Simon">Neil Simon</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Barefoot_in_the_Park" title="Barefoot in the Park">Barefoot in the Park</a></i> had its premiere at the theater in 1963, starring <a href="/wiki/Robert_Redford" title="Robert Redford">Robert Redford</a> and <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_Ashley" title="Elizabeth Ashley">Elizabeth Ashley</a>.  Other notable actors who performed at the theater over the years include <a href="/wiki/Bela_Lugosi" title="Bela Lugosi">Bela Lugosi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dick_Van_Dyke" title="Dick Van Dyke">Dick Van Dyke</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tyne_Daly" title="Tyne Daly">Tyne Daly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grace_Kelly" title="Grace Kelly">Grace Kelly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Angela_Lansbury" title="Angela Lansbury">Angela Lansbury</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Walter_Matthau" title="Walter Matthau">Walter Matthau</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> 
</p><p>The Bucks County Playhouse Conservancy, a public/private partnership, raised sufficient funds to regain the property following a 2010 foreclosure.  Following an extensive renovation, the theater reopened on July 2, 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bucks_County_Playhouse.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Bucks_County_Playhouse.JPG/220px-Bucks_County_Playhouse.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Bucks_County_Playhouse.JPG/330px-Bucks_County_Playhouse.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Bucks_County_Playhouse.JPG/440px-Bucks_County_Playhouse.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bucks_County_Playhouse.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bucks County Playhouse in 2012</div></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Memorable_productions">Memorable productions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bucks_County_Playhouse&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Memorable productions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<table class="box-Unreferenced_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Unreferenced" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>does not <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">cite</a> any <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">sources</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bucks_County_Playhouse&amp;action=edit">improve this section</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">removed</a>.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">October 2012</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>July 1, 1939: 
</p>
<ul><li>Bucks County Playhouse opening night- Springtime for Henry starring Edward Everett Horton.</li></ul>
<p>1941: 
</p>
<ul><li>Hume Cronyn starring in Clifford Odets’ Golden Boy.</li>
<li>The Man Who Came to Dinner, starring George S. Kaufman, Moss Hart and Harpo Marx (who actually spoke!), a memorable production from BCP producers Theron and Phyllis Bamberger</li></ul>
<p>1946: 
</p>
<ul><li>Helen Hayes (and 16-year-old daughter Mary MacArthur who made her stage debut as a BCP Apprentice) appeared in James M. Barrie's Alice Sit-by-the-Fire.</li></ul>
<p>1949: 
</p>
<ul><li>BCP Apprentice Grace Kelly makes her stage debut in playwright George Kelly's The Torchbearers, followed by The Heiress.</li></ul>
<p>1951: 
</p>
<ul><li>Jessica Tandy and Hume Cronyn star together for the first time on stage in the pre-Broadway opening of The Fourposter.</li></ul>
<p>1952: 
</p>
<ul><li>Angela Lansbury graced the BCP stage in Affairs of State.</li>
<li>Grace Kelly returned to the BCP, fresh from Broadway, television and Hollywood to star with Jerome Cowen in Accent on Youth.</li></ul>
<p>1955: 
</p>
<ul><li>The Today Show broadcast live, with host Dave Garoway, from the BCP with an NBC radio simulcast which had never been done before in the US.  It was national recognition for the Bucks County Playhouse.</li></ul>
<p>1959: 
</p>
<ul><li>Dick Van Dyke's first dramatic stage appearance in BCP's Cradle and All and Robert Redford's first role at BCP in Tiger at the Gates.</li></ul>
<p>1960: 
</p>
<ul><li>Come Blow Your Horn was Neil Simon's first play and made its world premiere at the BCP. Producers Michael Ellis and William Hammerstein, after Simon's rewrites, took Come Blow Your Horn from BCP to Broadway.</li></ul>
<p>1963: 
</p>
<ul><li>Barefoot in the Park (Nobody Loves Me), Neil Simon's third play, had its premiere at the theater starring Robert Redford and Elizabeth Ashley. It was the first play that Mike Nichols ever directed which also led to his first Tony Award for Best Director (Dramatic) on Broadway in 1964.</li>
<li>James Daly and his family, seventeen-year-old Tyne, fifteen-year-old daughter Glynn and seven-year-old son Tim all appeared together in playwright Jean Kerr's first comedy, Jenny Kissed Me, in 1963.  James Daly first starred in 1954's Millicent's Castle and later in the 1962 hit The Advocate at the BCP.  Tyne Daly started her career by performing in summer stock with her family, earned her Equity Card at age 15, and made her professional debut at the BCP.</li>
<li>Alan Alda appeared in Jean Kerr's King of Hearts, directed by James Hammerstein.</li></ul>
<p>1964: 
</p>
<ul><li>Liza Minnelli stars in Time Out For Ginger by Ronald Alexander with Chester Morris.</li>
<li>BCP Apprentice Rob Reiner worked on Sunday In New York (starring Alan Alda), Bus Stop, The Choice is Murder, Broadway (starring Merv Griffin), and A Perfect Frenzy by John D. Hess (starring Shelley Berman)</li>
<li>The entire US and Canada heard all about the little town of New Hope, PA when The Arthur Godfrey Show, on CBS radio, originated from the stage of the BCP for two weeks while Mr. Godfrey starred in a revival of Thornton Wilder's Our Town.</li></ul>
<p>1966: 
</p>
<ul><li>George C. Scott and Colleen Dewhurst star in The Lion in Winter</li>
<li>Bernadette Peters appeared in Riverwind, starring Robert Alda, directed by James Hammerstein.</li></ul>
<p>1970: 
</p>
<ul><li>John Lithgow Directed and/or acted in 4 shows at BCP: Sir in The Roar of the Greasepaint, the Smell of the Crowd, Dr.Talacryn in Hadrian VII and Captain Vale in The Magistrate (which he also directed). Mr. Lithgow even directed a BCP revival of Barefoot in the Park in 1970 right before heading off to the bright lights of Broadway!</li></ul>
<p>1974: 
</p>
<ul><li>Give ‘Em Hell Harry, world premiere starring James Whitmore- went on to Ford's Theatre in Washington, DC.</li></ul>
<p>1976: 
</p>
<ul><li>Anne Jackson and Eli Wallach's two-week run of The House of Blue Leaves broke the Playhouse's attendance record. Ms. Jackson starred in Dear Ruth, under the direction of Theron Bamberger, which provided the biggest profit in the 1947 season, and S.J. Behrman's witty comedy of the thirties, Biography, during the tenure of producer Walter Perner, Jr. in 1966.</li></ul>
<p>1989: 
</p>
<ul><li>Audra McDonald garners rave reviews as Aldonza in BCP's Man of La Mancha.</li></ul>
<p>2012: 
</p>
<ul><li>Actor's Equity shows return to the BCP with Producing Director <a href="/wiki/Jed_Bernstein" title="Jed Bernstein">Jed Bernstein</a>.</li>
<li>Rodgers and Hammerstein's A Grand Night for Singing, directed by Lonny Price, starring Courtney Balan, Ron Bohmer, Greg Bosworth, Erin Davie and Kenita R. Miller</li>
<li>Barefoot in the Park, directed by Sheryl Kaller, starring Robert John Biedermann, Candy Buckley, Jonathan Hadary, Lee Aaron Rosen and Virginia Veale</li>
<li>It's a Wonderful Life: A Live Radio Play, directed by Gordon Greenberg, starring <a href="/wiki/Justin_Guarini" title="Justin Guarini">Justin Guarini</a>, Garth Kravits, Lauren Molina, Jill Paice, Kevin Pariseau, and Mark Price</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bucks_County_Playhouse&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<table class="box-More_citations_needed plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bucks_County_Playhouse&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. </div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>James Bundy</b> (born May 8, 1959 in <a href="/wiki/Boston" title="Boston">Boston</a>, Massachusetts) is an American <a href="/wiki/Theatre" title="Theatre">theatre</a> director and teacher who has served in the dual roles of Dean of <a href="/wiki/Yale_School_of_Drama" title="Yale School of Drama">Yale School of Drama</a> and Artistic Director of <a href="/wiki/Yale_Repertory_Theatre" title="Yale Repertory Theatre">Yale Repertory Theatre</a> since 2002.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Bundy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Bundy attended Groton School and received his AB in English and American Literature from <a href="/wiki/Harvard_College" title="Harvard College">Harvard College</a> in 1981. He studied acting at the <a href="/wiki/London_Academy_of_Music_and_Dramatic_Art" title="London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art">London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art</a>, 1981-1984, and received his MFA in directing from <a href="/wiki/Yale_School_of_Drama" title="Yale School of Drama">Yale School of Drama</a> in 1995.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Bundy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>As an actor, Bundy made his theatrical debut playing <a href="/wiki/Santa_Claus" title="Santa Claus">Santa Claus</a> in a school Christmas pageant in the first grade.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> He worked professionally as an actor from 1984–89, appearing in productions at Magic Theatre, Woodminster Summer Musicals, San Jose Repertory Theatre, Music Hall Theater in San Francisco, Berkeley Repertory Theatre, and <a href="/wiki/Oregon_Shakespeare_Festival" title="Oregon Shakespeare Festival">Oregon Shakespeare Festival</a>.
</p><p>From 1989-91, he was the Managing Director of <a href="/wiki/Cornerstone_Theater_Company" title="Cornerstone Theater Company">Cornerstone Theatre Company</a> prior to enrolling in Yale School of Drama in 1992. He served as Associate Producing Director of <a href="/wiki/The_Acting_Company" title="The Acting Company">The Acting Company</a> in New York City from 1996–98 and Artistic Director of <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes_Theater" title="Great Lakes Theater">Great Lakes Theater</a> Festival in Cleveland, Ohio, 1998-2002.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> His appointment as Dean/Artistic Director of Yale School of Drama/Yale Repertory Theatre in <a href="/wiki/New_Haven,_Connecticut" title="New Haven, Connecticut">New Haven, Connecticut</a>, began full-time in 2002 and he has been reappointed for three consecutive five-year terms in 2007,<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> in 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> and again in 2016, at which time Yale President Peter Salovey noted  that Bundy's leadership "has sustained the school’s record as the top drama program in the country and advanced Yale Rep as one of the premiere locations for the development of new plays…[and] increased philanthropic support for drama at Yale including the transformational gift that endowed the Binger Center for New Theatre.” <sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>His directing credits at Yale Rep include Assassins, book by John Weidman, music and lyrics by <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Sondheim" title="Stephen Sondheim">Stephen Sondheim</a>, 2016; Happy Days by <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Beckett" title="Samuel Beckett">Samuel Beckett</a> starring <a href="/wiki/Dianne_Wiest" title="Dianne Wiest">Dianne Wiest</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jarlath_Conroy" title="Jarlath Conroy">Jarlath Conroy</a>, a production which Bundy directed again at Theater for a New Audience Brooklyn, New York, in 2017; Arcadia by <a href="/wiki/Tom_Stoppard" title="Tom Stoppard">Tom Stoppard</a>, 2014; Hamlet by <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a>, starring <a href="/wiki/Paul_Giamatti" title="Paul Giamatti">Paul Giamatti</a>, 2013; <a href="/wiki/Edward_Albee" title="Edward Albee">Edward Albee</a>'s A Delicate Balance, 2011; <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Miller" title="Arthur Miller">Arthur Miller</a>'s Death of a Salesman starring <a href="/wiki/Charles_S._Dutton" title="Charles S. Dutton">Charles S. Dutton</a>, 2009; <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Wilde" title="Oscar Wilde">Oscar Wilde</a>'s A Woman of No Importance, 2008; Shakespeare's All's Well That Ends Well, co-directed by Mark Rucker, 2006; The Ladies of the Camellias by <a href="/wiki/Lillian_Garrett-Groag" title="Lillian Garrett-Groag">Lillian Groag</a>, 2004, and The Psychic Lives of Savages by <a href="/wiki/Amy_Freed" title="Amy Freed">Amy Freed</a>, 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Teaching">Teaching</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Bundy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Teaching">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Bundy has taught text analysis classes in Shakespeare, Molière, and Wilde; and Chekhov and Ibsen, since 2004. He has also taught various summer classes for actors at <a href="/wiki/British_American_Drama_Academy" title="British American Drama Academy">British American Drama Academy</a> since 2005.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_and_Honors">Awards and Honors</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Bundy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Awards and Honors">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>Tony Award nomination, Yale Repertory Theatre: Best Play, Indecent, 2017</li>
<li>National Theater Conference Outstanding Theater Award, Yale Repertory Theatre, 2014</li>
<li>Tom Killen Award, Connecticut Critics Circle, 2007</li>
<li>Outstanding Production, Connecticut Critics Circle, Yale Repertory Theatre, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2010, 2011, 2013, 2014, 2016</li>
<li>John Houseman Award, The Acting Company, 2012</li>
<li>Leadership Cleveland, 2000</li>
<li>Crain's Cleveland, 40 Under 40, 1998</li>
<li>Class Marshal, Yale School of Drama, 1995</li>
<li>Best Ensemble (Ah, Wilderness!), Bay Area Critics Circle, 1988</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Service">Service</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Bundy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Service">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Bundy served as a trustee of <a href="/wiki/Groton_School" title="Groton School">Groton School</a>, 2003–15, and a trustee of <a href="/wiki/Theatre_Communications_Group" title="Theatre Communications Group">Theatre Communications Group</a>, 2007-13.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal">Personal</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Bundy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Personal">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Bundy was born in Boston in 1959, one of four children of <a href="/wiki/McGeorge_Bundy" title="McGeorge Bundy">McGeorge Bundy</a> and Mary Bundy. He married singer Anne Tofflemire in 1988. They have two daughters.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Bundy&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Dave Burgering</b> is a Team USA Olympic diver, Fort Lauderdale Dive Team Diving Director and Head Coach, and is part of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Olympic_Committee" class="mw-redirect" title="United States Olympic Committee">United States Olympic Committee</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> Burgering began diving at an early age and his career included collegiate diving  at Michigan State University. He was part of the USA team selected for the <a href="/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics" title="1980 Summer Olympics">1980 Olympic Games</a>. However, he was unable to dive because the United States boycotted the Olympics. He has been coaching for 32 years, including attending the <a href="/wiki/2008_Olympic_Games" class="mw-redirect" title="2008 Olympic Games">2008 Olympic Games</a> as part of the coaching staff.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dave_Burgering&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Burgering has a long history with diving as he started diving in 1967 and finished his career in 1984. He first coached for the Missions Viejo Nadadores, as head coach, where his team won two National Team Titles in 1987 and 1988. Then, he coached in <a href="/wiki/Boca_Raton,_Florida" title="Boca Raton, Florida">Boca Raton, Florida</a>, for the Mission Bay Makos, where his team beat his old team by one point in the national championship. He is now the head coach of Fort Lauderdale Diving Team, having begun coaching there on in 2007.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>As of 2018, he has coached 128 junior national finalists and 46 senior national finalists.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>

</ol></div></div>
~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">March 2016</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>David Burris</b> (sometimes credited as Dave Burris or David Allen Burris) is an American filmmaker, television producer, writer and musician. He directed the feature film <i>The World Made Straight</i> (<i>Millennium Entertainment</i>) and the short film <i>The Side of the Road</i>, which he also wrote.  He was the executive producer on CBS's <i><a href="/wiki/Survivor_(TV_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="Survivor (TV series)">Survivor</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> and a writer on the USA/SyFy series <i><a href="/wiki/Good_vs_Evil_(TV_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="Good vs Evil (TV series)">Good vs. Evil</a></i>. As a musician, he was a founding member and songwriter for Sire/Warner recording artists <a href="/wiki/Jolene_(band)" title="Jolene (band)">Jolene</a> and a recording and touring member of Mercury/Polygram recording artists The Veldt.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Burris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Background">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Burris was born in Durham, raised in Raleigh and educated in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. His father, Craven Allen Burris was the dean of Raleigh's Meredith College and traveled overseas often for academic programs. David accompanied him on these sojourns, spending considerable chunks of his childhood in London while also traveling across the UK and Europe. His mother, Jane Russell Burris, was a high school librarian and instilled in him a deep love of literature and storytelling from an early age.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Burris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Burris did a year of study at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Edinburgh" title="University of Edinburgh">University of Edinburgh</a> but ultimately took his bachelor's degree from <a href="/wiki/University_of_North_Carolina_at_Chapel_Hill" title="University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill">UNC–Chapel Hill</a> and his master's degree from <a href="/wiki/Wake_Forest_University" title="Wake Forest University">Wake Forest University</a>. At UNC's student television station Burris formed a sketch comedy troupe with future filmmakers <a href="/wiki/Peyton_Reed" title="Peyton Reed">Peyton Reed</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Schultz_(director)" title="John Schultz (director)">John Schultz</a>, among others. They produced a series called The World of Fun that was heavily influenced by <a href="/wiki/Monty_Python%27s_Flying_Circus" title="Monty Python&#39;s Flying Circus">Monty Python's Flying Circus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Second_City_Television" title="Second City Television">Second City Television</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Burris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<table class="box-BLP_sources_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-BLP_sources" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section of a <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Biographies_of_living_persons" title="Wikipedia:Biographies of living persons">biography of a living person</a> <b>needs additional <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">citations</a> for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help by adding <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources">reliable sources</a>. Contentious material about living persons that is unsourced or poorly sourced <b>must be removed immediately</b>, especially if potentially <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Libel" title="Wikipedia:Libel">libelous</a> or harmful.<br /><small><span class="plainlinks"><i>Find sources:</i>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?as_eq=wikipedia&amp;q=%22David+Burris%22">"David Burris"</a>&#160;–&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbm=nws&amp;q=%22David+Burris%22+-wikipedia">news</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?&amp;q=%22David+Burris%22+site:news.google.com/newspapers&amp;source=newspapers">newspapers</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbs=bks:1&amp;q=%22David+Burris%22+-wikipedia">books</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22David+Burris%22">scholar</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/action/doBasicSearch?Query=%22David+Burris%22&amp;acc=on&amp;wc=on">JSTOR</a></span></small></span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">March 2016</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span id="Early_film_work_in_New_York_.281990-1995.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_film_work_in_New_York_(1990-1995)">Early film work in New York (1990-1995)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Burris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Early film work in New York (1990-1995)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Burris moved to New York after college where he worked on a number of films for such NY indie-film scene notables as <a href="/wiki/Abel_Ferrara" title="Abel Ferrara">Abel Ferrara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jim_Jarmusch" title="Jim Jarmusch">Jim Jarmusch</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Paul_Auster" title="Paul Auster">Paul Auster</a>. In 1992 he produced the short film <i>Howard Black</i> starring <a href="/wiki/John_C._Reilly" title="John C. Reilly">John C. Reilly</a>, followed by <i>The Side of the Road</i> in 1994, starring <a href="/wiki/Jared_Harris" title="Jared Harris">Jared Harris</a> and Stephen Gevedon.
</p>
<h3><span id="Musical_work_.281992-2002.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Musical_work_(1992-2002)">Musical work (1992-2002)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Burris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Musical work (1992-2002)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 1992 Burris hooked up with childhood friends Danny and Daniel Chavis and Marvin Levy to join Mercury/Polygram recording artists and soulful, shoegaze innovators The Veldt for their major label debut Afrodisiac. This led to numerous tours of the country, most notably with British ethereal rock legends <a href="/wiki/Cocteau_Twins" title="Cocteau Twins">The Cocteau Twins</a>. Burris left the band as a full-time member in 1995 but continues to perform with the band when called upon.
</p><p>In 1996 Burris formed the atmospheric American rock band Jolene with first cousin John Crooke. After four albums and multiple tours of Europe, The United Kingdom and the US, the band has taken an "extended break" since playing a final show at the classic London venue The Borderline in 2002 – a fledgling iteration of the band <a href="/wiki/Bloc_Party" title="Bloc Party">Bloc Party</a> opened the show. Jolene songs penned by Burris feature on the soundtracks of the films <a href="/wiki/Election_(1999_film)" title="Election (1999 film)">Election</a> and <a href="/wiki/A_Simple_Plan_(film)" title="A Simple Plan (film)">A Simple Plan</a>.
</p>
<h3><span id="TV_work_-_Los_Angeles_.281999-present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="TV_work_-_Los_Angeles_(1999-present)">TV work - Los Angeles (1999-present)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Burris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: TV work - Los Angeles (1999-present)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 1999 Burris moved to Los Angeles and took a job writing on the SyFy/USA series <a href="/wiki/Good_vs_Evil_(TV_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="Good vs Evil (TV series)"><i>Good vs. Evil</i></a> with fellow Carolinians <a href="/wiki/Jonas_Pate" title="Jonas Pate">Jonas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Josh_Pate" title="Josh Pate">Josh Pate</a>.
</p><p>Burris eventually moved on to the CBS blockbuster series <a href="/wiki/Survivor_(TV_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="Survivor (TV series)"><i>Survivor</i></a> where he began as a supervising producer before taking on the role of "Show Runner" as the program's Executive Producer.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> In his time there he created hundreds of hours of TV and filmed on location in dozens of countries around the world.
</p>
<h3><span id="Film_work_.282013_.E2.80.93_present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Film_work_(2013_–_present)">Film work (2013 – present)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Burris&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Film work (2013 – present)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 2013 Burris returned to the world of feature film. He directed and produced <i>The World Made Straight</i>, an adaptation of <a href="/wiki/Ron_Rash" title="Ron Rash">Ron Rash</a>'s award-winning <a href="/wiki/The_World_Made_Straight" title="The World Made Straight">novel of the same name</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> Burris' producing partners on the picture were fellow North Carolina natives Todd Labarowski of Dreambridge Films and Michael Wrenn (currently based in Sydney). Shot entirely on location in the mountains around Asheville, North Carolina, the film stars <a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Irvine" title="Jeremy Irvine">Jeremy Irvine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Noah_Wyle" title="Noah Wyle">Noah Wyle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Minka_Kelly" title="Minka Kelly">Minka Kelly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adelaide_Clemens" title="Adelaide Clemens">Adelaide Clemens</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Earle" title="Steve Earle">Steve Earle</a> and <a href="/wiki/Haley_Joel_Osment" title="Haley Joel Osment">Haley Joel Osment</a>. It was released theatrically in 2015 by Millennium Entertainment.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a> calls the World Made Straight "a coming-of-age story in which codes and vendettas loom larger than the outside world."<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/New_York_Post" title="New York Post">The New York Post</a> describes the film as "Southern noir with literary heft" and having "a neo-Faulknerian atmosphere of indelible sin in a story that rises above cliché..."<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> The film's soundtrack features a score by NC psych-folk band <a href="/wiki/Megafaun" title="Megafaun">Megafaun</a> and songs from <a href="/wiki/Ellie_Goulding" title="Ellie Goulding">Ellie Goulding</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Frames" title="The Frames">The Frames</a>, <a href="/wiki/Algia_Mae_Hinton" title="Algia Mae Hinton">Algia Mae Hinton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Susan_Cowsill" title="Susan Cowsill">Susan Cowsill</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Connells" title="The Connells">The Connells</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hotel_Lights" title="Hotel Lights">Hotel Lights</a> and others.
</p><p>Burris is currently developing an adaptation of Nic Brown's novel <i>Doubles</i> and an original screenplay by Miles Ross, <i>The Golden Rule</i>.
</p>

</p>
<table class="infobox vcard plainlist" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;background-color: #f4bf92"><div style="display:inline;" class="fn">Terry Burrus</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Terry_Burrus.jpg" class="image" title="Terry Burrus"><img alt="Terry Burrus" 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1920" /></a><div>Terry Burrus</div></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color: #f4bf92">Background information</th></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Birth name</span></th><td class="nickname">Terrance Corley Burrus</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><a href="/wiki/Brooklyn,_New_York" class="mw-redirect" title="Brooklyn, New York">Brooklyn, New York</a>, United States</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Genres</th><td>Pop, rock, R&amp;B,  <a href="/wiki/Electro_music" class="mw-redirect" title="Electro music">electro</a>, <a href="/wiki/House_music" title="House music">house</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soul_music" title="Soul scope="row">Instruments</th><td class="note">Keyboards</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Labels</th><td><a href="/wiki/Ichiban_Records" title="Ichiban Records">Ichiban</a>, <a href="/wiki/EMI_Records" title="EMI Records">Ichiban-EMI</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arista_Records" title="Arista Records">Arista</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zakia_Records&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zakia Records (page does not exist)">Bee Pee</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Easystreet_Records&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Easystreet Records (page does not exist)">Easystreet</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Blue_Corner_Records&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blue Corner Records (page does not exist)">Blue Corner</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lovelight_Records&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lovelight Records (page does not exist)">Lovelight</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Website</th><td><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.terryburrus.com">www<wbr />.terryburrus<wbr />.com</a></span></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Terrance Corley Burrus</b> is an American keyboardist, composer, record producer, conductor, business, realty and fashion designer executive.
</p><p>Born in <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a>, New York, he started touring as a teenager playing with jazz fusion violinist <a href="/wiki/Micha%C5%82_Urbaniak" title="Michał Urbaniak">Michał Urbaniak</a> and singer <a href="/wiki/Jean_Carne" class="mw-redirect" title="Jean Carne">Jean Carne</a>, while still in high school in New York. At that time Burrus replaced Urbaniak's keyboardist Barry Eastman (who wrote "You Are My Lady" years later for <a href="/wiki/Freddie_Jackson" title="Freddie Jackson">Freddie Jackson</a>). Burrus was brought to Jean Carne through percussionist-producer Norman Hedman who was one of Burrus's musical mentors as a child. Later on through these types of associations, Burrus went on to play with trumpeter <a href="/wiki/Tom_Browne_(trumpeter)" title="Tom Browne (trumpeter)">Tom Browne</a>, drummer <a href="/wiki/Lenny_White" title="Lenny White">Lenny White</a> and singer <a href="/wiki/Melba_Moore" title="Melba Moore">Melba Moore</a>. Recommended by his friend pianist <a href="/wiki/Kenny_Kirkland" title="Kenny Kirkland">Kenny Kirkland</a>, who was the keyboardist for <a href="/wiki/Sting_(musician)" title="Sting (musician)">Sting</a> during the mid-1980s, Burrus had moved on to play with the great <a href="/wiki/Lena_Horne" title="Lena Horne">Lena Horne</a> in her award-winning show <i>Lady and Her Music</i> in 1984. Her band comprised Terry on piano and keyboards, Ben Brown on bass, <a href="/wiki/Rodney_Jones_(guitarist)" title="Rodney Jones (guitarist)">Rodney Jones</a> on guitar, Wilby Fletcher on drums, along with music director Linda Twine and an array of musicians including the <a href="/wiki/London_Symphony_Orchestra" title="London Symphony Orchestra">London Symphony Orchestra</a>. While still playing for artists, Burrus was releasing solo recordings and concertizing on his own.
</p><p>In 1983 Terry released his first solo single, called "Love Rockin'", for <a href="/wiki/Arista_Records" title="Arista Records">Arista Records</a> a funk/electro/soul piece written and with all vocals and instruments by Burrus, with high-school buddy <a href="/wiki/Omar_Hakim" title="Omar Hakim">Omar Hakim</a> drumming. This was known as Terry Burrus And Transe, produced by Burrus and <a href="/wiki/Marcus_Miller" title="Marcus Miller">Marcus Miller</a>, another high-school friend. Burrus and Miller, along with drummer Poogie Bell, <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Broom" title="Bobby Broom">Bobby Broom</a>, another high-school guitar friend, and <a href="/wiki/Bernard_Wright" title="Bernard Wright">Bernard Wright</a> (also a high-school companion) went on to play for an off-Broadway show written by <a href="/wiki/Weldon_Irvine" title="Weldon Irvine">Weldon Irvine</a> in 1977 called <i>Young Gifted And Broke</i> at the <a href="/wiki/Billie_Holiday" title="Billie Holiday">Billie Holiday</a> Theater in <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a>, New York. Irvine had co-written with <a href="/wiki/Nina_Simone" title="Nina Simone">Nina Simone</a> the famed song "<a href="/wiki/To_Be_Young,_Gifted_and_Black" title="To Be Young, Gifted and Black">To Be Young, Gifted and Black</a>". <a href="/wiki/Return_To_Forever" class="mw-redirect" title="Return To Forever">Return To Forever</a>'s drummer,and <a href="/wiki/Jazz_fusion" title="Jazz fusion">jazz fusion</a> pioneer <a href="/wiki/Lenny_White" title="Lenny White">Lenny White</a> joined the "Young Gifted And Broke" crew of musicians as a second and replacement drummer for Poogie Bell at times, during the post <a href="/wiki/Chick_Corea" title="Chick Corea">Chick Corea</a> Return to Forever season.
</p><p>As time went on Terry became a highly respected and successful recording session man, playing on recordings of <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson" title="Michael Jackson">Michael Jackson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toni_Braxton" title="Toni Braxton">Toni Braxton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Janet_Jackson" title="Janet Jackson">Janet Jackson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swing_Out_Sister" title="Swing Out Sister">Swing Out Sister</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mariah_Carey" title="Mariah Carey">Mariah Carey</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Cardigans" title="The Cardigans">The Cardigans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donna_Summer" title="Donna Summer">Donna Summer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lisa_Stansfield" title="Lisa Stansfield">Lisa Stansfield</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gloria_Estefan" title="Gloria Estefan">Gloria Estefan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aretha_Franklin" title="Aretha Franklin">Aretha Franklin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phyllis_Hyman" title="Phyllis Hyman">Phyllis Hyman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frankie_Knuckles" title="Frankie Knuckles">Frankie Knuckles</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Morales" title="David Morales">David Morales</a>, <a href="/wiki/Satoshi_Tomiie" title="Satoshi Tomiie">Satoshi Tomiie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Todd_Terry" title="Todd Terry">Todd Terry</a> and others. Being no stranger to synthesizers and electronic sounds, Burrus is said to own just about every electric keyboard that has come out since the <a href="/wiki/Wurlitzer" title="Wurlitzer">Wurlitzer</a> electric piano. In addition Burrus has always been intrigued by the great <a href="/wiki/Classical_music" title="Classical music">classical</a> masters, having studied the artistry of <a href="/wiki/Mozart" class="mw-redirect" title="Mozart">Mozart</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beethoven" class="mw-redirect" title="Beethoven">Beethoven</a>, <a href="/wiki/Handel" class="mw-redirect" title="Handel">Handel</a> and others during his school days in New York, and in his contemporary piano compositions and playing can be heard classical influences. He performs many classical piano recitals around the world as well playing as in the jazz and pop genres.
</p><p>Burrus has been sideman/music director on many tours of Jazz Explosion, as they were known in the 1980s and '90s, as well as on soul and gospel concerts with the Harlem Gospel Singers, <a href="/wiki/Lionel_Hampton" title="Lionel Hampton">Lionel Hampton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gato_Barbieri" title="Gato Barbieri">Gato Barbieri</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Benson" title="George Benson">George Benson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Angela_Bofill" title="Angela Bofill">Angela Bofill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Larry_Carlton" title="Larry Carlton">Larry Carlton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bill_Withers" title="Bill Withers">Bill Withers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ramsey_Lewis" title="Ramsey Lewis">Ramsey Lewis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crown_Heights_Affair" title="Crown Heights Affair">Crown Heights Affair</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chaka_Khan" title="Chaka Khan">Chaka Khan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ronnie_Laws" title="Ronnie Laws">Ronnie Laws</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Main_Ingredient_(band)" title="The Main Ingredient (band)">The Main Ingredient</a>, <a href="/wiki/Johnny_Kemp" title="Johnny Kemp">Johnny Kemp</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Clarke" title="Stanley Clarke">Stanley Clarke</a>, <a href="/wiki/Noel_Pointer" title="Noel Pointer">Noel Pointer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bobbi_Humphrey" title="Bobbi Humphrey">Bobbi Humphrey</a>, Sherry Winston. Burrus also wrote and produced with the president of <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_International_Records" title="Philadelphia International Records">Philadelphia International Records</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kenny_Gamble" class="mw-redirect" title="Kenny Gamble">Kenny Gamble</a>, including "Living In Confusion" and "Forever With You" for Phyllis Hyman. Burrus wrote "I Just Love You So Much" for <a href="/wiki/Billy_Paul" title="Billy Paul">Billy Paul</a> and wrote/produced "Love Goddess" for <a href="/wiki/Lonnie_Liston_Smith" title="Lonnie Liston Smith">Lonnie Liston Smith</a>. Burrus also wrote and produced "I'll Wait for You" and "The One And Only Lady In My Life" for Virgin recording group Burrell, among a long list of other compositions and productions to his credit.
</p><p>With contributions to the many remixes of artists from the 1980s and '90s to the present day, reinforcing the sound of <a href="/wiki/House_music" title="House music">house music</a> and <a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">electronic music</a>, his early associations working with Def Mix Productions, Frankie Knuckles, David Morales, Satoshi Tomei and Todd Terry, <a href="/wiki/Junior_Vasquez" title="Junior Vasquez">Junior Vasquez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_Simpson_(musician)" title="Paul Simpson (musician)">Paul Simpson</a>, Winston Jones, Dave Shaw, <a href="/wiki/Jellybean_Benitez" class="mw-redirect" title="Jellybean Benitez">Jellybean Benitez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tony_Humphries_(musician)" title="Tony Humphries (musician)">Tony Humphries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_K" class="mw-redirect" title="François K">François K</a> and many other international and American DJ producers have rooted him well on the dance-floor and in the remix world. Burrus has created sounds in <a href="/wiki/Electronica" title="Electronica">electronica</a> that he has extended into the world of <a href="/wiki/Techno" title="Techno">Techno</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trance_music" title="Trance music">Trance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ambient_music" title="Ambient music">Ambient</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_music" title="World music">World music</a> and more, his piano style especially being prevalent and dominant in the 1990s on many recordings by well known and new artists around the world. From his teenage days as a <a href="/wiki/Jazz_fusion" title="Jazz fusion">jazz fusionist</a> to <a href="/wiki/Funk" title="Funk">funkster</a> to house and electronica pioneer, Burrus has been an ambassador of electronic music.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<ul>

</li>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Terry_Burrus&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Terry Burrus's interest in the organ and piano began at the age of five in Brooklyn at the Washington Temple Church Of God In Christ, a Pentecostal church under the founder Pastor Bishop F.D. Washington. Terry's mother Carter Lee and father James had been singing in the choir there since the mid-1950s. By the time Terry was five his parents enrolled him at the Alfred Miller Music school where he excelled to the point where he was playing gospel hymns a year or so later.
</p><p>He went on to study music in New York City at the La Guardia School of Arts (formerly known as Music and Art) and later attended <a href="/wiki/Long_Island_University" title="Long Island University">Long Island University</a> in New York. All the while he was recording in his personal and public recording studios as well as playing concerts worldwide as a sideman with Jean Carne, Michael Urbaniak, Tom Browne, <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Turrentine" title="Stanley Turrentine">Stanley Turrentine</a>, Lenny White, Lena Horne, Phyllis Hyman, Crown Heights Affair and The Main Ingredient with <a href="/wiki/Cuba_Gooding,_Sr." class="mw-redirect" title="Cuba Gooding, Sr.">Cuba Gooding</a>. Terry Burrus always credits <a href="/wiki/Sticks_Evans" title="Sticks Evans">Sticks Evans</a>, his junior high-school music teacher at John Coleman I.S.271 Junior High School in Brooklyn, for giving him encouragement and inspiration as a youngster. Stick Evans played drums for <a href="/wiki/Aretha_Franklin" title="Aretha Franklin">Aretha Franklin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sammy_Davis,_Jr." class="mw-redirect" title="Sammy Davis, Jr.">Sammy Davis, Jr.</a> Apart from being his teacher and mentor, Stick Evans regarded Terry as a little brother or even a son, and it was through this relationship that Burrus acquired strength to go on in the music world in life. In the late 1980s Burrus even took a newly built apartment in mid-Manhattan, in the area where Evans lived for many years until his death in the early '90s.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Discography">Discography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Terry_Burrus&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Discography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="As_a_leader">As a leader</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Terry_Burrus&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: As a leader">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li><i>Bust It Out</i> (1989; Easystreet)</li>
<li><i>Dance to the Mix</i> (EP) (1990; Easystreet)</li>
<li><i>Urban Smooth Jazz</i> (2006; Ichiban)</li>
<li><i>Mighty Mouth Vavoom</i> (1985; Zakia/Bee Pee)</li>
<li><i>Invisible Weapon</i> (1994; Startrak)</li>
<li><i>Love Rockin</i> (1983; Arista)</li>
<li><i>Nation 2 Nation</i> (1992; Ichiban)</li>
<li><i>Free Spirit</i> (1991; Ichiban-EMI)</li>
<li><i>Soul of Jazz</i> (1996; Ichiban)</li>
<li><i>I Am for You</i> (1996; Lovelight)</li>
<li><i>Acid Jazz Hipabop Project</i> (1994; Lovelight)</li>
<li><i>At the Konzerthaus in Dortmund</i> (2007; Blue Corner)</li>
<li><i>Global Dancefloor Booked</i> (2008; Lovelight)</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="As_a_sideman">As a sideman</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Terry_Burrus&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: As a sideman">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

<li>Lonnie Liston Smith - <i>Love Goddess</i> (1990; Startrak/Ichiban)</li>
<li>Tom Browne - <i>Yours Truly</i> (1981; GRP/Arista)</li>
<li>Michael Jackson - <i>You Are Not Alone</i> (1995; Epic)</li>
<li>Cardigans - <i>Love Fool</i> (1997; Motor/Mercury)</li>
<li>Mary J. Blige - <i>Everything</i> (1997; MCA/Universal)</li>
<li>Phyllis Hyman - <i>Prime of My Life</i> (1992; Zoo Entertainment)</li>

<table class="box-Primary_sources plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Primary_sources" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="Question book-new.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article <b>relies too much on <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">references</a> to <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources" title="Wikipedia:No original research">primary sources</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please improve this  by adding <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources" title="Wikipedia:No original research">secondary or tertiary sources</a>.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">December 2011</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><div class="fn" style="display:inline">William C. Burton</div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Nationality</th><td class="category">American</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Occupation</th><td class="role">Attorney and Lobbyist</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Employer</th><td class="org">Sagat l Burton</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Website</th><td><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://sagatburton.com/">http://sagatburton.com/</a>, <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.burtonawards.com/">http://www.burtonawards.com/</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>William C. Burton</b> is a partner in the <a href="/wiki/Law_firm" title="Law firm">law firm</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sagat_Burton_LLP&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sagat Burton LLP (page does not exist)">Sagat Burton LLP</a>, <a href="/wiki/Park_Avenue_(Manhattan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Park Avenue (Manhattan)">Park Avenue</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>. His practice is devoted primarily to <a href="/wiki/Lobbying" title="Lobbying">lobbying</a> for <a href="/wiki/Banking" class="mw-redirect" title="Banking">banking</a>, <a href="/wiki/Financial_services" title="Financial services">financial services</a> and <a href="/wiki/Insurance" title="Insurance">insurance</a> business interests.  As an attorney, Burton has contributed a substantial part of the past seventeen years to promoting the legal profession through his non-profit foundation. He is the author of the legal profession's first-ever legal thesaurus entitled <i>Burton's Legal Thesaurus</i>.  Burton served as New York State Assistant Attorney General, as well as an Assistant New York State Special Prosecutor.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2012)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Previously, Burton was Director of Government Affairs for one of the world's largest insurers, Continental Insurance. He was also a partner in the law firm of <a href="/w/index.php?title=D%27Amato_%26_Lynch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="D&#39;Amato &amp; Lynch (page does not exist)">D'Amato &amp; Lynch</a> LLP.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Early_life"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Early life</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#The_Burton_Foundation_and_Burton_Awards_Program"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">The Burton Foundation and Burton Awards Program</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Published_works"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Published works</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Awards"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Awards</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Education"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Education</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=William_C._Burton&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Burton grew up in Great Neck, New York, and now  resides in East Hills, New York. He  is married to Michele Burton and has two children: Brian, a lawyer married to Rebecca Pinkus; and Marni, a celebrity make-up artist engaged to Jarek Gabor.
</p><p>For the past 15 years, Burton has served as the Village attorney for East Hills, New York.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Burton_Foundation_and_Burton_Awards_Program">The Burton Foundation and Burton Awards Program</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=William_C._Burton&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: The Burton Foundation and Burton Awards Program">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In 1999, Burton established and funded the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Burton_Foundation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Burton Foundation (page does not exist)">Burton Foundation</a>, to promote the profession and practice of law. The foundation is a 501(c) (3), non-profit, academic organization. That same year, Burton founded "The Burton Awards Program" which honors and rewards the finest achievements in law. The Burton Awards is run in association with the Library of Congress, and in 2015 became co-sponsored by the American Bar Association. Each year, more than 50 leaders in law are honored at the Library of Congress in Washington, DC including professors, partners in the leading law firms, general counsel in the largest corporations in America, and members of the military. Many prominent jurists have been guest speakers, including the following United States Supreme Court Justices:  Justice Stephen Breyer, Justice <a href="/wiki/Antonin_Scalia" title="Antonin Scalia">Antonin Scalia</a>, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Justice Sonia Sotomayor and Justice John Paul Stevens. In the past, other dignitaries who have also spoken at the national awards program, included <a href="/wiki/Tom_Brokaw" title="Tom Brokaw">Tom Brokaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bob_Schieffer" title="Bob Schieffer">Bob Schieffer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tim_Russert" title="Tim Russert">Tim Russert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chris_Matthews" title="Chris Matthews">Chris Matthews</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Will" title="George Will">George Will</a>,  Jeffrey Toobin and master of ceremonies, <a href="/wiki/Bill_Press" title="Bill Press">Bill Press</a>. Performers have included Jay Leno, Kristen Chenoweth, Bernadette Peters, Katherine Jenkins and Vanessa Williams.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Burton is also credited with having established the Holmes Debates at the Library of Congress which featured a national debate between members of the United States Justice Department and renowned legal scholars on an issue confronting the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Published_works">Published works</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=William_C._Burton&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Published works">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul><li>Burton's Legal Thesaurus, 5th Edition, McGraw Hill</li></ul>
<p>Burton's Legal Thesaurus was declared "Leading Thesaurus in Law"In an in-depth empirical study, entitled "Beyond Black's and Webster's: The Persuasive Value of Thesauri in legal Research and Writing." Author Brian Craig affirmed "Burton's Legal Thesaurus as the leading legal thesaurus" based on the frequency of citations in written decisions by the Supreme Court and Federal and State Courts.
</p><p>In September 2013, Burton spoke at the National Book Fair in Washington, D.C. about the new fifth edition of his reference book. The newest edition celebrates the 35th anniversary since the book was first printed.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=William_C._Burton&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Awards">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In  2010, the <a href="/wiki/Legal_Writing_Institute" title="Legal Writing Institute">Legal Writing Institute</a> awarded Burton the Golden Pen Award, which is given to a recipient who has most significantly advanced the cause of better legal writing. The organization said that Burton was selected because he "has become one of the most listened to and melodic voices in the world of people who advocate for legal writing excellence."<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In June of that same year, the Friends of the Law Library of Congress presented Burton with the "Blackstone Award" for exemplifying the best objectives of the Law Library of Congress and advancing the mission and activities of the Law Library of Congress.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Roberta_I._Shaffer" title="Roberta I. Shaffer">Roberta I. Shaffer</a>, Associate Librarian of Congress said "Mr. Burton shares an unerring sense of legal excellence."<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2012)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>When "Burton's Legal Thesaurus" was published, The Association of Legal Publishers honored it as "One of the Most Innovative and Creative Projects of the Year." The fifth edition (<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r982806391">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-subscription,.mw-parser-output .cs1-registration{color:#555}.mw-parser-output .cs1-subscription span,.mw-parser-output .cs1-registration span{border-bottom:1px dotted;cursor:help}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output code.cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left,.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-wl-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right,.mw-parser-output (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0071818812" title="Special:BookSources/0071818812">0071818812</a>) of the book was released in 2013, celebrating its 35th anniversary.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=William_C._Burton&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Burton attended Long Island University and obtained a BA and MA. He received a scholarship to graduate school before attending Hofstra Law School.
He is admitted to both the New York and Florida Bars.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2012)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>

<table class="infobox vcard plainlist" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;background-color: #f0e68c"><div style="display:inline;" class="fn">Ron Cahute</div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td>1955 (age&#160;64&#8211;65)<br /><a href="/wiki/Toronto" title="Toronto">Toronto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Genres</th><td><a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">Folk</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Occupation(s)</span></th><td class="role">Singer, musician, songwriter</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Instruments</th><td class="note"><a href="/wiki/Accordion" title="Accordion">Accordion</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Associated acts</span></th><td>Burya</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Ron Cahute</b> (<a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>: <span lang="uk">Рoман Кoгут</span>) (born March 26, 1955 in <a href="/wiki/Toronto" title="Toronto">Toronto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a>) is a Ukrainian-Canadian recording artist and songwriter. He is an <a href="/wiki/Accordion" title="Accordion">accordion</a> player and founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian-Canadian" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian-Canadian">Ukrainian-Canadian</a> music band Burya (<a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>: <span lang="uk">Буря</span>) (English translation: Storm). He is an arranger, sound engineer, music producer, and musical director for Ukrainian dance ensembles in Toronto.
</p><p>Cahute began his music career in 1962 as a drummer in the band of his late father Maurice Cahute. In 1969, he founded a <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian-Canadian" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian-Canadian">Ukrainian-Canadian</a> music band, which was later called Burya.
</p><p>He released over 30 albums either with Burya or as a solo artist.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> As a guest performer with other music artists he has performed on 178 albums<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Cahute has performed with <a href="/wiki/Nana_Mouskouri" title="Nana Mouskouri">Nana Mouskouri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sofia_Rotaru" title="Sofia Rotaru">Sofia Rotaru</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lisa_Dalbello" class="mw-redirect" title="Lisa Dalbello">Lisa Dalbello</a>, <a href="/wiki/Melissa_Manchester" title="Melissa Manchester">Melissa Manchester</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Catherine_McKinnon" title="Catherine McKinnon">Catherine McKinnon</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Burya_musicians">Burya musicians</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ron_Cahute&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Burya musicians">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>In its 30+ year history the line-up of Burya musicians has included:
</p>
<ul><li>Ron Cahute: Accordion, Lead Vocals</li>
<li>Jaroslaw Hryhorsky: Violin, Viola, Trombone, Vocals, Percussion</li>
<li>Len Steciuk: Guitar, Fiddle, Vocals</li>
<li>Steve Krachko: Drums</li>
<li>Bill Hawryschuk: Drums</li>
<li>David Monis: Drums</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mark_Zubek" title="Mark Zubek">Mark Zubek</a>: Drums</li>
<li>Michael Monis: Guitar</li>
<li>Michael Romanick: Tenor Saxophone, Clarinet, Percussion</li>
<li>Tom Romanick: Saxophone</li>
<li>Ron Lutz: Alto &amp; Tenor Saxophone, Percussion</li>
<li>Frank Uhran: Tenor Saxophone, Clarinet, Percussion</li>
<li>John Lockwood: Flute</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Albums">Albums</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ron_Cahute&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Albums">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ron_Cahute_albums">Ron Cahute albums</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ron_Cahute&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Ron Cahute albums">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li>Хpиcтoc Paждaєтьcя (1988)</li>
<li>Ultimate Polka (1989)</li>
<li>Accordion Music - The Ron Cahute Collection</li>
<li>Українські Народні Танці (Traditional Ukrainian Folk Dance) (1993)</li>
<li>Canada's Ukrainian Festival (1997)</li>

<li>Ron Cahute Generic Volume 2 (1989)</li></ul>
