<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Recording_guest_appearances">Recording guest appearances</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ron_Cahute&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Recording guest appearances">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li>Played accordion on "Tango", <a href="/wiki/Lisa_Dalbello" class="mw-redirect" title="Lisa Dalbello">Lisa Dalbello</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/She_(Dalbello_album)" title="She (Dalbello album)">She</a>" album</li>
<li>Arranged, played keyboards, and co-produced "Paзoм - Visions" (1988)</li>
<li>Played accordion on "Sailor Song" by Sarah Lentz</li>
<li>Played accordion on "Heartbroken" by Keisha Prince</li>
<li>Played accordion on "Amsterdam" by Steve Wildesmith</li>
<li>Arranged, played all instruments, and co-produced "Bread for my brother" by Oksana</li>
<li>Arranged, played all instruments, and produced "Nostalgie Di Tutti I Tempi" by Vince Paparo</li>
<li>Arranged, played accordion, percussion, recorded and co-produced "Blossoming" by Voloshky (1996)</li>
<li>Arranged, played accordion, recorded and co-produced "Fantazia" by Voloshky (1999)</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ukrainian_comedy_albums">Ukrainian comedy albums</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ron_Cahute&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Ukrainian comedy albums">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Ron Cahute has recorded Ukrainian comedy albums with Ihor Baczynskyj including:
</p>
<ul><li>...And the Garden Goes Here! (1997)</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Children_educational_albums">Children educational albums</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ron_Cahute&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Children educational albums">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Ron Cahute has recorded a series of children's educational albums with Ihor Baczynskyj and Jane Lapko including:
</p>
<ul><li>Barabolya (1997)</li>
<li>Borscht (1999)</li>
<li>Booryak and Carrots Too (1999)</li>
<li>Tsyboolya (1999)</li>
<li>Barabolya High (2000)</li>
<li>Poutine, Fries with an Attitude (2000)</li></ul>

<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">

padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">Membership  </div></th><td>120</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right:0.6em;"><div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">Official language </div></th><td>English</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right:0.6em;"><div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">Executive Directors</div></th><td>Karine Titizian <br /> Olivia Henderson</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right:0.6em;">Affiliations</th><td>Associated Students of the University of California (ASUC)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right:0.6em;">Website</th><td><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://caltv.berkeley.edu">caltv<wbr />.berkeley<wbr />.edu</a></span></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>CalTV</b> is the first and only student-run online television station at <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_Berkeley" title="University of California, Berkeley">University of California, Berkeley</a>, producing videos in news, sports, and entertainment. Since its founding, CalTV has grown into one of the largest student-run media organizations on the West Coast and is currently a chartered organization of the <a href="/wiki/Associated_Students_of_the_University_of_California" title="Associated Students of the University of California">Associated Students of the University of California (ASUC)</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=CalTV&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Although there had been multiple attempts to get a television station for Berkeley off the ground, it wasn't until Spring 2005 that the <a href="/wiki/Asuc" class="mw-redirect" title="Asuc">ASUC</a> was able to allocate sufficient seed money towards setting up an online TV network.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Technology">Technology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=CalTV&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Technology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>CalTV uses web and digital media technologies to produce its online broadcasts.  As its web platform, CalTV uses standards compliant and customized content management system coupled with the <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a>'s online video player. CalTV produces video content using a Canon 60D DSLR and <a href="/wiki/Adobe_Creative_Cloud" title="Adobe Creative Cloud">Adobe Creative Cloud</a> software running on <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple</a> <a href="/wiki/IMac_G5" title="IMac G5">iMac G5</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Content">Content</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=CalTV&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Content">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Seven different departments make up CalTV- four on-camera and three behind-the-scenes. They include:
</p><p><b>On-Camera</b>
</p>
<ul><li>News</li>
<li>Sports</li>
<li>Entertainment</li>
<li>Comedy</li></ul>
<p><b>Behind-the-Scenes</b>
</p>
<ul><li>Post-Production</li>
<li>Cinematography</li>
<li>Business/Advertising/Marketing (BAM)</li></ul>
<p>The station's content has evolved with time. In its first iteration, the station produced a single show focusing exclusively on news events (local, national and international) but produced in a <a href="/wiki/Citizen_journalism" title="Citizen journalism">citizen journalism</a> mode. The show featured brief backgrounds on stories introduced by CalTV journalists followed by opinion from Berkeley students and professors.
</p><p>With time, CalTV's content expanded into sports, arts and eventually entertainment. "The CalTV Sports Highlight" was born in 2006 and covered <a href="/w/index.php?title=California_football&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="California football (page does not exist)">California football</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cal_baseball&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cal baseball (page does not exist)">baseball</a>, water polo and much more. The semester of Spring 2007 marked the debut of "The CalTV Show", an off-beat news show offering a summary of local and national news as well as commentary on issues of concern to students.  "The CalTV Show" has now since been renamed "The CalBear Report."
</p><p>CalTV sports features high octane highlights of Cal sports action, including "The CalTV Sports Highlight" which airs every Monday.  Also included in the programming are CalTV sports' "Back and Forth" and "Sports Shorts."  "Back and Forth" resembles <a href="/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Pardon_the_Interruption" title="Pardon the Interruption">Pardon the Interruption</a> and features banter on all sports related topics from the <a href="/wiki/California_Golden_Bears_football" title="California Golden Bears football">Cal Football Team</a> to Women's Field Hockey.  "Sports Shorts" features updates on recent teams in action, as well as interviews with students on <a href="/wiki/Sproul_Plaza" title="Sproul Plaza">Sproul Plaza</a>. A new show, "Bear in Mind" has since also been added and cover many off-the-field stories on <a href="/wiki/Student_athlete" title="Student athlete">student athletes</a> and teams.
</p><p>CalTV News features many informative weekly shows including Berkeley Beat, CalConnect, InFocus, and Investigative Report.
</p><p>CalTV debuted its Entertainment programming in 2010 when the former Music Department officially changed its name to Entertainment.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Special_events">Special events</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=CalTV&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Special events">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>CalTV has also been involved in the coverage of many on-campus and off-campus special events. These events included exclusive interviews with such celebrities as:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Jesse_Eisenberg" title="Jesse Eisenberg">Jesse Eisenberg</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Andrew_Garfield" title="Andrew Garfield">Andrew Garfield</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Channing_Tatum" title="Channing Tatum">Channing Tatum</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Michael_Moore" title="Michael Moore">Michael Moore</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Danny_Boyle" title="Danny Boyle">Danny Boyle</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Morgan_Spurlock" title="Morgan Spurlock">Morgan Spurlock</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ryan_Reynolds" title="Ryan Reynolds">Ryan Reynolds</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Chelsea_Clinton" title="Chelsea Clinton">Chelsea Clinton</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/John_C._Reilly" title="John C. Reilly">John C. Reilly</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Jason_Reitman" title="Jason Reitman">Jason Reitman</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Roland_Emmerich" title="Roland Emmerich">Roland Emmerich</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Michel_Gondry" title="Michel Gondry">Michel Gondry</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Will_Ferrell" title="Will Ferrell">Will Ferrell</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Conan_O%27Brien" title="Conan O&#39;Brien">Conan O'Brien</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Adam_Sandler" title="Adam Sandler">Adam Sandler</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Woody_Harrelson" title="Woody Harrelson">Woody Harrelson</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/David_Schwimmer" title="David Schwimmer">David Schwimmer</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Don_Cheadle" title="Don Cheadle">Don Cheadle</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Jerry_Seinfeld" title="Jerry Seinfeld">Jerry Seinfeld</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Regina_King" title="Regina King">Regina King</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Emile_Hirsch" title="Emile Hirsch">Emile Hirsch</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Viggo_Mortensen" title="Viggo Mortensen">Viggo Mortensen</a></li>
<li>The cast of <a href="/wiki/Hot_Rod_(2007_film)" title="Hot Rod (2007 film)"><i>Hot Rod</i></a></li>
<li>The cast of <a href="/wiki/Superbad_(film)" title="Superbad (film)"><i>Superbad</i></a></li>
<li>The cast of Comedy Central's <i><a href="/wiki/Reno_911!" title="Reno 911!">Reno 911!</a></i></li>
<li>California First Lady <a href="/wiki/Maria_Shriver" title="Maria Shriver">Maria Shriver</a></li>
<li>Former CBS anchor <a href="/wiki/Dan_Rather" title="Dan Rather">Dan Rather</a></li>
<li>CNN Sr. Medical Correspondent <a href="/wiki/Sanjay_Gupta" title="Sanjay Gupta">Sanjay Gupta</a></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Funding">Funding</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=CalTV&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Funding">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>CalTV has been supported in a large way by the <a href="/wiki/Associated_Students_of_the_University_of_California" title="Associated Students of the University of California">Associated Students of the University of California</a> (ASUC). CalTV also works closely with <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://bigideas.berkeley.edu/">Big Ideas @ Berkeley</a>, an initiative that provides funding, support, and encouragement to interdisciplinary teams at UC Berkeley. The station has also been exploring revenue generation through ads and promotional activities.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Footage">Footage</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=CalTV&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Footage">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>CalTV's footage has been featured on numerous media outlets including:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/KTVU" title="KTVU">KTVU</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Russia_Today" class="mw-redirect" title="Russia Today">Russia Today</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Colbert_Report" class="mw-redirect" title="Colbert Report">Colbert Report</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Rachel_Maddow" title="Rachel Maddow">Rachel Maddow</a> Blog</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Alumni">Alumni</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=CalTV&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Alumni">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>CalTV Alumni have gone on the work in the media industry for companies such as:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Creative_Artists_Agency" title="Creative Artists Agency">Creative Artists Agency</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/William_Morris_Endeavor" class="mw-redirect" title="William Morris Endeavor">William Morris Endeavor</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/International_Creative_Management" class="mw-redirect" title="International Creative Management">International Creative Management</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pixar" title="Pixar">Pixar</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Disney_Animation" class="mw-redirect" title="Disney Animation">Disney Animation</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Focus_Features" title="Focus Features">Focus Features</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Show" title="The Daily Show">The Daily Show</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Colbert_Report" class="mw-redirect" title="Colbert Report">Colbert Report</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/MSNBC" title="MSNBC">MSNBC</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/NPR" title="NPR">NPR</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pac-12_Network" title="Pac-12 Network">Pac-12 Network</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Recognition">Recognition</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=CalTV&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Recognition">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>CalTV has been recognized in local media. The Daily Cal, Berkeley's newspaper, published articles on CalTV <sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
The station has also gaining visibility in the Berkeley blogging community<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

</li>

</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="background:#003262; color:#FFFFFF; -moz-box-shadow: inset 2px 2px 0 #FDB515, inset -2px -2px 0 #FDB515; -webkit-box-shadow: inset 2px 2px 0 #FDB515, inset -2px -2px 0 #FDB515; box-shadow: inset 2px 2px 0 #FDB515, inset -2px -2px 0 #FDB515;;width:1%">Research</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">April 2019</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="infobox vcard plainlist" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;background-color: #f0e68c"><div style="display:inline;" class="fn">Cam'ron</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Cam%27ron_2014_(Cropped).jpg" class="image" title="Cam&#39;ron in April 2014"><img alt="Cam&#39;ron in April 2014" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Cam%27ron_2014_%28Cropped%29.jpg/220px-Cam%27ron_2014_%28Cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="456" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Cam%27ron_2014_%28Cropped%29.jpg/330px-Cam%27ron_2014_%28Cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Cam%27ron_2014_%28Cropped%29.jpg/440px-Cam%27ron_2014_%28Cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1116" data-file-height="2314" /></a><div>Cam'ron in April 2014</div></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color: #f0e68c">Background information</th></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Birth name</span></th><td class="nickname">Cameron Ezike Giles</td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Also known as</span></th><td class="nickname">Killa Cam</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><span style="display:none"> (<span class="bday">1976-02-04</span>) </span>February 4, 1976<span class="noprint ForceAgeToShow"> (age&#160;44)</span><br /><a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City,_New_York" class="mw-redirect" title="New York City, New York">New York City, New York</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">U.S.</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Genres</th><td><div class="hlist hlist-separated">

</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Occupation(s)</span></th><td class="role"><div class="hlist hlist-separated">
<ul><li>Rapper</li>

<li>actor</li>

<li>businessman</li>
<li>entrepreneur</li>
<li>philanthropist</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Years active</span></th><td>1993–present</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Labels</th><td><div class="hlist hlist-separated">
<ul><li>Killa</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Diplomat_Records" title="Diplomat Records">Diplomat Records</a></li>

</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Associated acts</span></th><td><div class="hlist hlist-separated">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/The_Diplomats" title="The Diplomats">Dipset</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Children_of_the_Corn_(group)" title="Children of the Corn (group)">Children of the Corn</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/AraabMuzik" title="AraabMuzik">AraabMuzik</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Wiz_Khalifa" title="Wiz Khalifa">Wiz Khalifa</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Cameron Ezike Giles</b> (born February 4, 1976<sup id="cite_ref-Curr_Bio_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Curr_Bio-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>), better known by his stage name <b>Cam'ron</b>, is an American rapper, record executive, and actor from <a href="/wiki/East_Harlem,_New_York" class="mw-redirect" title="East Harlem, New York">East Harlem, New York</a>. Beginning his career in the mid-1990s as <b>Killa Cam</b>, Giles signed to <a href="/wiki/Lance_Rivera" title="Lance Rivera">Lance "Un" Rivera</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Lance_Rivera" title="Lance Rivera">Untertainment</a> under the aegis of <a href="/wiki/Epic_Records" title="Epic Records">Epic</a> and released his first two studio albums <a href="/wiki/Confessions_of_Fire" title="Confessions of Fire">Confessions of Fire</a> and <a href="/wiki/S.D.E._(album)" title="S.D.E. (album)">S.D.E. (Sports Drugs &amp; Entertainment)</a> in 1998 and 2000 respectively; the former achieved <a href="/wiki/Gold_certification" class="mw-redirect" title="Gold certification">Gold</a> status by the <a href="/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America" title="Recording Industry Association of America">RIAA</a>. After demanding his release from Epic, Giles signed to <a href="/wiki/Roc-A-Fella_Records" title="Roc-A-Fella Records">Roc-A-Fella Records</a> in 2001 and released his third studio album <i><a href="/wiki/Come_Home_with_Me" title="Come Home with Me">Come Home with Me</a></i> the following year; it achieved <a href="/wiki/Platinum_certification" class="mw-redirect" title="Platinum certification">Platinum</a> status by the RIAA, and also contained Cam'ron's highest-charting singles to date; "<a href="/wiki/Oh_Boy_(Cam%27ron_song)" title="Oh Boy (Cam&#39;ron song)">Oh Boy</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Hey_Ma_(Cam%27ron_song)" title="Hey Ma (Cam&#39;ron song)">Hey Ma</a>", which peaked at #4 and #3 on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">Billboard Hot 100</a>, respectively. His fourth studio album and final release on Roc-A-Fella, <i><a href="/wiki/Purple_Haze_(album)" title="Purple Haze (album)">Purple Haze</a></i> was released in 2004 to critical acclaim and commercial success, being certified <a href="/wiki/Gold_certification" class="mw-redirect" title="Gold certification">gold</a> by the RIAA.
</p><p>After separating his label, <a href="/wiki/Diplomat_Records" title="Diplomat Records">Diplomat Records</a> from Roc-A-Fella in 2005 due to disagreements between himself and label-head <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a>, Cam'ron signed the label to a distribution deal with <a href="/wiki/Asylum_Records" title="Asylum Records">Asylum Records</a>. In 2006 Cam'ron released his fifth studio album, <i><a href="/wiki/Killa_Season" title="Killa Season">Killa Season</a></i>, which contained a <a href="/wiki/Killa_Season_(film)" title="Killa Season (film)">film of the same name</a>, in which Cam'ron made his director-screenwriter debut and starred as the main character. In 2009, after taking a hiatus due to his mother's health, Cam'ron returned to music and released his sixth studio album <i><a href="/wiki/Crime_Pays_(Cam%27ron_album)" title="Crime Pays (Cam&#39;ron album)">Crime Pays</a></i>. It reached number 3 on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200">Billboard 200</a>.
</p><p>Aside from his solo career, he is the leader of <a href="/wiki/The_Diplomats" title="The Diplomats">The Diplomats</a> (also known as Dipset), a group he formed in 1997 with his childhood friend <a href="/wiki/Jim_Jones_(rapper)" title="Jim Jones (rapper)">Jim Jones</a> and his cousin <a href="/wiki/Freekey_Zekey" title="Freekey Zekey">Freekey Zekey</a>. He was also one half of the duo <a href="/wiki/U.N._(group)" title="U.N. (group)">U.N.</a> (Us Now), and a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Children_of_the_Corn_(group)" title="Children of the Corn (group)">Children of the Corn</a> before they disbanded in 1997. Giles has also occasionally worked as an actor, starring in the <a href="/wiki/Roc-A-Fella_Records" title="Roc-A-Fella Records">Roc-A-Fella</a> films <i><a href="/wiki/Paper_Soldiers" title="Paper Soldiers">Paper Soldiers</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Paid_in_Full_(2002_film)" title="Paid in Full (2002 film)">Paid in Full</a></i> in 2002.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biography">Biography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Biography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span id="1976.E2.80.9397:_Early_life_and_career_beginnings"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1976–97:_Early_life_and_career_beginnings">1976–97: Early life and career beginnings</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: 1976–97: Early life and career beginnings">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Giles was born on February 4, 1976 and raised in East Harlem.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> He was raised by his mother, Fredericka Giles. He went to school at the <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Center_for_Science_and_Mathematics" title="Manhattan Center for Science and Mathematics">Manhattan Center for Science and Mathematics</a>, where he met his longtime friends <a href="/wiki/Mase" title="Mase">Mase</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jim_Jones_(rapper)" title="Jim Jones (rapper)">Jim Jones</a>. He was a promising basketball player alongside Mase, however, he was unable to take advantage of scholarship offers due to his poor academic standing. Instead, he enrolled in a college in Texas, without even graduating from high school, but soon dropped out and returned to Harlem where he began selling drugs before starting his rap career. Giles was eventually introduced to <a href="/wiki/The_Notorious_B.I.G." title="The Notorious B.I.G.">The Notorious B.I.G.</a> through his childhood friend Mase. BIG introduced Giles to <a href="/wiki/Lance_Rivera" title="Lance Rivera">Lance Rivera</a>, who signed him to his label, Untertainment.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>He began his musical career in the mid-1990s, rapping alongside <a href="/wiki/Big_L_(rapper)" class="mw-redirect" title="Big L (rapper)">Big L</a>, Mase, and his cousin Bloodshed, in a group called <a href="/wiki/Children_of_the_Corn_(band)" class="mw-redirect" title="Children of the Corn (band)">Children Of The Corn</a>. After Bloodshed's death in a car accident on March 2, 1997, the group disbanded and the remaining members pursued solo careers.
</p>
<h3><span id="1998.E2.80.932002:_Confessions_of_Fire.2C_S.D.E._and_Come_Home_with_Me"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1998–2002:_Confessions_of_Fire,_S.D.E._and_Come_Home_with_Me">1998–2002: <i>Confessions of Fire</i>, <i>S.D.E.</i> and <i>Come Home with Me</i></span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: 1998–2002: Confessions of Fire, S.D.E. and Come Home with Me">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Two years before Big L's murder in 1999, Cam'ron was introduced to <a href="/wiki/The_Notorious_B.I.G." title="The Notorious B.I.G.">The Notorious B.I.G.</a> by Mase who was signed to <a href="/wiki/Bad_Boy_Records" title="Bad Boy Records">Bad Boy Records</a> at the time. Biggie was so impressed by Cam'ron that he introduced him to his partner Lance "Un" Rivera who signed Cam'ron to his Untertainment label, distributed by Epic Records. His debut album, <i>Confessions of Fire</i>, was released a year later in July 1998 and included singles such as "3-5-7" (which was also featured in the movie <a href="/wiki/Woo_(film)" title="Woo (film)">Woo</a>), and "Horse and Carriage" featuring Mase, which reached the R&amp;B Top Ten. The album achieved gold status and made the Top 10 of both the pop and R&amp;B charts.
</p><p>In 2000, Cam'ron was working with music executive <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Mottola" title="Tommy Mottola">Tommy Mottola</a> and released his second album <i><a href="/wiki/S.D.E._(album)" title="S.D.E. (album)">S.D.E. (Sports Drugs &amp; Entertainment)</a></i> on Sony/Epic Records. With features from <a href="/wiki/Destiny%27s_Child" title="Destiny&#39;s Child">Destiny's Child</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juelz_Santana" title="Juelz Santana">Juelz Santana</a>, Jim Jones, <a href="/wiki/N.O.R.E." title="N.O.R.E.">N.O.R.E.</a>, and producer Digga, it included the relatively successful singles, "Let Me Know" and "What Means The World To You". The album reached Number 2 on the R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Albums chart, and Number 14 on the Billboard 200.
</p><p>After demanding a release from Sony/Epic Records, Cam'ron signed with his childhood friend and new manager <a href="/wiki/Damon_Dash" title="Damon Dash">Damon Dash</a> to <a href="/wiki/Roc-A-Fella_Records" title="Roc-A-Fella Records">Roc-A-Fella Records</a> in 2001, alongside artists such as <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beanie_Sigel" title="Beanie Sigel">Beanie Sigel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freeway_(rapper)" title="Freeway (rapper)">Freeway</a> and <a href="/wiki/Memphis_Bleek" title="Memphis Bleek">Memphis Bleek</a>. A reported $4.5 million record deal was agreed upon with and Damon Dash and his Roc-A-Fella partners Kareem Biggs and Jay-Z in the form of a record advance.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> His third and most successful album <i>Come Home with Me</i> was released in 2002 featuring guests such as Jay-Z, <a href="/wiki/Beanie_Sigel" title="Beanie Sigel">Beanie Sigel</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Memphis_Bleek" title="Memphis Bleek">Memphis Bleek</a>, and production from <a href="/wiki/Just_Blaze" title="Just Blaze">Just Blaze</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kanye_West" title="Kanye West">Kanye West</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Heatmakerz" title="The Heatmakerz">The Heatmakerz</a>. It included the hit singles "<a href="/wiki/Oh_Boy_(Cam%27ron_song)" title="Oh Boy (Cam&#39;ron song)">Oh Boy</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Hey_Ma_(Cam%27ron_song)" title="Hey Ma (Cam&#39;ron song)">Hey Ma</a>", which both featured <a href="/wiki/The_Diplomats" title="The Diplomats">The Diplomats</a> newest member <a href="/wiki/Juelz_Santana" title="Juelz Santana">Juelz Santana</a>. The album achieved platinum status and served as a stepping stone for Cam'ron's group <a href="/wiki/The_Diplomats" title="The Diplomats">The Diplomats</a> to sign with Roc-A-Fella.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2002, Cam'ron went on to appear in the <a href="/wiki/Damon_Dash" title="Damon Dash">Damon Dash</a> produced film, <i><a href="/wiki/Paid_in_Full_(2002_film)" title="Paid in Full (2002 film)">Paid in Full</a></i>, in which he played one of three main characters alongside <a href="/wiki/Mekhi_Phifer" title="Mekhi Phifer">Mekhi Phifer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wood_Harris" title="Wood Harris">Wood Harris</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> In 2006 he started shooting his movie for his album titled <i><a href="/wiki/Killa_Season_(film)" title="Killa Season (film)">Killa Season</a></i>; the film would mark both Cam'ron's screenwriting and directorial debuts, as well as his return to acting. Killa Season was released to DVD on April 25, 2006, after a special two-day theatrical release.<sup id="cite_ref-theatre_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-theatre-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="2003.E2.80.9309:_Purple_Haze.2C_Killa_Season_and_Crime_Pays"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2003–09:_Purple_Haze,_Killa_Season_and_Crime_Pays">2003–09: <i>Purple Haze</i>, <i>Killa Season</i> and <i>Crime Pays</i></span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: 2003–09: Purple Haze, Killa Season and Crime Pays">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 2003 Cam'ron teamed up with his fellow Diplomats Members <a href="/wiki/Jim_Jones_(rapper)" title="Jim Jones (rapper)">Jim Jones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juelz_Santana" title="Juelz Santana">Juelz Santana</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Freekey_Zeeky" class="mw-redirect" title="Freekey Zeeky">Freekey Zeeky</a> to release the <a href="/wiki/The_Diplomats" title="The Diplomats">Diplomats</a>' debut double disc album, <i><a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_Immunity_(The_Diplomats_album)" title="Diplomatic Immunity (The Diplomats album)">Diplomatic Immunity</a></i>, in 2003 under Roc-A-Fella/Diplomat Records, which was quickly certified <a href="/wiki/Oro_album" class="mw-redirect" title="Oro album">gold</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America" title="Recording Industry Association of America">RIAA</a>. The album featured the lead single "Dipset Anthem", a remix to Cam'rons hit "Hey Ma" and the (street anthem) single "I Really Mean It", as well as featuring production from <a href="/wiki/Kanye_West" title="Kanye West">Kanye West</a>, <a href="/wiki/Just_Blaze" title="Just Blaze">Just Blaze</a>, and <a href="/wiki/The_Heatmakerz" title="The Heatmakerz">The Heatmakerz</a>. A year later, the Diplomats released their second album, <i>Diplomatic Immunity 2</i>. Although not as successful as their debut, it still was boosted to <a href="/wiki/Oro_album" class="mw-redirect" title="Oro album">gold</a> status. Around this time in the height of his mainstream fame, Cam'ron was known for popularizing the color pink. During this period, Cam'ron was always seen wearing pink clothing and even bought an all-pink <a href="/wiki/Range_Rover" title="Range Rover">Range Rover</a>, which can be seen in his video for "Killa Cam".<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> Cam'ron's fourth studio album, <i><a href="/wiki/Purple_Haze_(album)" title="Purple Haze (album)">Purple Haze</a></i>, was released on December 7, 2004 on <a href="/wiki/Def_Jam" class="mw-redirect" title="Def Jam">Def Jam</a>/<a href="/wiki/Roc-A-Fella_Records" title="Roc-A-Fella Records">Roc-A-Fella Records</a>. It featured collaborations with Kanye West, <a href="/wiki/Jaheim" title="Jaheim">Jaheim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Twista" title="Twista">Twista</a>, Juelz Santana, and various other artists and ultimately reached gold status.<sup id="cite_ref-RIAA_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RIAA-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> The album was also a critical success, being ranked 114th on <a href="/wiki/Pitchfork_Media" class="mw-redirect" title="Pitchfork Media">Pitchfork Media</a>'s Top 200 Albums of the first decade of the 21st century List, and 10th on <a href="/wiki/Rhapsody_(online_music_service)" class="mw-redirect" title="Rhapsody (online music service)">Rhapsody</a>'s Hip Hop's Best Albums Of The Decade List. However, after feeling that the album was poorly promoted and that his projects were not receiving enough attention, Cam'ron requested his release from <a href="/wiki/Roc-A-Fella_Records" title="Roc-A-Fella Records">Roc-A-Fella Records</a>.
</p><p>On April 28, 2005, Cam'Ron officially joined the <a href="/wiki/Warner_Music_Group" title="Warner Music Group">Warner Music Group</a> under the Asylum Records imprint.<sup id="cite_ref-asylum_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-asylum-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> He began work on what would be his first project for the new label. Cam'ron's fifth studio album, titled <i><a href="/wiki/Killa_Season" title="Killa Season">Killa Season</a></i>, was released on May 16, 2006, featuring production from long-term collaborators The Heatmakerz, Charlmagne and <a href="/wiki/Ty_Fyffe" title="Ty Fyffe">Ty Fyffe</a>, as well as others such as <a href="/wiki/Alchemist" class="mw-redirect" title="Alchemist">Alchemist</a> and <a href="/wiki/I.N.F.O." title="I.N.F.O.">I.N.F.O.</a>. Along with the album, Cam'ron released his first film, in which he wrote, directed and starred in, also titled "Killa Season". Despite selling 112,000 units in the first week and debuting at number 2 on the charts, <i>Killa Season</i> failed to have the same sales strength as his two previous releases, but <i>Killa Season</i> became certified gold.
</p><p>After the release of <i>Killa Season</i> and his feud with <a href="/wiki/50_Cent" title="50 Cent">50 Cent</a> in 2007, Cam'ron took a three-year hiatus from music after his mother suffered three strokes which left her paralyzed on her left side. He moved to Florida with her to set up her rehabilitation and therapy, and stayed there until she had fully recovered.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> Cam'ron's 2009 album, <i><a href="/wiki/Crime_Pays_(Cam%27ron_album)" title="Crime Pays (Cam&#39;ron album)">Crime Pays</a></i> was released on Asylum/Diplomat Records, featuring the majority of the production handled by <a href="/wiki/Skitzo" title="Skitzo">Skitzo</a> and <a href="/wiki/AraabMuzik" title="AraabMuzik">AraabMuzik</a>. Although none of the singles from the album managed to chart, the album still reached number 3 on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200">Billboard 200</a> but only sold 150,000 units, making it the lowest selling album of his career. In 2009 Cam'ron formed a new label, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dipset_West&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dipset West (page does not exist)">Dipset West</a> and new group the <a href="/wiki/U.N._(group)" title="U.N. (group)">U.N.</a>.
</p>
<h3><span id="2010.E2.80.93present:_Mixtapes.2C_EPs.2C_and_collaborations"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2010–present:_Mixtapes,_EPs,_and_collaborations">2010–present: Mixtapes, EPs, and collaborations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: 2010–present: Mixtapes, EPs, and collaborations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In late 2009–early 2010, Cam'ron released a series of mixtapes hosted by <a href="/wiki/DJ_Drama" title="DJ Drama">DJ Drama</a> called <i>Boss of All Boses</i> which featured his new upcoming artist <a href="/wiki/Vado_(rapper)" title="Vado (rapper)">Vado</a>. Cam'ron also released a collaboration album with his new group the <a href="/wiki/U.N._(group)" title="U.N. (group)">U.N. (group)</a> which included himself and fellow <a href="/wiki/Harlem" title="Harlem">Harlem</a> rapper Vado titled <i><a href="/wiki/Heat_in_Here_Vol._1" title="Heat in Here Vol. 1">Heat in Here Vol. 1</a></i>; the first single off the album was "Speaking Tongues" which peaked at No. 82 on the <a href="/wiki/Hot_R%26B/Hip-Hop_Songs" title="Hot R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Songs">U.S. R&amp;B</a> charts. Cam'ron announced that he would be releasing a joint album with rapper Vado called <i><a href="/wiki/Gunz_n%27_Butta" title="Gunz n&#39; Butta">Gunz n' Butta</a></i>; on April 19, 2011, the album was released on <a href="/wiki/E1_Music" class="mw-redirect" title="E1 Music">E1 Music</a>. In 2013, Vado signed with <a href="/wiki/We_the_Best_Music_Group" title="We the Best Music Group">We the Best Music Group</a><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> after his personal friendship with Cam'ron eroded, although Vado maintained at the time that they still worked on a business level and had no animosity towards him.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> After three years Cam'ron and Jim Jones decided to mend their differences and start working together again for the third installment of the <i>Diplomatic Immunity</i> album along with fellow Diplomat members <a href="/wiki/Juelz_Santana" title="Juelz Santana">Juelz Santana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freekey_Zekey" title="Freekey Zekey">Freekey Zekey</a>. Cam'ron announced that <a href="/wiki/The_Diplomat" title="The Diplomat">The Diplomat</a> album's release would take place around Christmas 2010. The first promotional single featuring the reunited Diplomat members was titled "Salute"; it was produced by upcoming Diplomat producer <a href="/wiki/AraabMuzik" title="AraabMuzik">AraabMuzik</a>, though the track would later appear on <a href="/wiki/Jim_Jones_(rapper)" title="Jim Jones (rapper)">Jim Jones</a> album <i><a href="/wiki/Capo_(album)" title="Capo (album)">Capo</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2012 Cam'ron was featured on rapper/singer <a href="/wiki/Wiz_Khalifa" title="Wiz Khalifa">Wiz Khalifa</a>'s second studio album <i><a href="/wiki/O.N.I.F.C." title="O.N.I.F.C.">O.N.I.F.C.</a></i> on a song titled "The Bluff". Also In 2012 Cam'ron would be featured on rapper/singer <a href="/wiki/Nicki_Minaj" title="Nicki Minaj">Nicki Minaj</a>'s second studio album <i><a href="/wiki/Pink_Friday:_Roman_Reloaded" title="Pink Friday: Roman Reloaded">Pink Friday: Roman Reloaded</a></i> on a song titled "I Am Your Leader" along with rapper <a href="/wiki/Rick_Ross" title="Rick Ross">Rick Ross</a>.
</p><p>In 2013 during an interview Cam'ron discussed his seventh upcoming studio album <i>Killa Season 2</i> stating that it will feature guest appearances from <a href="/wiki/Dipset" class="mw-redirect" title="Dipset">Dipset</a>, <a href="/wiki/T.I." title="T.I.">T.I.</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nicki_Minaj" title="Nicki Minaj">Nicki Minaj</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wiz_Khalifa" title="Wiz Khalifa">Wiz Khalifa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> On October 1, 2013, Cam'ron released his promotional mixtape for the album titled <i>Ghetto Heaven Vol 1</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 2014, according to <i><a href="/wiki/Complex_Magazine" class="mw-redirect" title="Complex Magazine">Complex Magazine</a></i>, Cam'ron and <a href="/wiki/A-Trak" title="A-Trak">A-Trak</a> were to team up for a collaborative EP to be titled <i>Federal Reserve</i> which would be executive-produced by <a href="/wiki/Dame_Dash" class="mw-redirect" title="Dame Dash">Dame Dash</a> and have featured appearances by <a href="/wiki/Juelz_Santana" title="Juelz Santana">Juelz Santana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jim_Jones_(rapper)" title="Jim Jones (rapper)">Jim Jones</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> In May, they put out the first single from the album, titled "Dipsh*ts", featuring commentary from <a href="/wiki/Dame_Dash" class="mw-redirect" title="Dame Dash">Dame Dash</a> and <a href="/wiki/Juelz_Santana" title="Juelz Santana">Juelz Santana</a> on the hook and an accompanying official video. On February 11, 2014, Cam'ron along with fashion designer <a href="/wiki/Mark_McNairy" title="Mark McNairy">Mark McNairy</a> revealed their "<a href="/wiki/Cape" title="Cape">Cape</a> line" during New York fashion week.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> On October 20, 2014, via his Instagram Cam'ron revealed and released his "<a href="/wiki/Ebola" title="Ebola">Ebola</a> mask" stating on the caption "Ebola is no joking matter, so if u have to be safe, be fashionable".<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> Cam'ron also has a fashion clothing line titled "Dipset USA" which is branded off his former label Diplomat Records.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> On July 1, 2014, Cam'ron released his <i><a href="/wiki/1st_of_the_Month_Vol._1" title="1st of the Month Vol. 1">1st of the Month, Vol. 1</a></i> EP.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> On August 1, 2014 Cam'ron released his <i><a href="/wiki/1st_of_the_Month_Vol._2" title="1st of the Month Vol. 2">1st of the Month, Vol. 2</a></i> EP, it included the single "So Bad" featuring <a href="/wiki/Nicki_Minaj" title="Nicki Minaj">Nicki Minaj</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> On September 1, 2014 Cam'ron released his <i><a href="/wiki/1st_of_the_Month_Vol._3" title="1st of the Month Vol. 3">1st of the Month, Vol. 3</a></i> EP.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup> On October 1, 2014, Cam'ron released his <i><a href="/wiki/1st_of_the_Month_Vol._4" title="1st of the Month Vol. 4">1st of the Month, Vol. 4</a></i> EP.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> On November 1, 2014, Cam'ron released his <i><a href="/wiki/1st_of_the_Month_Vol._5" title="1st of the Month Vol. 5">1st of the Month, Vol. 5</a></i> EP.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup> On December 1, 2014 Cam'ron released his <i>1st of the Month, Vol. 6</i> EP.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> On December 11, 2014 Cam'ron announced that his next studio album will not be a sequel to his fifth album <a href="/wiki/Killa_Season" title="Killa Season">Killa Season</a> but will be a sequel to his critically acclaimed fourth studio album <i><a href="/wiki/Purple_Haze_(album)" title="Purple Haze (album)">Purple Haze</a></i> titled <i>Purple Haze 2</i>; Cam'ron would also announced that this would be his final album.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> On December 16, 2014 Cam'ron would release his compilation <i>1st of the Month: Box Set (Deluxe Edition)</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On January 1, 2015 well known DJ <a href="/wiki/Funkmaster_Flex" title="Funkmaster Flex">Funkmaster Flex</a> announced via his Instagram that he had spoken to fellow <a href="/wiki/The_Diplomats" title="The Diplomats">Diplomat</a> members Cam'ron, <a href="/wiki/Jim_Jones_(rapper)" title="Jim Jones (rapper)">Jim Jones</a> and <a href="/wiki/Juelz_Santana" title="Juelz Santana">Juelz Santana</a> about an upcoming Diplomat's mixtape which included fellow member <a href="/wiki/Freekey_Zeekey" class="mw-redirect" title="Freekey Zeekey">Freekey Zeekey</a>. He also confirmed and stated that he will be hosting the mixtape along with DJ's/Rappers/Producers <a href="/wiki/DJ_Khaled" title="DJ Khaled">DJ Khaled</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swizz_Beatz" title="Swizz Beatz">Swizz Beatz</a> and <a href="/wiki/DJ_Mustard" class="mw-redirect" title="DJ Mustard">DJ Mustard</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2016, he announced that he will release an album called Killa Pink and he promoted his line of signature the Reebok Flea 2's, and announced that the shoe will be released in combination with the album.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_ventures">Other ventures</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Other ventures">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Directing_and_acting_career">Directing and acting career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Directing and acting career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 2002, Cam'ron went on to appear in the <a href="/wiki/Damon_Dash" title="Damon Dash">Damon Dash</a> produced film, <i><a href="/wiki/Paid_in_Full_(2002_film)" title="Paid in Full (2002 film)">Paid in Full</a></i>, in which he played one of three main characters alongside <a href="/wiki/Mekhi_Phifer" title="Mekhi Phifer">Mekhi Phifer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wood_Harris" title="Wood Harris">Wood Harris</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> In 2006, started shooting his movie for his album titled <i><a href="/wiki/Killa_Season_(film)" title="Killa Season (film)">Killa Season</a></i>, the film would mark both Cam'ron's screenwriting and directorial debuts, as well as his return to acting. <i>Killa Season</i> was released to DVD on April 25, 2006, after a special two-day theatrical release.<sup id="cite_ref-theatre_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-theatre-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion_designing">Fashion designing</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Fashion designing">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>On February 11, 2014, Cam'ron, along with fashion designer <a href="/wiki/Mark_McNairy" title="Mark McNairy">Mark McNairy</a>, revealed their "<a href="/wiki/Cape" title="Cape">Cape</a> line" during the New York fashion week.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> On October 20, 2014, via his Instagram, Cam'ron revealed and released his "<a href="/wiki/Ebola" title="Ebola">Ebola</a> mask", stating on the caption: "Ebola is no joking matter, so if u have to be safe, be fashionable".<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> Cam'ron also has a fashion clothing line titled "Dipset USA" which is branded off his former label <a href="/wiki/Diplomat_Records" title="Diplomat Records">Diplomat Records</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Controversies">Controversies</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Controversies">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Jay-Z">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Although there had been rumors of a feud between the two emcees, Cam'ron went public first with a track on "Killa Season" called "You Gotta Love It (Jay-Z Diss)" featuring ex-Dipset member <a href="/wiki/Max_B" title="Max B">Max B</a>. In the song, Cam'ron takes jabs at Jay-Z's age, his alleged "biting" (stealing) of lyrics, and his current girlfriend. He references Jay-Z using <a href="/wiki/The_Notorious_B.I.G." title="The Notorious B.I.G.">The Notorious B.I.G.</a>'s rhymes, rapping "You ain't the only one with big wallets got it my shit's brolick but ya publishing should go to Miss Wallace." He then released another song "Swagger Jacker (Biter Not a Writer)" to highlight the many songs Jay-Z has borrowed lines from. In the next issue of <a href="/wiki/XXL_(magazine)" title="XXL (magazine)">XXL</a>, Cam'ron explained the beef originated when Jay-Z became CEO and President of <a href="/wiki/Roc-A-Fella_Records" title="Roc-A-Fella Records">Roc-A-Fella Records</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup> In 2010, Cam'ron stated he does not have any issues with Jay-Z anymore.
</p><p>In 2013, on "Pound Cake", a song by <a href="/wiki/Drake_(rapper)" class="mw-redirect" title="Drake (rapper)">Drake</a>, Jay-Z mentioned Cam'ron again by rapping (in the middle of a verse): 
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r960796168">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Now here's the icing on the cake/ Cake, cake-cake, cake-cake, uhh/ I'm just getting started, oh, yeah, we got it bitch/ I've done made more millionaires than the lotto did/ <a href="/wiki/Damon_Dash" title="Damon Dash">Dame</a> made millions, Bigg made millions/ <a href="/wiki/Kanye_West" title="Kanye West">Ye</a> made millions, <a href="/wiki/Just_Blaze" title="Just Blaze">Just</a> made millions/ <a href="/wiki/Lyor_Cohen" title="Lyor Cohen">Lyor</a> made millions, Cam made millions/ <a href="/wiki/Beanie_Sigel" title="Beanie Sigel">Beans</a> would tell you if he wasn't in his feelin[g]s<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>Cam replied briefly on "Come and Talk to Me" off of <i>Ghetto Heaven Vol. 1</i>:
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r960796168"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>She said Jay made you a millionaire? and looked me in the eyes/ Said cake, cake, cake, got that from the pies/ We made each other millions, that was my reply/ had a mill before I met him, baby, that ain't no lie/ See he named some Harlem cats and the <a href="/wiki/Kanye_West" title="Kanye West">homey from the Chi</a> / but my thing, he ain't name nobody from the <a href="/wiki/Bedford-Stuyvesant" class="mw-redirect" title="Bedford-Stuyvesant">Stuy</a><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>On April 26, 2019, he and Jay-Z ended their feud at the re-opened Webster Hall.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="50_Cent">50 Cent</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: 50 Cent">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>On February 1, 2007, Cam'ron and <a href="/wiki/50_Cent" title="50 Cent">50 Cent</a> had a live argument on <i>The <a href="/wiki/Angie_Martinez" title="Angie Martinez">Angie Martinez</a> Show</i> on <a href="/wiki/WQHT" title="WQHT">Hot 97</a> radio. 50 Cent commented that he felt <a href="/wiki/Koch_Entertainment" title="Koch Entertainment">Koch Entertainment</a> was a "graveyard", meaning major record labels would not work with their artists.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> Cam'ron then ridiculed the record sales of <a href="/wiki/G-Unit" title="G-Unit">G-Unit</a> members <a href="/wiki/Lloyd_Banks" title="Lloyd Banks">Lloyd Banks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mobb_Deep" title="Mobb Deep">Mobb Deep</a> by pointing out that <a href="/wiki/The_Diplomats" title="The Diplomats">Dipset</a> member <a href="/wiki/Jim_Jones_(rapper)" title="Jim Jones (rapper)">Jim Jones</a> outsold both of their albums despite not being signed to a major label, and also went on to clarify that his group, The Diplomats, had a distribution deal from several labels.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> Both rappers released diss songs with videos on <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a>. 50 Cent released "Funeral Music", and suggested in the song that Cam'ron is no longer able to lead The Diplomats and that Jim Jones should take his place. Cam'ron responded with "Curtis" and "Curtis Pt. II", in which he makes fun of 50 Cent's appearance, calling him "a gorilla, with rabbit teeth". 50 Cent responded by releasing "<a href="/wiki/Hold_On_(Young_Buck_song)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hold On (Young Buck song)">Hold On</a>" with <a href="/wiki/Young_Buck" title="Young Buck">Young Buck</a>. Since 2009, the feud slowly died down, and they eventually reconciled in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Jim_Jones">Jim Jones</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Jim Jones">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Cam'ron revealed in 2007 that he was no longer speaking to his fellow Diplomat members Juelz Santana and Jim Jones, leading to speculation that the group had officially broken up. However, despite admitting that he did not want to contact Jim Jones, he said that he had no hard feelings towards him. In an interview with Miss Info, Cam'ron said: "I still haven't spoken to Jim. But Jim ran with me for over 10 years, he worked hard, and I wish him the best of luck. Everybody thinks I'm mad at Jim. Why am I mad? I told people for years that Jimmy was gonna be a star. So it's better on my resume. I wish him the best."<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> After three years of not speaking, Cam'ron and Jim Jones mended their differences in April 2010. In late 2011, both appeared together on <a href="/wiki/Wolfgang_Gartner" title="Wolfgang Gartner">Wolfgang Gartner</a>'s album <a href="/wiki/Weekend_in_America" title="Weekend in America">Weekend in America</a>, on the track "Circus Freaks".
</p>
<h3><span id="Stop_Snitchin.27"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Stop_Snitchin'">Stop Snitchin'</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Stop Snitchin&#039;">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>On April 22, 2007, Cam'ron was interviewed on <i><a href="/wiki/60_Minutes" title="60 Minutes">60 Minutes</a></i> as part of a piece on the <a href="/wiki/Stop_Snitchin%27" title="Stop Snitchin&#39;">Stop Snitchin'</a> movement.<sup id="cite_ref-60min_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60min-43">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> He also stated that he would "not help the police" try to locate the shooter saying he is "not a snitch" and helping the police would probably hurt his record sales. He stated in the interview, "Because with the type of business I'm in, it would definitely hurt my business. And the way that I was raised, I just don't do that. I was raised differently, not to tell... It's about business but it's still also a code of ethics" When asked by <a href="/wiki/Anderson_Cooper" title="Anderson Cooper">Anderson Cooper</a> if he would tell the police if a <a href="/wiki/Serial_killer" title="Serial killer">serial killer</a> was living next to him, Cam'ron replied "I would probably move" but would not inform the police.
</p><p>Cam'ron later issued an apology for his comments, calling them an "error in judgement":<sup id="cite_ref-60min_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60min-43">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> "Where I come from, once word gets out that you've cooperated with the police that only makes you a bigger target of criminal violence. That is a dark reality in so many neighborhoods like mine across America. I'm not saying its right, but its reality. And it's not unfounded. There's a harsh reality around violence and criminal justice in our inner cities."  Cam'ron has had contact with the police in the past. According to <a href="/wiki/The_Smoking_Gun" title="The Smoking Gun">The Smoking Gun</a>, New York Police Department records indicate that Giles filed a report with police after he was assaulted at a park in Harlem in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Kanye_West">Kanye West</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Kanye West">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Both Cam'ron and Jim Jones took out their frustrations on former label-mate Kanye West in defense of former CEO Dame Dash (due to their longtime friendship dating back to growing up in Harlem)<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup> by releasing a song titled "Toast" rhyming over Kanye West's song "<a href="/wiki/Runaway_(Kanye_West_song)" title="Runaway (Kanye West song)">Runaway</a>". The feud eventually ended, evidenced by Cam'ron, Jim Jones, and Kanye West collaborating on a song called "<a href="/wiki/G.O.O.D._Fridays" class="mw-redirect" title="G.O.O.D. Fridays">Christmas in Harlem</a>".
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">Personal life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Personal life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>On October 23, 2005, Cam'ron was leaving a nightclub in Washington D.C., having performed the day before at <a href="/wiki/Howard_University" title="Howard University">Howard University</a>. While stopped at a traffic light at the intersection of New York and New Jersey Avenue shortly after midnight, a passenger of a nearby car threatened Cam'ron to "give up" his 2006 <a href="/wiki/Lamborghini" title="Lamborghini">Lamborghini</a>. Cam'ron resisted, and the man then shot him. Cam'ron was struck at least once as he was holding the steering wheel, but he was able to drive, going the wrong way on streets and flashing his lights, until a fan drove him to Howard University Hospital. The gunman and passenger drove off, crashed into a parked car, and fled the scene. D.C. Metro Police recovered a cell phone from the scene of the crash, which they tried to use to trace the suspects. He stated that he does not know who shot him, although later, in the song "Gotta Love It" featuring <a href="/wiki/Max-B" class="mw-redirect" title="Max-B">Max-B</a>, Cam’ron claims that he saw the gunman throw up the <a href="/wiki/Roc-A-Fella_Records" title="Roc-A-Fella Records">Roc-A-Fella Records</a> diamond hand signal before shots were fired.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<li id="cite_note-theatre-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-theatre_7-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-theatre_7-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20060829013252/http://xxlmag.com/online/?p=823">"Cam'ron's Killa Season Hits Big Screens in Limited Engagement"</a>. XXL. March 30, 2006. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://xxlmag.com/online/?p=823">the original</a> on August 29, 2006<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-46"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-46">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/10/23/AR2005102301334.html">"Rapper Shot in Alleged Carjacking in D.C."</a><span class="reference-accessdate"> Retrieved <span class="nowrap">March 11,</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Rapper+Shot+in+Alleged+Carjacking+in+D.C.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.washingtonpost.com%2Fwp-dyn%2Fcontent%2Farticle%2F2005%2F10%2F23%2FAR2005102301334.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACam%27ron" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r982806391"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-47"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-47">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://globalgrind.com/4284644/roc-back-jay-z-ends-20-year-beef-with-camron-but-heres-how-it-started-in-the-first-place/">"Roc Back: Jay-Z Ends 20-Year Beef With Cam'ron — But Here's How It Started In The First Place"</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cam%27ron&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<div role="navigation" class="navbox authority-control" aria-labelledby="Authority_control_frameless_&amp;#124;text-top_&amp;#124;10px_&amp;#124;alt=Edit_this_at_Wikidata_&amp;#124;link=https&amp;#58;//www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q434913#identifiers&amp;#124;Edit_this_at_Wikidata" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks hlist navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th id="Authority_control_frameless_&amp;#124;text-top_&amp;#124;10px_&amp;#124;alt=Edit_this_at_Wikidata_&amp;#124;link=https&amp;#58;//www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q434913#identifiers&amp;#124;Edit_this_at_Wikidata" scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Help:Authority_control" title="Help:Authority control">Authority control</a> <a href="https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q434913#identifiers" title="Edit this at Wikidata"><img alt="Edit this at Wikidata" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8a/OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg/10px-OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg.png" decoding="async" width="10" height="10" style="vertical-align: text-top" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8a/OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg/15px-OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8a/OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg/20px-OOjs_UI_icon_edit-ltr-progressive.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20" /></a></th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

</div></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div>
~~~~
<table class="box-Peacock plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-peacock" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40" /></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This article contains wording that <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Puffery" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">promotes the subject in a subjective manner</a> without imparting real information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please remove or replace such wording and instead of making proclamations about a subject's importance, use facts and attribution to demonstrate that importance.</span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">February 2011</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
    </div>
</div><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Canadian Armed Forces (CAF) divers</b> are specialists trained to conduct underwater operations within their respective environmental commands. Divers within the CAF are qualified in any sub-category of diving, whether a member of a diving team or a CAF member who is maintaining currency and qualification through casual diving with a CAF diving team. Divers within the CAF be trained as <a href="/wiki/Clearance_Diver" class="mw-redirect" title="Clearance Diver">Clearance Divers</a> (CL Diver), Search and Rescue Technicians (SAR), Port Inspection Divers (PID), Ship's Team Divers, and <a href="/wiki/Frogman" title="Frogman">Combat Divers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-aem_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aem-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Combat_divers"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Combat divers</span></a>
<ul>

</ul>
</li>
