</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Training">Training</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Armed_Forces_Divers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Training">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The CAF training agencies authorized to conduct CAF diving training are:<sup id="cite_ref-aem_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aem-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ol><li>Fleet Diving Unit (Atlantic) (FDU (A));</li>
<li>Fleet Diving Unit (Pacific) (FDU (P)); and</li>
<li>Army Dive Centre (ADC).</li></ol>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Clearance_divers">Clearance divers</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Armed_Forces_Divers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Clearance divers">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Royal Canadian Navy Clearance Divers are trained to conduct a wide variety of diving operations.  These include the use of traditional open circuit (SCUBA) diving equipment, lightweight portable surface supplied diving systems, commercial grade mixed gas surface supplied diving systems, mixed gas rebreather systems (such as the CCDA and <a href="/wiki/CUMA" title="CUMA">CUMA</a> sets<sup id="cite_ref-CUMA_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CUMA-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>) as well as fixed and portable hyperbaric chambers.
</p><p>Canada currently has two operational diving units from which RCN Clearance Diving Officers, Clearance Divers and Port Inspection Divers perform a variety of core capabilities, as outlined in their Naval Diving Operational Concept of Employment (ND OCE) terms of reference. These core capabilities are:
</p>
<ul><li>Battle Damage Repair (BDR)</li>
<li>Maritime Explosive Ordnance Disposal (MEOD)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Naval_mine" title="Naval mine">Mine</a> Counter-Measures (MCM)</li>
<li>Force Protection Support (FPS)</li></ul>
<p>They also perform a number of secondary or support functions to these core capabilities include but are not limited to:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Improvised_Explosive_Device" class="mw-redirect" title="Improvised Explosive Device">Improvised Explosive Device</a> Disposal (IEDD) for devices found in military establishments within defined areas of responsibility in Canada;</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Submarine" title="Submarine">Submarine</a> Search and Rescue (SUBSAR) first line response (RCC and light-weight Surface Supplied Diving equipment)</li>
<li>Second line response (ROVs and/or diving);</li>
<li>Provision of a minimum six-person 45 metre CABA diving team on each coast for emergencies;</li>
<li>Diving Support Roles (which amplifies Para 13 b.) consist of:</li></ul>
<ol><li>Underwater ship and infrastructure maintenance</li>
<li>Light salvage</li>
<li>Seabed search</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Underwater_demolition" title="Underwater demolition">Underwater demolitions</a></li>
<li>Inspection, maintenance and repair of critical diver life support equipment<sup id="cite_ref-CUMA_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CUMA-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Operation of Working Class <a href="/wiki/Remotely_operated_underwater_vehicle" title="Remotely operated underwater vehicle">Remote Operated Vehicle</a> (ROV), Inspection Class ROV, ROV Simulator, Diver Evaluation Systems, and <a href="/wiki/Side_scan_sonar" class="mw-redirect" title="Side scan sonar">side scan sonar</a> (SSS)</li>
<li>Support for medical treatment in hyperbaric chamber</li>
<li>Support to JTF2</li>
<li>Operating the Experimental Diving Unit (EDU) at <a href="/wiki/DRDC_Toronto" title="DRDC Toronto">DRDC Toronto</a> in support of R&amp;D efforts related to CF diving activities</li></ol>
<p>The two operational naval diving units are:
</p>
<ul><li>Fleet Diving Unit Pacific based at CFB <a href="/wiki/Esquimalt,_British_Columbia" class="mw-redirect" title="Esquimalt, British Columbia">Esquimalt, British Columbia</a>.</li>
<li>Fleet Diving Unit Atlantic based near Halifax in <a href="/wiki/CFB_Shearwater" title="CFB Shearwater">CFB Shearwater</a>, Nova Scotia.</li></ul>
<p>The Royal Canadian Clearance Diver motto is "Strength in depth".
</p><p>Clearance Diving Officers and Divers also serve at:
</p>
<ul><li>the Experimental Diving Unit (EDU) at <a href="/wiki/Defence_Research_and_Development_Canada" title="Defence Research and Development Canada">Defence Research and Development Canada</a></li>
<li>the EOD School in <a href="/wiki/CFB_Gagetown" title="CFB Gagetown">CFB Gagetown</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Brunswick" title="New Brunswick">New Brunswick</a>.</li>
<li>Director of Diving Safety (D Dive S), at the National Defence Headquarters (NDHQ) in Ottawa, Ontario.</li></ul>
<p><b>Royal Canadian Navy Clearance Divers' Prayer</b>
</p><p>On 30 April 2015 the RCN Clearance Diving Branch adopted the following prayer as their official branch prayer.  The prayer was originally written by Padre David Jackson, the unit chaplain of Fleet Diving Unit Atlantic, for the occasion of the 60th Anniversary of the RCN Clearance Diving Branch.  The prayer is based on Psalm 146:6 &amp; 139:9-10 and also incorporates the branch motto "Strength in Depth".
</p>
<ul><li>English: <i>Lord God Almighty, who made heaven and earth, the sea, and all that is in them; we ask You to look with favour upon us, the members of the Royal Canadian Navy Clearance Diving Branch, that as we dwell in the uttermost parts of the sea, even there Your hand may lead us and Your right hand may hold us.  Be our strength in depth and preserve us from all the perils of the sea and the assaults of the enemy; that we may serve Queen, Country and Branch with loyalty, courage and honour.  Amen.</i></li>
<li>French: <i>Dieu Tout-Puissant, Toi qui a créé le ciel et la terre, la mer avec tout ce qu'elle contient; Nous te demandons de tourner ton regard vers nous les membres de la Branche des Plongeurs Démineurs de la Marine Royale Canadienne surtout lorsque nous sommes dans les profondeurs de la mer.  Là aussi ta main puisse nous conduire, Et ta droite nous saisir. Sois notre force dans les profondeurs et préserve-nous de tous les dangers de la mer et de nos ennemis; pour que nous puissions servir la Reine, notre pays et la Branche avec loyauté, courage et honneur. Amen</i></li></ul>
<p>(See <a href="/wiki/Professional_diving" title="Professional diving">Professional diving</a>.)
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Combat_divers">Combat divers</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Armed_Forces_Divers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Combat divers">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Armed_Forces_Divers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Diving in the Canadian Army began in the 1960s when, as a result of the introduction of amphibious vehicles, it was essential to provide a diving capability to the safety organization for the swimming of the vehicles. Amphibious operations also required a better capability for the underwater reconnaissance of crossing sites. Following trials in 1966, diving sections were established in engineer units in 1969. Once the diving capability was established, additional tasks were added to make combat diving an extension of combat engineering into the water. Other tasks such as obstacle construction and breaching, employing and detecting landmines and limited underwater construction were added to the safety standby and reconnaissance tasks.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="General_Description">General Description</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Armed_Forces_Divers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: General Description">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Combat divers provide the Army with the capability of performing combat engineer tasks underwater. They generally conduct tasks as part of the combined arms team; however, if required, they have the ability to execute tasks independently. Combat divers are combat engineers who perform combat diving as a secondary duty. They are grouped into mission-specific teams when a task is identified and ordered, to support operations.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Niche_area">Niche area</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Armed_Forces_Divers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Niche area">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Combat divers do the majority of their work on inland waterways, either on the surface or beneath the water with breathing apparatus. They usually work close to shorelines and riverbanks because that is where the rest of the army will be conducting operations. At times the combat divers will work in salt water to support Army operations. In some circumstances, combat divers can be used to conduct reconnaissance in the face of enemy forces. They would be doing this reconnaissance with the support of the manoeuvre forces, which could assist the dive team with observation and suppressive fire.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Canada's Combat Divers are an Occupation Sub-Specialization (OSS) in its <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Forces_Land_Force_Command" class="mw-redirect" title="Canadian Forces Land Force Command">Army</a> <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Forces_Land_Force_Command#Combat_engineers" class="mw-redirect" title="Canadian Forces Land Force Command">Combat Engineer Regiments</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Training_2">Training</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Armed_Forces_Divers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Training">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Each of the four dive teams, one located in each of the Canadian army engineer regiments, conducts an intense preliminary selection course (typically two weeks in length) to select combat diver candidates for training.  Successful candidates then proceed to a Fleet Diving Unit to begin initial dive training, and then proceed to the Army Dive Center at the Combat Training Center to complete the remainder of Combat Diver training.  Once this training is completed, combat divers must dive at least once every ninety days in order to maintain their diving currency.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Armed_Forces_Divers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
